notes: Reference to David Hume's History of England. Smith's distinction between subsistence (stays home) and surplus value (exported) anticipates later economic analysis of value added in trade. The argument links industrial development to military power. Cross-reference: 4.1.38 on the wartime role of manufactures.

refashioned: The quantity of circulating money in medieval England must have borne the same proportion to commerce as it does now -- or rather, a greater proportion, since there was then no paper money to occupy part of gold and silver's role. Among nations unfamiliar with commerce and manufacturing, the sovereign can rarely extract significant aid from his subjects in emergencies, for reasons to be explained later. In such countries, therefore, he generally tries to accumulate a treasure as his only resource for crises. Beyond this necessity, he is naturally inclined toward the thrift required for accumulation. In that simpler state, even a sovereign's spending is directed not by the vanity that delights in court splendor but by generosity toward tenants and hospitality toward retainers.
elegant: Medieval money supply was proportional to commerce -- likely higher per transaction than today, since paper money did not yet exist. In pre-commercial societies, rulers must accumulate treasures because they cannot easily tax their subjects. Such rulers are also naturally thrifty, spending on generosity and hospitality rather than courtly vanity.
summary: Smith explains that pre-commercial rulers accumulated treasure because they could not effectively tax their subjects and were naturally thrifty, spending on bounty and hospitality rather than court splendor. The money supply in such periods was proportional to commerce, with a higher metal-to-transaction ratio than in modern economies with paper money.
distilled: Pre-commercial rulers accumulated treasure because they could not easily tax subjects and spent on generosity rather than courtly vanity, while money supply was proportionally higher without paper currency.
notes: Historical sociology of royal finance -- the transition from treasure-based to tax-based fiscal systems. Smith links spending patterns to social structure: pre-commercial sovereigns spend on personal loyalty (bounty, hospitality), commercial-era sovereigns on status display (court pageantry). Cross-reference: Book V on public finance.

refashioned: Generosity and hospitality rarely lead to extravagance, though vanity almost always does. Accordingly, every Tartar chief has a treasure. The treasures of Mazepa, chief of the Ukrainian Cossacks and famous ally of Charles XII of Sweden, are said to have been enormous. The Merovingian kings of France all had treasures; when they divided their kingdoms among their children, they divided their treasures as well. The Saxon princes and the first kings after the Norman Conquest also appear to have accumulated treasures. The first act of every new reign was typically to seize the preceding king's treasure, as the most essential step in securing the succession.
elegant: Generosity and hospitality rarely cause extravagance; vanity almost always does. Accordingly, pre-commercial rulers from Tartar chiefs to Merovingian kings to early English monarchs all accumulated treasures. Seizing the previous king's treasury was typically the first act of a new reign -- the essential step in securing power.
summary: Smith provides historical examples showing that pre-commercial rulers universally accumulated treasure because their lifestyle of generosity and hospitality promoted thrift rather than extravagance. From Tartar chiefs to Merovingian kings to early English monarchs, royal treasure was the essential basis of power.
distilled: Pre-commercial rulers from Tartar chiefs to Merovingian kings universally accumulated treasures because generosity and hospitality, unlike vanity, promote thrift.
notes: Historical examples: Ivan Mazepa (c. 1639-1709), Hetman of the Cossacks, ally of Charles XII of Sweden. Merovingian dynasty (c. 450-751). The treasure-seizure pattern at succession reflects the centrality of bullion to pre-commercial state power. Cross-reference: 4.1.43 on the contrast with modern rulers.

refashioned: The rulers of advanced commercial countries are under no such necessity to accumulate treasures, because they can generally extract extraordinary revenues from their subjects in extraordinary circumstances. They are also less inclined to save. They naturally -- perhaps inevitably -- follow the fashions of their era, and their spending comes to be governed by the same extravagant vanity that drives all the other great landowners in their domains. The trivial pageantry of their courts grows more splendid every day, and the expense of it not only prevents accumulation but frequently eats into funds set aside for more important purposes. What Dercyllidas said of the Persian court could be applied to many European courts: that he saw much splendor but little strength, many servants but few soldiers.
elegant: Modern commercial rulers need not accumulate treasures because they can tax their subjects in emergencies. They are also less inclined to save, following the era's fashion of extravagant court display. Their pageantry grows ever more brilliant, consuming funds meant for necessary purposes. As Dercyllidas said of Persia: much splendor, little strength; many servants, few soldiers.
summary: Smith contrasts modern commercial rulers with their pre-commercial predecessors: modern monarchs can tax rather than save, but they are also driven by courtly vanity to spend extravagantly, consuming resources meant for essential purposes. He quotes Dercyllidas's observation of Persia: 'much splendor but little strength.'
distilled: Commercial-era rulers need not hoard treasure because they can tax, but their courtly vanity consumes resources that should fund essential purposes -- much splendor, little strength.
notes: Dercyllidas was a Spartan general who served in Asia Minor (c. 399 BC). The contrast between pre-commercial thrift and commercial-era vanity parallels Smith's broader theme about how luxury spending can undermine national strength. Cross-reference: Book V on the expenses of the sovereign.

refashioned: Importing gold and silver is not the principal benefit a nation derives from foreign trade, much less the sole one. Every country engaged in foreign trade derives two distinct benefits from it. First, trade carries away the surplus produce for which there is no domestic demand and brings back something for which there is demand. It gives value to surpluses by exchanging them for goods that satisfy wants and increase enjoyments. Second, by opening a wider market for whatever part of production exceeds domestic consumption, foreign trade enables the division of labor to be carried to its highest perfection, even in industries where the home market alone would be too small. This encourages nations to improve their productive powers and maximize their annual output, thereby increasing the real revenue and wealth of society. Foreign trade continually performs these great services for all countries involved. All benefit from it, though the country where the merchant resides typically benefits most, since he is generally more occupied in supplying the needs and carrying off the surpluses of his own country. Importing gold and silver for countries without mines is undoubtedly part of foreign commerce -- but the most insignificant part. A country that traded abroad solely to obtain precious metals would barely need to send a ship once a century.
elegant: Foreign trade's real benefits are two: it gives value to surplus production by exchanging it for desired goods, and it enables the division of labor to reach full perfection by opening markets wider than any single country could provide. By expanding markets, trade encourages nations to improve productivity and maximize output, increasing real national wealth. These great services -- increased productivity, expanded employment, growing wealth -- dwarf the trivial matter of importing gold and silver. A country trading solely for precious metals would scarcely need to freight a ship once in a century.
summary: Smith identifies the true benefits of foreign trade: converting surplus production into desired goods and enabling deeper division of labor through expanded markets, which increases productivity and national wealth. Importing gold and silver, far from being the point of trade, is so insignificant that a country trading solely for precious metals would barely need one ship per century.
distilled: Foreign trade's real value lies in giving worth to surplus production and enabling deeper division of labor through wider markets, not in the trivial business of importing gold and silver.
notes: Central statement of Smith's positive theory of trade -- the 'vent for surplus' and 'division of labor' arguments. These are the constructive counterpart to his negative critique of mercantilism. The ship-per-century remark underscores how trivial bullion imports are relative to total trade. Cross-reference: Book I on division of labor; Book III on the extent of the market.

refashioned: It was not the importation of gold and silver that made the discovery of America enrich Europe. The abundance of American mines simply made those metals cheaper. A set of silver plate can now be bought for about a third of the grain, or a third of the labor, it would have cost in the fifteenth century. With the same annual expenditure of labor and commodities, Europe can now purchase about three times the plate it could have then. But when a commodity falls to a third of its former price, not only can previous buyers afford three times as much, but the lower price brings the commodity within reach of a much larger number of purchasers -- perhaps ten or even twenty times as many. So Europe today may have not merely three times but twenty or thirty times the quantity of plate it would have had without the American mines. This is no doubt a real convenience, though surely a very trivial one.
elegant: The discovery of America enriched Europe not through gold and silver imports but despite them. American mines simply made precious metals cheaper -- plate costs a third of what it did in the 1400s. Lower prices expanded the market to perhaps twenty times more buyers, multiplying Europe's plate twenty- or thirty-fold. A real convenience, but a trivial one.
summary: Smith argues that America's gold and silver did not enrich Europe in any meaningful way. The metals simply became cheaper, making silverware more affordable and abundant -- perhaps twenty to thirty times as much plate as before. Smith dismisses this as a real but trivial convenience.
distilled: American gold and silver merely made precious metals cheaper and plate more abundant -- a real but trivial convenience that was not the true source of Europe's enrichment from the discovery of America.
notes: Smith carefully distinguishes between the price effect (cheaper metals) and the wealth effect (real economic benefit). The plate example shows how price reductions expand markets through increased accessibility. Cross-reference: 4.1.46 on the real source of America's impact on Europe.

refashioned: The cheapness of gold and silver actually makes them somewhat less suitable as money than before. To make the same purchases, we must carry more metal -- a shilling where a groat once sufficed. It is hard to say which is more trivial: this inconvenience or the opposite convenience of cheaper plate. Neither could have made any essential change in Europe's condition. The discovery of America, however, certainly did make an essential change. By opening a new and seemingly inexhaustible market for all European commodities, it created opportunities for new divisions of labor and technological improvements that could never have emerged within the narrow confines of the old trade routes, which lacked a market large enough to absorb the output such specialization would produce.
elegant: Cheaper gold and silver made money slightly less convenient (more metal needed for the same purchase) while making plate slightly more accessible. Neither effect was significant. The real transformation came from America as a vast new market that enabled new divisions of labor and innovations impossible within the narrow scope of pre-Columbian commerce.
summary: Smith dismisses both the convenience of cheaper plate and the inconvenience of heavier coins as trivial. The real impact of discovering America was opening a vast new market that enabled unprecedented divisions of labor and technological improvements -- transformations that the limited pre-Columbian trade network could never have supported.
distilled: The real benefit of discovering America was not cheaper gold but a vast new market that enabled divisions of labor and innovations impossible within the narrow scope of pre-Columbian commerce.
notes: Division of labor as the true engine of wealth -- the market-expansion thesis. Smith returns to his foundational principle from Book I: the division of labor is limited by the extent of the market. America's contribution was expanding that market, not supplying metals. Cross-reference: Book I, Ch. 3 on the extent of the market.

refashioned: The productive powers of labor improved and output increased across all European countries, along with the real revenue and wealth of their inhabitants. European goods were almost entirely new to America, and many American goods were new to Europe. An entirely new set of exchanges began, unprecedented in history, and these should naturally have been as beneficial to the new continent as they certainly were to the old. But the savage injustice of the Europeans turned an event that should have benefited everyone into one that was ruinous and destructive for several of those unfortunate countries.
elegant: Labor productivity and output rose across Europe, increasing real wealth. A new set of exchanges began between continents with complementary goods -- an event that should have benefited both equally. But European injustice turned what should have been universally beneficial into ruin and destruction for many New World peoples.
summary: Smith acknowledges that the discovery of America boosted European productivity and wealth through new exchanges, but condemns the European colonizers for turning what should have been a mutually beneficial event into a catastrophe for indigenous peoples through 'savage injustice.'
distilled: The discovery of America boosted European productivity through new exchanges but, through savage European injustice, became ruinous for the indigenous peoples it should have equally benefited.
notes: Rare moral condemnation from Smith -- 'the savage injustice of the Europeans' is one of his strongest ethical judgments in the entire work. He recognizes that mutual gains from trade were possible but destroyed by colonialism. Cross-reference: Book IV, Ch. 7 on colonies.

refashioned: The discovery of the sea route to the East Indies via the Cape of Good Hope, which occurred around the same time, opened what was potentially an even more extensive field for foreign commerce than America, despite the greater distance. In the Americas, only two nations were in any way more advanced than the rest, and both were destroyed almost as soon as discovered. The remainder were entirely uncivilized. But the empires of China, India, Japan, and several other East Asian nations -- though without richer gold or silver mines -- were in every other respect far wealthier, better cultivated, and more advanced in arts and manufacturing than either Mexico or Peru, even if we accept the exaggerated accounts of Spanish writers about those empires, which plainly do not deserve credit.
elegant: The Cape route to the East Indies potentially opened an even wider commercial field than America. The Americas had only two semi-civilized nations, both quickly destroyed. But China, India, Japan, and other Eastern empires were far wealthier, more cultivated, and more advanced in arts and manufacturing than Mexico or Peru -- offering far richer trading partners.
summary: Smith argues that the sea route to the East Indies offered even greater commercial potential than the Americas, because Asian empires like China, India, and Japan were far wealthier and more advanced than anything in the New World, making them far more valuable trading partners.
distilled: The East Indies route offered even greater trade potential than America because Asian civilizations were far wealthier and more advanced than the Aztec or Inca empires.
notes: Smith's assessment of relative civilizational advancement. He dismisses Spanish accounts of Aztec and Inca greatness while acknowledging Asian superiority in arts and manufactures. The key economic insight: richer trading partners enable greater gains from trade. Cross-reference: 4.1.49 on why this potential was unrealized.

refashioned: Rich and civilized nations can always exchange goods of far greater value with one another than they can with less developed peoples. Yet Europe has so far derived far less benefit from its trade with the East Indies than from its trade with America. The Portuguese monopolized the East India trade for about a century. Only indirectly, through Portuguese intermediaries, could other European nations send or receive goods from that region. When the Dutch began to encroach on the Portuguese in the early seventeenth century, they placed their entire East India trade under the control of an exclusive company.
elegant: Rich nations can trade far more valuably with each other than with less developed peoples. Yet Europe gained less from East Indian trade than American, because the Portuguese monopolized it for a century, and when the Dutch displaced them, they too concentrated trade in an exclusive company.
summary: Smith explains that although rich Asian nations should have been Europe's most valuable trading partners, monopolistic control first by the Portuguese and then by Dutch exclusive companies prevented the potential gains from being realized.
distilled: Europe gained less from East Indian trade than American despite Asia's greater wealth, because Portuguese and then Dutch monopolies prevented the full benefits of free commerce.
notes: The Portuguese Estado da India (c. 1500-1600) and the Dutch East India Company (VOC, founded 1602). Smith blames monopoly, not geography or culture, for the underdevelopment of East-West trade. Cross-reference: 4.1.50 on other European companies; Book IV, Ch. 7 on monopoly and colonies.

refashioned: The English, French, Swedes, and Danes all followed the Dutch example, so no major European nation has ever enjoyed the benefits of free trade with the East Indies. No other explanation is needed for why this trade has never been as profitable as the American trade, which between almost every European nation and its own colonies is open to all subjects. The exclusive privileges of these East India companies -- their vast wealth and the great favor and protection their governments have granted them -- have provoked considerable envy. This envy has often led to the claim that their trade is entirely harmful, because of the large quantities of silver it exports annually from the countries where it operates.
elegant: Every major European nation followed the Dutch in creating exclusive East India companies, so none has ever enjoyed free trade with Asia. This alone explains why Asian trade has been less beneficial than American trade, which is open to all subjects. The companies' exclusive privileges and enormous wealth have excited envy, prompting claims that their trade is harmful because it exports silver.
summary: Smith attributes the underperformance of European-Asian trade entirely to monopolistic East India companies. No European nation has enjoyed free trade with Asia, unlike the relatively open American trade. Envy of these companies' privileges has led to the mercantilist complaint that their trade harmfully exports silver.
distilled: No European nation has ever enjoyed free trade with Asia because all created exclusive East India companies, which alone explains why Asian trade has underperformed the more open American trade.
notes: East India companies: English (1600), Dutch (1602), Danish (1616), French (1664), Swedish (1731). Smith's consistent position: monopoly, not the nature of the trade itself, causes underperformance. The silver-export complaint is a mercantilist red herring. Cross-reference: 4.1.51-52 on the silver objection.

refashioned: The East India companies have replied that while their trade's continual export of silver might impoverish Europe in general, it does not impoverish the particular country conducting the trade, because re-exporting some of the returns to other European countries brings back far more silver than was originally sent out. Both the objection and the reply rest on the popular fallacy I have been examining, so nothing further need be said about either. The annual silver exports to the East Indies probably make plate somewhat dearer in Europe than it would otherwise be, and coined silver probably buys a larger quantity of both labor and goods.
elegant: Both the complaint that East India trade drains silver and the companies' reply that re-exports bring back more rest on the same mercantilist fallacy. The actual effects -- slightly dearer plate and slightly more valuable coins -- are trivial either way.
summary: Smith dismisses the debate about whether East India companies drain European silver, noting that both sides argue from the same mercantilist fallacy. The actual effects on plate prices and silver purchasing power are too trivial to matter.
distilled: Both the complaint about silver exports to the East Indies and the companies' defense rest on the same mercantilist fallacy, and the actual effects on prices are trivially small.
notes: Smith refuses to engage with a debate whose premises he has already demolished. Both the mercantilist critics and the company defenders share the error of treating silver flows as the measure of trade benefit. Cross-reference: 4.1.1-10 on the fallacy that wealth equals money.

refashioned: The first of these effects -- slightly dearer plate -- is a very small loss. The second -- slightly more valuable coins -- is a very small advantage. Both are too insignificant to warrant any public attention. East India trade, by opening a market for European commodities (or equivalently, for the gold and silver purchased with those commodities), must necessarily tend to increase European production and consequently Europe's real wealth and revenue. That it has so far increased them so little is probably due to the monopolistic restrictions under which this trade everywhere operates.
elegant: Slightly dearer plate is a trivial loss; slightly more valuable coins, a trivial gain. Neither deserves attention. East India trade should increase European production by opening new markets. That it has barely done so is probably because monopoly restrictions have crippled it everywhere.
summary: Smith dismisses the silver-price effects as trivial and argues that East India trade should naturally increase European wealth by opening new markets. Its failure to do so is blamed not on the nature of the trade but on the monopolistic restrictions imposed by exclusive companies.
distilled: East India trade should increase European wealth by opening markets, but monopolistic restrictions have prevented it from realizing its potential.
notes: Consistent application of Smith's anti-monopoly principle: the problem is never the trade itself but the institutional restrictions placed upon it. Cross-reference: 4.1.49-50 on East India company monopolies; Book IV, Ch. 7 on colonial monopoly.

refashioned: I thought it necessary, even at the risk of being tedious, to examine this popular notion that wealth consists in money or precious metals at full length. In common language, as I have already noted, 'money' frequently means 'wealth,' and this verbal ambiguity has made the fallacy so deeply familiar that even those convinced of its absurdity frequently forget their own principles and, in the course of their reasoning, treat it as undeniable truth. Some of the best English writers on commerce begin by correctly observing that a country's wealth includes not just gold and silver but its land, buildings, and consumable goods of every kind. As their arguments proceed, however, the land, buildings, and consumable goods seem to slip from their memory, and their reasoning effectively assumes that all wealth consists in gold and silver and that multiplying these metals is the supreme goal of national industry and commerce.
elegant: I have examined at length the fallacy that wealth equals money because the verbal ambiguity between 'money' and 'wealth' makes it uniquely persistent. Even writers who correctly begin by defining wealth broadly -- including land, buildings, and goods -- invariably slip back into assuming that all wealth is gold and silver and that multiplying these metals is the supreme economic goal.
summary: Smith justifies his extended critique of the money-as-wealth fallacy by noting its extraordinary persistence: even writers who correctly define wealth broadly invariably revert to treating gold and silver as the sole measure of national prosperity, due to the linguistic ambiguity between 'money' and 'wealth.'
distilled: The equation of money with wealth is so deeply embedded in language that even writers who know better invariably revert to it in the course of their reasoning.
notes: Linguistic philosophy applied to economics -- Smith identifies verbal confusion as the root of persistent analytical error. This anticipates modern concerns about how framing and language shape economic thinking. The observation that good economists slip back into mercantilism mid-argument is psychologically acute.

refashioned: With these two principles established -- that wealth consists in gold and silver, and that countries without mines can acquire these metals only through a favorable balance of trade (exporting more value than they import) -- the central goal of political economy necessarily became minimizing imports of foreign goods for domestic consumption while maximizing exports of domestic production. The two principal instruments for enriching the country were therefore restraints on imports and encouragements to exports.
elegant: From two mercantilist premises -- wealth equals gold, and gold comes only from export surpluses -- followed the inevitable policy conclusion: minimize imports, maximize exports. The two great instruments of this system were import restraints and export encouragements.
summary: Smith summarizes how the mercantilist premises (wealth is gold; gold comes from trade surpluses) logically produced the policy of restricting imports and encouraging exports as the two principal means of national enrichment.
distilled: The mercantilist system's two core policies -- restricting imports and encouraging exports -- follow logically from its two false premises that wealth is gold and gold comes only from trade surpluses.
notes: Structural overview of the mercantilist policy framework that Smith will dismantle chapter by chapter. The logical clarity of the system (false premises lead to wrong conclusions) is what makes it both coherent and dangerous. Cross-reference: 4.1.55-59 for the taxonomy of specific instruments.

refashioned:
Import restraints were of two kinds.

First, restraints on the importation of foreign goods for domestic consumption that could be produced at home, regardless of the country of origin.
elegant: Import restraints took two forms. First: restricting foreign goods that could be produced domestically, from any country.
summary: Smith identifies the first type of mercantilist import restraint: restricting imports of any goods that could be produced domestically, applied universally regardless of origin.
distilled: The first type of import restraint targeted any foreign goods that could be produced domestically, regardless of the exporting country.
notes: Taxonomy of mercantilist instruments, Part 1. This type of restraint protects domestic producers against all foreign competition. Smith will address this in Chapter 4.2. Cross-reference: 4.2.1 onward.

refashioned:
Second, restraints on the importation of goods of nearly all kinds from specific countries with which the balance of trade was believed to be unfavorable.

These various restraints took the form either of high duties or of outright prohibitions.
elegant: Second: restricting imports from countries with supposedly unfavorable trade balances, through high duties or outright prohibitions.
summary: The second type of import restraint targeted goods from specific countries believed to have an unfavorable trade balance, implemented through high duties or outright prohibitions.
distilled: The second type of import restraint targeted specific countries believed to have unfavorable trade balances, using high duties or outright prohibitions.
notes: Taxonomy of mercantilist instruments, Part 2. This type of restraint is country-specific and driven by balance-of-trade calculations. Smith addresses this in Chapter 4.3. Cross-reference: 4.3.1 on restraints against French goods.

refashioned:
Exports were encouraged through four methods: drawbacks, bounties, favorable commercial treaties with foreign states, and the establishment of colonies in distant lands.

Drawbacks were granted on two occasions. When domestically manufactured goods were subject to duties or excise taxes, all or part of the tax was frequently refunded upon export. When foreign goods that had been imported with a duty were re-exported, all or part of that duty was sometimes refunded as well.
elegant: Four methods encouraged exports: drawbacks (tax refunds on exported goods), bounties, favorable trade treaties, and colonial establishment. Drawbacks applied when domestic duties were refunded upon export and when import duties were refunded upon re-export.
summary: Smith catalogs the four methods used to encourage exports: drawbacks (refunds of domestic or import duties upon export), bounties, favorable trade treaties, and colonial establishment.
distilled: The mercantilist system encouraged exports through four instruments: drawbacks on duties, bounties, favorable trade treaties, and colonial establishment.
notes: Taxonomy of mercantilist instruments, Parts 3-6 (export encouragements). Drawbacks are essentially tax rebates for exporters. Smith will address drawbacks in Ch. 4.4, bounties in Ch. 4.5, trade treaties in Ch. 4.6, and colonies in Ch. 4.7.

refashioned:
Bounties were given to encourage either new manufactures in their infancy or other types of industry deemed to deserve special support.

Through favorable treaties of commerce, special privileges were secured in foreign countries for the goods and merchants of the home country, beyond those granted to other nations.
elegant: Bounties supported infant manufactures or favored industries. Trade treaties secured special privileges for domestic goods and merchants in foreign markets, exceeding those granted to other nations.
summary: Smith describes two more export-encouragement tools: bounties to support infant industries or favored sectors, and trade treaties that secured preferential treatment for domestic merchants in foreign markets.
distilled: Bounties supported new or favored industries, while trade treaties secured preferential foreign market access for domestic goods and merchants.
notes: Infant industry argument (bounties) and most-favored-nation treatment (treaties). Smith will critique the infant industry argument -- an early version appears here. Cross-reference: Ch. 4.5 on bounties, Ch. 4.6 on treaties of commerce.

refashioned:
Through the establishment of colonies in distant lands, not just special privileges but outright monopolies were frequently secured for the goods and merchants of the colonizing country.

The two types of import restraints, together with these four export encouragements, constitute the six principal means by which the mercantilist system proposed to increase a country's gold and silver by creating a favorable balance of trade. I shall examine each in a separate chapter, and rather than dwelling further on their supposed tendency to bring money into the country, I shall focus primarily on their likely effects on the annual output of national industry. Insofar as they tend to increase or decrease the value of that annual output, they must evidently tend to increase or decrease the real wealth and revenue of the country.
elegant: Colonial establishment secured outright monopolies for the colonizing country's merchants. These six instruments -- two import restraints and four export encouragements -- constitute the mercantilist toolkit. Smith announces he will evaluate each by its effect on annual industrial output, not on gold flows, since real wealth depends on production, not bullion.
summary: Smith completes his taxonomy of mercantilist policy (six instruments total) and announces his analytical framework for the chapters ahead: he will judge each policy not by its effect on gold flows but by its impact on annual productive output, which is the true measure of national wealth.
distilled: The six mercantilist instruments will be judged not by their effect on gold flows but by their impact on annual productive output -- the true measure of national wealth.
notes: Methodological statement that frames all of Book IV, Chapters 2-7. Smith's criterion for evaluation shifts from bullion accumulation (the mercantilist measure) to annual produce (Smith's measure). This is the operational consequence of rejecting the money-as-wealth fallacy. Cross-reference: 4.1.1 on the foundational error; Book II on annual produce as wealth.

refashioned: By restricting the import of foreign goods that can be produced domestically -- through either high duties or outright prohibitions -- the home market is more or less monopolized for the domestic industries that produce those goods. The prohibition on importing live cattle or salt provisions from abroad secures the home market monopoly for British graziers. High duties on imported grain, which during times of moderate plenty effectively amount to a prohibition, give the same advantage to domestic grain growers. The ban on importing foreign woolens is equally favorable to British woolen manufacturers. The silk industry, though working entirely with foreign materials, has recently obtained the same protection. The linen industry has not yet achieved it but is making significant progress. Many other manufactures have similarly obtained either complete or near-complete monopolies against their own countrymen in Britain. The variety of goods whose importation into Britain is prohibited, absolutely or conditionally, far exceeds what anyone unfamiliar with customs law would suspect.
elegant: High duties and outright prohibitions on foreign goods give domestic producers a monopoly of the home market. British graziers, grain growers, woolen manufacturers, and silk makers all enjoy such protection. The linen industry is making strides toward obtaining it. Many other manufactures have similarly secured either complete or near-complete monopolies against their own countrymen. The variety of goods whose importation into Britain is prohibited, either absolutely or under certain conditions, is far wider than most people would suspect.
summary: Smith opens Chapter 2 by cataloging the extensive import restrictions that give British domestic producers -- graziers, grain growers, woolen and silk manufacturers -- monopoly power in the home market. He notes that the range of prohibitions is far broader than most people realize.
distilled: Import restrictions through high duties and prohibitions give domestic British producers extensive monopoly power over the home market across many industries.
notes: Opening of Chapter 4.2 -- 'Of Restraints upon Importation from Foreign Countries of such Goods as can be Produced at Home.' Smith catalogs the breadth of British protectionism before arguing against it. Key industries: cattle, grain, wool, silk, linen. Cross-reference: 4.1.55 on this category of restraint.

refashioned: There is no doubt that this home-market monopoly greatly encourages the particular industry that enjoys it and diverts a larger share of the society's labor and capital toward that industry than would naturally flow there. But whether it increases the overall level of industry in the society, or directs it more advantageously, is not nearly so clear.
elegant: Home-market monopoly undoubtedly boosts the specific industry that enjoys it. But whether it increases total industry or directs it more productively is far from obvious.
summary: Smith concedes that protectionism benefits the specific protected industry but questions whether it increases total national industry or directs it more productively -- the critical question for the chapter.
distilled: Protectionism clearly benefits the specific protected industry, but whether it increases total industry or directs resources more productively is the real question.
notes: The key analytical distinction: partial vs. general equilibrium effects. Mercantilists see the benefit to protected industries; Smith asks about the net effect on the whole economy. This frames the entire chapter.

refashioned: A society's total industry can never exceed what its total capital can support. Just as the number of workers any individual can employ depends on his capital, the number that an entire society can keep employed depends on its total capital and can never exceed it. No trade regulation can increase total industry beyond what the nation's capital can maintain. It can only redirect part of that industry toward activities it would not naturally have entered. And there is no reason to believe that this artificial direction is more beneficial to society than the direction industry would have taken on its own.
elegant: Total industry is limited by total capital -- no regulation can push it beyond that ceiling. Regulation can only redirect industry, not expand it. And there is no reason to believe this forced redirection is more beneficial than the direction industry would have chosen naturally.
summary: Smith establishes his fundamental principle: total industry is constrained by total capital, so no trade regulation can increase it. Regulations can only redirect existing industry, and there is no guarantee this artificial direction is better than the natural one.
distilled: No regulation can increase total industry beyond what national capital supports; it can only redirect it, with no assurance the artificial direction is superior to the natural one.
notes: The capital constraint on total employment -- a foundational macroeconomic insight. This is Smith's master argument against protectionism: since total employment is fixed by capital, protecting one industry merely diverts resources from another. Cross-reference: Book II on capital as the constraint on industry.

refashioned: Every individual constantly strives to find the most profitable use for whatever capital he controls. It is his own advantage, not the society's, that he has in mind. But pursuing his own advantage naturally -- or rather, inevitably -- leads him to favor the employment of capital that is most beneficial to society as well.
elegant: Every individual seeks the most profitable employment for his capital. He aims at his own advantage, not society's. But pursuing his own advantage naturally leads him to the employment most beneficial to society.
summary: Smith introduces the key insight: individuals seeking their own profit are naturally led to employ their capital in ways that benefit society, even though social benefit is not their intention.
distilled: Individuals pursuing their own profit are naturally led to employ capital in ways that benefit society, even without intending to.
notes: Setup for the invisible hand passage (4.2.10). The alignment of private interest with public benefit is the core mechanism. 'Naturally, or rather necessarily' -- Smith emphasizes this is not coincidental but structural. Cross-reference: Book I on self-interest as the engine of the market.

refashioned:
First, every individual tries to employ his capital as close to home as possible, and therefore favors domestic industry as much as he can, so long as he can earn the normal rate of profit or close to it.

Accordingly, given equal or nearly equal profits, every wholesale merchant naturally prefers domestic trade over the foreign trade of consumption, and the foreign trade of consumption over the carrying trade. In domestic trade, his capital is never out of his sight for long as it often is in foreign trade. He can better assess the character and reliability of the people he deals with, and if deceived, he better understands the laws under which he must seek redress. In the carrying trade, the merchant's capital is effectively split between two foreign countries, and none of it ever necessarily comes home or remains under his direct oversight and control.
elegant: Individuals naturally prefer to invest capital close to home. Given equal profits, merchants prefer domestic trade to foreign trade, and foreign trade to the carrying trade. At home, capital stays visible, partners are known, and legal recourse is familiar. In the carrying trade, capital is split between foreign countries and never under direct control.
summary: Smith's first principle of natural capital deployment: investors prefer to keep capital close to home, choosing domestic trade over foreign trade and foreign trade over the carrying trade, because proximity provides better oversight, more reliable partners, and more accessible legal recourse.
distilled: Investors naturally prefer domestic trade over foreign trade because proximity provides better oversight of capital, more reliable partners, and more accessible legal recourse.
notes: The 'home bias' in investment -- a well-documented phenomenon in modern finance that Smith identifies from first principles. The hierarchy of trade types (home > foreign consumption > carrying) reflects decreasing control over capital. Cross-reference: Book II, Ch. 5 on the relative advantages of different employments of capital.

refashioned: An Amsterdam merchant who carries grain from Konigsberg to Lisbon and fruit and wine from Lisbon to Konigsberg must keep roughly half his capital in each of those cities at all times. None of it ever needs to come to Amsterdam. Logically, such a merchant should reside in Konigsberg or Lisbon; only very particular circumstances would justify choosing Amsterdam as his base. Yet the anxiety he naturally feels at being separated so far from his capital typically compels him to route some of both the Konigsberg goods he destines for Lisbon and the Lisbon goods he destines for Konigsberg through Amsterdam. Although this necessarily subjects him to the extra costs of double loading and unloading as well as customs duties, he willingly bears these charges for the comfort of keeping part of his capital always within sight and under his direct control. This is how every country with a significant share of the carrying trade inevitably becomes the emporium -- the general marketplace -- for the goods of all the countries whose trade it carries.
elegant: An Amsterdam merchant carrying grain between Konigsberg and Lisbon logically should live in one of those cities, since his capital is split between them. But the anxiety of separation from his capital leads him to route goods through Amsterdam despite added costs. This is how carrying-trade nations become general emporiums -- merchants' desire to keep capital nearby draws goods through their ports.
summary: Smith explains how carrying-trade nations like Holland become commercial emporiums: merchants' anxiety about distant capital leads them to route goods through their home ports, even at extra cost, just to keep their investments within sight. This psychological preference for proximity shapes international trade patterns.
distilled: Carrying-trade nations become commercial emporiums because merchants willingly pay extra costs to route goods through home ports and keep their capital within sight.
notes: Behavioral economics of international trade -- the psychological cost of capital separation drives physical trade routes. Amsterdam as the archetype of the entrepot economy. Cross-reference: 4.2.5 on the merchant's preference for proximity.

refashioned: To avoid the extra cost of loading and unloading twice, the carrying-trade merchant always tries to sell as much as he can in his home market, effectively converting his carrying trade into a foreign trade of consumption. Similarly, a merchant engaged in foreign consumption trade, when gathering goods for foreign markets, will gladly sell as much at home as he can at equal or nearly equal profits, thus converting foreign trade into domestic trade. He saves himself the risk and trouble of exporting. Home is, in this way, the center around which every country's capital continually circulates and toward which it always gravitates, even though particular circumstances may occasionally push it toward more distant employments.
elegant: Merchants naturally convert carrying trade into foreign trade, and foreign trade into home trade, whenever they can sell locally at comparable profits. Home is the gravitational center around which capital circulates -- always pulling investment back, though particular forces may temporarily push it outward.
summary: Smith describes capital's natural gravitational pull toward the home market: carrying-trade merchants try to sell locally to avoid extra costs, and foreign-trade merchants prefer home sales to avoid export risks. Capital always tends homeward, though circumstances may temporarily push it abroad.
distilled: Capital naturally gravitates toward the home market as merchants convert distant trade into local trade wherever possible to reduce costs and risks.
notes: The 'gravitational' model of capital -- home as the natural center of economic activity. This natural tendency is key to Smith's argument that protectionism is unnecessary: capital already prefers domestic employment without government intervention. Cross-reference: 4.2.8 on the employment multiplier of domestic capital.

refashioned: Capital employed in domestic trade, as has already been shown, necessarily activates a greater quantity of domestic industry and provides revenue and employment to more of the country's inhabitants than an equal capital in the foreign trade of consumption. Capital in the foreign trade of consumption, in turn, has the same advantage over an equal capital in the carrying trade. Given equal or nearly equal profits, therefore, every individual naturally tends to employ his capital in the way most likely to support domestic industry and provide revenue and employment to the greatest number of his fellow citizens.
elegant: Domestic trade activates more domestic industry and employment than foreign trade, which in turn activates more than the carrying trade. Since individuals naturally prefer domestic investment at equal profits, capital naturally flows toward maximum domestic employment without any government direction.
summary: Smith establishes that domestic trade generates the most domestic employment per unit of capital, followed by foreign trade and then the carrying trade. Since individuals naturally prefer domestic investment at equal profits, the market naturally maximizes domestic employment.
distilled: Capital employed domestically generates the most domestic industry and employment, and since individuals naturally prefer domestic investment, the market maximizes domestic employment without government intervention.
notes: The employment hierarchy: home trade > foreign consumption trade > carrying trade. This natural preference makes protectionism redundant -- capital already gravitates toward maximum domestic employment. Cross-reference: Book II, Ch. 5 on the domestic employment effects of different capital uses.

refashioned:
Second, every individual who invests his capital in domestic industry necessarily tries to direct that industry so its output has the greatest possible value.

The produce of industry is the value it adds to the materials it works upon. The greater this added value, the greater the employer's profits. Since profit is the sole motive for employing capital in industry, every investor will always try to direct his capital toward the industry whose product is likely to have the greatest value, or to exchange for the greatest quantity of money or other goods.
elegant: Second, every domestic investor naturally directs industry toward its highest-value output, because profits are proportional to the value added. Since profit is the sole motive for investing, capital naturally flows toward the most valuable production.
summary: Smith's second principle: investors naturally direct capital toward the highest-value production because their profits depend on value added. This profit motive ensures that domestic industry is naturally directed toward its most productive use.
distilled: Investors naturally direct capital toward the highest-value production because profits are proportional to value added, ensuring industry gravitates toward its most productive uses.
notes: The profit motive as the mechanism for optimal resource allocation. 'The produce of industry is what it adds to the subject or materials upon which it is employed' -- an early formulation of value-added. Cross-reference: 4.2.10 where this leads to the invisible hand.

refashioned: The annual revenue of every society is always precisely equal to the total exchangeable value of its annual industrial output -- or rather, it is precisely the same thing. Since every individual strives both to invest his capital in domestic industry and to direct that industry toward producing the greatest value, every individual necessarily works to make the society's annual revenue as large as he can. He generally neither intends to promote the public interest nor knows how much he is promoting it. By preferring domestic over foreign industry, he intends only his own security. By directing industry so that its output has the greatest value, he intends only his own profit. And in this, as in many other cases, he is led by an invisible hand to promote an end that was no part of his intention. Nor is it always worse for society that it was unintended. By pursuing his own interest, he frequently advances the society's interest more effectively than when he deliberately tries to promote it. I have never known much good done by those who claimed to trade for the public benefit. It is an affectation not very common among merchants, and very few words are needed to dissuade them from it.
elegant: Society's annual revenue equals the total value of its annual output. Since individuals naturally invest domestically and pursue maximum value, they necessarily maximize national revenue. Each person intends only his own security and profit, yet is led by an invisible hand to promote the public interest -- an end no part of his intention. By pursuing self-interest, he often advances society's welfare more effectively than when deliberately trying to. Those who claim to trade for the public good rarely accomplish much.
summary: Smith presents his most famous argument: individuals pursuing their own profit and security naturally maximize national revenue by investing domestically and seeking the highest-value output. They are 'led by an invisible hand' to promote the public interest without intending to, and typically advance it more effectively than those who deliberately try.
distilled: Individuals pursuing self-interest are led by an invisible hand to promote the public good more effectively than those who deliberately intend to, by naturally directing capital toward its most productive domestic use.
notes: THE invisible hand passage -- Smith's single most famous paragraph and the conceptual foundation of free-market economics. Key elements: (1) self-interest aligns with public interest through market mechanisms; (2) unintended consequences can be beneficial; (3) deliberate promotion of public good is less effective than self-interested action. Often misread as a blanket endorsement of laissez-faire, but Smith's context is specifically about domestic vs. foreign investment, not about the absence of all regulation. Cross-reference: TMS III.2 for the other 'invisible hand' passage; 4.2.11 on the limits of central planning.

refashioned: Which type of domestic industry his capital can employ, and which is likely to produce the greatest value, every individual can clearly judge far better from his local situation than any statesman or legislator could judge for him. A statesman who attempted to tell private individuals how they should invest their capital would not only burden himself with a completely unnecessary responsibility but would claim an authority that could not safely be entrusted to any single person, any council, or any senate -- and which would be most dangerous in the hands of someone foolish and presumptuous enough to think himself qualified to exercise it.
elegant: Individuals, from their local knowledge, can judge the best use of their capital far better than any statesman. A legislator who tried to direct private investment would assume an authority safely entrusted to no one -- most dangerous of all in the hands of someone foolish enough to think himself fit for it.
summary: Smith argues that individuals, with their local knowledge, are always better judges of how to employ their capital than any central authority. Any statesman who attempted such direction would be claiming a power too dangerous for anyone to hold, especially someone presumptuous enough to want it.
distilled: No statesman can direct private capital better than individuals with local knowledge, and the authority to try would be most dangerous in the hands of anyone presumptuous enough to claim it.
notes: The knowledge problem argument against central planning -- later developed by Hayek. Smith's point is epistemological: local knowledge is always superior to centralized knowledge for investment decisions. The closing barb about presumption is aimed at Colbert and similar dirigiste statesmen. Cross-reference: 4.2.10 on the invisible hand; Hayek's 'The Use of Knowledge in Society' (1945).

refashioned: Giving the home market monopoly to domestic producers in any art or manufacture is, in effect, telling private individuals how they should invest their capital, and must in almost all cases be either useless or harmful. If domestic goods can be produced as cheaply as foreign ones, the regulation is obviously unnecessary. If they cannot, it is generally harmful. Every prudent head of household follows the maxim: never try to make at home what costs more to make than to buy. The tailor does not make his own shoes but buys from the shoemaker. The shoemaker does not make his own clothes but hires a tailor. The farmer makes neither, employing both craftsmen instead. All of them find it in their interest to devote their entire effort to the work in which they have an advantage over their neighbors, and to buy everything else with part of their output or, equivalently, with the proceeds from selling it.
elegant: Home-market monopoly is almost always useless or harmful. If domestic goods are as cheap as foreign, protection is unnecessary. If they are not, it is damaging. Every prudent household follows the rule: never make what costs more to produce than to buy. Tailors buy shoes, shoemakers buy clothes, farmers hire both. Everyone specializes in their advantage and purchases the rest.
summary: Smith applies the household maxim -- never make what is cheaper to buy -- to nations. Protectionism is useless if domestic goods match foreign prices, and harmful if they do not. Just as tailors, shoemakers, and farmers all specialize and trade, nations should focus on their advantages and import the rest.
distilled: Protectionism is useless if domestic goods are competitive and harmful if they are not, since the basic rule of every prudent household is to buy what costs more to make than to purchase.
notes: The household analogy -- one of Smith's most influential arguments for free trade, later formalized as comparative advantage by Ricardo. The tailor/shoemaker/farmer example illustrates the universal principle of specialization and exchange. Cross-reference: Book I, Ch. 1-3 on division of labor.

refashioned: What is prudent for every private family can hardly be foolish for a great nation. If a foreign country can supply a commodity more cheaply than we can make it, we are better off buying from them with part of the output of our own industry, employed in activities where we have an advantage. The country's total industry, being always proportional to the capital that supports it, will not shrink -- any more than the tailor's or shoemaker's work shrank when they stopped making each other's products. Industry will simply find the activities where it can be employed most profitably. It is certainly not employed to greatest advantage when directed toward making something it could buy more cheaply. The value of annual output is diminished whenever industry is diverted from producing goods of greater value to producing goods of lesser value. The protected commodity could have been purchased from abroad with only a portion of what domestic industry would have produced if left to follow its natural course. Every such regulation therefore diverts industry from more to less productive uses, and necessarily diminishes rather than increases the total value of annual output.
elegant: What is wise for a household is wise for a nation. If foreigners make something cheaper, buy it from them and focus domestic industry on its strengths. Total employment will not shrink -- it will simply shift to more productive uses, since total industry is always proportional to total capital. Forcing industry to make what it could buy cheaper necessarily diverts resources from higher- to lower-value production. The protected commodity could have been purchased abroad with only a fraction of what domestic industry would have produced if left to follow its natural course. Every protectionist regulation therefore reduces, rather than increases, the total value of national output.
summary: Smith extends the household analogy to the national level: buying cheaply from abroad and specializing in domestic strengths maximizes total output. Protectionism diverts industry from more to less productive activities, necessarily reducing the total value of national output rather than increasing it as legislators intend.
distilled: What is prudent for a household is prudent for a nation: buying cheaply from abroad and specializing domestically maximizes output, while protectionism diverts resources to less productive uses.
notes: The foundation of comparative advantage theory, though Smith frames it as absolute advantage. Key insight: protectionism does not increase total industry (capped by capital) but merely redirects it less productively. Cross-reference: 4.2.3 on capital as the constraint; Ricardo's later formalization of comparative advantage.

refashioned: Through such regulations, a particular manufacture may sometimes be established sooner than it otherwise would be, and might eventually produce at costs equal to or below foreign competitors. But even if industry can be channeled with advantage into a particular activity ahead of schedule, it by no means follows that the total level of industry or revenue will increase as a result. Total industry can grow only as capital grows, and capital can grow only from savings out of revenue. But the immediate effect of every protectionist regulation is to reduce revenue. What reduces revenue is hardly likely to accelerate capital accumulation faster than natural growth would have achieved, had both capital and industry been left free to find their own most productive uses.
elegant: Protectionism may establish a specific industry sooner, but cannot increase total industry or revenue. Industry grows only as capital grows, and capital grows only from savings. Since protectionism immediately reduces revenue by misallocating resources, it cannot accelerate capital formation faster than free markets would.
summary: Smith concedes that protectionism can accelerate the development of a specific industry but argues it cannot increase total economic output. Since industry grows only with capital, and capital grows only from saved revenue, and protectionism immediately reduces revenue through misallocation, it actually slows rather than accelerates economic growth.
distilled: Protectionism may establish a specific industry sooner but cannot increase total output, since it reduces revenue and thereby slows the capital accumulation on which all industrial growth depends.
notes: The infant industry argument addressed and rejected. Smith acknowledges the short-term benefit (earlier establishment) but denies the long-term one (faster growth). The chain of reasoning: protection reduces revenue, lower revenue reduces savings, lower savings reduce capital growth, slower capital growth means less total industry. Cross-reference: 4.2.15 on the counterfactual.

refashioned: Even if a society never acquired the protected manufacture due to the absence of regulation, it would not necessarily be any poorer at any point. Throughout its history, its entire capital and industry could still have been employed -- just on different activities -- in the most advantageous manner available at each time. At every stage, its revenue could have been the maximum its capital could generate, and both capital and revenue could have grown at the fastest possible rate.
elegant: Even without protectionist regulation, a country would not be poorer for lacking a particular manufacture. Its capital and industry would simply be employed differently, in whatever was most advantageous at each moment, generating maximum revenue and growing at the fastest possible rate.
summary: Smith argues that failing to develop a particular industry through protectionism does not make a country poorer. Without intervention, capital and industry find their naturally most productive uses, generating maximum revenue and growing at the fastest possible pace.
distilled: A country is not poorer for lacking a protected industry, since free markets would direct its capital to whatever is most productive, maximizing revenue and growth at every point.
notes: The counterfactual to the infant industry argument. Smith's key point: the opportunity cost of protectionism is the foregone productivity of capital in its natural employment. Cross-reference: 4.2.14 on why protectionism reduces revenue.

refashioned: Some countries' natural advantages in producing certain goods are so enormous that everyone acknowledges the futility of competing with them. Using greenhouses, hotbeds, and heated walls, very good grapes can be grown in Scotland, and very good wine can be made from them -- at roughly thirty times the cost of importing equally good wine from abroad. Would it be reasonable to ban all foreign wine imports merely to encourage the production of claret and Burgundy in Scotland? If it would be manifestly absurd to direct thirty times more capital and labor toward an activity than is needed to buy the same quantity from abroad, then there must be an absurdity -- not as glaring but exactly the same in kind -- in directing even a thirtieth, or even a three-hundredth, more than necessary toward any such protected activity. Whether one country's advantage over another is natural or acquired makes no difference in this respect. As long as one country possesses the advantage and the other lacks it, it will always be more beneficial for the latter to buy rather than to make. An artisan's advantage over his neighbor who practices a different trade is only an acquired one, yet both find it more profitable to buy from each other than to make what belongs to the other's trade.
elegant: Scotland could grow grapes in greenhouses at thirty times the cost of importing wine. Banning wine imports to encourage Scottish winemaking would be absurd -- and there is an equal absurdity, only less glaring, in any protectionism that diverts even slightly more resources than free trade requires. Whether natural or acquired, an advantage is an advantage: it always pays to buy from those who have it rather than to produce at higher cost. Even the advantage one artisan has over another is merely acquired, yet both find it more profitable to buy from each other than to attempt each other's trade.
summary: Smith uses the famous Scottish wine example to argue that protectionism is always absurd in kind, differing only in degree. Whether an advantage is natural (climate) or acquired (skill), it always makes sense to buy from the more efficient producer rather than produce at higher cost -- just as artisans buy from each other rather than attempting each other's trades.
distilled: Forcing Scotland to grow wine at thirty times the import cost would be absurd, and all protectionism is the same absurdity in kind, differing only in degree.
notes: The Scottish wine argument -- Smith's most memorable illustration of comparative advantage. The 'natural vs. acquired advantage' point preempts the objection that natural advantages are different from learned skills. Cross-reference: 4.2.12 on the tailor/shoemaker analogy; Ricardo on comparative advantage.

refashioned: Merchants and manufacturers are the people who benefit most from home-market monopoly. The protections given to British graziers and farmers -- bans on importing foreign cattle and salt provisions, and duties on grain that effectively prohibit imports during normal times -- are far less valuable to agricultural producers than equivalent protections are to manufacturers. Fine manufactures, especially those of higher quality, are easily transported from one country to another, far more so than grain or cattle. Foreign trade is chiefly occupied with transporting manufactures. In manufacturing, even a small foreign advantage in cost or quality is sufficient to undersell domestic producers in the home market. In the case of raw agricultural produce, only a very large advantage could achieve the same result. If the free importation of foreign manufactures were permitted, several domestic manufacturing industries would likely suffer, some might be destroyed entirely, and considerable amounts of capital and labor currently employed in them would be forced to find other employment. But the freest possible importation of raw agricultural produce could have no comparable effect upon the farming interests of the country.
elegant: Merchants and manufacturers gain most from protectionism because fine manufactures are easily transported, making them genuinely vulnerable to foreign competition -- a small cost advantage can undersell domestic producers. Agriculture, dealing in bulky, perishable goods, faces little realistic import threat. Free manufacture imports would hurt some industries, but free import of farm produce would barely affect British agriculture.
summary: Smith argues that protectionism primarily benefits manufacturers rather than farmers, because fine manufactures are easily transported and face real foreign competition, while agricultural products are too bulky for imports to pose a serious threat to domestic producers.
distilled: Protectionism benefits manufacturers far more than farmers because manufactures are easily transported and face real foreign competition, while agricultural products are too bulky for imports to threaten domestic producers.
notes: The asymmetric impact of free trade -- manufactures are vulnerable, agriculture is naturally protected by transport costs. This distinction is important: Smith argues that the very people least threatened (farmers) are being recruited to support protectionism by those most threatened (manufacturers). Cross-reference: 4.2.22 on farmers' natural generosity vs. manufacturers' monopoly spirit.

refashioned: Even with the freest possible importation of foreign cattle, so few could actually be imported that British graziers would scarcely notice. Live cattle may be the only commodity whose sea transport is more expensive than overland transport: by land they walk themselves to market, but by sea their food and water must also be shipped at considerable cost. The short sea crossing from Ireland makes Irish cattle imports somewhat more practical, but even if permanently allowed, this could have no significant effect on British graziers. The regions bordering the Irish Sea are all grazing country themselves. Irish cattle could never serve their local market but would have to be driven through these extensive regions at great cost before reaching their real destination. Fat cattle could not survive such a long drive, so only lean cattle could be imported, which would affect only breeding regions, not feeding and fattening ones -- indeed, cheaper lean cattle would actually benefit the fattening regions. The small number of Irish cattle imported since the trade was permitted, and the continued strong prices for lean cattle, demonstrate that even Britain's breeding regions have little to fear. It is true that Irish commoners have sometimes violently opposed the export of their cattle, but if exporters had found the trade truly profitable, they could easily have overcome such resistance with the law on their side.
elegant: Free cattle imports would barely affect British graziers. Live cattle are uniquely expensive to ship by sea -- they walk themselves to market on land but at sea require food, water, and cargo space. Even Irish cattle, despite the short crossing, would need to be driven long distances through existing grazing regions to reach actual markets. Only lean cattle could survive such journeys, and they would affect only breeding regions while actually benefiting fattening regions through lower input prices. Evidence since Irish imports were permitted confirms the minimal impact: few cattle have arrived, and lean cattle prices remain strong.
summary: Smith demonstrates through detailed analysis that free cattle imports pose virtually no threat to British graziers. Live cattle are uniquely expensive to ship by sea, can only be imported lean over the short Irish crossing, and would affect only breeding regions while benefiting fattening regions. Empirical evidence confirms the negligible impact.
distilled: Free cattle imports pose minimal threat to British graziers because live cattle are uniquely costly to transport by sea, limiting practical imports to lean Irish cattle that affect only breeding regions.
notes: Detailed empirical case study in the economics of transport costs as natural protection. The self-transporting nature of cattle ('by land they carry themselves to market') is a clever observation. Smith anticipates the general point that agriculture is naturally protected by the bulk and perishability of its products. Cross-reference: 4.2.17 on the natural protection of agriculture.

refashioned: Countries that specialize in feeding and fattening cattle must always be highly improved agricultural regions, whereas breeding countries are generally uncultivated. High prices for lean cattle increase the value of uncultivated land, functioning as a bounty against agricultural improvement. For any thoroughly improved country, it would be more advantageous to import lean cattle than to breed them -- Holland reportedly follows this practice. The mountains of Scotland, Wales, and Northumberland, being largely incapable of improvement, seem naturally destined to serve as Britain's breeding regions. The freest importation of foreign cattle could only prevent these breeding regions from exploiting the growing population and improvement of the rest of the kingdom to push their prices to extortionate heights and impose a real tax on the more cultivated parts of the country.
elegant: Fattening regions are improved; breeding regions are uncultivated. High lean-cattle prices reward uncultivated land, acting as a bounty against improvement. Improved countries like Holland import lean cattle rather than breed them. Free cattle imports would merely prevent Britain's mountain breeding regions from exploiting their position to impose extortionate prices on the rest of the country.
summary: Smith argues that free cattle imports would actually benefit Britain's improved agricultural regions by preventing mountain breeding areas from charging extortionate prices that effectively tax the rest of the country. He notes that highly improved countries like Holland find it more efficient to import lean cattle than to breed them.
distilled: Free cattle imports would benefit improved agricultural regions by preventing mountain breeding areas from exploiting their position to impose extortionate prices on the rest of the country.
notes: Economic geography of cattle trade -- breeding regions (mountains) vs. fattening regions (lowlands). Smith identifies a tension between natural protection and monopoly pricing. Holland as the exemplar of rational agricultural specialization. Cross-reference: 4.2.18 on the logistics of cattle trade.

refashioned: The freest importation of salt provisions could have just as little effect on British graziers as the importation of live cattle. Salt provisions are not only very bulky but, compared with fresh meat, are an inferior product that costs more in labor and expense, making them more expensive. They could never compete with fresh meat, only with domestic salt provisions. They might be used for provisioning ships on long voyages and similar purposes, but could never constitute a significant part of the people's diet. The small quantity of salt provisions imported from Ireland since imports were made free provides experimental proof that British graziers have nothing to worry about. The price of fresh meat appears never to have been noticeably affected.
elegant: Free salt provision imports are equally harmless. Salt meat is bulky, inferior to fresh meat, and more expensive to produce. It competes only with domestic salt provisions, mainly for ship provisioning. The negligible imports from Ireland since liberalization prove graziers have nothing to fear.
summary: Smith extends his analysis to salt provisions, showing they pose even less threat to British graziers than live cattle: they are bulky, inferior, expensive, and compete only with domestic salt meat for niche uses like ship provisioning. Irish import data confirms the negligible impact.
distilled: Free importation of salt provisions cannot harm British graziers because salt meat is bulky, inferior, and expensive compared to fresh meat, competing only in niche markets like ship provisioning.
notes: Continuation of the empirical case that agriculture is naturally protected. Salt provisions were important for naval and maritime provisioning but irrelevant to domestic food markets. Smith consistently appeals to actual import data as evidence.

refashioned: Even the free importation of foreign grain could barely affect British farmers' interests. Grain is far bulkier in proportion to its value than meat -- a pound of wheat at a penny costs as much to transport as a pound of meat at fourpence. The tiny quantity of foreign grain imported even during the worst shortages should reassure farmers that completely free importation poses no threat. According to the well-informed author of the Tracts upon the Corn Trade, average annual imports total only 23,728 quarters of all grain types -- amounting to just one five-hundred-and-seventy-first part of annual consumption. Moreover, the corn bounty system, by encouraging excessive exports in years of plenty, actually necessitates greater imports during years of scarcity than would otherwise occur. Through the bounty, the abundance of one year does not compensate for the shortage of another. Without the bounty, less grain would be exported in good years, and consequently less would need to be imported in bad years. The corn merchants -- the middlemen who transport grain between Britain and foreign countries -- would lose considerable business and might suffer significantly. But the country gentlemen and farmers themselves could suffer very little from the change. Accordingly, it is among the corn merchants, not the farmers and country gentlemen, that I have observed the greatest anxiety for the bounty's renewal and continuation.
elegant: Free grain imports could barely affect British farmers. Grain is extremely bulky relative to its value, and average annual imports amount to a mere 1/571st of national consumption. The corn bounty actually worsens the situation by encouraging excessive exports in good years, which necessitates greater imports in bad years -- the abundance of one year fails to compensate for the shortage of another. Abolishing the bounty would reduce both exports and imports, harming only the corn merchants who profit from the trade, while leaving farmers and country gentlemen largely unaffected. This explains why merchants, not farmers, lobby most eagerly for the bounty's renewal.
summary: Smith shows that free grain imports pose minimal threat to British farmers: grain is too bulky for cheap transport, imports are negligible (1/571st of consumption), and the corn bounty actually worsens import dependence. Abolishing the bounty would hurt only corn merchants, who are the true lobbyists for its continuation, not the farmers it supposedly protects.
distilled: Free grain imports would barely affect British farmers since grain is too bulky for cheap transport and imports are negligible, while the corn bounty actually increases import dependence and benefits only corn merchants.
notes: Detailed analysis of the British corn trade. The Tracts upon the Corn Trade (1766) was by Charles Smith. The 23,728 quarters figure illustrates import insignificance. Smith's insight that the bounty increases both exports AND imports is an early example of policy feedback analysis. Cross-reference: Ch. 4.5 on bounties.

refashioned: Country gentlemen and farmers are, to their great credit, the people least susceptible to the wretched spirit of monopoly. A major manufacturer is sometimes alarmed when a rival sets up within twenty miles; the Dutch proprietor of the woolen works at Abbeville stipulated that no similar factory should be established within thirty leagues. Farmers and country gentlemen, by contrast, generally promote rather than obstruct the improvement of neighboring farms and estates. They have no trade secrets like manufacturers; they are typically eager to share with neighbors any new technique they have found beneficial. As old Cato said: 'Of all gainful pursuits, farming is the most reliable, the most natural, and the least resented; and those engaged in it are the least prone to ill intentions.' Country gentlemen and farmers, dispersed across the countryside, cannot combine as easily as merchants and manufacturers, who are concentrated in towns and accustomed to the exclusive corporate spirit that prevails there.
