But the real exchange was not necessarily against London. Since the reform, it has been in London's favor even with those places. The computed exchange has generally favored London with Lisbon, Antwerp, Livorno, and most other European places paying in common currency -- and the real exchange probably did so as well.
elegant: Third, some places pay bills in bank money (Amsterdam, Hamburg, Venice), others in common currency (London, Lisbon). Bank money carries a premium -- about 5% in Amsterdam. This means computed exchange can favor bank-money countries even when real exchange does not. Before England's gold reform, the computed exchange ran against London with bank-money cities, but the real exchange may not have. Since the reform, both computed and real exchange have favored London.
summary: Smith explains that the distinction between bank money and common currency distorts exchange rate comparisons. Cities paying in premium bank money appear to have favorable exchange rates even when the real exchange may favor the country paying in common currency.
distilled: The distinction between bank money and common currency creates a systematic bias in computed exchange rates favoring cities that pay foreign bills in higher-value bank money.
notes: Bank money vs. common currency -- agio of Bank of Amsterdam (~5%) -- computed vs. real exchange -- London, Venice, Hamburg, Amsterdam comparisons -- English gold coin reform effects -- systematic measurement bias in exchange rate calculations

refashioned:
Digression on Banks of Deposit, Particularly the Bank of Amsterdam.

The currency of a large state like France or England consists almost entirely of its own coins. If this currency becomes worn, clipped, or otherwise debased below standard, the state can effectively restore it through currency reform. But the currency of a small state like Genoa or Hamburg can rarely consist entirely of its own coins; it must be composed largely of coins from neighboring states with which its inhabitants constantly trade. Such a state, therefore, cannot always fix its currency simply by reforming its own coins. If foreign bills of exchange are paid in this mixed currency, the uncertain value of any sum denominated in such an inherently uncertain medium must make the exchange rate run heavily against such a state, since foreign countries will necessarily value its currency even below its true worth.
elegant: Large states can reform debased currency by reforming their own coins. Small trading states like Genoa or Hamburg cannot, because their currency consists largely of foreign coins. This uncertain mixed currency makes exchange rates run against small states, whose money is valued abroad even below its actual worth.
summary: Smith begins his digression on deposit banks by explaining why small trading states face currency problems that large states do not. Their currencies, composed largely of foreign coins, cannot be fixed by domestic reform alone, causing exchange rates to run against them.
distilled: Small trading states cannot fix their mixed-currency problems through domestic coin reform alone, causing exchange rates to systematically run against them.
notes: Banks of deposit -- digression begins -- large vs. small state currency management -- mixed currency problem -- Genoa and Hamburg -- currency reform limitations -- exchange rate disadvantage of small states

refashioned: To remedy the disadvantageous exchange rates that burdened their merchants, small states that began paying attention to trade frequently mandated that foreign bills of exchange above a certain value must be paid not in ordinary currency but by transfer in the books of a bank established under state authority. These banks were always required to pay out in sound money, exactly according to the state's standard. The banks of Venice, Genoa, Amsterdam, Hamburg, and Nuremberg all appear to have been originally established for this purpose, though some later served additional functions. Because bank money was better than the common currency, it naturally carried a premium -- larger or smaller depending on how much the common currency had deteriorated below the state's standard. The agio of the Hamburg bank, for example, commonly runs at about fourteen percent, representing the estimated gap between the state's good standard money and the clipped, worn, and diminished coins flowing in from neighboring states.
elegant: To fix their exchange rate problems, small trading states established banks of deposit -- at Venice, Genoa, Amsterdam, Hamburg, and Nuremberg. These banks paid in sound money at the state standard, and foreign bills above a certain value had to be settled through them. Bank money naturally carried a premium (agio) over degraded common currency -- about 14% at Hamburg, reflecting the gap between good standard money and worn foreign coins.
summary: Small trading states established banks of deposit to remedy their currency problems. These banks held and transacted in sound money, creating a premium (agio) over the degraded common currency, which solved the exchange rate disadvantage.
distilled: Banks of deposit at Venice, Amsterdam, Hamburg, and elsewhere were created to provide sound money for trade settlements, naturally earning a premium over degraded common currency.
notes: Banks of deposit -- Venice, Genoa, Amsterdam, Hamburg, Nuremberg -- agio (bank money premium) -- Hamburg agio ~14% -- institutional solution to mixed currency problem -- sound money vs. degraded currency

refashioned: Before 1609, the large volume of clipped and worn foreign coins brought into Amsterdam by its extensive trade had reduced the value of its currency to about nine percent below that of freshly minted money. Whenever good money appeared, it was immediately melted down or exported, as always happens in such circumstances. Merchants had plenty of ordinary currency but could not always find enough good money to pay their bills of exchange, and despite several regulations aimed at preventing this, the value of those bills became largely unpredictable.
elegant: Before 1609, Amsterdam's extensive trade flooded it with degraded foreign coins, reducing its currency to 9% below mint value. Good money was immediately melted or exported. Merchants could not find enough sound money to pay bills of exchange, and their value became unpredictable.
summary: Before the Bank of Amsterdam was established, the city's currency was debased by clipped foreign coins, good money disappeared through Gresham's Law, and the value of bills of exchange became uncertain.
distilled: Before 1609, Amsterdam's currency was debased by worn foreign coins, good money disappeared, and the value of bills of exchange became unpredictable.
notes: Gresham's Law (bad money drives out good) -- Amsterdam pre-1609 -- currency debasement from trade -- 9% below mint value -- bills of exchange uncertainty -- motivation for Bank of Amsterdam

refashioned: To remedy these problems, a bank was established in 1609 under the guarantee of the city of Amsterdam. This bank accepted both foreign coins and the light, worn domestic coins at their actual intrinsic value in the country's good standard money, deducting only enough to cover the costs of coinage and management. For the remaining value after this small deduction, it gave a credit in its books. This credit was called bank money. Because it represented money exactly according to the mint standard, it always held the same real value and was inherently worth more than circulating currency. At the same time, a law required that all bills drawn on or negotiated in Amsterdam worth 600 guilders or more must be paid in bank money. This immediately eliminated all uncertainty about the value of such bills. Every merchant consequently had to maintain an account with the bank in order to pay foreign bills of exchange, which naturally created steady demand for bank money.
elegant: In 1609, Amsterdam established a city-guaranteed bank that accepted coins at their true intrinsic value, deducted minting costs, and credited the remainder as bank money -- always worth its full standard value. Bills of 600 guilders or more had to be paid in bank money, eliminating value uncertainty and creating steady demand as every merchant needed a bank account for foreign exchange.
summary: The Bank of Amsterdam, founded in 1609, accepted coins at intrinsic value and credited standardized bank money. By requiring large bills to be paid in bank money, it eliminated uncertainty and created guaranteed demand for the bank's services.
distilled: The Bank of Amsterdam solved currency uncertainty by converting coins to standardized bank money credits and requiring all large bills be settled through it.
notes: Bank of Amsterdam founded 1609 -- city guarantee -- intrinsic value assessment -- bank money as standard -- 600 guilder threshold for mandatory bank settlement -- institutional demand creation -- elimination of currency uncertainty

refashioned: Beyond its inherent superiority to ordinary currency and the additional value created by this mandatory demand, bank money had several other advantages. It was safe from fire, robbery, and other accidents since the city of Amsterdam guaranteed it. It could be transferred by a simple bookkeeping entry, without the trouble of counting coins or the risk of transporting them. Because of these combined advantages, bank money seems to have carried a premium from the very beginning. It is generally believed that all the money originally deposited in the bank was left there, since nobody wanted to withdraw a deposit they could sell at a premium on the market. By demanding payment from the bank, the owner of a bank credit would lose this premium. Just as a freshly minted shilling buys no more in the marketplace than a worn one, good money withdrawn from the bank and mixed into ordinary circulation would be worth no more than the common currency it could no longer be distinguished from. While in the bank's vaults, its superior quality was known and verified. Once in private hands, verifying that superiority would require more effort than the difference was worth. Besides losing the premium, money withdrawn from the bank would also lose the safety of bank storage, the ease and security of transfer, and its usefulness for paying foreign bills. On top of all this, as will become apparent, money could not be withdrawn without first paying a storage fee.
elegant: Bank money was also secure from fire and theft, city-guaranteed, and transferable by simple bookkeeping. These advantages meant it always carried a premium, and depositors left their money in the bank rather than withdraw it and lose that premium. Good money mixed back into ordinary circulation became indistinguishable from worn coins, losing its verified superiority, security, transferability, and utility for foreign exchange -- plus withdrawal required paying a storage fee.
summary: Bank money carried a premium due to its security, easy transferability, and guaranteed quality. Depositors had no incentive to withdraw since good money mixed into circulation lost its premium and all the advantages of remaining in the bank.
distilled: Bank money's premium persisted because withdrawing it meant losing security, easy transfer, verified quality, and foreign exchange utility -- plus paying storage fees.
notes: Advantages of bank money -- security from theft/fire -- city guarantee -- transfer by bookkeeping -- Gresham's Law in reverse (good money stays in bank) -- premium as incentive to maintain deposits -- storage fees for withdrawal -- network effects of bank money

refashioned: The coin deposits that the bank was obligated to return in coin constituted the bank's original capital -- the entire value represented by bank money. Today these are believed to represent only a very small portion of it. To facilitate the bullion trade, the bank has for many years extended credit in its books for deposits of gold and silver bullion, typically at about five percent below the mint price. The bank simultaneously issues what is called a receipt, entitling the depositor or bearer to withdraw the bullion within six months by transferring back to the bank an equivalent amount of bank money and paying a storage fee of one-quarter percent for silver or one-half percent for gold. If this payment is not made and the six-month term expires, the deposit becomes the bank's property at the price originally credited. This storage fee functions as a kind of warehouse rent. Several explanations have been offered for why gold storage costs more than silver: gold's fineness is harder to verify, fraud is easier and more costly with the more precious metal, and since silver is the standard metal, the state supposedly wishes to encourage silver deposits more than gold deposits.
elegant: The bank's original capital was coin deposits it was bound to return. Now, most bank money is created through bullion deposits at 5% below mint price. Depositors receive receipts allowing bullion withdrawal within six months upon returning equivalent bank money plus storage fees -- 0.25% for silver, 0.5% for gold. Expired receipts forfeit the bullion to the bank. Gold storage costs more because its fineness is harder to verify, fraud is costlier, and silver is the preferred standard metal.
summary: The Bank of Amsterdam evolved from holding only coin to primarily crediting deposits of bullion at 5% below mint price, issuing receipts redeemable within six months upon paying storage fees. Gold storage costs more than silver due to verification difficulties and policy preferences.
distilled: The Bank of Amsterdam primarily creates bank money through bullion deposits credited at 5% below mint price, with six-month receipts and differential storage fees for gold and silver.
notes: Bank capital evolution -- bullion deposits vs. coin deposits -- 5% below mint price -- receipt system -- six-month term -- warehouse rent analogy -- gold vs. silver storage fees (0.5% vs. 0.25%) -- fineness verification -- standard metal preference

refashioned: Bullion deposits are typically made when the price is somewhat below its usual level, and withdrawn when it rises. In Holland, the market price of bullion generally exceeds the mint price, for the same reason it did in England before the gold coin reform. The difference is said to commonly range from about six to sixteen stivers per mark (eight ounces of silver at eleven parts fine and one part alloy). The bank price -- the credit given for silver deposits of well-known foreign coins like Mexican dollars -- is twenty-two guilders per mark. The mint price is about twenty-three guilders, and the market price ranges from twenty-three guilders six stivers to twenty-three guilders sixteen stivers -- roughly two to three percent above the mint price.
elegant: Bullion deposits are made when prices are low and withdrawn when they rise. In Holland, the market price of bullion typically exceeds the mint price by six to sixteen stivers per mark. The bank credits Mexican dollars at 22 guilders per mark against a mint price of about 23 guilders and a market price of 23 guilders 6-16 stivers -- roughly 2-3% above mint price.
summary: Bullion deposits at the Bank of Amsterdam follow price cycles, with depositors buying low and withdrawing high. The bank credit, mint price, and market price of silver exist in a tiered relationship, with market prices typically 2-3% above the mint price.
distilled: Bullion deposits at the Bank of Amsterdam are timed to buy low and sell high, with the bank credit, mint price, and market price forming a tiered pricing structure.
notes: Bullion price arbitrage -- Dutch bullion market -- Mexican dollars as standard coin -- bank price vs. mint price vs. market price -- 2-3% spread -- stivers and guilders -- mark as weight unit (8 ounces)

refashioned:
The following are the prices at which the Bank of Amsterdam receives bullion and coin of various kinds (as of September 1775):

Fine bars at 28 guilders per mark.

refashioned: Gold: Portuguese coin at 310 guilders per mark; Guineas at 310; new Louis d'ors at 310; old Louis d'ors at 300; new ducats at 4 guilders 19 stivers 8 penningen per ducat. Bar or ingot gold is received in proportion to its fineness compared to the listed foreign gold coins. For fine bars, the bank pays 340 guilders per mark. Generally, somewhat more is given for coins of known fineness than for gold and silver bars, whose fineness can only be determined through the expensive process of melting and assaying.

refashioned: The relationships between the bank price, mint price, and market price of gold bullion follow roughly the same pattern as for silver. A depositor can generally sell his receipt for the difference between the mint price and the market price of bullion. Since a receipt is almost always worth something, people very rarely let their receipts expire or allow their bullion to fall to the bank at the price at which it was originally received. They either withdraw it before the six months end or pay the storage fee to obtain a new receipt for another six-month period. This default happens seldom, though it is said to occur occasionally -- more often with gold than with silver, because of the higher storage charge on the more precious metal.
elegant: The bank-mint-market price relationships for gold mirror those for silver. Receipt holders can sell for the mint-to-market price spread, so receipts almost always retain value. Depositors rarely let receipts expire, though it happens slightly more often with gold due to its higher storage fee.
summary: Receipts for bullion deposits almost always retain value because of the spread between mint and market prices. Defaults are rare but occur slightly more often with gold than silver due to higher storage fees.
distilled: Bullion receipts almost always retain value because of the mint-to-market price spread, with rare defaults occurring slightly more often for gold due to higher storage fees.
notes: Receipt valuation -- mint-market price spread -- receipt expiration -- gold vs. silver default rates -- higher gold storage fees -- bank-mint-market price triangle for gold

refashioned: The person who deposits bullion and obtains both a bank credit and a receipt uses the bank credit to pay bills of exchange as they come due, and either sells or keeps the receipt depending on whether bullion prices seem likely to rise or fall. The receipt and the bank credit rarely stay together for long, and there is no reason they should. Anyone who holds a receipt and wants to withdraw bullion can always find plenty of bank credits available for purchase at the ordinary price. Likewise, anyone who holds bank money and wants to withdraw bullion can always find receipts readily available.
elegant: Depositors use bank credits to pay bills and trade receipts based on bullion price expectations. The two instruments naturally separate: receipt holders easily buy bank money, and bank money holders easily buy receipts. Both markets remain liquid.
summary: Bank credits and receipts naturally separate after deposit, functioning as independent instruments. Receipt holders and bank money holders can always find counterparties, keeping both markets liquid.
distilled: Bank credits and bullion receipts naturally separate into independently traded instruments, with liquid markets for both.
notes: Separation of bank credit and receipt -- two-instrument system -- market liquidity -- bullion price speculation through receipts -- bills of exchange settlement through bank credits -- financial instrument innovation

refashioned: The owners of bank credits and the holders of receipts constitute two different kinds of creditors against the bank. A receipt holder cannot withdraw bullion without first transferring back to the bank an amount of bank money equal to the original credited price. If he has no bank money of his own, he must buy it from those who do. A bank money owner cannot withdraw bullion without presenting receipts for the desired quantity. If he has none, he must buy them from those who do. When a receipt holder buys bank money, he is purchasing the power to withdraw bullion whose mint price is five percent above the bank price. The five percent agio he typically pays therefore represents real value, not an imaginary one. When a bank money owner buys a receipt, he is purchasing the power to withdraw bullion whose market price commonly exceeds the mint price by two to three percent. The price he pays for the receipt is likewise for real value. The receipt price and the bank money price together make up the full value of the bullion.
elegant: Receipt holders and bank money owners are two distinct classes of bank creditors. Neither can withdraw bullion alone: receipt holders need bank money, bank money holders need receipts. The agio paid for bank money (about 5% above bank price) and the price paid for receipts (reflecting the 2-3% mint-to-market spread) each represent real value. Together, they equal the full market value of the bullion.
summary: The Bank of Amsterdam's two-instrument system requires both bank money and a receipt to withdraw bullion. The prices paid for each represent genuine value -- the agio covers the bank-to-mint spread, and the receipt price covers the mint-to-market spread -- together equaling the bullion's full value.
distilled: Withdrawing bullion from the Bank of Amsterdam requires both bank money and a receipt, whose combined prices equal the bullion's full market value.
notes: Two classes of bank creditors -- receipt holders vs. bank money owners -- mutual dependency for withdrawal -- real vs. imaginary value -- agio as genuine value -- receipt price as genuine value -- full bullion value = bank money agio + receipt price

refashioned: The bank also issues receipts and credits for deposits of common domestic coins, but these receipts are frequently worthless on the market. For ducatoons, which circulate at three guilders three stivers each, the bank credits only three guilders -- five percent below their current value -- and issues a receipt redeemable within six months for a quarter-percent storage fee. This receipt typically has no market value because three guilders of bank money generally sells for three guilders three stivers anyway, and the storage fee for withdrawal would be a pure loss to the receipt holder. However, if the bank's agio were to fall to three percent, such receipts might be worth about one and three-quarters percent. Since the agio normally runs at about five percent, these receipts are frequently allowed to expire -- or as the Dutch say, to "fall to the bank." Gold ducat receipts expire even more frequently because their higher storage fee of one-half percent makes renewal less worthwhile. The five percent the bank gains when deposits of either coin or bullion are allowed to expire may be considered the warehouse rent for perpetual storage.
elegant: The bank also accepts common domestic coins but credits them at 5% below face value. The resulting receipts are usually worthless because bank money already trades at a premium equal to the difference. Unless the agio falls below 5%, holders gain nothing by redeeming and must pay storage fees, so these receipts frequently expire. Gold ducat receipts expire even more often due to higher storage costs. The bank's 5% gain on expired deposits amounts to a perpetual storage fee.
summary: Receipts for domestic coin deposits at the Bank of Amsterdam are typically worthless because the bank's 5% agio already accounts for the difference between bank credit and face value. These receipts frequently expire, giving the bank a perpetual 5% gain as effective warehouse rent.
distilled: Receipts for domestic coin deposits are typically worthless due to the bank's agio, so they frequently expire, giving the bank a perpetual 5% gain as warehouse rent.
notes: Domestic coin deposits -- ducatoons -- receipt worthlessness -- agio threshold for receipt value -- gold ducat receipts -- higher gold storage fees -- perpetual warehouse rent -- 5% bank gain on expired deposits

refashioned: The total bank money represented by expired receipts must be very substantial. It presumably includes the bank's entire original capital, which is generally believed to have been left in place since first deposited, since neither renewing the receipt nor withdrawing the deposit could be done without loss. Whatever this amount may be, the proportion it bears to the total mass of bank money is believed to be quite small. The Bank of Amsterdam has for many years been Europe's great bullion warehouse, and receipts on bullion deposits are very seldom allowed to expire. The far greater part of the bank's credits are believed to have been created in recent years by bullion deposits that dealers continually make and withdraw.
elegant: The bank money from expired receipts -- including the entire original capital left since first deposited -- must be substantial in absolute terms but small relative to total bank money. Most bank credits now come from continual bullion deposits and withdrawals by dealers, making the Bank of Amsterdam Europe's great bullion warehouse.
summary: While the bank money from expired receipts (including the original capital) is substantial, it represents only a small fraction of total bank money, which is now predominantly created through the continual flow of bullion deposits and withdrawals by dealers.
distilled: Most of the Bank of Amsterdam's money supply is now created through the continuous flow of bullion deposits and withdrawals rather than from the original dormant coin deposits.
notes: Original capital vs. current operations -- bullion warehouse function -- Europe's central bullion repository -- dynamic vs. static deposits -- receipt turnover in bullion trade -- evolution of bank money creation

refashioned: No withdrawal from the bank can be made without a receipt. The smaller pool of bank money for which receipts have expired is mixed in with the much larger pool for which receipts are still active. So although a considerable sum of bank money has no corresponding receipt, there is no specific portion that might not be claimed by someone at any time. The bank cannot owe the same sum to two different people, and anyone holding bank money without a receipt cannot demand payment until they buy one. In ordinary, peaceful times, this presents no difficulty -- receipts can be purchased at the market price, which generally corresponds to the price at which one could sell the coin or bullion the receipt entitles one to withdraw.
elegant: Withdrawals require receipts, and expired-receipt bank money is mixed indistinguishably with active-receipt money. Though no specific portion is unclaimed, all bank money is potentially redeemable. Bank money holders without receipts must buy one at market price before withdrawing -- easily done in normal times.
summary: Bank money from expired receipts blends with active-receipt money, making every unit potentially claimable. Since withdrawals require receipts, bank money holders must purchase one at market price, which poses no difficulty under normal conditions.
distilled: All bank money is potentially redeemable regardless of receipt status, but holders must purchase a receipt at market price to make actual withdrawals.
notes: Fungibility of bank money -- expired vs. active receipt pools -- receipt as withdrawal prerequisite -- market liquidity in normal times -- no double claims -- operational mechanics of Bank of Amsterdam

refashioned: Things could be very different during a public crisis -- an invasion, for example, like the French invasion of 1672. If all bank money holders rushed to withdraw their funds for safekeeping, demand for receipts could drive their price to extraordinary levels. Receipt holders might demand not just two or three percent but half the bank money for which the original deposit credit had been given. An invading enemy, understanding the bank's structure, might even buy up receipts to prevent the treasure from being carried away. In such emergencies, the bank would presumably break its normal rule of paying only receipt holders. Receipt holders without bank money would have received within two or three percent of their deposit's value. The bank, it is said, would therefore pay the full credited value to bank money holders who could not obtain receipts, while paying receipt holders without bank money only two or three percent -- this being the entire value that could reasonably be attributed to them under such circumstances.
elegant: During a crisis like the 1672 French invasion, a bank run would drive receipt prices to extortionate levels, and enemies might buy receipts to trap the treasure. The bank would presumably abandon normal rules: paying bank money holders their full credited value directly, while receipt holders without bank money would receive only 2-3% -- their fair share in a panic.
summary: Smith describes how a crisis like the 1672 French invasion could disrupt the Bank of Amsterdam's normal operations, driving receipt prices to extreme levels and potentially forcing the bank to abandon its usual withdrawal procedures.
distilled: In a crisis, the Bank of Amsterdam would likely abandon normal receipt requirements and pay bank money holders directly while limiting receipt-only holders to a small percentage.
notes: Bank run scenario -- French invasion of 1672 -- receipt price manipulation -- enemy exploitation of banking structure -- emergency measures -- crisis departure from normal rules -- distinction between bank money and receipt value in panic conditions

refashioned: Even in ordinary, peaceful times, receipt holders have an interest in pushing the agio down -- either to buy bank money (and hence bullion) more cheaply, or to sell their receipts at a higher price to bank money holders who want to withdraw bullion. The receipt's price generally equals the gap between the market price of bank money and the price of the coin or bullion for which it was issued. Bank money owners, by contrast, have an interest in pushing the agio up -- either to sell their bank money at a higher price or to buy receipts more cheaply. To prevent the speculative manipulation that these opposing interests might cause, the bank in recent years has resolved to sell bank money for currency at a five percent agio and to buy it back at four percent. As a result, the agio can never rise above five percent or fall below four percent, and the ratio between bank money and regular currency stays close to the ratio between their intrinsic values. Before this resolution, the market price of bank money sometimes rose as high as nine percent agio and sometimes fell to par, depending on which set of interests happened to dominate the market.
elegant: Receipt holders want the agio low (to buy bank money cheaply); bank money owners want it high (to sell dearly). To prevent speculative manipulation, the bank now sells bank money at 5% agio and buys at 4%, keeping the agio in a narrow band near the intrinsic value ratio. Before this policy, the agio swung wildly between 0% and 9%.
summary: The Bank of Amsterdam stabilized the agio by committing to sell bank money at 5% and buy at 4%, preventing the speculative manipulation that had previously caused wild swings between 0% and 9%.
distilled: The Bank of Amsterdam stabilized its agio within a 4-5% band by committing to buy and sell bank money at fixed rates, ending speculation-driven volatility.
notes: Agio stabilization -- opposing interests of receipt holders vs. bank money owners -- speculative manipulation (stock-jobbing) -- floor and ceiling pricing mechanism -- 4-5% band -- historical volatility (0-9%) -- proto-central banking -- market-making by the bank

refashioned: The Bank of Amsterdam claims to lend out none of what is deposited with it, maintaining in its vaults the full value of every guilder credited in its books, whether in money or bullion. That it keeps all the money and bullion for which active receipts exist -- money that is constantly flowing in and out -- can hardly be doubted. Whether it does the same for the portion of its capital whose receipts expired long ago -- money it cannot be asked to return in normal times and which will likely remain with it forever, or at least as long as the Dutch Republic endures -- is perhaps more uncertain. In Amsterdam, however, there is no article of faith more firmly established than this: that for every guilder of bank money in circulation, a corresponding guilder of gold or silver sits in the bank's vaults.
elegant: The Bank of Amsterdam claims to hold the full value in metal of every guilder it credits. This is surely true for active-receipt deposits in constant circulation. Whether it applies equally to the capital from long-expired receipts -- which will likely stay permanently -- is less certain. Yet Amsterdammers hold it as an unshakeable article of faith that every guilder of bank money has a corresponding guilder of metal in the vaults.
summary: The Bank of Amsterdam professes full reserve backing for all bank money. While this is certain for active deposits, the status of funds from long-expired receipts is more questionable, though the people of Amsterdam treat full backing as an article of faith.
distilled: The Bank of Amsterdam claims full reserve backing for all bank money, which is certain for active deposits but uncertain for long-dormant funds from expired receipts.
notes: Full reserve banking claim -- 100% reserve question -- active vs. dormant deposits -- fractional reserve suspicion -- public faith in banking -- Dutch Republic context -- proto-central banking credibility

refashioned: The city guarantees this. The bank is directed by the four reigning burgomasters, who are replaced annually. Each new group of burgomasters inspects the treasure, compares it with the books, takes charge of it under oath, and passes it on with the same solemn ceremony to their successors. In this sober and religious country, oaths are not yet taken lightly. Such a rotation of oversight alone seems sufficient protection against any practices that cannot be openly justified. Through all the political upheavals that faction has caused in Amsterdam's government, the winning party has never accused its predecessors of mismanaging the bank. No accusation could have more devastatingly damaged the disgraced party's reputation and fortune, and if such a charge could have been sustained, we can be sure it would have been made. In 1672, when the French king was at Utrecht, the Bank of Amsterdam met withdrawals so readily that no doubt remained about its faithful observance of its commitments. Some of the coins brought from the vaults appeared to have been scorched by the fire that struck the town hall shortly after the bank was established. Those coins must therefore have been sitting there since that time.
elegant: The city guarantees the bank's integrity. Four annually rotated burgomasters audit the vaults under oath, providing continuous oversight. Through all Amsterdam's political upheavals, no faction has ever accused its predecessors of bank mismanagement -- an accusation too damaging to leave unmade if it could be supported. In the 1672 crisis, the bank paid readily, producing coins scorched by a fire from near its founding -- proof they had lain untouched for decades.
summary: The Bank of Amsterdam's integrity is maintained through annual audits by rotating burgomasters under oath. Its credibility was never challenged even during political upheavals, and the 1672 crisis demonstrated its faithful reserve-keeping when it produced coins visibly stored since the bank's earliest years.
distilled: Annual audits by rotating officials under oath, unchallenged credibility through political upheavals, and the 1672 crisis all testify to the Bank of Amsterdam's honest management.
notes: Governance structure -- annual burgomaster rotation -- oath-based accountability -- political incentives against fraud -- 1672 French crisis as stress test -- scorched coins as proof of long-term storage -- institutional credibility mechanisms

refashioned: The actual amount of treasure in the bank has long been a subject of speculation, and only conjecture is possible. It is generally estimated that about 2,000 people maintain accounts with the bank. If we allow them to hold, on average, about 1,500 pounds sterling each -- a very generous estimate -- the total bank money, and therefore total treasure in the bank, would amount to about 3,000,000 pounds sterling, or roughly 33,000,000 guilders at eleven guilders per pound. This is a considerable sum, sufficient for extensive financial operations, but vastly less than the extravagant figures some people have imagined.
elegant: The bank's treasure can only be estimated. With roughly 2,000 account holders averaging a generous 1,500 pounds sterling each, the total comes to about 3 million pounds sterling (33 million guilders) -- a large sum sufficient for extensive circulation, but far below the extravagant figures popularly imagined.

distilled: The Bank of Amsterdam's treasure is estimated at roughly 3 million pounds sterling -- considerable but far less than the extravagant sums popularly imagined.
notes: Bank of Amsterdam treasure estimate -- ~2,000 account holders -- ~1,500 pounds average -- ~3 million pounds / 33 million guilders total -- popular exaggeration vs. reality -- exchange rate of 11 guilders per pound sterling

refashioned: The city of Amsterdam derives considerable revenue from the bank. Beyond the warehouse rents already mentioned, each person pays a fee of ten guilders to open an initial account and three guilders three stivers for each subsequent account. Each transfer costs two stivers, or six stivers if it is for less than 300 guilders, to discourage excessive small transactions. Anyone who fails to balance their account twice yearly forfeits twenty-five guilders. Anyone who orders a transfer exceeding their balance must pay three percent on the overdraft, and the order is voided. The bank is also believed to profit significantly from selling foreign coins or bullion that fall to it when receipts expire, which it holds until it can sell advantageously. It also profits from selling bank money at five percent agio and buying it back at four percent. These various revenues amount to well more than enough to cover officers' salaries and management expenses. The revenue from bullion storage alone is estimated at 150,000 to 200,000 guilders annually. However, public utility, not revenue, was the bank's original purpose -- to relieve merchants of the burdens caused by unfavorable exchange rates. The revenue was unforeseen and accidental. But it is now time to return from this long digression, into which I was drawn while trying to explain why the exchange rate between countries paying in bank money and those paying in common currency generally appears to favor the former. Countries paying in bank money pay in a currency whose intrinsic value is always the same and exactly matches their mint standard; the others pay in a currency whose intrinsic value is constantly changing and is almost always below standard.
elegant: Amsterdam earns substantial bank revenue: account fees, transfer charges, overdraft penalties, profits from expired deposits, and the 1% spread on bank money (selling at 5% agio, buying at 4%). Bullion storage alone yields 150,000-200,000 guilders annually. Yet revenue was not the original purpose -- the bank was created for public utility, to fix exchange rate problems. To conclude this digression: exchange rates appear to favor bank-money countries because their payments have stable intrinsic value matching the mint standard, while common-currency countries pay in money that fluctuates below standard.
summary: The Bank of Amsterdam generates substantial revenue from fees, penalties, expired deposits, and the agio spread, though public utility was its original purpose. Smith concludes his digression by explaining that exchange rates favor bank-money countries because their payments maintain stable intrinsic value.
distilled: The Bank of Amsterdam generates significant revenue as a byproduct of its public utility purpose, and exchange rates favor bank-money countries because their payments maintain stable intrinsic value.
notes: Bank revenue sources -- account fees, transfer fees, overdraft penalties -- minimum transaction size -- agio spread profit -- expired receipt gains -- 150,000-200,000 guilders annual storage revenue -- public utility as original purpose -- digression conclusion -- bank money stability vs. common currency fluctuation

refashioned:
In the earlier part of this chapter, I tried to show, even on the mercantilist system's own principles, how unnecessary it is to impose extraordinary restrictions on imports from countries with which the trade balance is supposedly unfavorable.

Nothing, however, can be more absurd than this entire doctrine of the balance of trade, upon which not only these restrictions but nearly all other trade regulations are founded. When two places trade with each other, this doctrine assumes that if the balance is even, neither gains nor loses; but if the balance tips to one side, one gains and the other loses in proportion. Both assumptions are false. Trade that is forced through bounties and monopolies may be, and usually is, harmful to the country it is meant to benefit, as I will show later. But trade that is carried on naturally and freely between two places, without force or constraint, is always beneficial to both -- though not always equally so.
elegant: Even on mercantilist principles, extraordinary import restrictions are unnecessary. But the entire balance of trade doctrine is absurd. It falsely assumes that one country's gain is another's loss, and that even trade produces no gains. In reality, forced trade through bounties and monopolies typically harms the favored country, while natural, free trade always benefits both parties -- though not always equally.
summary: Smith declares the entire balance of trade doctrine absurd, rejecting its zero-sum assumptions. He argues that naturally conducted free trade always benefits both parties, while trade forced through bounties and monopolies typically harms the country it was meant to help.
distilled: The balance of trade doctrine is entirely absurd: free trade always benefits both parties, while trade forced through bounties and monopolies typically harms the country it supposedly favors.
notes: Balance of trade doctrine -- complete rejection -- zero-sum fallacy -- mutual gains from trade -- natural vs. forced trade -- bounties and monopolies as harmful -- transition from mercantilist critique to positive free trade argument -- cross-reference to later chapters on bounties

refashioned:
By advantage or gain, I mean not an increase in gold and silver, but an increase in the exchangeable value of a country's annual production of land and labor -- that is, an increase in the annual income of its inhabitants.

If the trade balance is even and the trade consists entirely of exchanging each country's domestic products, both countries will usually gain, and gain roughly equally. Each provides a market for part of the other's surplus production. Each replaces the capital that had been used to produce and prepare that surplus for market -- capital that had been distributed among and provided income and livelihood to a certain number of workers. Some inhabitants of each country therefore derive their income and livelihood directly from the other. Since the goods exchanged are assumed to be of equal value, the two capitals employed in the trade will usually be roughly equal. Both being used to produce domestic goods, the income they distribute to each country's inhabitants will be roughly equal. This mutual income will be greater or smaller in proportion to the volume of trade. If it amounts to 100,000 pounds annually on each side, for example, each country provides an annual income of 100,000 pounds to the inhabitants of the other; if 1,000,000 pounds, then 1,000,000 each.
elegant: Gain from trade means not more gold and silver, but greater exchangeable value of a nation's annual output -- that is, higher real income. When balanced trade involves exchanging domestic products, both countries gain roughly equally: each provides a market for the other's surplus, replacing capital and sustaining employment. The mutual benefit scales with trade volume.
summary: Smith defines trade gains as increases in real national income, not gold accumulation. In balanced trade of domestic products, both countries gain roughly equally as each provides a market that sustains the other's employment and capital.
distilled: Trade gain means increased real national income, not gold accumulation, and balanced trade in domestic goods benefits both countries roughly equally by sustaining each other's employment.
notes: Real vs. nominal trade gains -- exchangeable value of annual produce -- rejection of bullionist definition -- mutual gains from trade -- balanced trade -- capital replacement -- employment effects -- trade volume and proportional benefit -- cross-reference to Book 1 on value

refashioned: If the trade were such that one country exported only domestic goods while the other's returns consisted entirely of foreign goods, the balance would still be considered even -- commodities being paid for with commodities. Both countries would still gain, but not equally. The country exporting only domestic goods would gain more. If England, for example, imported nothing from France but French domestic products, but had no suitable goods of its own to send in return, and instead annually repaid France by sending large quantities of foreign goods -- say, tobacco and East India goods -- this trade would provide income to inhabitants of both countries, but more to the French than the English. The entire French capital employed in this trade would be distributed annually among the people of France. But only the portion of English capital used to produce the English goods that purchased those foreign goods would be distributed among the people of England. The greater part would replace capitals employed in Virginia, India, and China, providing income to the inhabitants of those distant countries. Even with equal capitals, the French capital would generate far more income for the French people than the English capital would for the English. France would be conducting a direct foreign trade of consumption with England, whereas England would be conducting a roundabout trade of the same kind with France. The different effects of direct versus roundabout foreign trade have already been fully explained.
elegant: Even when trade is balanced by value, gains are unequal if one country exports only domestic goods while the other pays in foreign goods. The domestic-goods exporter gains more because its entire capital circulates among its own people, while the other's capital largely replaces investments in distant countries. This is the difference between direct and roundabout foreign trade.
summary: When one country exports domestic products and the other pays with foreign goods, both gain but unequally. The domestic-goods exporter benefits more because its entire trade capital circulates domestically, while the other's capital largely sustains employment in distant countries.
distilled: Countries that export domestic products in trade gain more than those paying with foreign goods, because their entire trade capital circulates domestically rather than replacing distant investments.
notes: Direct vs. roundabout foreign trade -- unequal gains from balanced trade -- domestic vs. foreign goods in export composition -- England-France-Virginia-India-China trade chain -- capital circulation and domestic employment -- cross-reference to earlier explanation of roundabout trade

refashioned: In reality, no trade between two countries consists entirely of domestic goods on both sides, or of domestic goods on one side and foreign goods on the other. Almost all countries trade a mixture of both. The country whose shipments contain the highest proportion of domestic goods and the lowest of foreign goods will always be the principal beneficiary.
elegant: In practice, all trade involves a mix of domestic and foreign goods. The country exporting a higher proportion of domestic goods always gains more from the exchange.
summary: Real trade always involves a mixture of domestic and foreign goods, and the country with the higher proportion of domestic goods in its exports always gains the most.
distilled: The country exporting the highest proportion of domestic goods relative to foreign goods always gains the most from bilateral trade.
notes: Domestic vs. foreign goods composition in exports -- practical vs. theoretical trade -- principal gainer in trade -- application of direct vs. roundabout trade principle

refashioned: If England paid for its French imports not with tobacco and East India goods but with gold and silver, the balance would be considered uneven -- since commodities would not be exchanged for commodities, but for precious metals. The trade would nonetheless provide income to inhabitants of both countries, though more to the French than the English. It would still provide some income to the English. The capital used to produce the English goods that originally purchased the gold and silver -- the capital distributed among certain English workers, providing their income -- would be replaced and would continue to fund that employment.
elegant: Even if England paid France in gold and silver rather than goods, both countries would still gain -- though France would gain more. English capital used to produce the goods that originally earned the gold and silver would still be replaced, maintaining English employment and income.
summary: Smith argues that even paying for imports with gold and silver rather than goods still benefits both trading partners, since the capital used to earn those metals continues to sustain domestic employment.
distilled: Paying for imports with gold and silver still benefits both countries because the capital that originally earned those metals continues to sustain domestic employment.
notes: Gold and silver as trade payment -- commodities vs. precious metals in exchange -- continued capital replacement -- employment maintenance despite gold outflow -- critique of bullionist balance of trade concern

refashioned: England's total capital would no more be diminished by exporting gold and silver than by exporting an equal value of any other goods. On the contrary, it would usually be increased. No goods are sent abroad unless demand for them is expected to be greater abroad than at home, and the returns are expected to be worth more domestically than the goods exported. If tobacco worth 100,000 pounds in England will purchase wine worth 110,000 pounds in England when sent to France, the exchange increases England's capital by 10,000 pounds.
elegant: Exporting gold and silver no more diminishes national capital than exporting any other goods -- it typically increases it. Goods are exported only when returns exceed the domestic value of what was sent. If 100,000 pounds of tobacco buys 110,000 pounds of French wine in England, capital grows by 10,000 pounds.
summary: Smith argues that exporting gold and silver does not diminish national capital any more than exporting other goods, since trade is only conducted when returns exceed the value of what was exported.
distilled: Exporting gold and silver does not diminish national capital because trade only occurs when expected returns exceed the domestic value of what is exported.
notes: Gold export does not diminish capital -- trade surplus through exchange -- comparative value of goods at home vs. abroad -- 100,000/110,000 tobacco-wine example -- refutation of bullionist fears

refashioned: If 100,000 pounds of English gold purchases French wine worth 110,000 pounds in England, this exchange equally increases England's capital by 10,000 pounds. A merchant with 110,000 pounds worth of wine in his cellar is richer than one with only 100,000 pounds worth of tobacco in his warehouse, and he is equally richer than one with only 100,000 pounds worth of gold in his coffers. He can set in motion a greater quantity of industry, and provide income, sustenance, and employment to a greater number of people than either of the other two.
elegant: If 100,000 pounds in English gold buys French wine worth 110,000 pounds, capital increases by 10,000 pounds -- just as with tobacco. A merchant with 110,000 pounds of wine is richer than one with 100,000 in tobacco or gold, commanding more industry and employing more people.
summary: Gold exported for goods of greater value increases national capital just as any other profitable trade does. The measure of wealth is not the metal held but the ability to command industry and employment.
distilled: A merchant with 110,000 pounds of wine is wealthier than one with 100,000 pounds of gold, because real wealth is the ability to command industry and employment.
notes: Gold vs. wine vs. tobacco as wealth -- real wealth = command over industry and labor -- gold as just another commodity -- capital increase through profitable exchange -- rejection of gold hoarding as wealth

refashioned: A country's total capital equals the combined capital of all its inhabitants, and the total industry it can maintain annually equals what all those capitals can support. Both the country's capital and its annual industry must therefore generally be increased by this kind of profitable exchange. It would, of course, be even more advantageous for England to purchase French wines directly with its own hardware and broadcloth, rather than with Virginia tobacco or Brazilian and Peruvian gold and silver. A direct foreign trade of consumption is always more advantageous than a roundabout one.
elegant: Since national capital is the sum of individual capitals, profitable exchange increases the whole. Direct trade -- selling English manufactures for French wine -- is more advantageous than roundabout trade through colonial goods or gold, but both increase national wealth.
summary: National capital grows through profitable trade regardless of what is exported, though direct trade in domestic manufactures is always preferable to roundabout trade through colonial products or precious metals.
distilled: Profitable trade always increases national capital, though direct exchange of domestic manufactures is more advantageous than roundabout trade through colonial goods or gold.
notes: National capital as sum of individual capitals -- direct vs. roundabout trade preference -- English hardware and broadcloth -- Virginia tobacco, Brazilian/Peruvian gold -- hierarchy of trade advantages -- cross-reference to earlier discussion of direct vs. roundabout trade

refashioned: A roundabout foreign trade conducted with gold and silver is no less advantageous than any other equally roundabout trade. Nor is a country without mines more likely to be exhausted of gold and silver by annual exports of those metals than a country that does not grow tobacco is likely to be exhausted of that plant by its annual export. Just as a country that can afford to buy tobacco will never long be without it, neither will a country that can afford to buy gold and silver ever long lack those metals.
elegant: Roundabout trade using gold and silver is no worse than any other roundabout trade. A country without mines will no more run out of precious metals from exporting them than a non-tobacco-growing country will run out of tobacco. Whatever a country can afford to buy, it will not long lack.
summary: Smith argues that exporting gold and silver is no more likely to exhaust a country of those metals than exporting tobacco would exhaust a non-growing country of tobacco -- whatever can be purchased will be available.
distilled: A country will no more run out of gold and silver from exporting them than it will run out of any other commodity it can afford to purchase.
notes: Gold and silver as ordinary commodities -- self-regulating supply through purchasing power -- no risk of exhaustion -- equivalence of roundabout trades -- refutation of bullionist anxiety about precious metal drainage

refashioned: It is said that the trade a workman carries on with the alehouse is a losing one, and that trade between a manufacturing nation and a wine-producing country is essentially the same. I respond that trade with the alehouse is not inherently a losing proposition. By its nature, it is just as beneficial as any other trade, though perhaps somewhat more liable to abuse. The professions of brewer and even liquor retailer are as necessary a division of labor as any other. A workman will generally find it more advantageous to buy his drink from a brewer than to brew it himself, and a poor workman will find it more practical to buy in small quantities from a retailer than in bulk from a brewer. He may certainly buy too much from either -- but he could also buy too much from the butcher if he is a glutton, or from the clothier if he fancies himself a gentleman among his peers.
elegant: The argument that trade with wine countries resembles a workman's losing trade with the alehouse is wrong. Alehouse trade is inherently as useful as any other -- brewing and retailing are legitimate divisions of labor. A workman benefits from buying rather than brewing. He may overconsume, but he can overconsume anything -- meat from the butcher, clothes from the draper.
summary: Smith rejects the analogy between a manufacturing nation trading with a wine country and a workman losing money at the alehouse. The trades of brewing and retailing are legitimate divisions of labor, and the possibility of overconsumption applies to all goods, not just alcohol.
distilled: Trade with wine countries is no more inherently wasteful than any other trade -- the possibility of overconsumption exists for all goods, not just alcohol.
notes: Alehouse analogy refuted -- brewing and retailing as division of labor -- overconsumption as universal risk -- wine trade defense -- butcher-draper comparison -- individual choice in consumption -- freedom of trade argument

refashioned: It benefits the working population as a whole that all these trades remain free, even though this freedom may be abused in all of them, and perhaps more so in some than others. Although individual people may ruin themselves through excessive consumption of alcohol, there is no real risk that an entire nation will do so. In every country, while many spend more on drink than they can afford, there are always many more who spend less. It is also worth noting that experience suggests the cheapness of wine promotes not drunkenness but sobriety.
elegant: Freedom in all trades benefits workers, even though some individuals will abuse it. While some people overconsume alcohol, more people underconsume. And experience shows that cheap wine promotes sobriety, not drunkenness.
summary: Smith argues that free trade in alcohol benefits the population overall despite individual abuse, and observes that experience shows cheap wine promotes sobriety rather than drunkenness.
distilled: Free trade in alcohol benefits society overall, and experience shows that cheap wine promotes sobriety rather than drunkenness.
notes: Freedom of trade despite abuse potential -- individual vs. national risk -- cheap wine and sobriety -- empirical observation on alcohol pricing and consumption -- paternalism critique

refashioned: The inhabitants of wine-producing countries are generally the most sober people in Europe. Consider the Spanish, the Italians, and the people of southern France. People rarely overindulge in what they consume every day. Nobody tries to appear generous and convivial by being lavish with a drink as cheap as small beer. On the other hand, in countries that produce no grapes due to excessive heat or cold, where wine is consequently expensive and rare, drunkenness is a common vice -- as among the northern nations and all those living between the tropics, such as the people on the coast of Guinea.
elegant: Wine-country inhabitants -- Spaniards, Italians, southern French -- are Europe's most sober people. Nobody flaunts generosity with a drink as cheap as small beer. Where wine is rare and expensive -- in northern countries and tropical regions -- drunkenness is common.
summary: Smith observes that wine-producing countries like Spain, Italy, and southern France have the most sober populations, while drunkenness is common in countries where wine is scarce and expensive.
distilled: Wine-producing countries are the most sober in Europe because people do not overindulge in what is cheaply and commonly available.
notes: Empirical evidence on wine and sobriety -- Spain, Italy, southern France as examples -- scarcity increases excess -- northern nations and tropical regions -- price and consumption behavior -- cultural attitudes toward cheap vs. expensive drink

refashioned: When a French regiment transfers from the northern provinces, where wine is somewhat expensive, to be stationed in the south, where it is very cheap, the soldiers are at first led into excess by the cheapness and novelty of good wine. But after a few months, most of them become as sober as the local inhabitants. If the duties on foreign wines and the excise taxes on malt, beer, and ale were all removed at once, something similar might happen in Britain: a fairly widespread and temporary bout of drunkenness among the middle and lower classes, which would probably be followed soon by a permanent and nearly universal sobriety. Currently, drunkenness is by no means a vice of fashionable people or those who can easily afford the most expensive drinks. A gentleman drunk on ale has almost never been seen among us.
elegant: French soldiers stationed in the cheap-wine south are initially debauched but soon become as sober as locals. Removing all British alcohol duties might similarly cause brief widespread drunkenness, soon followed by permanent sobriety. Drunkenness is already no vice of the wealthy. A gentleman drunk on ale is virtually unheard of.
summary: Smith uses the example of French soldiers adapting to cheap southern wine to argue that removing British alcohol duties would cause only temporary excess, quickly followed by lasting sobriety -- just as drunkenness is already absent among the wealthy who can afford any drink.
distilled: Removing alcohol duties would cause only temporary excess before permanent sobriety, just as French soldiers quickly adapt to cheap southern wine.
notes: French regiment anecdote -- adaptation to cheap alcohol -- prediction of British sobriety with duty removal -- class and drinking habits -- drunkenness as vice of scarcity not abundance -- policy implication for wine duties

refashioned: Britain's restrictions on the wine trade seem designed not so much to keep people from drinking as to prevent them from buying the best and cheapest wine. They favor the wine trade of Portugal and discourage that of France. The Portuguese, we are told, are better customers for our manufactures than the French, and should therefore be preferred. Since they give us their business, we supposedly owe them ours. The petty tactics of small shopkeepers are thus elevated into governing maxims for a great empire. It is only the most small-minded tradesmen who make it a rule to deal mainly with their own customers. A great trader always buys his goods where they are cheapest and best, regardless of such minor considerations.
elegant: Britain's wine restrictions do not discourage drinking -- they discourage buying the best and cheapest wine. They favor Portugal over France because the Portuguese supposedly buy more British manufactures. This is shopkeeper logic elevated to imperial policy. A great trader buys where goods are cheapest and best, regardless of who his customers are.
summary: Smith criticizes British wine restrictions for favoring Portuguese over French wine based on reciprocal purchasing logic -- the small-minded tactics of petty shopkeepers elevated to national policy. A great trader buys where goods are best and cheapest.
distilled: Favoring Portuguese wine over cheaper French wine because Portugal buys British goods is shopkeeper logic unworthy of a great trading nation.
notes: British wine policy -- Portuguese preference over French -- Methuen Treaty context -- reciprocal purchasing fallacy -- shopkeeper mentality vs. great trader mentality -- critique of mercantilist trade partner favoritism

refashioned: Through such thinking, nations have been taught that their prosperity consists in impoverishing all their neighbors. Each nation has learned to view the prosperity of its trading partners with jealousy and to regard their gain as its own loss. Commerce, which ought naturally to be a bond of friendship among nations as among individuals, has become the most prolific source of conflict and hostility. The reckless ambition of kings and ministers has not, in this and the preceding century, been more destructive to Europe's peace than the petty jealousy of merchants and manufacturers. The violence and injustice of rulers is an ancient evil that the nature of human affairs can probably never fully remedy. But the grasping, monopolizing spirit of merchants and manufacturers -- who neither are, nor should be, the rulers of mankind -- though it may not be curable, can quite easily be prevented from disturbing anyone's peace but their own.
elegant: Nations have been taught that their interest lies in impoverishing neighbors, turning commerce from a natural bond of friendship into the greatest source of conflict. Merchant jealousy has been as destructive to European peace as royal ambition. While the violence of rulers is an ancient, perhaps incurable evil, the monopolizing spirit of merchants can easily be prevented from disturbing anyone but themselves.
summary: Smith argues that mercantilist thinking has perverted commerce from a bond of friendship into a source of national hostility. While the violence of rulers may be incurable, the destructive jealousy of merchants and manufacturers can be restrained from harming the public.
distilled: Mercantilist thinking has transformed commerce from a natural bond of friendship into the greatest source of conflict between nations.
notes: Commerce as bond of friendship vs. source of conflict -- zero-sum mentality critique -- merchant jealousy vs. royal ambition -- monopolizing spirit -- who should rule -- restraining merchant influence on policy -- one of Smith's most powerful rhetorical passages

refashioned: That the spirit of monopoly both invented and promoted this doctrine is beyond doubt, and those who first taught it were not nearly as foolish as those who believed it. In every country, it always is and must be in the interest of the general public to buy what they need from whoever sells it cheapest. This principle is so obvious it seems absurd to prove, and it would never have been questioned had the self-serving sophistries of merchants and manufacturers not confused public common sense. Their interest runs directly contrary to that of the general public. Just as members of a guild benefit from preventing outsiders from practicing their trade, merchants and manufacturers benefit from securing a monopoly of the home market. Hence Britain and most other European countries impose extraordinary duties on nearly all goods imported by foreign merchants. Hence the high duties and outright bans on foreign manufactures that might compete with domestic ones. Hence too the extraordinary restrictions on imports from countries with which the trade balance is supposedly unfavorable -- that is, countries against which national hostility happens to be most intense.
elegant: The monopoly spirit invented this doctrine, and its teachers were shrewder than its believers. It is always in the public interest to buy from the cheapest seller -- a proposition so obvious it needs no proof, except that merchant sophistry has confused common sense. Merchants' interests directly oppose the public's: they seek home-market monopoly through import duties on foreign merchants, bans on competing manufactures, and restrictions on trade with countries targeted by national hostility.
summary: Smith argues the balance of trade doctrine was invented by monopolists whose interests directly oppose the public's. The obvious truth -- that people should buy from the cheapest seller -- has been obscured by merchant sophistries that produced import duties, manufacturing bans, and trade restrictions driven by national animosity.
distilled: The balance of trade doctrine was invented by monopolists to confuse the obvious truth that the public benefits from buying at the lowest price.
notes: Spirit of monopoly as origin of balance of trade doctrine -- merchant self-interest vs. public interest -- guild analogy -- import duties on alien merchants -- protection of domestic manufactures -- national animosity and trade restrictions -- common sense obscured by interested sophistries

refashioned: The wealth of neighboring nations, though dangerous in war and politics, is certainly advantageous in trade. In wartime, wealthy neighbors can maintain larger fleets and armies than our own. But in peacetime and commerce, their wealth enables them to trade with us at greater value and provide a better market for our products or for whatever we purchase with them. Just as a rich person is likely to be a better customer for the industrious people in his neighborhood than a poor one, so too is a rich nation. A rich person who is himself a manufacturer is indeed a very dangerous rival to all those in the same line of business. But the rest of his neighbors -- the vast majority -- benefit from the large market his spending creates. They even benefit from his ability to undersell the poorer producers in the same trade.
elegant: Neighboring wealth is dangerous in war but advantageous in trade. A rich neighbor provides a larger market and better customers, just as a wealthy individual does for local businesses. A rich manufacturer may threaten rivals in his own trade, but the vast majority of neighbors benefit from his spending and even from his competitive pressure on weaker producers.
summary: Smith argues that wealthy neighbors, while potentially dangerous in war, are beneficial in trade by providing better markets and greater demand. Most people benefit from a wealthy neighbor's spending, even though specific competitors may be threatened.
distilled: The wealth of neighboring nations is dangerous in war but advantageous in trade, providing larger markets that benefit the vast majority of producers.
notes: Wealth of neighbors as trade advantage -- war vs. peace distinction -- rich man analogy -- competitive threat to specific rivals vs. broad benefit to community -- market size and spending power -- beggar-thy-neighbor critique

refashioned: The manufacturers of a wealthy nation may certainly be formidable rivals to those in neighboring countries. But this competition itself benefits the general population, who also profit greatly from the extensive market that the wealthy nation's spending creates in every other respect. People seeking to make their fortune never retire to remote, poor provinces but head to the capital or to major commercial cities. They understand that where little wealth circulates, there is little to be gained, but where a great deal is in motion, some share of it may come their way.
elegant: Competition from a wealthy nation's manufacturers threatens specific rivals but benefits the general public through extensive markets. Just as fortune-seekers head to capitals and commercial cities rather than poor provinces, nations prosper most near wealthy neighbors where more wealth circulates.
summary: Though manufacturers may face tough competition from wealthy neighbors, the public benefits from the large markets such wealth creates. Just as individuals seek fortune where wealth concentrates, nations prosper most when surrounded by wealthy trading partners.
distilled: People and nations alike prosper more when surrounded by wealth, because where more capital circulates, more opportunities arise for everyone.
notes: Competition benefits the public -- fortune-seekers go to wealthy places -- capital city vs. remote province analogy -- wealth concentration and opportunity -- benefits of proximity to prosperous trading partners

refashioned: The same common sense that would guide one person, or ten, or twenty, should equally guide one million, ten million, or twenty million, and should lead every nation to view the wealth of its neighbors as a likely means and occasion for acquiring wealth itself. A nation seeking to enrich itself through foreign trade is most likely to succeed when its neighbors are all wealthy, industrious, and commercially active. A great nation surrounded entirely by poor, wandering peoples might acquire wealth by cultivating its own land and developing its internal commerce, but not through foreign trade. It seems to have been in this manner that the ancient Egyptians and the modern Chinese acquired their great wealth.
elegant: What is common sense for an individual should guide nations: view neighbors' wealth as an opportunity, not a threat. A nation surrounded by wealthy, commercial neighbors has the best prospects for enrichment through trade. One surrounded by poor peoples can grow through domestic development alone, as ancient Egypt and modern China did, but not through foreign commerce.
summary: Smith argues that nations should apply individual common sense at the national level: wealthy neighbors create opportunities for mutual enrichment through trade, while nations surrounded by poor peoples must rely on internal development, as Egypt and China did.
distilled: Nations seeking wealth through foreign trade prosper most when surrounded by wealthy, industrious neighbors -- just as individuals prosper most in wealthy communities.
notes: Individual-to-national reasoning -- wealthy neighbors as opportunities -- foreign trade requires prosperous partners -- Egypt and China as self-development examples -- internal vs. external sources of growth -- common sense applied to national policy

refashioned: The ancient Egyptians, it is said, neglected foreign trade, and the modern Chinese are known to hold it in the utmost contempt, barely deigning to give it the protection of law. The modern doctrines of foreign trade, by aiming to impoverish all neighbors, tend to make foreign trade itself insignificant and contemptible -- producing exactly the result they should be trying to prevent.
elegant: Ancient Egypt neglected foreign trade; modern China holds it in contempt. Modern mercantilist doctrines, by aiming to impoverish neighbors, tend to render the very foreign trade they champion insignificant and contemptible.
summary: Smith notes the irony that mercantilist policies aimed at impoverishing neighbors make foreign trade itself insignificant -- exactly what they should be trying to prevent, paralleling the trade indifference of Egypt and China.
distilled: By aiming to impoverish trading partners, mercantilist policies undermine the very foreign trade they claim to promote.
notes: Self-defeating nature of mercantilism -- Egypt and China analogies -- impoverishing neighbors reduces trade opportunity -- ironic outcome of beggar-thy-neighbor policies -- contempt for trade as consequence of trade restrictions

refashioned: It is because of these doctrines that trade between France and England has been loaded with so many restrictions in both countries. Yet if both nations considered their real interests, free of commercial jealousy and national hostility, French trade might be more valuable to Britain than that of any other country, and British trade equally valuable to France. France is Britain's nearest neighbor. Trade between the southern coast of England and the northern and northwestern coast of France could allow capital to turn over four, five, or six times a year, just as in domestic trade.
elegant: Mercantilist doctrines have burdened Franco-British trade with heavy restrictions. Yet France and Britain, as nearest neighbors, could be each other's most valuable trading partners. Capital employed in cross-Channel trade could turn over four to six times a year -- matching the frequency of domestic trade.
summary: Smith argues that France and Britain, as nearest neighbors, could be each other's most valuable trading partners if freed from mercantilist restrictions, with capital turning over as rapidly as in domestic trade.
distilled: France and Britain, as nearest neighbors, could be each other's most valuable trading partners with capital turning over four to six times annually.
notes: France as Britain's most natural trading partner -- proximity advantage -- capital turnover frequency -- cross-Channel trade potential -- comparison to domestic trade -- mercantilist restrictions as obstacle to mutual benefit

refashioned: The capital employed in this cross-Channel trade could therefore keep in motion four, five, or six times the quantity of industry and support four, five, or six times the number of workers that the same capital could in most other branches of foreign trade. Even between the most distant parts of France and Britain, returns could be expected at least once a year, making this trade at least as advantageous as most other European trade. It would be at least three times more advantageous than the much-celebrated trade with the North American colonies, where returns seldom came in less than three years and frequently not for four or five. France, moreover, was estimated to have 24 million inhabitants compared to the colonies' 3 million at most. France is also a much richer country than North America, though its more unequal distribution of wealth means more poverty alongside the riches. France could therefore offer a market at least eight times larger, and -- accounting for the higher frequency of returns -- twenty-four times more profitable than the North American colonies ever did.
elegant: Cross-Channel capital could support 4-6 times the industry of most foreign trade. Even between the most distant parts of France and Britain, annual returns make it at least as good as most European trade and three times better than North American colonial trade (which took 3-5 years per return). With 24 million people versus the colonies' 3 million, and far more wealth despite greater inequality, France offered a market 8 times larger and 24 times more profitable than the colonies.
summary: Smith calculates that free trade with France would be enormously more profitable than the celebrated colonial trade, offering a market eight times larger with capital turning over far more frequently, making it potentially twenty-four times more advantageous overall.
distilled: Free trade with France would have been twenty-four times more profitable than colonial trade, combining an eight-times-larger market with far more frequent capital returns.
notes: Capital turnover and trade profitability -- France (24 million) vs. North American colonies (3 million) -- market size comparison -- return frequency: annual vs. 3-5 years -- 24x advantage calculation -- inequality and poverty in France -- critique of colonial trade preference
