refashioned: British trade would be just as beneficial to France, and in proportion to each country's wealth, population, and proximity, would hold the same superiority over France's trade with its own colonies. Such is the enormous difference between the trade that both nations' wisdom has chosen to discourage and the trade they have chosen to promote the most.
elegant: British trade would benefit France equally, outperforming France's colonial trade in the same proportions. The irony is stark: both nations actively discourage their most naturally advantageous trade while promoting far inferior alternatives.
summary: Smith emphasizes that both France and Britain would benefit equally from free cross-Channel trade, which would far outperform the colonial trades both nations perversely favor instead.
distilled: Both nations actively discourage their most naturally profitable trade with each other while promoting far less advantageous colonial commerce.
notes: Reciprocal benefit of Anglo-French trade -- colonial trade inferiority -- mutual policy failure -- irony of trade policy -- symmetry of argument for both nations

refashioned: The very circumstances that would have made open trade between the two countries so advantageous have also created the principal obstacles to it. Being neighbors, they are necessarily rivals, and each nation's wealth and power makes it more threatening to the other. What should increase the benefits of national friendship instead inflames national hostility. Both are rich and industrious, and the merchants and manufacturers of each fear the competition of the other's skill and energy. Commercial jealousy is aroused and fuels national hostility, while national hostility fuels commercial jealousy in return. The merchants of both countries have proclaimed, with all the passionate conviction of self-interested deception, that each nation faces certain ruin from the unfavorable trade balance they claim would result from unrestricted commerce with the other.
elegant: The same proximity and prosperity that make free Anglo-French trade so valuable also create the obstacles to it. Being rich neighbors, each threatens the other. Commercial jealousy and national hostility feed each other in a vicious cycle, while merchants on both sides proclaim -- with the passionate conviction of self-interested falsehood -- that free trade would bring certain ruin.
summary: Smith identifies a tragic irony: the proximity and prosperity that make Anglo-French trade so valuable also produce the jealousy and hostility that obstruct it, with merchants on both sides cynically stoking fears of ruin from free trade.
distilled: The very proximity and prosperity that make Anglo-French trade so valuable also produce the commercial jealousy and national hostility that prevent it.
notes: Proximity as both advantage and obstacle -- vicious cycle of commercial jealousy and national hostility -- merchants as propagandists of protectionism -- interested falsehood -- tragic irony of trade policy -- self-reinforcing animosity

refashioned: There is no commercial country in Europe whose approaching ruin has not been frequently predicted by the advocates of this system, based on some unfavorable trade balance. Despite all the anxiety they have generated, and despite every nation's futile attempts to tip the balance in its own favor and against its neighbors, not a single European nation appears to have been impoverished by this cause. On the contrary, every town and country that has opened its ports to all nations has been enriched by free trade, not ruined as the mercantilist system would predict. While there are a few European towns that in some respects deserve to be called free ports, no country has fully achieved this status. Holland comes closest, though it is still far from it, and Holland is acknowledged to derive not only its entire wealth but much of its basic sustenance from foreign trade.
elegant: Every commercial nation in Europe has been warned of approaching ruin from unfavorable trade balances. None has been impoverished by this cause. Every town and country that has opened its ports has been enriched, not ruined. Holland, the most open though still far from truly free, derives its entire wealth and much of its sustenance from foreign trade.
summary: Smith observes that despite constant predictions of ruin from unfavorable trade balances, no European nation has been impoverished by free trade. Every place that opened its ports has prospered, with Holland -- the most open -- deriving its entire wealth from foreign commerce.
distilled: Despite constant predictions of ruin from trade deficits, every European town and country that has opened its ports has prospered, not declined.
notes: Empirical refutation of balance of trade fears -- no nation impoverished by free trade -- Holland as most open economy -- free ports -- prosperity from openness -- predictions of ruin never materialized -- inductive argument against mercantilism

refashioned: There is another balance, very different from the balance of trade, which has already been discussed and which actually determines whether a nation prospers or declines. This is the balance between annual production and annual consumption. If the exchangeable value of what a society produces annually exceeds what it consumes, the nation's capital must grow in proportion to the excess. The society in this case lives within its income, and what it saves is naturally added to its capital and employed to increase production further. If, on the other hand, the value of annual production falls short of annual consumption, the nation's capital must shrink by that shortfall. Its spending exceeds its income and necessarily eats into its capital. Capital therefore decays, and with it the exchangeable value of the nation's annual output.
elegant: The balance that truly matters is not the balance of trade but the balance between annual production and consumption. When production exceeds consumption, savings increase capital and future output. When consumption exceeds production, capital decays and output shrinks. This is the real determinant of national prosperity or decline.
summary: Smith contrasts the meaningless balance of trade with the genuinely important balance between production and consumption. National prosperity depends on whether a society produces more than it consumes, accumulating capital, or consumes more than it produces, eroding it.
distilled: National prosperity depends on the balance between production and consumption, not the balance of trade -- savings grow capital while excess consumption erodes it.
notes: Balance of produce and consumption vs. balance of trade -- the real measure of national prosperity -- savings and capital accumulation -- spending exceeding income -- capital decay -- fundamental critique of mercantilist accounting -- cross-reference to earlier discussion

refashioned: This balance of production and consumption is entirely distinct from the so-called balance of trade. It could exist in a nation with no foreign trade at all, completely isolated from the rest of the world. It could apply to the entire globe, whose wealth, population, and development may be either gradually increasing or gradually declining.
elegant: The balance of production and consumption is entirely distinct from the balance of trade. It applies even to a completely isolated nation or to the whole globe -- wherever wealth and population are either growing or declining.
summary: The balance between production and consumption is fundamentally different from the balance of trade, operating even in isolated economies or at a global level.
distilled: The balance of production and consumption operates independently of foreign trade and applies universally, from isolated nations to the entire globe.
notes: Production-consumption balance as universal principle -- independence from foreign trade -- global application -- closed economy applicability -- fundamental vs. superficial economic measures

refashioned: A nation's balance of production and consumption may be consistently favorable even when its so-called balance of trade is persistently unfavorable. A nation may import more than it exports for half a century. All the gold and silver flowing in during that time may immediately flow out again. Its circulating coin may gradually deteriorate, replaced by various forms of paper money, and its debts to the principal nations it trades with may steadily increase. Yet its real wealth -- the exchangeable value of its land and labor's annual output -- may during the same period increase by an even greater proportion. The situation of the North American colonies and their trade with Britain before the current disturbances (this paragraph was written in 1775) may serve as proof that this is by no means an impossible scenario.
elegant: A nation can run persistent trade deficits for decades -- losing gold, replacing coin with paper, accumulating foreign debt -- while its real wealth (the exchangeable value of annual output) grows even faster. The North American colonies before 1775 proved this was not merely hypothetical.
summary: Smith demonstrates that persistent trade deficits are compatible with growing real wealth, citing the North American colonies which ran chronic deficits with Britain while their real prosperity increased rapidly -- proving the balance of trade is irrelevant to genuine prosperity.
distilled: The North American colonies proved that a nation can run persistent trade deficits while its real wealth grows rapidly, making the balance of trade irrelevant to genuine prosperity.
notes: Trade deficit compatible with prosperity -- North American colonies as proof -- written in 1775 -- paper money replacing coin -- growing foreign debt alongside growing wealth -- balance of produce and consumption as true indicator -- definitive empirical refutation of balance of trade doctrine

refashioned:
Merchants and manufacturers are not satisfied with monopolizing the home market; they also want the most extensive foreign sales for their goods. Since their country has no authority in foreign nations and can rarely secure monopolies there, they must generally settle for petitioning the government for export incentives.

Of these incentives, drawbacks seem the most reasonable. Allowing a merchant to reclaim upon export all or part of the excise or internal duties imposed on domestic goods can never cause a greater volume of exports than would have occurred without the duty in the first place. Such measures do not direct any more of the country's capital toward a particular industry than would go there naturally; they simply prevent the duty from diverting capital elsewhere. They do not overturn the natural balance that establishes itself among the society's various industries; they merely prevent the duty from overturning it. They do not destroy but rather preserve what is usually advantageous to preserve: the natural division and distribution of labor in society.
elegant: Merchants want foreign market advantages too. Of the available export incentives, drawbacks are the most reasonable. Refunding domestic duties on export merely prevents those duties from distorting the natural allocation of capital and labor. Drawbacks do not force capital into particular industries but simply prevent duties from driving it away -- preserving rather than overturning the natural balance of employment.
summary: Smith identifies drawbacks -- refunds of domestic duties upon export -- as the most reasonable form of export encouragement because they merely prevent duties from distorting the natural allocation of capital and labor rather than artificially redirecting it.
distilled: Drawbacks are the most reasonable export incentive because they merely prevent domestic duties from distorting the natural allocation of capital, without artificially redirecting it.
notes: Drawbacks defined -- refund of domestic duties on export -- preservation of natural balance -- contrast with bounties and monopolies -- does not distort capital allocation -- most reasonable mercantilist tool -- Chapter 4.4 introduction (Of Drawbacks)

refashioned: The same reasoning applies to drawbacks on the re-export of imported foreign goods, which in Britain generally refund the bulk of the import duty. Under the Old Subsidy act, every merchant -- whether English or foreign -- could reclaim half the duty upon re-export: English merchants within twelve months, foreign merchants within nine. Wines, currants, and wrought silks were the only exceptions, having their own more favorable allowances. The duties under this act were at that time the only import duties. The deadline for claiming these and all other drawbacks was later extended to three years by a 1721 statute.
elegant: The same logic applies to drawbacks on re-exported imports, which in Britain typically refund most of the import duty. The Old Subsidy allowed half-duty reclaims within 12 months for English merchants and 9 for foreigners, later extended to 3 years. Wines, currants, and silks had special provisions.
summary: Smith notes that drawback principles apply equally to re-exported foreign goods, describing Britain's Old Subsidy system which allowed merchants to reclaim half the import duty within specified deadlines, later extended to three years.
distilled: Drawbacks on re-exported imports, typically refunding most of the duty, follow the same logic as drawbacks on domestic goods and facilitate Britain's carrying trade.
notes: Drawbacks on re-exports -- Old Subsidy act -- half-duty reclaim -- 12-month/9-month deadlines -- 1721 extension to 3 years -- wines, currants, wrought silks as exceptions -- carrying trade facilitation

refashioned:
The duties imposed after the Old Subsidy are, for the most part, fully refundable upon export. This general rule, however, has many exceptions, and the drawback system has become much more complicated than it was originally.

For some imported foreign goods expected to far exceed domestic consumption needs, all duties are refunded upon re-export, without even retaining the half of the Old Subsidy. Before the revolt of the North American colonies, Britain monopolized the tobacco trade of Maryland and Virginia. We imported about 96,000 hogsheads, while domestic consumption was estimated at only 14,000. To facilitate the massive re-export needed to dispose of the rest, all duties were refunded provided re-export occurred within three years.
elegant: Post-Old Subsidy duties are mostly fully refundable on export, though exceptions abound. Where imports vastly exceed domestic needs, full drawbacks apply. Before the American revolt, Britain imported 96,000 hogsheads of tobacco but consumed only 14,000, so full duty refunds on re-export within three years facilitated the massive surplus trade.
summary: Smith describes how drawback rules evolved to become more complex, with full duty refunds granted for goods like tobacco where imports vastly exceeded domestic consumption, facilitating Britain's role as a re-export hub.
distilled: Full drawbacks on goods like tobacco -- where Britain imported 96,000 hogsheads but consumed only 14,000 -- facilitated the massive re-export trade.
notes: Post-Old Subsidy drawbacks -- increasing complexity -- full refund on surplus imports -- tobacco monopoly from Maryland and Virginia -- 96,000 imported vs. 14,000 consumed -- three-year re-export window -- carrying trade support

refashioned: Britain still holds, though not exclusively, a near-monopoly on sugar from the West Indian islands. If sugars are re-exported within a year, all import duties are refunded; within three years, all except half the Old Subsidy, which continues to be retained on most re-exported goods. Although sugar imports considerably exceed domestic consumption, the surplus is modest compared to what it used to be for tobacco.
elegant: Britain's near-monopoly on West Indian sugar allows full duty drawbacks on re-export within one year, or all but half the Old Subsidy within three years. The sugar surplus is significant but much smaller than tobacco's was.
summary: Britain's sugar drawback system allows full duty refunds on re-export within one year, though the sugar surplus for re-export is much smaller than tobacco's was.
distilled: Britain's sugar drawback system refunds most duties on re-export within specified timeframes, though the surplus available for re-export is smaller than for tobacco.
notes: West Indian sugar near-monopoly -- drawback terms: 1 year full, 3 years minus half Old Subsidy -- sugar surplus vs. tobacco surplus -- continuing retention of half Old Subsidy -- colonial trade system

refashioned: Certain goods that domestic manufacturers particularly fear as competitors are banned from import for domestic consumption. They may, however, be imported and warehoused for re-export upon paying certain duties -- but no part of these duties is refunded when they are re-exported. Our manufacturers seem unwilling to allow even this limited importation, fearing that some of these goods might be smuggled out of warehouses to compete with their own products. Under these restrictions, we can import wrought silks, French cambrics and lawns, and painted, printed, stained, or dyed calicoes, among other items.
elegant: Goods that threaten domestic manufacturers are banned from home consumption but may be imported and warehoused for re-export -- with no duty refund. Manufacturers fear even this, worried goods will be smuggled from warehouses. This applies to wrought silks, French cambrics, and printed calicoes.
summary: Some goods banned from domestic consumption may be warehoused for re-export but receive no drawback, reflecting manufacturers' fear that even warehoused goods might be smuggled into competition with domestic products.
distilled: Goods banned from domestic sale may be warehoused for re-export without drawbacks, reflecting manufacturers' extreme fear of foreign competition.
notes: Import for re-export only -- no drawback on warehoused goods -- manufacturer protectionism -- smuggling fears -- wrought silks, French cambrics, printed calicoes -- warehousing system -- extreme protectionist measures

refashioned:
Britain is unwilling even to serve as a carrier of French goods, choosing to forgo profit rather than allow its enemies to benefit through British trade. Not only half the Old Subsidy but an additional twenty-five percent is retained on re-exports of all French goods.

Under the Old Subsidy rules, the drawback on wine exports considerably exceeded half the import duties, suggesting the legislature intended to give special encouragement to the carrying trade in wine. Several subsequently imposed duties -- the additional duty, the new subsidy, the one-third and two-thirds subsidies, the 1692 impost, and the wine tonnage -- were all fully refundable on export. However, since most of these duties were paid in cash upon import, the interest cost on such large sums made a profitable carrying trade in wine impractical. Consequently, only part of the wine impost and none of the twenty-five pounds per ton on French wines, nor duties imposed in 1745, 1763, and 1778, could be reclaimed on export. The five percent duties added in 1779 and 1781 on all previous customs duties were fully refundable on all goods including wine. The final wine-specific duty, from 1780, was also fully refundable -- though with so many heavy non-refundable duties remaining, this gesture probably never enabled the export of a single additional barrel. These rules applied to all lawful export destinations except the British American colonies.
elegant: Britain refuses to carry French goods, retaining extra duties on their re-export. Wine drawback policy evolved into extreme complexity: the legislature originally encouraged wine carrying trade through generous refunds, but accumulating non-refundable duties and interest costs on upfront payments made wine re-export unprofitable. Late concessions on some duties were meaningless when heavy charges remained. These rules applied everywhere except the American colonies.
summary: Smith details how Britain's refusal to carry French goods and the accumulation of non-refundable wine duties -- despite some nominal concessions -- made the wine carrying trade unprofitable, illustrating the incoherence of protectionist policy.
distilled: Britain's accumulating non-refundable duties on wine made the carrying trade unprofitable despite nominal concessions, while French goods faced deliberately punitive re-export charges.
notes: Anti-French trade policy -- punitive re-export duties -- wine duty complexity -- Old Subsidy, new subsidy, one-third/two-thirds subsidies -- 1692 impost -- tonnage on wine -- interest cost on upfront duties -- French wine discrimination -- American colonies excluded -- incoherent evolution of drawback policy

refashioned: The 1663 Act for the Encouragement of Trade gave Britain the monopoly of supplying the colonies with all European goods, including wines. But in colonies with such extensive coastlines, where British authority was always thin, and where colonists could ship non-enumerated goods first to all of Europe and later to all ports south of Cape Finisterre, this monopoly was probably never well enforced. Colonists likely found ways to bring back goods from wherever they could ship their exports. They did, however, face difficulty importing European wines directly from producing countries, and could not easily import them from Britain, where wines bore heavy duties with limited drawbacks. Madeira wine, not being a European product, could be imported directly into America and the West Indies, which enjoyed free trade with Madeira for all non-enumerated goods. These circumstances had probably created the widespread taste for Madeira wine that British officers found throughout the colonies at the start of the 1755 war and brought home with them to Britain, where it had previously been unfashionable. After the war ended in 1763, a statute allowed all duties except three pounds ten shillings to be drawn back on wines exported to the colonies, except French wines, to which national prejudice would grant no encouragement whatsoever. But the period between this concession and the colonial revolt was probably too short for it to significantly change colonial drinking habits.
elegant: Britain's monopoly on supplying European goods to the colonies was largely unenforceable along vast coastlines. Colonists could not easily import European wines from Britain (heavy duties, limited drawbacks) but could freely import Madeira wine, which was not European. This created the colonial Madeira preference that British officers brought home after the 1755 war. After 1763, most wine duties were refundable on colonial exports except for French wines, but the interval before the revolution was too short to change established tastes.
summary: Smith explains how Britain's unenforceable trade monopoly and heavy wine duties inadvertently created the colonial preference for Madeira wine, and how belated duty concessions in 1763 came too late to change colonial habits before the revolution.
distilled: Britain's unenforceable trade monopoly and heavy wine duties inadvertently created the colonial preference for Madeira wine, and belated concessions came too late to change habits before the revolution.
notes: 1663 Act for Encouragement of Trade -- colonial monopoly unenforceability -- Madeira wine preference -- non-European goods loophole -- Cape Finisterre trade boundary -- 1755 war -- 1763 duty concession -- French wine exclusion -- colonial tastes -- unintended consequences of trade policy

refashioned: The same act that favored the colonies with generous wine drawbacks treated them much less favorably regarding most other goods. For most commodities exported to other countries, half the Old Subsidy was refundable. But this act decreed that no part of that duty would be drawn back on exports to the colonies of any European or East Indian goods, except wines, white calicoes, and muslins.
elegant: The same act that generously refunded wine duties for colonial exports stripped drawbacks on most other European and East Indian goods sent to the colonies -- except white calicoes and muslins. Colonies were thus treated worse than foreign countries for most goods.
summary: While granting generous wine drawbacks for colonial exports, the same act denied drawbacks on most European and East Indian goods exported to the colonies, making colonial terms less favorable than those for foreign countries.
distilled: The colonies received generous wine drawbacks but were denied duty refunds on most other European and East Indian goods, worse terms than foreign countries received.
notes: Inconsistent colonial trade policy -- wine favored, other goods penalized -- half Old Subsidy denied for colonial exports -- exceptions for white calicoes and muslins -- colonies treated worse than foreign countries -- contradictory incentive structure

refashioned: Drawbacks were probably originally created to encourage the carrying trade, which, since ships' freight is often paid by foreigners in money, was thought to be especially suited to bringing gold and silver into the country. Although the carrying trade deserves no special encouragement, and the original motivation was probably quite misguided, the institution itself makes good sense. Drawbacks cannot force more capital into the carrying trade than would go there naturally without import duties; they merely prevent capital from being excluded altogether by those duties. The carrying trade, though it deserves no preference, should not be prohibited but left free like all other trades. It serves as a necessary outlet for capital that cannot find employment in the country's agriculture, manufacturing, domestic trade, or direct foreign trade.
elegant: Drawbacks were originally meant to encourage the carrying trade as a gold-bringing activity -- a foolish rationale, but a reasonable institution. They do not force capital into carrying trade; they merely prevent import duties from excluding it. The carrying trade deserves no preference but should remain free as an outlet for capital that finds no other domestic employment.
summary: Smith defends drawbacks as a reasonable institution despite their foolish original rationale, arguing they simply prevent duties from excluding the carrying trade -- which deserves freedom as a necessary outlet for surplus capital, even if it merits no special preference.
distilled: Drawbacks are reasonable because they prevent duties from excluding the carrying trade, which serves as a necessary outlet for capital that cannot find other domestic employment.
notes: Drawbacks' original purpose -- carrying trade encouragement -- foolish rationale, reasonable institution -- natural capital allocation -- carrying trade as residual employment for capital -- freedom of trade principle -- no preference but no prohibition

refashioned: Government customs revenue actually benefits from drawbacks, through the portion of duty that is retained. If all duties were kept in full, the foreign goods they apply to could seldom be exported -- and therefore could seldom be imported -- for lack of a market. The duties from which a partial drawback is given would never have been collected at all.
elegant: Customs revenue actually benefits from drawbacks. If full duties were always retained, goods could not be profitably re-exported or even imported. The partial duty retained through the drawback system would never have been collected otherwise.
summary: Smith argues that customs revenue benefits from drawbacks because without them, the goods would never be imported in the first place, so the retained portion represents revenue that would otherwise not exist.
distilled: Drawbacks increase customs revenue because without them the goods would never be imported, so the retained duty portion is revenue that would not otherwise exist.
notes: Revenue effect of drawbacks -- partial duty retention -- goods would not be imported without drawback -- carrying trade enables import volume -- counterintuitive revenue benefit of duty refunds

refashioned: These arguments sufficiently justify drawbacks and would justify them even if all duties -- whether on domestic production or foreign goods -- were fully refunded upon export. In that case, excise revenue would suffer a little and customs revenue considerably more, but the natural balance of industry -- the natural division and distribution of labor, which duties always distort to some degree -- would be more closely restored by such a policy.
elegant: These arguments justify drawbacks even if all duties were fully refunded on export. Though this would reduce excise and customs revenue, it would more closely restore the natural balance of industry that duties always distort.
summary: Smith argues that full drawbacks on all duties would be justified because restoring the natural division of labor that duties distort is worth more than the lost revenue.
distilled: Full drawbacks on all exported goods would be justified because restoring the natural balance of industry outweighs the revenue lost.
notes: Full drawback justification -- natural balance of industry -- duty-induced distortion -- revenue vs. efficiency tradeoff -- natural division of labor -- theoretical ideal of drawback system

refashioned: These arguments, however, only justify drawbacks on goods exported to genuinely foreign and independent countries, not to colonies where our merchants and manufacturers enjoy a monopoly. A drawback on European goods exported to the American colonies, for example, will not always produce more exports than would occur without it. Thanks to the monopoly our merchants enjoy there, the same quantity might often be exported even with full duties retained. In such cases, the drawback is a pure loss to the excise and customs revenue without changing the trade at all or making it any more extensive. Whether such drawbacks are justified as encouragement to colonial industry, or whether it is fair that the colonies be exempted from taxes paid by all other subjects, I will address later when discussing colonies.
elegant: Drawbacks are only justified for exports to genuinely foreign countries, not monopolized colonies. Since British merchants hold a colonial monopoly, the same quantity would often be exported regardless of drawbacks, making them a pure revenue loss. Whether colonial tax exemptions are justified will be addressed later.
summary: Smith limits the justification for drawbacks to exports to independent countries, arguing that in monopolized colonial markets, drawbacks are a pure revenue loss since the same quantity would be exported regardless.
distilled: Drawbacks are only justified for exports to competitive foreign markets, not monopolized colonies where the same volume would be shipped regardless of duty refunds.
notes: Drawback limits -- monopolized vs. competitive markets -- colonial monopoly makes drawbacks a revenue loss -- colonial tax exemption question -- cross-reference to later chapter on colonies -- distinction between foreign and colonial trade

refashioned: It should always be understood that drawbacks are useful only when the goods they apply to are genuinely exported to a foreign country and not secretly re-imported into our own. It is well known that some drawbacks, particularly those on tobacco, have frequently been abused in this way, giving rise to many frauds that harm both government revenue and honest merchants.
elegant: Drawbacks are only useful when goods are genuinely exported, not secretly re-imported. Tobacco drawbacks in particular have been widely abused through fraudulent re-importation, harming both revenue and honest traders.
summary: Smith warns that drawbacks are only beneficial when goods are genuinely exported, noting widespread fraudulent abuse of tobacco drawbacks through secret re-importation.
distilled: Drawbacks are only useful when goods are genuinely exported, and tobacco drawbacks in particular have been widely abused through fraudulent re-importation.
notes: Drawback fraud -- tobacco drawback abuse -- clandestine re-importation -- harm to revenue and fair traders -- enforcement problem -- practical limitation of drawback system

refashioned: Export bounties are frequently petitioned for in Britain, and sometimes granted, for products of particular domestic industries. Through these bounties, our merchants and manufacturers are supposedly enabled to sell their goods as cheaply as or cheaper than their foreign rivals. A greater quantity will supposedly be exported, tipping the trade balance further in our country's favor. We cannot give our workers a monopoly in foreign markets as we have in the home market. We cannot force foreigners to buy our goods as we have forced our own citizens to do. The next best option, it has been thought, is to pay foreigners for buying. This is how the mercantilist system proposes to enrich the whole country and fill everyone's pockets through the balance of trade.
elegant: Export bounties supposedly enable British merchants to undercut foreign rivals, increase exports, and improve the trade balance. Since Britain cannot grant monopolies or compel purchases abroad as it does at home, the next best idea is to pay foreigners to buy British goods. This is the mercantilist formula for national enrichment.
summary: Smith introduces export bounties as the mercantilist solution for foreign markets where monopoly is impossible: subsidizing foreign purchases of British goods to improve the trade balance. He presents this as effectively paying foreigners to buy.
distilled: Export bounties are the mercantilist attempt to extend domestic monopoly advantages to foreign markets by essentially paying foreigners to buy British goods.
notes: Chapter 4.5 introduction (Of Bounties) -- export bounties defined -- mercantilist rationale -- paying foreigners to buy -- extension of domestic monopoly logic to foreign markets -- balance of trade objective -- ironic framing

refashioned: It is acknowledged that bounties should only be given to trades that cannot survive without them. But any trade where the merchant can sell his goods at a price that covers his entire capital plus the ordinary rate of profit requires no bounty. Such a trade is clearly on an equal footing with all other unbounties trades and needs no more assistance than they do. Only trades in which the merchant must sell at a loss -- below his total costs including normal profit -- require bounties. The bounty compensates this loss and encourages him to continue or begin a trade whose costs exceed its returns, where every transaction consumes part of the capital employed. If all trades operated this way, there would soon be no capital left in the country.
elegant: Bounties should only support trades that cannot survive without them. But any trade covering its costs plus normal profit needs no subsidy. Only inherently loss-making trades require bounties -- trades that consume capital with every transaction. If all trades worked this way, the country would soon have no capital left.
summary: Smith argues that bounties are logically only justified for trades that are inherently unprofitable, since profitable trades need no subsidy. But subsidizing trades that consume capital with every transaction is economically destructive.
distilled: Bounties are only logically needed for inherently unprofitable trades that consume capital with every transaction -- a self-evidently destructive policy.
notes: Bounty logic examined -- profitable trades need no subsidy -- loss-making trades consume capital -- self-defeating nature of bounty-dependent trade -- ordinary profits of stock -- reductio ad absurdum of bounty justification

refashioned: The only trades that can be carried on between two nations with one side consistently and regularly losing -- selling goods for less than the cost of bringing them to market -- are trades sustained by bounties. Without the bounty to compensate the merchant's losses, his own self-interest would quickly drive him to redirect his capital to some other trade where the price of goods would cover his costs plus normal profit. The effect of bounties, like all other devices of the mercantilist system, can only be to force a country's trade into channels far less advantageous than those it would naturally follow on its own.
elegant: Only bounty-supported trades can sustain regular losses. Without subsidies, self-interest quickly redirects capital to profitable trades. Bounties, like all mercantilist devices, force trade into channels less advantageous than those it would naturally follow.
summary: Smith argues that bounties are the only mechanism that can sustain consistently unprofitable trade. Without them, self-interest naturally redirects capital to profitable channels, and bounties therefore force trade into inferior directions.
distilled: Bounties force trade into less advantageous channels by sustaining losses that self-interest would otherwise eliminate through natural capital reallocation.
notes: Bounties sustain otherwise impossible losses -- self-interest as corrective mechanism -- forced vs. natural trade channels -- mercantilist system critique -- capital reallocation through market signals -- transition to specific analysis of corn bounty

refashioned: The well-informed author of the Tracts upon the Corn Trade has demonstrated clearly that, since the corn export bounty was first established, the price of corn exported -- valued moderately -- has exceeded the price of corn imported -- valued generously -- by a sum far greater than all bounties paid during the period. On mercantilist principles, he takes this as clear proof that the forced corn trade benefits the nation, since export value exceeds import value by more than the total public expense of promoting those exports. But he overlooks a crucial point: the bounty is the smallest part of what corn exports actually cost society. The farmer's capital used to grow the corn must also be counted. Unless the foreign sale price covers not only the bounty but also this capital plus ordinary profits, society loses by the difference -- its national stock is diminished. And the very reason the bounty was thought necessary in the first place is that the foreign price was supposedly insufficient to cover these costs.
elegant: A mercantilist author argues the corn bounty pays for itself because export values exceed import values by more than the total bounties paid. But the bounty is the smallest part of the real cost. The farmer's capital and expected profits must also be recovered from the foreign sale price. Since the bounty exists precisely because the price cannot cover these costs, the nation necessarily loses on each subsidized export.
summary: Smith critiques the mercantilist argument that corn export bounties are profitable because export values exceed import values. The bounty is only a fraction of the true cost, which must include the farmer's capital and normal profits. Since the bounty exists because foreign prices cannot cover these full costs, the nation is actually made poorer.
distilled: The corn bounty costs society far more than the subsidy itself, because the farmer's capital and profits must also be recovered from insufficient foreign prices.
notes: Critique of mercantilist accounting -- distinguishes visible subsidy cost from total social cost. Introduces opportunity cost reasoning. Cross-reference: balance of trade fallacy (4.1-4.3). The 'Tracts upon the Corn Trade' author is Charles Smith.

refashioned: It has been claimed that the average price of corn has fallen considerably since the bounty was established. I have already shown that the average price of corn did begin to decline toward the end of the last century and continued falling during the first sixty-four years of the present one. But this decline, if real as I believe it to be, happened in spite of the bounty, not because of it. The same trend occurred in France, where not only was there no bounty, but until 1764, corn exports were outright prohibited. This gradual fall in average grain prices is therefore probably attributable to neither regulation, but rather to the gradual rise in the real value of silver across European markets during this century -- a trend I examined in the first book. It seems entirely impossible that the bounty could ever have contributed to lowering the price of grain.
elegant: The claim that corn prices fell because of the export bounty ignores that the same decline occurred in France, where corn exports were prohibited until 1764. The real cause was the gradual rise in silver's real value across European markets -- a trend independent of any country's corn policy. The bounty could not possibly have lowered grain prices.
summary: Smith rejects the claim that the corn bounty lowered grain prices. The same price decline occurred in France, which prohibited corn exports. The true cause was a general European rise in silver's real value, as analyzed in Book I.
distilled: Falling corn prices since the bounty's establishment were caused by rising silver values across Europe, not by the bounty -- as proven by the identical trend in France where exports were banned.
notes: Empirical counter-argument using cross-national comparison -- France as natural experiment. Cross-reference: Book I analysis of silver's long-term value. Correlation vs. causation reasoning.

refashioned: In years of plenty, as I have already observed, the bounty keeps up the price of corn in the home market above what it would naturally fall to by encouraging extraordinary exports. This was, in fact, the bounty's stated purpose. In years of scarcity, although the bounty is frequently suspended, the large exports it caused during plentiful years must often prevent the surplus of one year from relieving the shortage of the next. Therefore, in both plentiful and scarce years, the bounty necessarily tends to raise the money price of corn above what it would otherwise be in the home market.
elegant: In plentiful years, the bounty raises domestic corn prices by encouraging exports -- its explicit purpose. In scarce years, though the bounty is suspended, the heavy exports during abundance prevent surpluses from relieving subsequent shortages. The bounty therefore raises domestic corn prices in all years.
summary: The corn bounty raises domestic prices in plentiful years by promoting exports, and in scarce years by having already drained surpluses that could have cushioned shortages. It raises home market prices regardless of the season.
distilled: The corn bounty raises domestic prices in every type of year -- directly during abundance by promoting exports, and indirectly during scarcity by having already drained away surpluses.
notes: Inter-temporal analysis of price effects -- surplus drainage in good years worsens bad years. Demonstrates unintended consequences across time. The bounty's own stated purpose contradicts claims that it lowers prices.

refashioned: That the bounty must raise prices given the current state of farming will not, I think, be disputed by any reasonable person. But many people have argued that the bounty encourages farming in two ways: first, by opening a larger foreign market for corn, it increases demand and therefore production; second, by guaranteeing a better price than the current state of farming would otherwise yield, it encourages cultivation. This double encouragement, they imagine, must over time produce such an increase in corn production that it would lower the home market price far more than the bounty raises it in the current state of farming.
elegant: No one disputes that the bounty raises current corn prices. But supporters argue it encourages farming two ways: by expanding the foreign market and thus demand, and by guaranteeing better prices than farmers would otherwise receive. They claim this double stimulus will eventually increase production enough to lower home prices below what the bounty currently raises them.
summary: While admitting the bounty raises current corn prices, supporters argue it stimulates farming through expanded foreign demand and guaranteed better prices. They believe the resulting production increase will eventually lower domestic prices more than the bounty raises them.
distilled: Bounty supporters concede it raises current prices but argue it will stimulate enough additional corn production to eventually lower domestic prices -- a claim Smith will refute.
notes: Sets up the opposition's strongest argument before dismantling it. Two-channel theory: demand expansion and price support. Smith's response follows in subsequent passages.

refashioned: I answer that whatever expansion of the foreign market the bounty causes must, in every particular year, come entirely at the expense of the home market. Every bushel of corn exported because of the bounty -- corn that would not have been exported without it -- would have remained at home to increase consumption and lower domestic prices. The corn bounty, like every export bounty, imposes two separate taxes on the people. First, the tax they must pay to fund the bounty. Second, the tax created by higher domestic prices, which, since everyone buys corn, falls on the entire population. This second tax is by far the heavier of the two. Suppose the bounty of five shillings per exported quarter of wheat raises the home market price by only sixpence per bushel, or four shillings per quarter. Even on this very moderate assumption, the public -- besides paying the five-shilling bounty on every quarter exported -- must also pay an additional four shillings on every quarter they themselves consume.
elegant: Every bushel the bounty diverts to export is a bushel removed from the home market. The bounty therefore imposes two taxes: the direct tax funding the subsidy, and the indirect tax from higher domestic corn prices -- which falls on every person. The indirect tax is far heavier. Even if the bounty raises prices by only four shillings per quarter, the public pays that surcharge on every quarter consumed, on top of the five-shilling bounty on every quarter exported.
summary: The corn bounty expands foreign markets only by shrinking the domestic one. It imposes two taxes: the direct cost of funding the bounty, and the heavier indirect tax of raised domestic prices that every corn buyer must pay.
distilled: The corn bounty's expansion of foreign markets comes entirely at the home market's expense, imposing both a direct subsidy tax and a far heavier indirect tax through raised domestic prices.
notes: Key insight: export promotion is domestic market contraction. Double taxation argument -- visible fiscal cost plus invisible price distortion cost. The second (price) tax is regressive, falling hardest on the poor. Cross-reference: Smith's general critique of mercantile export subsidies (4.1-4.3).

refashioned: According to the well-informed author of the Tracts upon the Corn Trade, the average proportion of corn exported to corn consumed at home is no more than one to thirty-one. For every five shillings they contribute to the first tax, the people must therefore contribute six pounds and four shillings to the second. So heavy a tax on the first necessity of life must either reduce the subsistence of the laboring poor, or force an increase in their money wages proportional to the increase in the money price of their food. Insofar as it operates the first way, it reduces the ability of the poor to raise and educate their children, tending to restrain population growth. Insofar as it operates the second way, it reduces employers' ability to hire as many workers, tending to restrain the country's industry.
elegant: If only one bushel in thirty-one is exported, then for every five shillings of bounty tax, the public pays over six pounds in higher domestic prices. This heavy tax on the primary necessity of life either reduces the subsistence of the poor -- restraining population -- or forces up wages, reducing employment. Either way, it damages the nation.
summary: Since only a tiny fraction of corn is exported, the price-raising effect of the bounty costs the public vastly more than the bounty itself. This tax on food either reduces the poor's subsistence and restrains population, or raises wages and reduces employment.
distilled: The domestic price tax from the corn bounty costs the public over seventy times more than the direct bounty tax, restricting either population growth or employment.
notes: Quantifies the ratio of hidden to visible costs -- 6 pounds 4 shillings vs. 5 shillings. Links corn policy to population dynamics (Malthusian foreshadowing) and employment effects. Charles Smith's data used against mercantilist conclusions.

refashioned: The extraordinary corn exports caused by the bounty therefore not only diminish the home market in every particular year by exactly as much as they extend the foreign market, but by restraining both population and industry, their ultimate effect is to stunt and restrain the gradual expansion of the home market itself. In the long run, the bounty tends to diminish rather than increase the total market and consumption of corn.
elegant: The bounty shrinks the home market by exactly as much as it expands the foreign one. Worse, by restraining population and industry, it stunts the long-term growth of domestic demand. Its ultimate effect is to reduce total corn consumption, not increase it.
summary: Export bounties on corn shrink the domestic market as much as they expand the foreign one. By suppressing population and industry, they ultimately reduce total corn demand over time.
distilled: The corn bounty's long-run effect is to shrink total corn demand by restraining the population and industry that would have expanded the home market.
notes: Completes the dynamic argument: short-run market diversion plus long-run demand suppression. Zero-sum foreign/domestic market trade-off. Links microeconomic price distortion to macroeconomic growth effects.

refashioned:
It has been argued, however, that raising the money price of corn makes it more profitable for the farmer, thereby encouraging production.

I answer that this would be true only if the bounty raised the real price of corn -- that is, if it enabled the farmer to use a given quantity of corn to maintain a greater number of laborers, at whatever standard of living prevails in his area. But neither the bounty nor any other human institution can achieve this effect. It is not the real but only the nominal price of corn that the bounty can significantly affect. And though the tax the bounty imposes on the whole population may be very burdensome to those who pay it, it provides very little real advantage to those who receive it.
elegant: The bounty would encourage farming only if it raised corn's real price -- enabling farmers to command more labor per bushel. But no policy can do this. The bounty affects only the nominal price of corn. The heavy tax it imposes on the whole population provides almost no real benefit to those it supposedly helps.
summary: The bounty raises only corn's nominal price, not its real price. Since it cannot enable farmers to command more actual labor per bushel, it provides no genuine encouragement to agriculture despite heavily taxing consumers.
distilled: The corn bounty raises only the nominal price, not the real price, of corn -- so it cannot genuinely encourage farming while it heavily burdens consumers.
notes: Central distinction between nominal and real prices -- core Smithian insight. No policy can alter corn's real value because corn is the ultimate measure of value. Cross-reference: Book I on real vs. nominal price.

refashioned: The bounty's real effect is not so much to raise the real value of corn as to degrade the real value of silver -- making an equal quantity of silver exchange for less corn and less of all other domestically produced goods. This is because the money price of corn regulates the money price of all other homemade commodities.
elegant: The bounty does not raise corn's real value but degrades silver's -- making silver buy less corn and less of everything else produced domestically, since the money price of corn governs the money price of all other homemade goods.
summary: The corn bounty effectively degrades the value of silver rather than increasing corn's real value, because corn's money price sets the benchmark for all domestic commodity prices.
distilled: The corn bounty degrades silver's purchasing power rather than raising corn's real value, since corn's price regulates all other domestic prices.
notes: Corn as numeraire -- its price governs the entire domestic price level. The bounty creates domestic inflation rather than real agricultural gains. Cross-reference: Book I on corn as the fundamental measure of value.

refashioned:
The money price of corn regulates the money price of labor, which must always be enough to enable the laborer to buy sufficient corn to maintain himself and his family -- whether liberally, moderately, or scantily -- as the advancing, stationary, or declining state of society requires his employers to maintain him.

It likewise regulates the money price of all other raw produce of the land, which in every period must bear a certain proportion to the price of corn, though this proportion varies over time. It regulates, for example, the money price of grass and hay, of butcher's meat, of horses and their upkeep, of land carriage, and consequently of the greater part of the country's inland commerce.
elegant: Corn's money price governs the money price of labor -- which must always buy enough corn for the worker's subsistence. It also governs the money price of all other raw produce, which must bear a proportional relationship to corn. Through these channels, the price of corn regulates meat, hay, horses, land transport, and most inland commerce.
summary: The money price of corn determines the money price of labor and of all other agricultural produce. Through these links, it effectively regulates the cost of meat, transport, and most domestic commerce.
distilled: Corn's money price is the master regulator of the economy, governing wages, raw produce prices, and the cost of inland commerce.
notes: Corn-wage nexus: subsistence wages must track corn prices. Corn as the anchor of the domestic price system. The three states of society (advancing, stationary, declining) cross-reference Book I, Ch. 8 on wages.

refashioned: By regulating the money price of raw produce, the price of corn regulates the cost of manufacturing materials. By regulating the money price of labor, it regulates the cost of manufacturing skill and effort. And by regulating both, it regulates the price of finished manufactured goods. The money price of labor, and of everything produced by land or labor, must necessarily rise or fall in proportion to the money price of corn.
elegant: The money price of corn governs manufacturing costs through two channels: raw material prices and labor costs. By regulating both inputs, it determines the price of all finished goods. Everything produced by land or labor must rise or fall with the price of corn.
summary: Corn's price determines both raw material costs and labor costs, thereby regulating the price of all manufactured goods. All prices in the economy move in proportion to corn.
distilled: Since corn's price governs both materials and labor costs, it ultimately determines the price of all manufactured goods in the economy.
notes: Completes the price transmission chain: corn -> wages + raw materials -> manufactured goods. Establishes corn as the economy's general price level anchor. Implies the bounty creates economy-wide inflation.

refashioned: Therefore, even if the bounty enables the farmer to sell his corn at four shillings per bushel instead of three shillings and sixpence, and to pay his landlord a proportionally higher money rent, yet if four shillings now buys no more domestic goods than three shillings and sixpence did before, neither farmer nor landlord is truly better off. The farmer cannot cultivate much better, and the landlord cannot live much better. This price increase may give them a small advantage in purchasing foreign goods, but for domestic goods it gives them none at all. And nearly all of the farmer's expenses, and the great majority of the landlord's, are for domestic goods.
elegant: If the bounty raises corn from three shillings sixpence to four shillings per bushel, but four shillings now buys no more domestic goods than three and six did before, neither farmer nor landlord gains anything real. They might gain slightly on foreign purchases, but nearly all their spending is domestic.
summary: Even if the bounty raises corn prices and land rents in money terms, the farmer and landlord gain nothing real if domestic goods prices rise proportionally. Their slight advantage in foreign purchases is negligible since nearly all their spending is domestic.
distilled: The bounty's nominal price increase gives farmers and landlords no real benefit because all domestic prices rise proportionally, and nearly all their spending is domestic.
notes: Demonstrates that nominal gains wash out in real terms when all prices adjust. Purchasing power parity within the domestic economy. Only foreign goods offer any (slight) gain -- an ironic partial benefit from the mercantilist perspective.

refashioned: When silver loses value because of the fertility of the mines -- a change that operates equally across most of the commercial world -- the consequences for any particular country are trivial. The resulting rise in all money prices, while it does not make those who receive them truly richer, does not make them truly poorer either. Silverware becomes genuinely cheaper, but everything else retains exactly the same real value as before.
elegant: When mine fertility causes a global decline in silver's value, the effect is insignificant for any single country. All money prices rise, but no one becomes truly richer or poorer. Only silverware becomes genuinely cheaper; everything else maintains its real value.
summary: A global decline in silver's value from mine productivity is harmless to any particular country. All prices rise proportionally, so real wealth is unchanged. Only silver items become genuinely cheaper.
distilled: A global decline in silver's value from productive mines is harmless because all prices adjust proportionally, leaving real wealth unchanged.
notes: Distinguishes global monetary inflation from country-specific policy-induced inflation. Neutral money proposition for global silver supply changes. Sets up contrast with the harmful country-specific effect in the next passage.

refashioned: But when silver loses value only in a particular country -- whether because of its special circumstances or its political institutions -- the consequences are very serious. Far from making anyone truly richer, it tends to make everyone truly poorer. The rise in all money prices, being confined to that country alone, discourages every kind of industry carried on within it. It enables foreign nations, who can supply almost all goods for less silver than domestic workers require, to undersell them not only abroad but even in the home market.
elegant: When silver's value falls in one country alone -- due to its circumstances or policies -- the effect is devastating. No one becomes richer; everyone becomes poorer. Domestic prices rise above international levels, allowing foreign producers to undersell domestic ones in every market, including at home.
summary: A country-specific decline in silver's value, caused by policy rather than global mine production, is deeply harmful. It raises domestic prices above international levels, allowing foreign producers to undersell domestic industry everywhere.
distilled: Country-specific silver devaluation through policy is devastating because it raises domestic costs above international levels, destroying competitiveness at home and abroad.
notes: Critical distinction: global vs. country-specific monetary effects. Country-specific inflation destroys competitive advantage. This is Smith's core argument against the corn bounty's macroeconomic damage. Anticipates modern concepts of real exchange rate appreciation from policy distortions.

refashioned: Spain and Portugal, as proprietors of the principal mines, are the distributors of gold and silver to all other European countries. These metals should naturally be somewhat cheaper there than elsewhere. The difference, however, should be no more than the cost of freight and insurance. Given the high value and small bulk of precious metals, freight costs are modest, and insurance is the same as for any other goods of equal value. Spain and Portugal would therefore suffer very little from their situation as mine-owning nations, if they did not aggravate the disadvantage through their own political institutions.
elegant: As owners of the main mines, Spain and Portugal naturally distribute gold and silver to Europe. These metals should be only slightly cheaper there -- by the cost of freight and insurance, which are minimal for such valuable, compact goods. The real damage comes not from their position but from their own misguided policies.
summary: Spain and Portugal, as mine owners, should have only slightly cheaper precious metals than other countries -- differing by minimal transport costs. Their real economic harm comes from policy mistakes, not their natural position.
distilled: Spain and Portugal's natural role as gold and silver distributors would cause them little harm if their own political institutions did not greatly worsen its effects.
notes: Sets up the Spain/Portugal case study as parallel to the corn bounty's effects. Natural price differentials should equal transport costs only -- a version of the law of one price. Policy failure, not resource endowment, causes damage.

refashioned: Spain taxes, and Portugal prohibits, the export of gold and silver. This loads those exports with the additional cost of smuggling, and raises the value of those metals in other countries above their value in Spain and Portugal by the full amount of that smuggling expense. When you dam up a stream, once the reservoir is full, exactly as much water must overflow the dam as if no dam existed at all. The prohibition on exports cannot retain more gold and silver in Spain and Portugal than what those countries can actually employ -- that is, what the annual produce of their land and labor allows them to use in coin, plate, gilding, and other gold and silver products.
elegant: Spain taxes and Portugal bans precious metal exports, adding smuggling costs that artificially widen the price gap with other nations. But like a dammed stream that overflows once full, no prohibition can retain more gold and silver than a country's economy can actually absorb -- determined by the annual produce of its land and labor.
summary: Spain and Portugal's restrictions on precious metal exports only add smuggling costs, widening the price gap with other nations. Like a full dam, the restrictions cannot retain more gold and silver than the economy can absorb.
distilled: Restrictions on precious metal exports are like a dam: once the economy is saturated, the metals overflow regardless, and the only lasting effect is the added cost of smuggling.
notes: Brilliant dam metaphor for monetary equilibrium -- a country can only absorb precious metals proportional to its productive capacity. Smuggling as evidence of policy failure. Cross-reference: 4.1 on futility of export prohibitions.

refashioned: Once they have accumulated all the gold and silver they can employ, the dam is full, and the entire stream flowing in must overflow. Accordingly, despite these restrictions, the annual export of gold and silver from Spain and Portugal is by all accounts very nearly equal to their annual imports. However, just as water must be deeper behind a dam than in front of it, the quantity of gold and silver retained in Spain and Portugal must, relative to the annual produce of their land and labor, be greater than what is found in other countries.
elegant: Once the economy is saturated, all incoming gold and silver must flow out again -- Spanish and Portuguese exports nearly equal their imports despite all restrictions. But like water behind a dam, the standing stock of precious metals relative to national output remains higher than in other countries.
summary: Spain and Portugal export nearly as much gold and silver as they import, despite restrictions. But like water pooling behind a dam, they retain a disproportionately large standing stock of precious metals relative to their economic output.
distilled: Despite export restrictions, Spain and Portugal's precious metal outflows nearly match inflows, but like a dammed stream, the standing stock behind the barrier remains disproportionately high.
notes: Extends the dam metaphor: flow equilibrium with stock disequilibrium. Distinguishes flow variables (annual imports/exports) from stock variables (accumulated holdings). The excess stock is the source of domestic price distortion.

refashioned: The higher and stronger the dam, the greater the difference in water depth on each side. Similarly, the higher the tax, the harsher the penalties guarding the prohibition, and the more vigilant and severe the enforcement, the greater the difference between the ratio of gold and silver to annual output in Spain and Portugal compared to other countries. This difference is reportedly very considerable. One frequently finds in those countries a profusion of silver plate in houses where nothing else would, in other countries, be considered appropriate or consistent with such magnificence.
elegant: The stricter the enforcement, the greater the gap in precious metal concentration between Spain and Portugal and other nations -- just as a higher dam creates a deeper pool behind it. The result is visible: houses filled with silver plate alongside nothing else that other countries would consider fitting for such display.
summary: Stricter enforcement of export restrictions only widens the gap in precious metal holdings, like a higher dam deepening the water behind it. This produces the absurd spectacle of Spanish and Portuguese homes overflowing with silver plate but lacking other markers of wealth.
distilled: Stricter precious metal export controls only widen the concentration gap, producing an absurd excess of silver plate in otherwise modest households.
notes: The dam height/depth metaphor illustrates enforcement futility. Silver plate anecdote as empirical evidence of resource misallocation. Conspicuous monetary wealth masking real poverty -- a theme relevant to modern resource curse discussions.

refashioned: The cheapness of gold and silver -- or equivalently, the dearness of all other goods -- that necessarily results from this excess of precious metals, discourages both the agriculture and manufactures of Spain and Portugal. It enables foreign nations to supply them with many kinds of raw produce and nearly all manufactured goods for less gold and silver than they themselves could raise or make those goods for at home. The tax and prohibition operate in two ways: they not only lower the value of precious metals within Spain and Portugal, but by retaining metals that would otherwise flow to other countries, they keep their value somewhat higher elsewhere. This gives foreign nations a double advantage in trade with Spain and Portugal. Open the floodgates, and water above the dam will fall while water below rises, until both reach the same level. Remove the tax and prohibition, and as the quantity of precious metals diminishes in Spain and Portugal and increases elsewhere, their value -- their ratio to annual output -- will quickly reach a level, or very near a level, across all countries.
elegant: Excess precious metals make everything expensive in Spain and Portugal, destroying domestic agriculture and manufacturing. Foreign nations gain a double advantage: domestic prices are inflated while metals retained at home keep prices lower abroad. Open the floodgates, and both sides equalize. Remove the restrictions, metals flow out, prices adjust, and the competitive disadvantage vanishes.
summary: The excess of precious metals in Spain and Portugal raises all domestic prices, destroying their agriculture and industry while giving foreign competitors a double advantage -- cheap metals abroad and expensive goods at home. Removing restrictions would equalize precious metal values across countries.
distilled: Spain and Portugal's precious metal restrictions destroy domestic industry by inflating prices, while giving foreign nations a double competitive advantage that would vanish if trade were freed.
notes: Double disadvantage mechanism: domestic inflation plus foreign deflation from the same policy. Floodgate metaphor completes the dam analogy. Predicts convergence under free trade -- an early statement of monetary equilibrium theory. 'Dutch disease' avant la lettre.

refashioned: The loss Spain and Portugal would sustain from exporting their gold and silver would be entirely nominal and imaginary. The nominal value of their goods and annual output would fall, expressed in a smaller quantity of silver than before. But their real value would remain the same -- sufficient to maintain, command, and employ the same quantity of labor as before. As the nominal value of goods fell, the real value of whatever gold and silver remained would rise, and a smaller quantity of those metals would serve all the same purposes of commerce and circulation that a larger quantity had served before.
elegant: If Spain and Portugal let their gold and silver flow out, the loss would be purely nominal. Goods would be expressed in less silver, but their real value -- the labor they command -- would be unchanged. The remaining precious metals would rise in value, performing the same commercial functions with a smaller quantity.
summary: Exporting excess gold and silver would inflict only a nominal loss on Spain and Portugal. Real values would be unchanged, and the remaining smaller stock of precious metals would serve commerce just as well at higher value per unit.
distilled: Letting excess gold and silver flow abroad would cause only nominal losses, as remaining metals would rise in value to serve the same economic functions.
notes: Nominal vs. real distinction applied to national wealth. Quantity theory logic: less money at higher value per unit serves the same function. Anticipates the neutrality of money proposition. Cross-reference: Book I on real vs. nominal value.

refashioned: The gold and silver flowing abroad would not go for nothing -- they would bring back goods of equal value. These goods would not all be mere luxuries consumed by idle people who produce nothing in return. Since the idle rich would have no increase in real wealth or revenue from this export of metals, their consumption would not much increase either. The returning goods would probably consist largely -- and certainly in part -- of materials, tools, and provisions for employing and maintaining industrious people, who would reproduce with profit the full value of what they consumed. A portion of the nation's dead stock would thus be converted into active stock, setting in motion a greater quantity of industry than before.
elegant: The exported gold and silver would return as goods of equal value -- not just luxuries for the idle, but largely materials, tools, and provisions for productive workers who would reproduce their value with profit. Dead stock -- hoarded precious metals -- would become active, productive capital, employing more industry than before.
summary: Exported precious metals would return as productive goods -- tools, materials, and provisions -- not just luxuries. Idle hoards of gold and silver would be converted into active capital employing more workers and generating greater output.
distilled: Precious metals sent abroad would return as productive capital, converting dead hoards into active stock that employs more labor and generates more wealth.
notes: Dead stock vs. active stock -- precursor to the concept of idle vs. productive capital. Precious metals as unproductive hoards vs. tools/materials as productive investment. Cross-reference: Book II on productive capital and stock.

refashioned:
The annual produce of their land and labor would immediately increase a little, and within a few years would probably increase a great deal, as their industry was relieved from one of its most oppressive burdens.

The bounty on corn exports operates in exactly the same way as this absurd policy of Spain and Portugal. Whatever the actual state of farming, it makes corn somewhat dearer in the home market and somewhat cheaper in the foreign market. Since the average money price of corn regulates all other prices, it lowers the value of silver considerably at home and tends to raise it slightly abroad. It enables foreigners -- the Dutch in particular -- not only to buy our corn cheaper than they otherwise could, but sometimes cheaper than even our own people can, as the excellent authority Sir Matthew Decker assures us. It prevents our workers from offering their goods for as little silver as they otherwise could, while enabling the Dutch to offer theirs for less. It tends to make our manufactures somewhat dearer in every market and theirs somewhat cheaper, giving their industry a double advantage over our own.
elegant: Freed from this burden, Spanish and Portuguese output would grow immediately and substantially over time. The English corn bounty operates identically to Spain's absurd policy: it inflates domestic prices, deflates foreign ones, and gives competitors -- especially the Dutch -- a double advantage. The Dutch can buy our corn cheaper than we can, and sell their manufactures cheaper than we can, because the bounty degrades silver's value at home while supporting it abroad.
summary: Smith draws a direct parallel between Spain's precious metal hoarding and England's corn bounty. Both inflate domestic prices and cheapen goods abroad, giving foreign competitors like the Dutch a double advantage in trade.
distilled: The English corn bounty replicates Spain's self-destructive precious metals policy, inflating domestic prices while giving foreign competitors like the Dutch a double commercial advantage.
notes: The Spain/Portugal parallel is the argumentative climax -- the corn bounty is the English version of Iberian bullionism. Sir Matthew Decker cited as authority. Double advantage for the Dutch: cheaper English corn imports and cheaper Dutch manufactured exports. Cross-reference: 4.5.17-22.

refashioned: The bounty raises not so much the real as the nominal price of corn in the home market. It increases not the quantity of labor a given amount of corn can maintain and employ, but only the quantity of silver it exchanges for. It thereby discourages our manufactures without rendering any considerable service to our farmers or country gentlemen. It does put a little more money in their pockets, and it may be hard to persuade most of them that this is not a very considerable benefit. But if this money loses in purchasing power -- in the labor, provisions, and domestic goods it can buy -- as much as it gains in quantity, the benefit will be little more than nominal and imaginary.
elegant: The bounty raises corn's nominal price, not its real value -- more silver per bushel, but no more purchasing power. It harms manufacturing while giving farmers and landlords only an illusory gain: more money that buys no more than before.
summary: The corn bounty raises only the nominal price, giving farmers more money but no more real purchasing power. Meanwhile, it discourages domestic manufacturing. The apparent benefit to agriculture is illusory.
distilled: The bounty gives farmers more silver per bushel but no more real purchasing power, delivering an illusory benefit while genuinely harming manufacturing.
notes: Money illusion -- farmers mistake nominal gains for real ones. The bounty's actual effect is to redistribute from manufacturing to agriculture in nominal terms only. Cross-reference: 4.5.11-12 on nominal vs. real prices.

refashioned: Perhaps the only group in the whole commonwealth to whom the bounty was or could be genuinely beneficial was the corn merchants -- the exporters and importers of corn. In years of plenty, the bounty necessarily caused greater exports than would otherwise have occurred. By preventing the surplus of one plentiful year from relieving the scarcity of the next, it also caused greater imports in years of scarcity. It thus increased the corn merchant's business in both directions. In scarce years, it not only enabled him to import a larger quantity but to sell it at a higher price, and therefore with greater profit, than he could have achieved if one year's plenty had been allowed to moderate the next year's shortage. It is among corn merchants, accordingly, that I have observed the greatest enthusiasm for continuing or renewing the bounty.
elegant: The only true beneficiaries of the corn bounty were the corn merchants. By promoting exports during plenty and preventing surpluses from moderating subsequent scarcity, it increased their business in both directions. In scarce years they could import more and sell at higher prices. Unsurprisingly, corn merchants are the bounty's most zealous advocates.
summary: Corn merchants were the bounty's only real beneficiaries. It boosted their export business in plentiful years and, by preventing surpluses from relieving future scarcity, increased their import business and profits in scarce years.
distilled: The corn bounty's only true beneficiaries were corn merchants, whose business expanded in both plentiful and scarce years at the public's expense.
notes: Identifies the real beneficiary class -- corn merchants, not farmers or landlords. Public choice insight: the most zealous advocates of a policy are its actual beneficiaries. Rent-seeking behavior. Cross-reference: 4.5.6 on inter-temporal surplus drainage.

refashioned: Our country gentlemen, when they imposed high duties on foreign corn imports -- duties amounting to a prohibition in times of moderate plenty -- and when they established the export bounty, seem to have imitated our manufacturers. Through import duties they secured for themselves a monopoly of the home market, and through the bounty they tried to prevent that market from ever being overstocked. By both measures they sought to raise the real value of their commodity, just as manufacturers had raised the real value of many manufactured goods through similar institutions. But they failed to recognize the great and essential difference that nature has established between corn and almost every other commodity. When monopoly or bounty enables woolen or linen manufacturers to sell their goods at a better price, it raises not merely the nominal but the real price of those goods -- making them equivalent to more labor and subsistence. It increases the real profit, real wealth, and real revenue of those manufacturers, enabling them to either live better or employ more labor.
