Such measures genuinely encourage those manufactures and direct toward them a greater share of the country's industry than would naturally flow there.
elegant: Country gentlemen imitated manufacturers by securing a home market monopoly through import duties and preventing oversupply through the export bounty. But they missed a crucial difference. For manufactured goods like wool or linen, monopoly and bounty raise real prices, real profits, and real wealth -- genuinely encouraging production. For corn, as Smith will show, this cannot work.
summary: Country gentlemen copied manufacturers' strategy of combining import protection with export bounties. While this genuinely raises the real price and profits of manufactured goods, Smith argues it cannot work the same way for corn due to a fundamental difference in the nature of the commodity.
distilled: Country gentlemen imitated manufacturers' protectionist strategy, not realizing that what raises real prices for manufactured goods cannot raise the real price of corn.
notes: Sets up the corn-manufactures distinction that is central to Smith's argument. Manufactured goods can have their real prices raised by policy; corn cannot. Import duties as home market monopoly. Cross-reference: 4.2 on import restrictions, 4.5.29 for the resolution.

refashioned: But when the same measures raise the nominal or money price of corn, they do not raise its real value. They do not increase the real wealth or real revenue of farmers or country gentlemen, because they do not enable them to maintain and employ more laborers. Nature has stamped upon corn a real value that cannot be altered by merely changing its money price. No export bounty or home market monopoly can raise that value. The freest competition cannot lower it. Throughout the world, corn's real value equals the quantity of labor it can maintain. In every particular place, it equals the quantity of labor it can maintain at the prevailing standard of living -- whether liberal, moderate, or scanty. Woolen or linen cloth are not the standard commodities by which the real value of all other goods must be finally measured. Corn is.
elegant: Raising corn's money price does not raise its real value -- it cannot enable farmers to employ more labor. Nature has fixed corn's real value at the quantity of labor it can maintain, and no policy can change this. Competition cannot lower it; monopoly cannot raise it. Corn, not manufactured cloth, is the ultimate measure of all real values.
summary: Unlike manufactured goods, corn has a natural real value -- the labor it can sustain -- that no policy can alter. Export bounties and import monopolies can change its money price but not its real value. Corn is the economy's true unit of account.
distilled: Corn's real value is fixed by nature at the labor it can sustain -- no bounty or monopoly can change it, because corn is the ultimate measure of all real values.
notes: Core theoretical claim: corn's real value is a natural constant, unlike manufactured goods. Corn as the 'regulating commodity' and ultimate numeraire. This is why the corn bounty fails where manufacturing bounties succeed. Cross-reference: Book I, Ch. 5 on real vs. nominal price, and Ch. 11 on corn as measure of value.

refashioned: The real value of every other commodity is ultimately measured by the ratio of its average money price to the average money price of corn. The real value of corn itself does not vary with the fluctuations in its average money price that sometimes occur from one century to another. It is the real value of silver that varies with them.
elegant: Every commodity's real value is measured against corn's money price. When corn's money price fluctuates over centuries, it is silver's real value changing, not corn's.
summary: All real values are measured relative to corn's price. Century-scale fluctuations in corn's money price reflect changes in silver's value, not corn's.
distilled: Corn is the fixed standard of real value; long-term changes in its money price actually measure changes in silver's value.
notes: Corn as invariable standard of value -- a position debated by later economists including Ricardo and Marx. Inverts the common assumption: it is money, not corn, whose value fluctuates. Cross-reference: Book I, Ch. 5 and Ch. 11.

refashioned: Bounties on the export of any domestic commodity are subject, first, to the general objection against all mercantilist measures: they force part of the country's industry into a less advantageous channel than it would follow naturally. Second, they are subject to the particular objection of forcing industry not merely into a less advantageous channel, but into a positively disadvantageous one -- since any trade that can only be conducted by means of a bounty is necessarily a losing trade. The corn bounty faces the additional objection that it cannot even promote the production of the very commodity it was designed to encourage. When our country gentlemen demanded the bounty, they imitated merchants and manufacturers but lacked their accurate understanding of self-interest. They burdened the public revenue with a very considerable expense. They imposed a very heavy tax on the entire population. Yet they did not meaningfully increase the real value of their commodity. And by somewhat lowering the real value of silver, they discouraged the country's general industry and, instead of advancing, actually retarded the improvement of their own lands -- which necessarily depends on the country's general prosperity.
elegant: Export bounties are doubly objectionable: they divert industry into less profitable channels, and since bounty-dependent trade is inherently unprofitable, they push it into actively losing ones. The corn bounty adds a third flaw: it cannot even promote the production it targets. Country gentlemen burdened the public, taxed the population, failed to raise corn's real value, and by depressing silver's value actually retarded the improvement of their own lands.
summary: Export bounties divert industry into unprofitable channels. The corn bounty is worse still: it cannot promote corn production, heavily taxes the public, and by degrading silver's value, actually retards agricultural improvement and general industry.
distilled: The corn bounty is triply defective: it misallocates industry, subsidizes inherently unprofitable trade, and cannot even achieve its stated goal of promoting corn production.
notes: Three-level critique: general anti-mercantilist objection, specific losing-trade objection, and corn-specific objection. Country gentlemen as less sophisticated rent-seekers than manufacturers. The bounty retards the very improvement it claims to promote -- a supreme irony. Cross-reference: 4.2 on misallocation of industry.

refashioned: To encourage production of any commodity, a bounty on production would seem to work more directly than one on export. It would impose only one tax on the people -- the bounty itself -- instead of two. Rather than raising the domestic price, it would tend to lower it, at least partially repaying the public for their contribution to the bounty. Yet production bounties have been very rarely granted. The mercantilist prejudice has taught us to believe that national wealth comes more directly from exports than from production, and so exports have been favored as the more direct means of bringing money into the country. Production bounties, it has also been claimed, are more liable to fraud -- how accurately, I cannot say. Certainly export bounties have been extensively abused for fraudulent purposes. But the merchants and manufacturers who invented these schemes have no interest in seeing the home market overstocked, which a production bounty might sometimes cause. An export bounty, by enabling them to send their surplus abroad while keeping up the home price, effectively prevents oversupply. It is therefore the mercantilist expedient they are fondest of. I have known manufacturers in certain trades to agree privately to pay an export bounty out of their own pockets on a certain proportion of their goods. This succeeded so well that it more than doubled the home market price, despite a considerable increase in production. If the corn bounty has lowered the money price of corn, its operation must have been wonderfully different.
elegant: A production bounty would be more logical: one tax instead of two, lower domestic prices, and a direct incentive. But merchants prefer export bounties because they prevent home market oversupply and keep domestic prices high. Production bounties are rare because the mercantilist doctrine values export over production. Private manufacturers have even paid export bounties from their own pockets, successfully doubling home prices. If the corn bounty somehow lowered corn prices, it would be a unique miracle.
summary: Production bounties would be more effective and less burdensome than export bounties, imposing one tax instead of two. But merchants prefer export bounties because they prevent domestic oversupply. Private manufacturers have voluntarily paid export bounties to raise home prices, proving the mechanism works against consumers.
distilled: Production bounties would be superior to export bounties, but merchants prefer export bounties precisely because they keep domestic prices high rather than lowering them.
notes: Production vs. export bounties -- a key policy distinction. Export bounties serve producer interests by maintaining domestic scarcity. Private bounty example proves the price-raising mechanism empirically. Merchants' revealed preference for export bounties exposes the real motive. Cross-reference: 4.5.8 on the double tax.

refashioned: Something resembling a production bounty has, however, been granted on certain occasions. The tonnage bounties given to the white herring and whale fisheries may perhaps be considered of this nature. They tend, presumably, to make these goods cheaper in the home market than they otherwise would be. In other respects, however, their effects are the same as export bounties: they employ part of the country's capital in bringing goods to market whose price does not repay the cost, together with ordinary profits on the capital invested.
elegant: The tonnage bounties for herring and whale fisheries resemble production bounties, potentially lowering domestic prices. But their broader effect is the same as export bounties: they divert capital into activities where the sale price cannot cover costs plus normal profits.
summary: Tonnage bounties on herring and whale fisheries are a form of production bounty that may lower domestic prices but still divert capital into unprofitable activities where revenues cannot cover costs and normal returns.
distilled: Fishery tonnage bounties resemble production bounties but still misallocate capital into trades where sale prices cannot cover costs and normal profits.
notes: Transition to the fishery bounty case study. Production bounty variant that still shares the fundamental flaw of subsidizing unprofitable activity. Cross-reference: 4.5.32 on production vs. export bounties.

refashioned: Although the tonnage bounties for fisheries do not contribute to national wealth, it may be argued that they contribute to national defense by increasing the number of sailors and ships. This, it may be claimed, can sometimes be achieved through such bounties at much less expense than by maintaining a large permanent navy -- in the same way that bounties might substitute for a standing army.
elegant: Fishery bounties may not increase national wealth, but their defense justification -- building a reserve of sailors and ships more cheaply than maintaining a standing navy -- deserves consideration.
summary: The fishery bounties' only defensible purpose is national security: building a reserve of sailors and ships at less cost than a permanent navy. Smith will examine whether even this justification holds up.
distilled: The sole plausible defense of fishery bounties is that they build naval capacity more cheaply than maintaining a standing navy.
notes: Defense exception to free trade -- one of Smith's few acknowledged justifications for intervention (see also Navigation Acts discussion). Parallels the standing army debate. Sets up the detailed critique that follows.

refashioned:
Notwithstanding these favorable arguments, the following considerations lead me to believe that in granting at least one of these bounties, the legislature has been grossly deceived.

First, the herring-buss bounty appears to be far too large.
elegant: Despite the defense argument, the legislature has been grossly deceived in granting these bounties. First, the herring-buss bounty is far too generous.
summary: Smith begins his detailed critique of the herring bounty by asserting the legislature was deceived, starting with the objection that the bounty is excessively large.
distilled: The legislature was grossly deceived in granting fishery bounties, beginning with the herring-buss bounty being far too generous.
notes: Opens a four-part empirical critique of the herring fishery bounty. 'Grossly imposed upon' -- strong language suggesting lobbying by interested parties. Buss = decked fishing vessel.

refashioned: From the start of the 1771 winter fishing season through the end of 1781, the tonnage bounty on the herring-buss fishery was thirty shillings per ton. During these eleven years, the total catch amounted to 378,347 barrels. Herrings caught and cured at sea are called sea-sticks. To make them into merchantable herrings, they must be repacked with additional salt, and three barrels of sea-sticks typically yield two barrels of merchantable herrings. The merchantable herrings caught during these eleven years therefore amounted to only about 252,231 barrels. The tonnage bounties paid during this period totaled 155,463 pounds, eleven shillings -- or eight shillings and twopence-farthing per barrel of sea-sticks, and twelve shillings and threepence-three-farthings per barrel of merchantable herrings.
elegant: Over eleven years (1771-1781), the herring-buss fishery caught 378,347 barrels of sea-sticks, yielding about 252,231 barrels of merchantable herrings after repacking. Tonnage bounties paid totaled over 155,000 pounds -- about eight shillings per barrel of sea-sticks and over twelve shillings per barrel of merchantable herrings.
summary: Between 1771 and 1781, the herring bounty cost over 155,000 pounds for a catch that, when processed into merchantable herrings, amounted to about 252,000 barrels -- a bounty of over twelve shillings per saleable barrel.
distilled: The herring bounty cost over twelve shillings per barrel of merchantable herrings across an eleven-year period -- an enormous subsidy per unit of output.
notes: Detailed empirical evidence of bounty costs. Sea-sticks vs. merchantable herrings -- a 3:2 conversion ratio inflates the per-unit cost. Smith's use of official customs data to build the case. The bounty per barrel is a substantial fraction of the final selling price.

refashioned: The salt used for curing these herrings is sometimes Scottish, sometimes foreign, both delivered duty-free to fish-curers. The excise duty on Scottish salt is one shilling sixpence per bushel, on foreign salt ten shillings. A barrel of herrings requires about one and a quarter bushels of foreign salt or two bushels of Scottish salt. If the herrings are entered for export, none of the duty is paid. If for home consumption, only one shilling per barrel is paid regardless of salt type -- the old Scottish duty on the quantity thought necessary for one barrel. Foreign salt is little used in Scotland except for curing fish. From April 1771 to April 1782, 936,974 bushels of foreign salt were imported at eighty-four pounds per bushel, while only 168,226 bushels of Scottish salt were delivered to fish-curers at fifty-six pounds per bushel. The fisheries clearly use mainly foreign salt. Beyond the tonnage bounty, there is also an export bounty of two shillings and eightpence per barrel, and more than two-thirds of buss-caught herrings are exported. Adding everything together: during these eleven years, every barrel of buss-caught herrings cured with Scottish salt cost the government seventeen shillings and elevenpence-three-farthings when exported, and fourteen shillings and threepence-three-farthings when sold domestically. Every barrel cured with foreign salt cost one pound, seven shillings, and fivepence-three-farthings when exported, and one pound, three shillings, and ninepence-three-farthings when sold domestically. A barrel of good merchantable herrings sells for between seventeen and twenty-five shillings -- about a guinea on average.
elegant: Including salt duty exemptions and the export bounty of two shillings eightpence per barrel, the total government cost per barrel of herring becomes staggering. Herrings cured with foreign salt -- the dominant method -- cost the government over twenty-seven shillings per exported barrel. Yet a barrel of merchantable herrings sells for only about a guinea. The subsidy approaches or exceeds the market price of the product itself.
summary: When all subsidies are tallied -- tonnage bounty, salt duty exemptions, and export bounty -- the government cost per barrel of herring cured with foreign salt exceeds twenty-seven shillings for exports, while the market price averages only about a guinea. The subsidy rivals the product's selling price.
distilled: The total government subsidy per barrel of exported herring nearly equals or exceeds the barrel's market selling price of about one guinea.
notes: Comprehensive cost accounting including hidden subsidies (salt duty exemption). Foreign salt dominates despite being more expensive -- revealing the fishery's dependence on subsidy. The subsidy-to-price ratio approaches 100%, making this essentially government-purchased fish. Cross-reference: accounts referenced at end of Book IV.

refashioned: Second, the white-herring bounty is a tonnage bounty, proportioned to the ship's burden rather than to its diligence or success in fishing. It has, I am afraid, been too common for vessels to fit out solely to catch the bounty rather than the fish. In 1759, when the bounty was fifty shillings per ton, the entire Scottish buss fishery brought in only four barrels of sea-sticks. That year, each barrel of sea-sticks cost the government in bounties alone 113 pounds and fifteen shillings. Each barrel of merchantable herrings cost 159 pounds, seven shillings, and sixpence.
elegant: The bounty rewards ship tonnage, not fishing success -- creating an incentive to catch bounties rather than fish. In 1759, at fifty shillings per ton, Scotland's entire buss fishery produced just four barrels. The government paid over 113 pounds per barrel of raw catch and nearly 160 pounds per barrel of merchantable herrings.
summary: Because the bounty rewards ship tonnage rather than catch size, vessels were fitted out to collect bounties rather than fish. In 1759, the entire Scottish buss fishery caught only four barrels, costing the government nearly 160 pounds per barrel of merchantable herrings.
distilled: The tonnage-based bounty incentivized catching bounties rather than fish, producing the absurdity of 160 pounds in government subsidy per barrel of herrings in 1759.
notes: Classic moral hazard / perverse incentive example -- paying for inputs (tonnage) rather than outputs (fish). The 1759 data point is devastating: 159 pounds per barrel vs. a market price of about one guinea. One of the most striking examples of subsidy waste in economic literature.

refashioned: Third, the mode of fishing for which the tonnage bounty has been given -- using busses, or decked vessels of twenty to eighty tons -- seems poorly suited to Scotland, though well adapted to Holland, from whose practice it was borrowed. Holland lies far from the seas where herrings mainly gather, so the Dutch must use large decked vessels capable of carrying water and provisions for distant voyages. But the Hebrides, the Shetland Islands, and the northern and northwestern Scottish coasts -- where the herring fishery is principally carried on -- are everywhere intersected by arms of the sea that extend deep into the land, locally called sea-lochs. Herrings resort mainly to these sea-lochs during their visits to these waters, though these visits are not entirely regular. A boat-fishery, therefore -- where fishers carry their catch ashore immediately to be cured or consumed fresh -- would be the mode best adapted to Scotland's particular geography. But the generous thirty-shilling-per-ton bounty for the buss fishery necessarily discourages the boat-fishery, which, receiving no such bounty, cannot bring cured fish to market on equal terms. The boat-fishery, which before the buss bounty was very considerable and reportedly employed as many seamen as the buss fishery now does, has nearly disappeared. Of this once-thriving fishery's former extent, I must admit I cannot speak with much precision, since no bounty was paid on boat outfits and therefore no official records were kept.
elegant: The buss-fishery model was borrowed from Holland, where distant fishing grounds require large decked vessels. But Scotland's geography -- sea-lochs running deep inland where herrings actually gather -- is perfectly suited to small boat-fishing, landing catches immediately for curing. The buss bounty destroyed this more appropriate boat-fishery by making it uncompetitive. The once-thriving boat-fishery has nearly vanished, though its former scale is hard to document since no bounty meant no official records.
summary: The buss bounty was modeled on Dutch practice unsuited to Scotland's geography. Scotland's sea-lochs favor small boat-fishing, but the bounty made the boat-fishery uncompetitive. This once-substantial industry has nearly vanished, its former extent poorly documented because it received no subsidies and thus generated no official records.
distilled: The buss bounty destroyed Scotland's geographically superior boat-fishery by subsidizing an imported Dutch fishing model unsuited to Scottish sea-lochs.
notes: Policy transfer failure -- borrowing institutions without considering local conditions. The bounty destroyed the more efficient existing industry. Survivorship bias in data: only subsidized activity gets recorded. Sea-lochs as natural advantage wasted by misguided policy.

refashioned: Fourth, in many parts of Scotland, herrings are an important part of the common people's diet during certain seasons. A bounty that lowered herring prices in the home market could significantly benefit many of our fellow subjects whose circumstances are far from affluent. But the herring-buss bounty serves no such good purpose. It has ruined the boat-fishery, which was by far the best suited for supplying the home market. And the additional export bounty of two shillings and eightpence per barrel sends the greater part -- more than two-thirds -- of the buss catch abroad. Thirty to forty years ago, before the buss bounty was established, sixteen shillings per barrel was reportedly the common herring price. Ten to fifteen years ago, before the boat-fishery was entirely ruined, the price was said to range from seventeen to twenty shillings. For the last five years, it has averaged twenty-five shillings -- though this may partly reflect genuine scarcity of herrings off the Scottish coast. I should note too that the barrel itself, whose price is included in all these figures, has roughly doubled since the American war, from about three to six shillings. And the accounts I have received of earlier prices have not been entirely consistent; one very accurate and experienced authority assured me that more than fifty years ago a guinea was the usual price, which I believe may still be considered the long-run average. All accounts agree, however, that the buss bounty has not lowered herring prices in the home market.
elegant: The buss bounty has failed the Scottish poor who depend on herrings. It ruined the boat-fishery best suited for home supply, while the export bounty sends two-thirds of the catch abroad. Herring prices have risen, not fallen: from sixteen shillings before the buss bounty to twenty-five shillings recently. Though some increase reflects genuine scarcity and wartime barrel costs, all sources agree the bounty has not lowered domestic herring prices.
summary: The herring bounty has harmed the Scottish poor it might have helped. It destroyed the boat-fishery that supplied the home market, sent most of the catch abroad via export bounties, and failed to lower domestic herring prices, which have actually risen substantially.
distilled: The herring bounty destroyed the domestic boat-fishery, diverted most catch to exports, and raised rather than lowered the domestic price of herrings that Scotland's poor depend on.
notes: Consumer welfare analysis -- the bounty harms the very population it could help. Price evidence: 16s -> 25s per barrel despite the bounty. Confounding factors honestly acknowledged (scarcity, barrel costs, American war). Smith's intellectual honesty about data limitations strengthens rather than weakens the argument.

refashioned: When fishing ventures continue selling their product at the same or higher prices despite such generous bounties, one might expect their profits to be very great. And some individuals may indeed have profited handsomely. But in general, I have every reason to believe otherwise. The usual effect of such bounties is to encourage reckless entrepreneurs to enter a business they do not understand. What they lose through negligence and ignorance more than offsets all the government's generosity. In 1750, the same act that established the thirty-shilling tonnage bounty created a joint-stock company with 500,000 pounds in capital. Subscribers received, beyond the tonnage bounty and export bounty and duty-free salt, an annual payment of three pounds for every hundred pounds subscribed, paid by the customs revenue for fourteen years. Alongside this great London-based company, smaller fishing chambers could be established in any port with at least 10,000 pounds in subscribed capital, enjoying identical subsidies. The great company's subscription was quickly filled, and several regional chambers were established. Despite all these encouragements, almost all of them -- large and small -- lost either their entire capital or the greater part of it. Scarcely a trace remains of any of them, and the white-herring fishery is now carried on almost entirely by private adventurers.
elegant: Despite lavish bounties, most fishing ventures lost money. Subsidies attracted reckless entrepreneurs who did not understand the business, and their losses exceeded all government generosity. A joint-stock company with 500,000 pounds in capital, plus numerous regional fishing chambers, all received tonnage bounties, export bounties, duty-free salt, and direct government annuities. Almost all lost their entire capital. The fishery is now carried on by private adventurers alone.
summary: Generous bounties attracted incompetent speculators whose losses exceeded all subsidies. A major joint-stock company and numerous regional fishing chambers, despite receiving every possible form of government support, nearly all lost their entire capital and disappeared.
distilled: Fishery bounties attracted reckless speculators who lost more through incompetence than they gained from subsidies, destroying nearly every subsidized fishing company.
notes: Adverse selection in subsidized industries -- bounties attract the incompetent. Echoes the joint-stock company critique in Book V. Government failure: subsidies cannot substitute for business competence. The private adventurers who survived without special subsidy proved more capable -- a market selection argument.

refashioned: If a particular manufacture were truly necessary for national defense, it might not always be wise to depend on foreign nations for its supply. If such a manufacture could not otherwise be sustained at home, it might not be unreasonable to tax all other industries in order to support it. The bounties on the export of British-made sailcloth and British-made gunpowder may perhaps be defended on this principle.
elegant: If a manufacture is essential for national defense and cannot survive without support, taxing other industries to sustain it may be justified. Export bounties on British sailcloth and gunpowder can perhaps be defended on these grounds.
summary: Smith acknowledges a defense exception: if a manufacture is essential to national security and cannot survive unaided, subsidizing it through taxes on other industries may be justified, as with sailcloth and gunpowder bounties.
distilled: Defense-essential manufactures that cannot survive without support may justifiably be subsidized, as with sailcloth and gunpowder bounties.
notes: Defense exception to free trade -- one of Smith's limited concessions to intervention. Parallels the Navigation Acts defense. National security as a legitimate reason to sacrifice economic efficiency. Cross-reference: 4.2 on the Navigation Acts.

refashioned: But though it can very rarely be reasonable to tax the general public to support a particular class of manufacturers, yet in times of great prosperity -- when the public revenue exceeds what the government knows how to spend well -- granting bounties to favored manufactures may be as natural as incurring any other idle expense. In public as in private life, great wealth may perhaps frequently be accepted as an excuse for great folly. But there must surely be something more than ordinarily absurd in continuing such extravagance during times of general difficulty and distress.
elegant: Subsidizing favored industries during prosperity may be excusable folly -- wealth often excuses waste, publicly as privately. But continuing such extravagance during times of hardship and fiscal strain is absurd beyond all ordinary folly.
summary: Granting bounties to favored industries may be excusable during prosperity as an indulgence of excess revenue. But maintaining such subsidies during periods of national difficulty and fiscal distress is inexcusable folly.
distilled: Subsidies to favored industries might be excused during prosperity but become absurd during periods of national hardship and fiscal strain.
notes: Fiscal prudence argument against bounties. Distinguishes between luxury spending in good times and irresponsible spending in bad times. Contextual -- likely referring to the fiscal pressures of the American Revolutionary War period.

refashioned: What is called a bounty is sometimes really just a drawback, and therefore not open to the same objections as a true bounty. For example, the bounty on exported refined sugar can be seen as a drawback of the duties on the brown and muscovado sugars from which it is made. The bounty on exported wrought silk is a drawback of duties on imported raw and thrown silk. The bounty on exported gunpowder is a drawback of duties on imported brimstone and saltpeter. In customs terminology, only allowances on goods exported in the same form as they were imported are called drawbacks. When manufacturing has transformed the goods enough to give them a new name, the allowance is called a bounty.
elegant: Some 'bounties' are really drawbacks -- refunds of import duties on raw materials embodied in exports. The refined sugar bounty refunds duties on raw sugar; the wrought silk bounty refunds duties on raw silk. Customs terminology reserves 'drawback' for goods exported unchanged, but calls it a 'bounty' when manufacturing has transformed them.
summary: Some nominal bounties are actually drawbacks -- refunds of import duties on raw materials that have been manufactured into new products. These are not subject to the same objections as genuine bounties, being merely a terminological distinction in customs law.
distilled: Some so-called bounties are really drawbacks of import duties on raw materials, differing from true bounties only in customs terminology.
notes: Important policy distinction: drawback-bounties vs. genuine bounties. Drawbacks restore free trade conditions by removing the distortion of input tariffs. No net subsidy if the bounty merely offsets earlier duties. Cross-reference: 4.4 on drawbacks.

refashioned: Premiums given by the public to artists and manufacturers who excel in their particular occupations are not subject to the same objections as bounties. By encouraging extraordinary skill and ingenuity, they sustain the competitive spirit among workers in those occupations. They are not large enough to divert toward any one industry a greater share of national capital than would flow there naturally. Their tendency is not to distort the natural balance of employment, but to make the work done in each occupation as perfect and complete as possible. The cost of premiums, moreover, is trivial, while the cost of bounties is enormous. The corn bounty alone has sometimes cost the public more than 300,000 pounds in a single year.
elegant: Premiums for exceptional skill differ fundamentally from bounties. They are too small to distort capital allocation, instead encouraging excellence within each trade without overturning the natural balance of employment. Their cost is trivial. The corn bounty alone has cost over 300,000 pounds in a single year.
summary: Public premiums for exceptional workmanship are benign, unlike bounties. They encourage excellence without distorting capital allocation, cost very little, and preserve the natural balance of industries. Bounties, by contrast, are enormously expensive.
distilled: Premiums for skill encourage excellence without distorting capital flows, costing trivially compared to bounties that can exceed 300,000 pounds per year.
notes: Premiums vs. bounties -- incentive for quality vs. subsidy for quantity. Premiums preserve market signals while encouraging marginal improvement. Key principle: policy should enhance quality within natural market allocation, not redirect capital flows. The 300,000 pound figure dramatizes the cost difference.

refashioned:
Bounties are sometimes called premiums, and drawbacks are sometimes called bounties. But in all cases we must attend to the nature of the thing itself, without being misled by the word.

Digression concerning the Corn Trade and Corn Laws.
elegant:
Bounties, premiums, and drawbacks are often mislabeled. Always examine the substance of a policy, not its name.

[Beginning of Digression on the Corn Trade and Corn Laws.]
summary: Smith warns against confusing policy types based on terminology. One must examine the actual nature of each measure. He then introduces his detailed digression on the corn trade and corn laws.
distilled: Policy must be judged by its substance, not its label -- a principle Smith applies as he begins his digression on the corn trade.
notes: Methodological principle: substance over semantics in policy analysis. Transitional passage introducing the major Digression on Corn. This digression is one of the longest and most detailed analytical sections in the Wealth of Nations.

refashioned: I cannot conclude this chapter on bounties without observing that the praise heaped upon the corn export bounty and its associated system of regulations is entirely undeserved. A careful examination of the corn trade and the principal British laws governing it will demonstrate this conclusively. The great importance of the subject must justify the length of this digression.
elegant: The praise lavished on the corn bounty and its regulatory system is wholly unmerited, as a careful examination of the corn trade and British corn laws will demonstrate. The subject's importance justifies a thorough digression.
summary: Smith declares that the corn bounty's reputation is undeserved and announces a detailed digression examining the corn trade and British corn laws to prove it.
distilled: The corn bounty's high reputation is entirely undeserved, as Smith's forthcoming examination of the corn trade and corn laws will demonstrate.
notes: Sets up the Digression on Corn Trade proper. Smith's confidence in his argument is evident. The digression covers the four branches of the corn trade and their legal framework.

refashioned: The corn merchant's trade comprises four distinct branches, which though sometimes conducted by the same person, are by their nature four separate trades. These are: first, the inland dealer's trade; second, the merchant-importer's trade, bringing foreign corn for home consumption; third, the merchant-exporter's trade, sending domestic corn abroad for foreign consumption; and fourth, the carrying trade -- importing corn in order to re-export it.
elegant: The corn trade has four distinct branches: the inland dealer, the importer for home consumption, the exporter of domestic corn, and the carrier who imports in order to re-export. Each follows different logic though sometimes the same person conducts all four.
summary: Smith identifies four distinct branches of the corn trade: inland dealing, importing for domestic consumption, exporting domestic production, and the carrying trade of importing to re-export.
distilled: The corn trade comprises four distinct branches: inland dealing, importing for consumption, exporting domestic production, and carrying (importing to re-export).
notes: Analytical framework for the Digression -- each branch will be examined for its contribution to public welfare. Systematic taxonomy typical of Smith's method. Each branch has different implications for the home market.

refashioned: First: the interest of the inland dealer and the interest of the general public, however opposite they may appear at first glance, are in years of even the greatest scarcity exactly the same. It is in the dealer's interest to raise the price of his corn as high as the real scarcity of the season demands, and it can never be in his interest to raise it higher. By raising the price, he discourages consumption and puts everyone -- particularly the lower ranks -- on a regimen of thrift and careful management. If he raises the price too high and discourages consumption so much that the season's supply will outlast demand and carry over until the next crop arrives, he risks not only losing a considerable portion of his corn to natural spoilage but being forced to sell the remainder for much less than he could have received months earlier. If, on the other hand, he does not raise the price high enough and consumption runs ahead of supply, he not only loses profit he might otherwise have made but exposes the people to suffering, before the season ends, not merely the hardships of a dearth but the dreadful horrors of a famine.
elegant: The inland corn dealer's interest and the public's are identical, even in severe scarcity. He profits by pricing corn to match the real shortage -- discouraging overconsumption and stretching supply through the season. Price too high, and he is stuck with spoiling surplus. Price too low, and supplies run out early, turning dearth into famine. His self-interest naturally rations the supply optimally.
summary: The inland corn dealer's self-interest aligns perfectly with the public interest. He profits most by pricing corn to match the real scarcity, rationing supply through the season. Overpricing leaves him with spoiling surplus; underpricing risks famine.
distilled: The inland corn dealer's profit motive naturally leads him to price corn at exactly the level that optimally rations scarce supply through the season.
notes: Invisible hand applied to grain markets -- self-interest produces socially optimal rationing. Price as information and allocation mechanism. The dealer as unintentional social planner. Sets up the comparison with government price-fixing in 4.5.56. Cross-reference: 'invisible hand' passage in 4.2.

refashioned: It is in the people's interest that their daily, weekly, and monthly consumption be proportioned as exactly as possible to the season's supply. The inland corn dealer's interest is the same. By supplying consumers in approximately this proportion, he is likely to sell all his corn at the highest price with the greatest profit. His knowledge of the crop's condition and of his daily, weekly, and monthly sales enables him to judge, with reasonable accuracy, how closely supply and demand are actually balanced. Without intending to serve the public interest, he is led by regard for his own interest to treat the people, even in years of scarcity, much as a prudent ship captain is sometimes obliged to treat his crew.
elegant: The people need consumption rationed evenly through the season; so does the dealer, to maximize his returns. His market knowledge enables him to judge the balance of supply and demand. Self-interest, not benevolence, leads him to ration the public as a prudent captain rations his crew.
summary: The dealer's profit motive drives him to ration corn sales evenly through the season, matching consumption to supply. His market knowledge makes him the best-informed agent for this task. Self-interest leads him to serve the public as a prudent captain serves his crew.
distilled: Self-interest and market knowledge lead the corn dealer to ration supply through the season as carefully as a prudent captain rations provisions for his crew.
notes: Ship captain metaphor for natural rationing through price. Information advantage of market participants over regulators. Self-interest as invisible social coordinator. Cross-reference: Book I on the butcher/brewer/baker passage; Book IV on the invisible hand.

refashioned: When a ship's captain foresees that provisions are likely to run short, he puts his crew on short allowance. Even if excessive caution sometimes leads him to do this unnecessarily, the inconvenience to his crew is trivial compared to the danger, misery, and ruin they might face from a less careful approach. In the same way, even if excessive greed sometimes leads the inland corn merchant to raise prices somewhat higher than the season's scarcity requires, the inconvenience to the people from this conduct -- which effectively secures them against famine by the season's end -- is trivial compared to what they might suffer from more liberal selling early in the season. The merchant himself is most likely to suffer from his own excessive greed: not only from the public outrage it typically provokes, but even if he escapes that, from the unsold corn left on his hands at the season's end, which -- if the next season proves favorable -- he must sell for much less than he could have gotten earlier.
elegant: A ship captain who over-rations causes minor discomfort; one who under-rations risks disaster. Similarly, a corn dealer who overprices causes inconvenience but prevents famine, while underpricing invites catastrophe. The dealer himself suffers most from overpricing -- through public hostility and unsold surplus. His self-interest naturally corrects the error.
summary: Like a cautious ship captain, a corn dealer who errs on the side of high prices causes minor inconvenience but prevents famine. The dealer himself bears the greatest cost of overpricing through public anger and unsold inventory, so self-interest naturally corrects the tendency.
distilled: A corn dealer who overprices causes minor inconvenience but prevents famine, and his own self-interest -- through unsold surplus and public hostility -- naturally corrects any excess.
notes: Asymmetric risk analysis: overpricing is self-correcting, underpricing leads to catastrophe. The market has a built-in error-correction mechanism. Self-interest as automatic regulator. Cross-reference: 4.5.49-50 on the dealer's aligned incentives.

refashioned: If it were possible for a single great company to monopolize an entire country's corn harvest, it might indeed be in their interest -- as the Dutch are said to do with the Moluccan spice trade -- to destroy or discard a large portion in order to keep up the price of the rest. But it is nearly impossible, even by force of law, to establish such a comprehensive monopoly over corn. And wherever the law leaves the trade free, corn is the commodity least susceptible to being cornered or monopolized by a few large capitalists buying up the greater part. Not only does its total value far exceed what a few private fortunes could purchase, but the way it is produced makes such a purchase entirely impracticable. Being the commodity with the greatest annual consumption in every civilized country, a greater quantity of industry is employed in producing corn than in producing anything else.
elegant: A single company might profit by destroying part of its monopolized supply, as the Dutch supposedly do with Moluccan spices. But monopolizing a nation's corn is nearly impossible. Its total value exceeds any combination of private fortunes, and its dispersed production makes cornering the market impracticable. Corn employs more industry and involves greater annual consumption than any other commodity.
summary: Unlike spices, corn cannot be monopolized. Its total value exceeds any private fortune, its production is too dispersed for cornering, and it involves more annual consumption and production than any other commodity. The feared engrossing of corn is practically impossible.
distilled: Corn cannot be monopolized because its total value exceeds private fortunes, its production is vastly dispersed, and it is the most heavily consumed and produced commodity in any economy.
notes: Natural monopoly resistance of agricultural staples -- scale, dispersal, and volume prevent cornering. Contrast with the Dutch East India Company's actual spice monopoly. Structural market competition argument. Cross-reference: Book I on natural vs. artificial monopolies.

refashioned: When corn first comes from the ground, it is necessarily divided among more owners than any other commodity. These owners are scattered across the entire country, unlike independent manufacturers who can be gathered in one place. They either supply consumers in their own neighborhood directly, or supply other inland dealers who serve those consumers. Inland corn dealers -- including both farmers and bakers -- are therefore more numerous than dealers in any other commodity, and their dispersed locations make any general combination among them entirely impossible. If, in a year of scarcity, any dealer found himself with more corn than he could expect to sell at the current price before the season ended, he would never maintain that price at his own expense for the sole benefit of his rivals. He would immediately lower his price to dispose of his stock before the new crop arrived.
elegant: Corn is initially divided among more scattered owners than any other commodity. Inland dealers -- farmers and bakers alike -- are too numerous and dispersed for any combination. In scarcity, no dealer would maintain an unsustainable price that benefits only his competitors. He would immediately cut prices to clear his stock before the new harvest.
summary: Corn's ownership is uniquely dispersed among scattered farmers, making dealer collusion impossible. Competition ensures that any dealer with excess stock will lower prices rather than hold them up for competitors' benefit.
distilled: The extreme dispersal of corn ownership among scattered producers makes dealer collusion impossible, as competitive pressure forces individual sellers to cut prices rather than maintain them for rivals' benefit.
notes: Structural impossibility of corn cartel -- geographic dispersal, numerous participants, and competitive incentives. Game theory logic: no individual dealer benefits from unilateral price maintenance. Free-rider problem prevents collusion. Cross-reference: Book I on competition among sellers.

refashioned:
The same motives and interests that govern one dealer's conduct would govern every other's, compelling all of them to sell their corn at whatever price best suits the scarcity or plenty of the season.

Anyone who examines carefully the history of dearths and famines in Europe over the present and two preceding centuries -- many of which are well documented -- will find, I believe, that no dearth has ever arisen from any combination among inland corn dealers, nor from any cause other than genuine scarcity, usually from bad seasons and occasionally from the destruction of war. And that no famine has ever arisen from anything other than the violence of government attempting, through improper means, to remedy the difficulties of a dearth.
elegant: Competitive pressure forces all dealers to price corn according to the real scarcity. European history confirms this: dearths have always resulted from genuine scarcity -- bad weather or war -- never from dealer conspiracies. Famines, by contrast, have arisen only from government violence attempting to fix dearths through improper intervention.
summary: Competition ensures all corn dealers price according to real scarcity. Historical evidence shows dearths come from natural scarcity, never dealer conspiracies. Famines arise only when governments intervene improperly, turning manageable dearths into catastrophes.
distilled: Dearths come from nature, never from dealer conspiracies; famines come from government intervention, never from free markets.
notes: Powerful historical generalization: markets cause dearths at worst; governments cause famines. Empirical claim based on European economic history. Distinction between dearth (manageable scarcity) and famine (catastrophic shortage). Government as the true cause of famine -- a thesis echoed by Amartya Sen centuries later.

refashioned: In any large corn-producing country with free internal trade, even the most unfavorable seasons can never cause a scarcity severe enough to produce famine. Even the scantiest harvest, if managed with frugality and economy, will feed through the year the same number of people who would normally be supplied more generously by a moderately plentiful crop. The worst seasons involve either extreme drought or extreme rain. But since corn grows on both high and low land, on ground prone to being too wet and on ground prone to being too dry, what harms one part of the country often benefits another. In both wet and dry seasons, the crop is smaller than a well-balanced year would produce, but what is lost in one area is partly compensated by gains in another. In rice-growing countries, where the crop requires very wet soil and must be flooded at a certain stage, drought has much more devastating effects. Yet even there, drought is probably never so universal as to cause famine by itself -- if the government allows free trade. The drought in Bengal a few years ago would probably have caused only a severe dearth. Improper regulations and injudicious restraints imposed by servants of the East India Company on the rice trade contributed, perhaps, to turning that dearth into a famine.
elegant: In a large country with free internal trade, even terrible seasons cannot produce famine. Drought harms lowlands but benefits highlands; excess rain does the opposite. The worst harvests, carefully managed, can still feed the population. Even in rice countries, where drought is more devastating, famine requires government mismanagement. The Bengal famine was likely worsened by East India Company trade restrictions turning a dearth into a catastrophe.
summary: Free internal trade prevents famine even in the worst seasons, because geographic diversity means no weather event is uniformly devastating. The Bengal famine illustrates how government trade restrictions can turn a manageable dearth into a catastrophe.
distilled: Geographic crop diversity in large countries prevents famine under free trade; government restrictions -- as in the Bengal famine -- are what turn dearths into catastrophes.
notes: Natural geographic hedging argument -- crop diversity across terrain reduces aggregate risk. Free trade as famine prevention. Bengal famine (1770) as case study in policy-induced catastrophe. East India Company as irresponsible quasi-government. Anticipates Amartya Sen's entitlement approach to famine.

refashioned: When a government, seeking to remedy a dearth, orders all dealers to sell their corn at what it considers a reasonable price, it either prevents them from bringing corn to market at all -- which can produce famine at the very beginning of the season -- or, if they do bring it, it enables the people to consume so fast that famine becomes inevitable before the season ends. The unlimited, unrestrained freedom of the corn trade is not only the best preventive of famine but also the best palliative for the difficulties of a dearth. The inconveniences of genuine scarcity cannot be remedied; they can only be eased. No trade deserves the full protection of the law more than the corn trade, and no trade needs it so badly, because no trade is so exposed to popular hostility.
elegant: Government price controls on corn either prevent dealers from selling at all -- causing immediate famine -- or encourage such rapid consumption that famine comes before the season ends. Complete freedom of the corn trade is both the best famine preventive and the best palliative for dearth. Real scarcity cannot be cured, only eased. No trade more deserves legal protection, because none is more exposed to popular hatred.
summary: Price controls on corn cause famine either by preventing supply from reaching market or by encouraging overconsumption. Free trade is the only effective famine prevention and the best palliative for scarcity. The corn trade deserves legal protection precisely because it faces such intense public hostility.
distilled: Government price controls on corn cause the very famines they aim to prevent; only unrestricted free trade can prevent famine and palliate dearth.
notes: Classic anti-price-control argument: controls cause shortages or overconsumption. 'The best palliative of the inconveniencies of a dearth' -- one of Smith's most quoted lines on free markets. Legal protection needed precisely because of popular prejudice. Cross-reference: 4.5.54 on government as the sole cause of famine.

refashioned: In years of scarcity, the lower classes blame the corn merchant for their distress. He becomes the target of their hatred and violence. Instead of profiting from such occasions, he is often in danger of ruin, his warehouses plundered and destroyed. Yet it is precisely in scarce years, when prices are high, that the corn merchant expects to earn his principal profit. He typically has contracts with farmers to supply a certain quantity of corn at a fixed price over several years. This contract price is set according to the ordinary average price, which before the recent years of scarcity was commonly about twenty-eight shillings per quarter of wheat. In scarce years, therefore, he buys much of his corn at the ordinary price but sells it much higher. Yet this extraordinary profit is apparently no more than enough to make his trade fairly competitive with other businesses -- compensating for his frequent losses from the perishable nature of corn and its unpredictable price swings. The evidence is that great fortunes are as rarely made in this trade as in any other. The popular hostility that attaches to it in scarce years -- the only years when it can be very profitable -- deters people of reputation and wealth from entering it. It is left to inferior dealers: millers, bakers, mealmen, and petty retailers are almost the only middlemen between the farmer and the consumer in the home market.
elegant: The public blames corn merchants for scarcity, attacking their warehouses. Yet scarce years -- the only profitable ones -- barely compensate for frequent losses from spoilage and price swings. Great fortunes are never made in the corn trade. The popular hatred deters respectable investors, leaving the trade to millers, bakers, and petty retailers -- ensuring the home market is served less capably than it might be.
summary: Popular hostility toward corn merchants is counterproductive. Their profits in scarce years barely compensate for chronic losses, as evidenced by the rarity of great fortunes in the trade. This hostility deters capable investors, leaving the trade to small-scale operators who serve the market less efficiently.
distilled: Popular hatred of corn merchants deters capable investors and leaves the trade to inferior operators, harming the very public that directs its anger at the merchant class.
notes: Public choice and behavioral economics: popular prejudice produces policy that harms the public. The corn trade's risk profile (perishable goods, volatile prices) justifies above-average returns in good years. Brain drain from stigmatized occupations. Cross-reference: 4.5.72 on popular fear compared to witchcraft.

refashioned: Ancient European policy, instead of discouraging this popular hostility against a trade so beneficial to the public, actually encouraged and authorized it. Under the statute of the fifth and sixth year of Edward VI, chapter 14, anyone who bought corn or grain intending to resell it was deemed an unlawful engrosser. The first offense brought two months' imprisonment and forfeiture of the corn's value. The second brought six months' imprisonment and double forfeiture. The third brought the pillory, imprisonment at the king's pleasure, and forfeiture of all goods and property. Ancient policy in most other parts of Europe was no better than England's.
elegant: Ancient European law actively encouraged hostility toward corn merchants. Under Edward VI, buying corn for resale was punished as unlawful engrossing: imprisonment and fines for first offenses, escalating to the pillory and total asset forfeiture for repeat offenses. Most of Europe had similar laws.
summary: Ancient English law criminalized the corn trade, punishing those who bought grain for resale with escalating penalties from imprisonment to the pillory and total asset forfeiture. Similar laws existed throughout Europe.
distilled: Ancient European law criminalized corn dealing as engrossing, punishing beneficial trade with imprisonment, the pillory, and asset forfeiture.
notes: Historical evidence of policy hostility to middlemen. Edward VI statute as exemplar of medieval anti-market legislation. The irony: laws targeting beneficial trade increased the very scarcity they aimed to prevent. Cross-reference: 4.5.56 on free trade as famine prevention.

refashioned: Our ancestors imagined that people would buy corn more cheaply from the farmer directly than from a corn merchant, who they feared would demand an exorbitant profit above the farmer's price. They therefore tried to eliminate the merchant's trade entirely. They even sought to prevent any middleman at all from coming between the grower and the consumer. This was the purpose of the many restrictions on those they called kidders, or carriers of corn -- a trade no one could exercise without a license certifying their good character. The statute of Edward VI required three justices of the peace to grant such a license. But even this was later thought insufficient, and under an Elizabethan statute the power to license was confined to the quarter-sessions.
elegant: Lawmakers assumed consumers would buy cheaper directly from farmers, fearing merchant markups. They tried to eliminate middlemen entirely, requiring corn carriers ('kidders') to obtain character licenses from justices of the peace. Later, even this was tightened by restricting licensing to the quarter-sessions.
summary: Medieval lawmakers tried to eliminate corn middlemen, assuming direct farmer-to-consumer sales would be cheaper. They required corn carriers to obtain character licenses, progressively tightening the licensing requirements.
distilled: Medieval attempts to eliminate corn middlemen through licensing requirements reflected the mistaken belief that direct farmer-to-consumer sales would lower prices.
notes: Anti-middleman prejudice in historical policy. Licensing as occupational restriction. Kidders/carriers -- specialized terminology for corn transport middlemen. Progressive regulatory tightening (Edward VI to Elizabeth) shows escalating policy failure. Cross-reference: 4.5.62-63 on why middlemen actually lower costs.

refashioned: Ancient European policy thus attempted to regulate agriculture -- the great trade of the country -- by entirely different principles from those it applied to manufactures -- the great trade of the towns. By leaving the farmer no customers except consumers or their immediate factors (the kidders and carriers), it tried to force him to act as both farmer and corn merchant or retailer. Conversely, in many cases it prohibited the manufacturer from selling his own goods directly to consumers. The first law aimed to promote the general interest by making corn cheap -- though without much understanding of how this was to be achieved. The second aimed to protect a particular order of men -- the shopkeepers -- who would supposedly be ruined if manufacturers were allowed to sell retail.
elegant: Policy treated agriculture and manufacturing asymmetrically. Farmers were forced to act as their own retailers, supposedly to keep corn cheap. Manufacturers were prohibited from retailing, supposedly to protect shopkeepers. One aimed at the general interest through misguided means; the other served a particular interest group outright.
summary: Medieval policy applied contradictory rules: farmers were forced to retail their own corn to keep prices low, while manufacturers were banned from retailing to protect shopkeepers. Both rules distorted the natural division of commercial functions.
distilled: Medieval policy forced farmers into retailing while prohibiting manufacturers from it -- contradictory rules that both distorted the natural commercial division of labor.
notes: Asymmetric regulation of agriculture vs. manufacturing. Forced vertical integration for farmers, forced specialization for manufacturers. The agricultural rule aimed at consumer welfare; the manufacturing rule at producer welfare. Both violated natural liberty and the division of labor principle. Cross-reference: Book I on the division of labor.

refashioned: The manufacturer, however, even if allowed to keep a shop and sell his goods retail, could not have undersold the ordinary shopkeeper. Whatever capital he devoted to his shop must have been withdrawn from manufacturing. To conduct both businesses competitively, he would need to earn the normal profit on each. If, for example, the normal profit rate were ten percent in both manufacturing and retailing, he would need to charge a twenty percent markup on every item sold in his shop. When moving goods from his workshop to his shop, he must value them at the wholesale price he could get from a dealer -- otherwise he would lose part of his manufacturing profit. When selling from his shop, he must match the shopkeeper's retail price -- otherwise he would lose part of his retail profit. Though he might appear to earn a double profit on the same goods, those goods successively formed part of two distinct capitals. He earned only a single profit on the total capital employed. If he earned less than this, he was a loser, and his capital was employed less advantageously than his neighbors' capital.
elegant: A manufacturer who also retailed could not undersell a specialized shopkeeper. His capital would be split between two functions, each requiring its normal profit rate. Goods moving from workshop to shop must be valued at wholesale; sales must match retail prices. The apparent double profit on one item is really a single normal return on two separate capital uses. Any less, and he loses relative to his neighbors.
summary: A manufacturer retailing his own goods could not undersell a specialized shopkeeper. Splitting capital between manufacturing and retailing requires earning the normal profit on each function. The apparent double profit is merely a single normal return on the total capital employed.
distilled: A manufacturer retailing his own goods cannot undersell specialized shopkeepers because both functions require their own normal profit, and splitting capital between them yields only a single combined return.
notes: Opportunity cost reasoning applied to vertical integration. Each capital function must earn its normal return. The 'double profit' illusion -- a common fallacy in competition analysis. Cross-reference: Book I on the division of labor; Book II on capital allocation and profit rates.

refashioned: What the manufacturer was prohibited from doing, the farmer was in some measure compelled to do: divide his capital between two different employments, keeping one portion in granaries and stackyards for supplying the market's occasional demands, while employing the other in cultivating his land. But just as he could not afford to employ his farming capital for less than the normal farming profit, neither could he employ his mercantile capital for less than the normal merchant's profit. Whether the capital used in the corn merchant's business belonged to someone called a farmer or someone called a corn merchant, an equal profit was required in both cases -- to compensate the owner for this use of capital, to keep his business competitive with other trades, and to prevent him from switching to a more profitable occupation. The farmer who was forced to also be a corn merchant could not, therefore, sell corn any cheaper than any other corn merchant would have in a free market.
elegant: The farmer was forced to split his capital between farming and corn dealing. But corn dealing requires its normal profit regardless of who conducts it. A farmer-turned-merchant needs the same return as a professional merchant. Forcing the farmer to retail corn therefore could not make it cheaper -- it merely imposed an additional burden on the farmer without benefiting the consumer.
summary: Forcing farmers to act as corn merchants could not lower prices because the corn-dealing function requires its normal profit regardless of who performs it. The policy simply burdened farmers with a second occupation without any consumer benefit.
distilled: Forcing farmers to act as their own corn merchants cannot lower prices because the dealing function requires its normal return regardless of who performs it.
notes: Arbitrage argument: capital earns the same normal return regardless of the owner's occupation. Forcing occupational bundling imposes costs without benefits. The law of one price applied to profit rates. Cross-reference: 4.5.61 on the manufacturer's equivalent situation.

refashioned: The dealer who can devote his entire capital to a single line of business has the same advantage as the worker who can devote his entire labor to a single task. Just as the specialized worker develops a dexterity that enables him to perform far more work with the same two hands, the specialized dealer develops such efficient methods of buying and selling that the same capital turns over far more business. Just as the specialized worker can offer his labor more cheaply, the specialized dealer can offer his goods somewhat cheaper than someone whose capital and attention are divided among many different activities. Most manufacturers could not afford to retail their goods as cheaply as an attentive, active shopkeeper whose sole business was buying wholesale and selling retail. Most farmers could even less afford to retail their corn -- supplying a town four or five miles away -- as cheaply as an attentive, active corn merchant whose sole business was buying corn in bulk, collecting it into a large warehouse, and retailing it.
elegant: Specialization in commerce yields the same advantages as specialization in labor. A dedicated dealer, like a dedicated worker, develops superior efficiency. Professional shopkeepers undersell part-time manufacturer-retailers; professional corn merchants undersell part-time farmer-retailers. Division of labor applies to commercial functions just as it does to production.
summary: Commercial specialization mirrors productive specialization: a dedicated corn merchant operates more efficiently than a farmer forced to also retail corn, just as a dedicated shopkeeper outsells a manufacturer forced to also keep shop. The division of labor principle applies to trading as well as making.
distilled: Commercial specialization yields the same efficiency gains as productive specialization -- professional corn merchants serve consumers more cheaply than farmers forced into part-time retailing.
notes: Division of labor extended from production to commerce -- a key analytical move. Specialization advantages: dexterity, efficiency, reduced capital requirements. Directly supports the case for middlemen. Cross-reference: Book I, Chapters 1-3 on the division of labor.

refashioned: The law prohibiting the manufacturer from retailing tried to accelerate the natural specialization of commercial functions. The law compelling the farmer to retail tried to retard it. Both were manifest violations of natural liberty, and therefore unjust. Both were also as foolish as they were unjust. It is in every society's interest that such specialization should be neither forced nor obstructed. A person who employs his labor or capital in more ways than his situation strictly requires can never hurt his neighbor by underselling him. He may hurt himself, and generally does. As the proverb says, a jack-of-all-trades will never be rich. But the law should always trust people to manage their own interests, since in their particular circumstances they are generally better judges than any legislature. The law that forced the farmer to also be a corn merchant was, however, by far the more harmful of the two.
elegant: Both laws violated natural liberty: one forced commercial specialization artificially fast, the other artificially slow. Neither can benefit society. A jack-of-all-trades hurts only himself, never his competitors. The law should trust individuals to manage their own affairs -- they know their circumstances better than any legislature. The law forcing farmers into retailing was the worse offender.
summary: Both the ban on manufacturer retailing and the requirement that farmers retail their own corn violated natural liberty and were economically foolish. The law should trust individuals to manage their own interests. Forcing farmers into corn dealing was the more damaging policy.
distilled: Both laws -- forcing specialization on manufacturers and preventing it for farmers -- violated natural liberty and harmed the economy, with the farmer regulation being the more damaging.
notes: Natural liberty argument applied to commercial regulation. The 'jack-of-all-trades' proverb as economic principle. Trust in individual judgment over legislative prescription -- core liberal principle. Asymmetric harm: the farmer regulation was worse because it damaged agriculture directly. Cross-reference: 4.9 on natural liberty.

refashioned: It obstructed not only the commercial specialization that benefits every society, but also the improvement and cultivation of the land itself. By forcing the farmer to carry on two trades, it compelled him to split his capital, devoting only part to cultivation. Had he been free to sell his entire crop to a corn merchant as soon as it was threshed, his whole capital could have returned immediately to the land -- buying more livestock, hiring more laborers, and improving cultivation. Instead, by being forced to retail his corn, he had to keep much of his capital locked up in granaries and stackyards throughout the year, unable to cultivate as well as his total capital would have allowed. This law therefore necessarily obstructed agricultural improvement and, rather than making corn cheaper, must have made it scarcer and therefore dearer.
elegant: Forcing farmers to retail corn obstructed both commercial specialization and agricultural improvement. Capital locked in granaries could not be invested in land, livestock, and labor. If farmers could sell wholesale to merchants immediately, their entire capital would return to cultivation. The law made corn scarcer and dearer -- the opposite of its intention.
summary: Forcing farmers to retail corn locked their capital in granaries instead of reinvesting it in agriculture. This obstructed both commercial specialization and land improvement, making corn scarcer and dearer rather than cheaper.
distilled: Forcing farmers into retailing locked their capital in granaries instead of productive agriculture, making corn scarcer and dearer -- the exact opposite of the law's intent.
notes: Capital tied up in inventory vs. capital deployed in production -- opportunity cost of forced vertical integration. Working capital velocity argument. The law produced the opposite of its intended effect -- a common theme in Smith's regulatory critiques. Cross-reference: Book II on circulating vs. fixed capital.

refashioned:
After the farmer's own business, the corn merchant's trade contributes more than any other to the growing of corn -- if properly protected and encouraged. It supports the farmer just as the wholesale dealer supports the manufacturer.

The wholesale dealer, by providing a ready market for the manufacturer's goods -- buying them as fast as they are made, and sometimes even advancing their price before production is complete -- enables the manufacturer to keep all his capital, and sometimes more than all his capital, constantly employed in production. This lets him manufacture far more goods than if he had to sell directly to consumers or even to retailers. Since the wholesale dealer's capital is generally large enough to replace that of many manufacturers, this relationship allows the owner of a large capital to support the owners of many small ones, helping them through losses and misfortunes that might otherwise prove ruinous.
elegant: The corn merchant supports the farmer as the wholesale dealer supports the manufacturer -- providing a ready market, maintaining capital turnover, and buffering against losses. Wholesalers buy goods as fast as they are produced, sometimes advancing payment, enabling continuous full-capacity production. Their large capital supports many smaller producers through difficulties that would otherwise ruin them.
summary: The corn merchant's role parallels the wholesale dealer's: providing farmers with a ready market, accelerating capital turnover, and offering financial resilience through a large capital base that supports many smaller producers.
distilled: The corn merchant supports farmers just as wholesalers support manufacturers -- providing ready markets, accelerating capital turnover, and buffering small producers against ruin.
notes: Middleman as value creator, not parasite -- directly counters the engrossing prejudice. Wholesale-retail division of labor enables continuous production. Large capital as insurance for small capitals. Cross-reference: Book II on the wholesaler's function in capital circulation.

refashioned: If a similar relationship were universally established between farmers and corn merchants, the effects would be equally beneficial. Farmers could keep their entire capital -- and even more -- constantly employed in cultivation. When misfortune struck, as it does in no trade more than farming, they would find in their regular customer, the wealthy corn merchant, someone with both the interest and the ability to support them. They would no longer depend entirely on the forbearance of their landlord or the mercy of his steward. Were it possible -- as perhaps it is not -- to establish this relationship universally and all at once; to redirect all the kingdom's farming capital entirely to cultivation, withdrawing it from every other use into which it may currently be diverted; and to provide, in addition, another stock almost equally large to support the farmer's operations -- it is hard to imagine how great, how extensive, and how sudden would be the improvement this change alone would produce across the entire face of the country.
elegant: Universal corn merchant-farmer partnerships would let farmers invest all their capital in cultivation, with wealthy merchants providing both ready markets and financial support in bad years. If all farming capital could be redirected to cultivation and an equal mercantile capital provided alongside it, the resulting agricultural improvement would be transformative beyond easy imagination.
summary: If all farmers had corn merchant partners to provide ready markets and financial support, they could devote all capital to cultivation rather than retailing. The resulting agricultural improvement across the country would be enormous.
distilled: Universal corn merchant-farmer partnerships would free all farming capital for cultivation, producing agricultural improvement on an almost unimaginable scale.
notes: Vision of a fully developed wholesale market for grain as a transformative institution. Financial intermediation applied to agriculture. Separation of production and marketing functions as capital efficiency. The conditional 'were it possible' shows Smith's realism about institutional change.

refashioned: The statute of Edward VI, by prohibiting as far as possible any middleman between grower and consumer, attempted to destroy a trade whose free exercise is not only the best palliative for dearth but the best preventive of famine. After the farmer's own trade, no trade contributes as much to corn production as the corn merchant's.
elegant: Edward VI's statute tried to destroy the very trade whose free exercise best prevents famine and palliates dearth. After farming itself, no trade contributes more to corn production than corn dealing.
summary: The statute of Edward VI attempted to destroy the corn trade -- the most important trade after farming itself for preventing famine and ensuring corn production.
distilled: Edward VI's anti-middleman statute tried to destroy the very trade that most contributes to famine prevention and corn production after farming itself.
notes: Summary condemnation of the Edward VI statute. Restatement of the two key functions of the corn trade: famine prevention and production support. Cross-reference: 4.5.56 on free trade as famine prevention; 4.5.66-67 on the corn merchant as farmer's partner.

refashioned: The severity of this law was gradually softened by subsequent statutes that progressively permitted the engrossing of corn at higher and higher price thresholds: first when wheat did not exceed twenty shillings per quarter, then twenty-four, then thirty-two, then forty shillings. Finally, by the statute of the fifteenth year of Charles II, chapter 7, buying corn for resale was declared lawful for everyone -- except forestallers, who resold in the same market within three months -- as long as the wheat price did not exceed forty-eight shillings per quarter. All the freedom the inland corn trade has ever enjoyed was granted by this statute. The statute of the twelfth year of the present king, which repeals almost all the other ancient laws against engrossers and forestallers, does not repeal the restrictions in this particular statute, which therefore remain in force.
elegant: Successive statutes gradually relaxed the engrossing ban, raising the permissible price threshold from twenty to forty-eight shillings per quarter. The statute of Charles II (15th year, c.7) finally legalized corn dealing below forty-eight shillings.
