This remains the foundation of whatever freedom the inland corn trade enjoys, since the later repeal of most anti-engrossing laws specifically preserved this statute's restrictions.
summary: The draconian engrossing laws were gradually relaxed over centuries, with the Charles II statute eventually legalizing corn dealing below forty-eight shillings per quarter. This statute remains the basis of the inland corn trade's limited freedom.
distilled: The inland corn trade's limited freedom rests on the Charles II statute, which legalized dealing below forty-eight shillings per quarter after centuries of gradually relaxed engrossing prohibitions.
notes: Legislative history of corn trade liberalization. Progressive reform through incremental threshold increases. The 48-shilling threshold becomes a recurring reference point. Even reform preserved arbitrary price triggers. Cross-reference: 4.5.70-71 on the statute's remaining defects.

refashioned:
This statute, however, authorizes two very absurd popular prejudices.

First, it assumes that when wheat rises above forty-eight shillings per quarter, corn is likely to be engrossed in a way that harms the people. But as I have already shown, corn can never at any price be engrossed by inland dealers so as to injure the public. Moreover, forty-eight shillings per quarter, though it may seem a very high price, is a price that frequently prevails immediately after harvest in years of scarcity, when virtually none of the new crop could possibly have been bought up. It is impossible even for ignorance to suppose that corn could have been harmfully engrossed at that point.
elegant: The Charles II statute endorses two absurd prejudices. First, it assumes corn can be harmfully engrossed above forty-eight shillings. But as shown, no inland engrossing can harm the public at any price. Furthermore, forty-eight shillings frequently occurs right after harvest during scarcity -- when obviously no engrossing could have taken place.
summary: The statute's first prejudice is assuming corn can be harmfully engrossed above forty-eight shillings. But inland engrossing cannot harm the public at any price, and forty-eight shillings commonly occurs right after harvest when engrossing is obviously impossible.
distilled: The statute wrongly assumes corn can be harmfully engrossed above forty-eight shillings -- a price that frequently occurs right after harvest when engrossing is clearly impossible.
notes: Logical critique of arbitrary price triggers in regulation. The 48-shilling threshold fails empirically: it triggers during natural post-harvest scarcity, not engrossing. Cross-reference: 4.5.52-53 on why corn engrossing is structurally impossible.

refashioned: Second, it assumes there is a certain price at which corn is likely to be forestalled -- that is, bought up to be resold soon after in the same market, harming the public. But if a merchant ever buys corn heading to a particular market, or already at one, intending to resell it soon in the same place, it must be because he judges that the market will not be as well supplied throughout the season as at that particular moment, and that the price must therefore rise soon. If he judges wrongly and the price does not rise, he loses not only the full profit on his invested capital but part of the capital itself, through the costs of storing and keeping corn. He hurts himself far more than he can possibly hurt the particular buyers who may have been inconvenienced on that market day, since they can always buy just as cheaply on another. If he judges correctly, instead of harming the public he renders them a most important service. By making them feel the inconveniences of scarcity somewhat earlier than they would otherwise, he prevents them from feeling those inconveniences far more severely later, when the cheapness of early prices would have encouraged overconsumption. When scarcity is real, the best thing that can be done for the people is to spread the hardship as evenly as possible across all the months, weeks, and days of the year. The corn merchant's own interest drives him to do this as precisely as he can. Since no one else has the same interest, knowledge, or ability to do it as well, this most important commercial function should be trusted entirely to him. In other words, the corn trade, at least as far as it supplies the home market, should be left perfectly free.
elegant: A forestaller who buys to resell soon either judges correctly that prices will rise, or incorrectly. If wrong, he bears heavy losses from storage costs and unsold stock. If right, he performs a vital public service: making scarcity felt earlier prevents worse hardship later by discouraging overconsumption. The merchant's self-interest, knowledge, and ability make him the best agent for rationing scarce supply evenly through the year. The corn trade should be left perfectly free.
summary: Forestalling either fails -- punishing the speculator with losses -- or succeeds in smoothing scarcity across the season, benefiting the public. The merchant's unique combination of self-interest, market knowledge, and ability makes him the best possible agent for rationing scarce supply. The corn trade should therefore be completely free.
distilled: Forestalling is either self-punishing when wrong or publicly beneficial when right, making the corn merchant the optimal agent for rationing scarce supply -- and the trade should be left perfectly free.
notes: Comprehensive defense of speculation as social service. Speculative losses as self-correction; speculative profits as social benefit (inter-temporal smoothing). The speculator as society's best rationing agent. 'Perfectly free' -- one of Smith's strongest policy prescriptions. Cross-reference: 4.5.49-50 on the dealer's aligned incentives.

refashioned: The popular fear of engrossing and forestalling may be compared to the popular terrors and suspicions of witchcraft. The unfortunate wretches accused of witchcraft were no more innocent of the misfortunes blamed on them than those accused of engrossing. The law that ended all prosecutions for witchcraft -- making it impossible for anyone to satisfy personal malice by accusing a neighbor of that imaginary crime -- seems to have effectively ended the fears and suspicions themselves, by removing the institution that encouraged and sustained them. A law restoring full freedom to the inland corn trade would probably prove equally effective in ending the popular fears of engrossing and forestalling.
elegant: Fear of engrossing resembles fear of witchcraft -- both scapegoat the innocent for natural misfortunes. Ending witchcraft prosecutions ended witchcraft fears by removing the institutional framework that sustained them. Ending corn trade restrictions would similarly end engrossing fears.
summary: Smith compares the popular fear of corn engrossing to the fear of witchcraft. Just as ending witchcraft prosecutions eliminated those fears, freeing the corn trade would eliminate fears of engrossing.
distilled: Fear of engrossing is the economic equivalent of fear of witchcraft -- both target innocent scapegoats, and both would vanish if the persecuting laws were abolished.
notes: One of Smith's most striking analogies. Laws create the very fears they claim to address. Institutional feedback loop: prosecution validates superstition. Cross-reference: this passage is frequently cited in discussions of market prejudice and scapegoating.

refashioned: The statute of the fifteenth year of Charles II, chapter 7, despite all its imperfections, has probably contributed more to both the plentiful supply of the home market and the increase of farming than any other law in the statute book. The inland corn trade derives all its liberty and protection from this law. And the inland trade promotes both the home market's supply and the interest of agriculture far more effectively than either the import or export trade.
elegant: Despite its flaws, the Charles II statute has done more for home market supply and agriculture than any other law, by granting the inland corn trade its only freedom. The inland trade serves both home supply and farming far more effectively than foreign trade does.
summary: The Charles II statute, despite its defects, has done more for domestic corn supply and agricultural improvement than any other law, because the inland trade it partially freed is far more important than foreign corn trade.
distilled: The Charles II statute's partial liberation of the inland corn trade has done more for domestic supply and agriculture than any other corn law, because inland trade matters far more than foreign trade.
notes: Pragmatic assessment: the imperfect statute still produced great benefits. Inland trade's primacy over foreign trade in serving the home market. Partial liberalization as significant improvement. Cross-reference: 4.5.74-75 for quantitative support.

refashioned: According to the author of the Tracts upon the Corn Trade, the average proportion of all grain imported into Great Britain to all grain consumed is no more than one to five hundred and seventy. For supplying the home market, therefore, the importance of the inland trade relative to the import trade is as five hundred and seventy to one.
elegant: Imports account for only about one five-hundred-and-seventieth of Britain's grain consumption. The inland trade is therefore 570 times more important than the import trade for supplying the home market.
summary: Imported grain amounts to only one five-hundred-and-seventieth of British consumption, making the inland corn trade 570 times more important than imports for domestic supply.
distilled: The inland corn trade is 570 times more important than imports for supplying the British home market.
notes: Quantitative evidence for inland trade primacy. Charles Smith's data. The ratio dramatically illustrates the relative insignificance of foreign trade in grain. Cross-reference: 4.5.75 for the corresponding export comparison.

refashioned:
According to the same author, the average quantity of all grain exported from Great Britain does not exceed one thirty-first part of the annual produce. For encouraging agriculture by providing a market for domestic production, the importance of the inland trade relative to the export trade is therefore as thirty to one.

I have no great faith in political arithmetic, and I do not guarantee the precision of either calculation. I cite them only to show how much less important the foreign corn trade is than the domestic trade, even in the estimation of the most judicious and experienced observers. The great cheapness of corn in the years just before the bounty was established may perhaps be reasonably attributed in part to the effects of the Charles II statute, which had been enacted about twenty-five years earlier and had therefore had ample time to take effect.
elegant: Exports account for only one thirty-first of annual grain production, making the inland trade thirty times more important than exports for supporting agriculture. Though Smith disclaims precision in 'political arithmetic,' the orders of magnitude show domestic trade vastly overshadows foreign trade. The corn cheapness before the bounty likely reflected the Charles II statute's beneficial effects over twenty-five years.
summary: The inland trade is thirty times more important than exports for supporting agriculture. Though Smith distrusts precise calculations, the magnitude demonstrates foreign trade's relative insignificance. Pre-bounty corn cheapness likely resulted from the Charles II statute's effects over twenty-five years.
distilled: The inland corn trade is thirty times more important than exports for agriculture, and pre-bounty corn cheapness likely reflected the Charles II statute's liberalizing effects.
notes: Smith's cautious attitude toward 'political arithmetic' (early statistics). Orders of magnitude matter more than precise numbers. Attribution of pre-bounty cheapness to the Charles II statute rather than the bounty itself. Cross-reference: 4.5.5 where the bounty gets false credit for falling prices.

refashioned:
A very few words will suffice for the other three branches of the corn trade.

Second: the trade of importing foreign corn for home consumption clearly contributes directly to the home market's supply and must therefore be immediately beneficial to the general public. It tends to lower the average money price of corn, though not to diminish its real value or the quantity of labor it can maintain. If imports were always free, our farmers and country gentlemen would probably receive less money for their corn, but that money would have greater purchasing power -- buying more goods and employing more labor. Their real wealth and real revenue would remain the same, merely expressed in a smaller quantity of silver. They would be neither disabled nor discouraged from growing corn. On the contrary, the rise in silver's real value, by lowering the money price of all other commodities, would give the country's industry some advantage in every foreign market, thereby tending to encourage and expand that industry. But the extent of the home market for corn depends on the country's general industry -- the number of people who produce something to exchange for it. The home market is always the nearest, most convenient, greatest, and most important market for corn. A rise in silver's real value would therefore enlarge this greatest market and encourage rather than discourage corn production.
elegant: Free corn imports would directly benefit the public by supplying the home market. Farmers would receive less money but with greater purchasing power -- their real wealth unchanged. Lower money prices would give domestic industry advantages in foreign markets, expanding the general economy and thus the home corn market. Since the home market is always the largest and most important, free imports would ultimately encourage corn production, not discourage it.
summary: Free corn imports benefit the public, and although farmers would receive less money per bushel, its purchasing power would be greater. The resulting lower price level would give domestic industry foreign competitive advantages, growing the economy and enlarging the home corn market -- ultimately encouraging production.
distilled: Free corn imports benefit the public without truly harming farmers, because lower money prices raise silver's value, boost industrial competitiveness, and enlarge the home market that drives corn production.
notes: Free import argument: nominal losses, real gains. Lower domestic prices improve international competitiveness. The home market as the primary driver of corn demand -- a key Smithian point. Virtuous cycle: free imports -> lower prices -> competitive industry -> larger home market -> more corn demand. Cross-reference: 4.5.12-14 on corn as price regulator.

refashioned: By the statute of the twenty-second year of Charles II, chapter 13, wheat imports were subjected to a duty of sixteen shillings per quarter whenever the home price did not exceed fifty-three shillings and fourpence, and to eight shillings whenever it did not exceed four pounds. The lower price threshold has occurred only during very great scarcity in the past century; the higher, so far as I know, has never been reached. Yet until wheat rose above the higher price, it faced a very substantial duty; and until it rose above the lower, the duty amounted to an effective prohibition. Imports of other grains were restrained by comparably high duties in proportion to their value. Before the thirteenth year of the present king, the following duties applied to grain imports:
elegant: Under Charles II's statute, wheat imports faced a sixteen-shilling duty (effectively prohibitive) below fifty-three shillings fourpence per quarter, and an eight-shilling duty below four pounds. Since these price thresholds were rarely or never reached, imports were effectively banned in all but the most extreme scarcity. Similar proportional duties applied to all other grains.
summary: Charles II's import duties on wheat were set at levels that amounted to prohibition in normal times and heavy taxation even in scarcity. Similar duties applied to all grains, effectively blocking imports except in extreme emergencies.
distilled: Charles II's grain import duties were set so high relative to prevailing prices that they amounted to a near-total prohibition on imports in all but the most extreme scarcity.
notes: Specific legislative detail supporting the general argument. Price-triggered tariffs as de facto import bans. The thresholds were set to almost never activate relief. Cross-reference: 4.5.79 on the need for temporary suspension statutes as proof of the system's failure.

refashioned: The import duties on different grains before the thirteenth year of the present king were as follows: Beans faced nineteen shillings and tenpence up to twenty-eight shillings per quarter, then sixteen shillings eightpence up to forty shillings, then one shilling. Barley faced nineteen shillings tenpence up to twenty-eight shillings, then sixteen shillings up to thirty-two shillings, then one shilling. Malt was prohibited by the annual malt-tax bill. Oats faced five shillings tenpence up to sixteen shillings, then ninepence-halfpenny. Pease faced sixteen shillings up to forty shillings, then ninepence-three-farthings. Rye faced nineteen shillings tenpence up to thirty-six shillings, then sixteen shillings eightpence up to forty shillings, then one shilling. Wheat faced twenty-one shillings ninepence up to forty-four shillings, then seventeen shillings up to fifty-three shillings fourpence, then eight shillings up to four pounds, and about one shilling fourpence thereafter. Buckwheat faced sixteen shillings up to thirty-two shillings per quarter. These duties were imposed partly by the twenty-second of Charles II in place of the old subsidy, partly by the new subsidy, the one-third and two-thirds subsidy, and the subsidy of 1747. Subsequent laws increased them further.
elegant: The pre-reform grain import duties formed a complex tiered system, with rates that were prohibitively high at normal price levels. Wheat faced duties of over twenty-one shillings below forty-four shillings per quarter -- nearly a fifty percent tariff. Malt was outright prohibited. These duties accumulated from multiple statutes over decades and were only increased over time.
summary: The grain import duty schedule was a complex tiered system with prohibitively high rates at normal price levels, accumulated from multiple statutes over decades. Malt was outright banned, and wheat faced duties approaching fifty percent.
distilled: Britain's grain import duties were a complex, multi-layered system of prohibitively high rates at normal prices, accumulated from decades of protectionist legislation.
notes: Detailed legislative record of protectionist grain policy. Layered subsidies (old, new, one-third, two-thirds, 1747) illustrate incremental protectionism. Malt's outright prohibition as the extreme case. Technical detail supports Smith's argument about the system's irrationality.

refashioned: The distress that strict enforcement of these laws might have caused the people in years of scarcity would probably have been very great. But on such occasions, enforcement was generally suspended by temporary statutes that permitted foreign corn imports for a limited period. The necessity of these temporary suspensions is itself sufficient proof of the permanent system's impropriety.
elegant: The government regularly had to suspend its own import restrictions through emergency temporary statutes during scarcity. The need for these repeated suspensions proves the permanent system was fundamentally flawed.
summary: The regular need to suspend grain import restrictions through emergency legislation during scarcity demonstrated that the permanent protectionist system was fundamentally misguided.
distilled: The repeated need for emergency suspensions of grain import duties during scarcity proves the permanent protectionist system was inherently flawed.
notes: Elegant logical argument: if a system must be regularly overridden, the system is wrong. Temporary exceptions as evidence against the rule. Cross-reference: 4.5.83 for a similar argument about export restrictions.

refashioned: These import restrictions, though enacted before the bounty, were motivated by the same spirit and principles that later produced it. However harmful in themselves, some form of import restriction became necessary once the bounty was established. If, when wheat was at or near forty-eight shillings per quarter, foreign corn could be imported duty-free or at only a small duty, it could then have been re-exported with the benefit of the bounty -- at great loss to the public revenue and in complete perversion of the bounty's purpose, which was to extend the market for domestic corn, not foreign.
elegant: Import restrictions and the bounty shared the same mercantilist logic. Once the bounty existed, import restrictions became necessary to prevent foreign corn from being imported and immediately re-exported to collect the bounty -- a perversion that would drain public revenue while subsidizing foreign rather than domestic production.
summary: Import restrictions became necessary after the bounty was established to prevent a perverse arbitrage: importing foreign corn cheaply and re-exporting it to collect the bounty, draining public funds while subsidizing foreign production.
distilled: The bounty made import restrictions necessary to prevent the absurd arbitrage of importing foreign corn to re-export for bounty payments.
notes: Policy interdependence: one distortion requires another to prevent arbitrage. Cascading intervention problem -- each regulation demands supplementary regulations. The bounty system was internally inconsistent without import barriers. Classic second-best problem.

refashioned:
Third: the trade of exporting domestic corn for foreign consumption does not contribute directly to the home market's plentiful supply, but it does so indirectly. Whether the home market is typically supplied from domestic production or foreign imports, unless more corn is usually grown or imported than consumed, the home market can never be abundantly supplied. And unless the surplus can normally be exported, growers will never grow more, and importers will never import more, than bare domestic consumption requires. The market will seldom be oversupplied, but will generally be undersupplied -- because those whose business is to supply it will be constantly afraid of being left with unsold stock. Prohibiting exports limits agricultural improvement to what domestic consumption alone demands. Freedom of export enables it to extend cultivation to supply foreign nations as well.

However, the exporter's interest can sometimes conflict with the public interest. If his own country is suffering dearth while a neighbor faces famine, it might be in his interest to ship corn in quantities that worsen the domestic dearth. The statutes' true purpose was not to supply the home market abundantly, but to raise corn's money price as high as possible under the pretense of encouraging agriculture -- creating a constant dearth at home. Imports were confined to domestic production; even at forty-eight shillings per quarter, exports were allowed. The frequent necessity of temporary statutes to prohibit exports and suspend import duties demonstrates the general system's fundamental impropriety. Had it been sound, Britain would not so often have been forced to depart from it.
elegant: Export freedom indirectly supports the home market: without an outlet for surplus, producers will grow only what domestic consumption demands, leaving the market chronically undersupplied. But exporters may sometimes worsen domestic scarcity by shipping to famine-stricken neighbors. The real purpose of the corn laws was not abundant home supply but artificially high prices. Import barriers and export encouragements combined to create perpetual domestic dearth. Britain's constant need for emergency legislation reversing these rules proves the system was fundamentally wrong.
summary: Export freedom indirectly supports domestic supply by encouraging production beyond bare consumption. But the corn law system's true purpose was to inflate prices, not ensure abundance. The constant need for emergency exceptions -- suspending exports and allowing imports -- proves the permanent system was fundamentally misguided.
distilled: Export freedom supports domestic supply by encouraging surplus production, but Britain's corn law system aimed to inflate prices, as proven by the constant need for emergency reversals.
notes: Indirect supply argument for export freedom. Export as safety valve preventing chronic undersupply. But the exporter's interest can diverge from the public's during scarcity -- one of Smith's rare acknowledgments of market failure. The constant emergency exceptions are damning evidence. Cross-reference: 4.5.79 on temporary suspensions.

refashioned: By the statute of the twelfth year of Charles II, chapter 4, corn exports were permitted when wheat did not exceed forty shillings per quarter. By the fifteenth year of the same reign, this freedom was extended to forty-eight shillings. By the twenty-second year, it was extended to all higher prices, subject only to a small poundage duty to the king. But grain was valued so low in the official rate book that this duty amounted to only one shilling per quarter on wheat, fourpence on oats, and sixpence on all other grain. By the act of William and Mary that established the bounty, this small duty was effectively removed when wheat did not exceed forty-eight shillings. By the eleventh and twelfth year of William III, chapter 20, it was expressly removed at all higher prices.
elegant: Successive statutes progressively freed corn exports: Charles II permitted exports below forty shillings, then forty-eight, then at all prices with a nominal duty. The bounty act of William and Mary effectively removed even this token duty below forty-eight shillings, and it was formally abolished at all prices by a subsequent William III statute.
summary: Corn export restrictions were progressively relaxed under Charles II, with the last token duties removed under William and Mary and William III, making exports essentially unrestricted.
distilled: Successive statutes from Charles II through William III progressively freed corn exports and removed all meaningful export duties.
notes: Legislative history of export liberalization, paralleling the import duty history. Progressive deregulation of exports while maintaining import barriers -- an asymmetric policy favoring price inflation. The bounty built on top of already-free exports. Cross-reference: 4.5.77-78 on import duties.

refashioned: The export trade was thus not only encouraged by a bounty but made much freer than the inland trade. Under these statutes, corn could be bought for export at any price, but for inland sale it could only be bought when the price did not exceed forty-eight shillings per quarter. However, as I have shown, the inland dealer's interest can never be opposed to the public's. The exporter's interest may, and in fact sometimes is. If his own country suffers a dearth while a neighboring country faces famine, his private interest might lead him to ship corn in quantities that greatly worsen the domestic crisis. The statutes' actual goal was not abundant home supply but, under the pretense of encouraging agriculture, to raise the money price of corn as high as possible and thereby create a constant dearth in the home market. By discouraging imports, they confined the home market to domestic production alone. By encouraging exports even at forty-eight shillings per quarter, they denied the home market the full benefit even of that domestic production. The frequent necessity for temporary statutes -- prohibiting exports for a time, suspending import duties for a time -- to which Great Britain has been so often forced to resort, sufficiently demonstrates the fundamental impropriety of the general system. Had the system been sound, there would have been no such frequent need to depart from it.
elegant: The law treated exporters more favorably than inland dealers -- corn could be freely bought for export at any price but not for inland resale above forty-eight shillings. Yet the inland dealer's interest never conflicts with the public's, while the exporter's may. The real aim was inflating corn prices, not ensuring supply. Britain's constant resort to emergency legislation -- suspending exports and admitting imports -- is conclusive evidence that the permanent system was fundamentally wrong.
summary: The corn law system paradoxically gave exporters more freedom than inland dealers, despite the exporter's interests sometimes conflicting with the public's. The system's true purpose was price inflation, not supply security. Britain's constant need for emergency reversals proves the permanent system was fundamentally flawed.
distilled: The corn law system absurdly privileged exporters over inland dealers, aimed at price inflation rather than supply, and was proved fundamentally wrong by Britain's constant need for emergency reversals.
notes: The asymmetry between export and inland trade regulation is perverse: the less dangerous trade (inland) is more restricted than the more dangerous (export). Repeated emergency legislation as proof of system failure -- Smith's most effective argumentative device. Cross-reference: 4.5.70-71 on inland trade restrictions; 4.5.79 on temporary suspensions.

refashioned: If all nations adopted the liberal system of free export and import, the different states of a great continent would resemble the provinces of a great empire. Just as free internal trade within a great empire is -- by both reason and experience -- not only the best palliative for dearth but the most effective preventive of famine, so would free international trade be among the states of a continent. The larger the continent and the easier its internal communications by land and water, the less any one part would be exposed to either calamity, since the scarcity of one area would more likely be relieved by the plenty of another.
elegant: Under universal free trade, the states of a continent would function like provinces of a single empire. Free internal trade prevents famine within empires; free international trade would do the same across continents. The larger the trading area and the better its communications, the less any region would suffer from scarcity.
summary: Universal free trade would make the states of a continent function like provinces of an empire, where free internal trade is the best famine prevention. Larger trading areas with better communications would make any region less vulnerable to scarcity.
distilled: Universal free trade among nations would replicate the famine-preventing benefits of free internal trade within empires, with larger trading areas providing greater security.
notes: Vision of continental free trade as extended internal market -- a precursor to common market theory and the EU concept. Scale and communication as determinants of food security. Free trade as insurance against regional scarcity. Cross-reference: 4.5.55 on geographic risk diversification.

refashioned: But very few countries have fully adopted this liberal system. The freedom of the corn trade is almost everywhere more or less restricted, and in many countries confined by regulations so absurd that they frequently turn the unavoidable misfortune of a dearth into the dreadful catastrophe of a famine. The resulting demand for corn from such countries may become so great and urgent that a small neighboring state, itself laboring under some degree of dearth, could not venture to supply them without risking the same catastrophe at home. The very bad policy of one country may thus make it dangerous and imprudent to establish in another country what would otherwise be the best policy.
elegant: Few countries have adopted full free trade in corn. Bad regulations elsewhere often turn dearths into famines, creating sudden desperate demand that could drain a small neighboring country's own scarce supply. One nation's bad policy can thus make free trade dangerous for its neighbors -- a contagion effect of protectionism.
summary: Since few countries practice free trade in grain, their bad policies often create famine-driven demand surges that could drain small neighbors' supplies. One country's protectionism can make free trade risky for others.
distilled: Bad corn policies in one country can make free trade dangerous for its neighbors by creating desperate famine-driven demand surges that drain their supplies.
notes: International policy contagion -- bad policy spreads through trade linkages. Second-best argument: optimal policy depends on others' policies. Strategic complementarity in trade regulation. This is Smith's most nuanced acknowledgment that unilateral free trade has risks. Cross-reference: 4.5.86 for his partial resolution.

refashioned: However, unlimited export freedom would be much less dangerous for large states, where growth is so substantial that no likely export volume could significantly affect supply. In a Swiss canton or an Italian city-state, it may sometimes be necessary to restrict corn exports. In great countries like France or England, this is almost never the case. Furthermore, to prevent the farmer from sending his goods at all times to the best market is clearly to sacrifice the ordinary laws of justice to a notion of public utility -- a kind of reason of state that should be invoked only, and can be forgiven only, in cases of the most urgent necessity.
elegant: Large countries like France or England face negligible risk from free corn exports -- no plausible volume could significantly affect their supply. Export restrictions might sometimes be necessary for tiny states like Swiss cantons. Blocking a farmer from selling in the best market sacrifices ordinary justice to reasons of state -- a power that should be exercised only in the most extreme necessity.
summary: Large countries face little risk from free corn exports, unlike small states. Restricting exports sacrifices ordinary justice to political expediency and should be tolerated only in cases of extreme necessity.
distilled: Large nations face negligible risk from free corn exports; restricting them sacrifices ordinary justice to political expediency and is justified only in extreme necessity.
notes: Size matters: large countries are naturally buffered against export-driven scarcity. Justice vs. utility tension -- Smith sides with justice except in extremis. 'Reason of state' used pejoratively. Property rights of farmers to sell freely as a justice claim. Cross-reference: 4.5.84-85 on the continental free trade ideal.

refashioned:
The price at which corn exports are prohibited, if they are ever to be prohibited, ought always to be set very high.

The laws concerning corn may everywhere be compared to the laws concerning religion. People feel so deeply invested in matters relating to their subsistence in this life, and to their happiness in a life to come, that government must yield to their prejudices and, to preserve public peace, establish whatever system they approve of. It is on this account, perhaps, that we so seldom find a reasonable system established with regard to either of these two fundamental subjects.
elegant: If corn exports are ever prohibited, the trigger price should be very high. Laws on corn, like laws on religion, must yield to popular prejudice to maintain public order. This is why reasonable policy on either subject is so rare.
summary: Any export prohibition on corn should be triggered only at very high prices. Smith compares corn laws to religious laws: both must accommodate deep popular prejudices, which is why rational policy on either subject is so rare.
distilled: Corn export prohibition should require very high trigger prices; corn laws, like religious laws, are distorted by deep popular prejudices that governments dare not challenge.
notes: Remarkable analogy between corn laws and religious laws -- both domains of deep popular feeling where rational policy is politically impossible. Political economy of democratic prejudice. The trigger price should be 'very high' -- as minimal a restriction as possible. Cross-reference: 4.5.72 on engrossing fear as witchcraft belief.

refashioned: Fourth: the trade of the merchant-carrier -- importing foreign corn in order to export it again -- contributes to the home market's plentiful supply. Although it is not the carrier's direct purpose to sell his corn domestically, he will generally be willing to do so, and for considerably less money than he might expect in a foreign market, because he saves the costs of loading, unloading, freight, and insurance. The inhabitants of a country that becomes, through the carrying trade, a warehouse and storehouse for supplying other nations can very seldom find themselves in want. Though the carrying trade would tend to reduce the average money price of corn in the home market, it would not lower corn's real value -- it would only raise the real value of silver somewhat.
elegant: The corn carrying trade -- importing to re-export -- benefits the home market as a side effect. Carriers will gladly sell domestically at below-foreign prices to save transport costs. Countries that become grain entrepots rarely face shortages. The carrying trade may lower corn's money price but not its real value -- only silver's value rises.
summary: The corn carrying trade benefits the home market indirectly, as carriers prefer selling domestically to save on transport costs. Countries serving as grain entrepots rarely face shortages. Lower money prices from this trade reflect higher silver value, not lower real corn value.
distilled: The corn carrying trade benefits the home market because carriers sell domestically to save transport costs, and countries that become grain entrepots rarely face shortages.
notes: Fourth and final branch of the corn trade. The entrepot effect: warehousing for others provides domestic supply security. Carrier's incentive to sell locally (transport cost savings) as automatic home market benefit. Real vs. nominal price distinction applied again. Cross-reference: 4.5.48 for the four-branch framework.

refashioned: The carrying trade was in effect prohibited in Great Britain under normal circumstances by the high import duties on foreign corn, most of which allowed no drawback. During emergencies, when scarcity forced temporary suspension of these duties, exports were always simultaneously prohibited. The British system of laws therefore effectively eliminated the carrying trade in corn.
elegant: Britain effectively prohibited the corn carrying trade through high import duties with no drawbacks. When emergencies forced temporary duty suspensions, simultaneous export bans prevented any carrying trade from developing. The system systematically excluded this beneficial commerce.
summary: Britain's corn laws effectively prohibited the carrying trade through high import duties without drawbacks, and by banning exports whenever emergency legislation temporarily reduced import duties.
distilled: Britain's corn laws systematically eliminated the beneficial carrying trade by combining prohibitive import duties with export bans during the only periods when those duties were suspended.
notes: The carrying trade's elimination shows how import and export regulations interact to compound harm. Drawback refusal as additional trade barrier. The system's internal logic prevents any beneficial loophole. Cross-reference: 4.5.80 on cascading policy distortions.

refashioned: The system of laws connected with the bounty therefore deserves none of the praise heaped upon it. The improvement and prosperity of Great Britain, so often attributed to these laws, can easily be explained by other causes. The security that British law gives to every person -- the assurance that they shall enjoy the fruits of their own labor -- is alone sufficient to make any country flourish, notwithstanding these and twenty other absurd commercial regulations. This security was perfected by the Revolution of 1688, roughly when the bounty was also established. The natural effort of every individual to better his own condition, when allowed to operate with freedom and security, is so powerful a principle that it is capable, entirely on its own, of carrying society to wealth and prosperity. It can even surmount a hundred impertinent obstructions with which the folly of human laws too often encumbers its operations -- though those obstructions always either encroach upon its freedom or diminish its security. In Great Britain, industry is perfectly secure; and though it is far from perfectly free, it is as free or freer than in any other part of Europe.
elegant: Britain's prosperity owes nothing to its corn laws and everything to the security of property and individual liberty established by the Revolution of 1688. Every individual's natural drive to improve their condition, operating with freedom and security, is powerful enough to overcome a hundred foolish regulations. Though British industry is not perfectly free, its perfect security suffices for prosperity despite every legislative folly.
summary: Smith attributes Britain's prosperity not to its corn laws but to the security of property perfected by the 1688 Revolution. Individual self-improvement, operating with freedom and security, is powerful enough to overcome even extensive government folly. Britain prospers because of its security despite, not because of, its commercial regulations.
distilled: Britain prospers because the Revolution of 1688 secured property rights and individual liberty -- forces powerful enough to overcome the folly of its corn laws and commercial regulations.
notes: One of Smith's most powerful passages on the resilience of markets. The 1688 Revolution as the true source of British prosperity. 'Natural effort to better his own condition' -- a key phrase for Smith's entire philosophy. Security of property as the fundamental prerequisite for prosperity. Regulations as 'impertinent obstructions' that are overcome, not that help. Cross-reference: 4.2 on the invisible hand; 4.9 on the system of natural liberty.

refashioned:
Though Great Britain's greatest prosperity came after the corn law system was established, we must not attribute it to those laws. It also came after the national debt was created, but the national debt most assuredly did not cause it.

Although the corn law system has the same tendency as the policies of Spain and Portugal -- lowering the value of precious metals domestically -- Britain remains one of the richest countries in Europe, while Spain and Portugal are among the poorest. This difference is easily explained by two factors. First, Spain's tax on and Portugal's prohibition of gold and silver exports, rigorously enforced in countries that together import over six million sterling of precious metals annually, operate far more directly and forcefully in depressing metal values than Britain's corn laws can. Second, this bad policy is not counterbalanced in Spain and Portugal by the general liberty and security of the people. Industry there is neither free nor secure. The civil and ecclesiastical governments of both countries are themselves sufficient to perpetuate poverty, even if their commercial regulations were wise instead of being mostly absurd and foolish.
elegant: Britain's prosperity followed but was not caused by its corn laws -- just as it followed but was not caused by the national debt. Britain thrives despite corn laws because its people enjoy liberty and security. Spain and Portugal, whose precious metal policies are far more damaging versions of the same logic, remain poor because they lack this counterbalance -- their oppressive civil and ecclesiastical governments perpetuate poverty regardless of trade policy.
summary: Post hoc reasoning cannot credit corn laws for British prosperity any more than for the national debt. Britain succeeds despite its corn laws because of property security and personal liberty. Spain and Portugal, with far worse versions of the same policies and no counterbalancing freedom, remain poor.
distilled: Britain prospers despite its corn laws because of liberty and property security; Spain and Portugal remain poor under similar but harsher policies because they lack these counterbalancing freedoms.
notes: Post hoc fallacy explicitly identified. National debt comparison is devastating. Comparative institutional analysis: same bad trade policy, different outcomes based on institutional quality. Liberty and security as the overriding determinants of prosperity. Spanish/Portuguese civil and ecclesiastical governments as ultimate causes of poverty. Cross-reference: 4.5.17-25 on Spain/Portugal; 4.5.90 on the 1688 Revolution.

refashioned:
The statute of the thirteenth year of the present king, chapter 43, seems to have established a new system regarding corn laws, in many respects better than the old one, though in one or two respects perhaps not quite as good.

Under this statute, the high import duties for home consumption are removed as soon as the price of middling wheat reaches forty-eight shillings per quarter, that of middling rye, peas, or beans reaches thirty-two shillings, that of barley twenty-four shillings, and that of oats sixteen shillings. In place of the old duties, only a small duty of sixpence per quarter of wheat is imposed, with other grains in proportion. For all these grains, but particularly for wheat, the home market is thus opened to foreign supply at considerably lower prices than before.
elegant: The new statute (13th of the present king) significantly improves on the old corn law system by lowering the price thresholds at which import duties are reduced. High duties now drop to just sixpence per quarter of wheat once prices reach forty-eight shillings -- opening the home market to foreign supply at much lower crisis points than before.
summary: The reformed corn law statute significantly lowered the price thresholds at which prohibitive import duties are replaced by a nominal sixpence per quarter, opening the home market to foreign supply during less severe scarcity than the old system allowed.
distilled: The reformed corn law improved on the old system by opening the home market to foreign grain at significantly lower price thresholds.
notes: Analysis of the 1773 reform (13 Geo. III, c.43). Import duty reform: replacing prohibitive duties with nominal ones at lower trigger prices. Smith's balanced assessment: improvement with caveats. Cross-reference: 4.5.77-78 for the old duty schedule.

refashioned: Under the same statute, the old bounty of five shillings on wheat exports ceases at forty-four shillings per quarter instead of the previous forty-eight shillings. The two shillings sixpence bounty on barley exports ceases at twenty-two shillings instead of twenty-four. The two shillings sixpence bounty on oatmeal exports ceases at fourteen shillings instead of fifteen. The bounty on rye is reduced from three shillings sixpence to three shillings, and ceases at twenty-eight shillings instead of thirty-two. If bounties are as improper as I have tried to prove, the sooner they cease and the lower they are set, the better.
elegant: The reformed statute lowers all bounty thresholds: wheat's bounty now ceases at forty-four shillings instead of forty-eight, with proportional reductions for other grains. Since bounties are fundamentally harmful, these reductions are improvements -- the sooner bounties cease and the lower they are, the better.
summary: The reform lowers the price thresholds at which export bounties cease, effectively reducing their scope. Smith approves: since all bounties are harmful, any reduction in their reach is an improvement.
distilled: The reformed law reduces export bounty thresholds, which Smith approves since any reduction in bounties' scope is beneficial.
notes: Bounty reform: lower cessation thresholds reduce the bounty's operating range. Smith's pragmatism: if abolition is impossible, reduction is welcome. Consistent with his earlier argument that bounties are fundamentally harmful. Cross-reference: 4.5.31 on bounties as triply defective.

refashioned: The same statute permits, at the lowest prices, the importation of corn for re-export duty-free, provided it is stored in a warehouse under the joint locks of the king and the importer. This liberty extends to only twenty-five of Great Britain's ports. These are, however, the principal ones, and there may not be warehouses suitable for this purpose in most of the others.
elegant: The reform also permits duty-free corn imports for re-export through bonded warehouses at twenty-five principal ports. This partially restores the carrying trade that the old system had effectively prohibited.
summary: The reformed statute partially restores the carrying trade by allowing duty-free corn imports for re-export through bonded warehouses at twenty-five principal ports.
distilled: The reform partially restores the corn carrying trade through bonded warehousing at twenty-five principal ports.
notes: Bonded warehouse system as a mechanism for restoring the carrying trade. Joint locks (king and importer) prevent diversion to the domestic market without duty. Limited to 25 ports -- practical constraint. Cross-reference: 4.5.88-89 on the carrying trade's elimination and benefits.

refashioned:
In these respects, the new law is clearly an improvement upon the old system.

But under the same law, a bounty of two shillings per quarter is given for exporting oats whenever the price does not exceed fourteen shillings. No bounty had ever been given before for exporting oats, nor for peas or beans.
elegant: The new law is generally an improvement. But it introduces a new bounty of two shillings per quarter on oat exports below fourteen shillings -- a bounty that never existed before for oats, peas, or beans.
summary: While the reformed corn law is generally superior, it introduces a new export bounty on oats that never previously existed, extending the harmful bounty system to additional crops.
distilled: The otherwise improved reform introduces a new oat export bounty, extending the harmful bounty system to a crop that had never before been subsidized.
notes: The reform's flaw: extending bounties to new commodities while reducing them on old ones. Two steps forward, one step back. Demonstrates the political difficulty of pure reform -- new subsidies attached to liberalizing legislation. Cross-reference: 4.5.31 on bounties as fundamentally harmful.

refashioned: Under the same law, wheat exports are banned once the price reaches forty-four shillings per quarter; rye at twenty-eight shillings; barley at twenty-two shillings; and oats at fourteen shillings. All of these price thresholds appear to be set considerably too low. Beyond that, there is an obvious inconsistency in banning exports at the exact same price levels where the bounty designed to encourage exports is withdrawn. Logically, either the bounty should have been removed at a much lower price, or exports should have been permitted to continue until a much higher price was reached.
elegant: The law bans grain exports at the same prices where bounties are withdrawn -- thresholds that are too low and logically inconsistent. Either bounties should end at lower prices, or exports should be allowed at higher ones.
summary: The export prohibition thresholds for various grains are set too low and are inconsistent with bounty withdrawal points. The policy contradicts itself by banning exports precisely where the incentive to export disappears.
distilled: Export bans trigger at the same prices where bounties end, creating an illogical policy gap.
notes: Export bounties vs. prohibitions -- policy inconsistency in grain trade regulation -- price thresholds for wheat, rye, barley, oats -- connects to 4.5.84 on bounty design

refashioned: In this respect, the new law appears inferior to the older system. Despite all its flaws, however, we might say of it what was said of the laws of Solon: that while not the best system in itself, it is the best that the interests, prejudices, and temper of the times would allow. Perhaps in time it will pave the way for something better.
elegant: The new law is inferior to the old system, but like Solon's laws, it may be the best the current political climate permits -- and may eventually prepare the way for genuine improvement.
summary: Though the new corn law is worse than the older system, it reflects what was politically achievable given prevailing interests and biases. It may gradually open the door to better policy.
distilled: The imperfect new law is the best current politics allows and may eventually lead to real reform.
notes: Solon's laws as pragmatic compromise -- political feasibility vs. ideal policy -- gradualism in reform -- concludes Chapter 4.5 on bounties

refashioned: When a nation commits by treaty to admit certain goods from one foreign country while prohibiting them from all others, or to exempt one country's goods from duties imposed on everyone else, the favored country -- or at least its merchants and manufacturers -- inevitably gains a major advantage. Those merchants and manufacturers enjoy what amounts to a monopoly in the country that grants such preferential terms. That country becomes a larger and more profitable market for their goods: larger, because competing nations' products are either excluded or subjected to heavier duties, so consumers buy more from the favored country; more profitable, because the favored merchants, facing less competition, can often charge higher prices than they could under open trade with all nations.
elegant: When a nation grants trade preferences to one country by treaty -- admitting its goods while excluding or taxing others -- the favored country's merchants gain a near-monopoly. They enjoy both a larger market (competitors being excluded) and higher prices (competition being reduced).
summary: Trade treaties that favor one country over others grant its merchants a virtual monopoly in the treaty partner's market, allowing them to sell more goods at higher prices than free competition would permit.
distilled: Preferential trade treaties grant the favored nation's merchants a monopoly advantage through both expanded market share and higher prices.
notes: Treaties of commerce -- preferential trade agreements -- monopoly through diplomatic privilege -- Chapter 4.6 begins: Of Treaties of Commerce -- connects to 4.2 on import restrictions

refashioned: Such treaties, while beneficial to the merchants and manufacturers of the favored nation, are necessarily harmful to those of the nation granting the favor. A monopoly is effectively given to a foreign nation at their expense, and they must frequently pay more for foreign goods than they would if all nations could compete freely. The domestic goods exchanged for these imports must consequently be sold more cheaply, since when two things are traded, the dearness of one necessarily implies the cheapness of the other. The exchangeable value of the favoring nation's annual output is therefore likely to be reduced by every such treaty. This reduction, however, does not amount to an absolute loss, but rather a diminished gain compared to what might otherwise be achieved. Although the favoring country sells its goods more cheaply than it otherwise would, it probably does not sell them below cost. Unlike the situation with bounties, prices will still cover the capital invested plus ordinary profits -- otherwise the trade could not continue. So even the favoring country still gains from the trade, just less than it would under free competition.
elegant: Preferential treaties harm the favoring country's merchants by granting a foreign monopoly against them. They pay more for imports and receive less for exports. However, this amounts to reduced gains rather than actual losses -- trade still covers costs and normal profits. The favoring country still benefits, just less than under free competition.
summary: Trade treaties that favor foreign nations force domestic merchants to buy imports at higher prices and sell exports at lower ones. While this reduces the exchangeable value of national output, it diminishes gains rather than causing outright losses, since trade still remains profitable.
distilled: Preferential trade treaties reduce the favoring nation's gains without causing absolute losses, since trade remains profitable even under unfavorable terms.
notes: Asymmetric gains from preferential trade -- exchangeable value of annual produce -- distinction between reduced gain and positive loss -- comparison with bounties -- connects to 4.3 on trade balance

refashioned: Some commercial treaties, however, have been praised on entirely different grounds. A commercial nation has sometimes granted a foreign monopoly against itself because it expected that, across the full scope of bilateral trade, it would sell more than it bought each year, receiving the balance in gold and silver. It is on this principle that the 1703 treaty of commerce between England and Portugal -- the Methuen Treaty -- has been so widely celebrated. What follows is a direct translation of that treaty, which contains just three articles.
elegant: Some treaties have been praised not for mutual advantage but because one country expected to run a trade surplus paid in gold and silver. The 1703 Methuen Treaty between England and Portugal was celebrated on precisely this mercantilist principle.
summary: The Methuen Treaty of 1703 between England and Portugal has been praised because England expected the overall trade balance to yield a surplus in gold and silver, though this reasoning reflects mercantilist assumptions about wealth.
distilled: The celebrated Methuen Treaty was praised on the mercantilist ground that England would receive gold and silver as a trade surplus.
notes: Methuen Treaty 1703 -- mercantilist logic of favorable trade balance -- gold and silver as wealth -- Anglo-Portuguese commerce -- connects to 4.1 on balance of trade doctrine

refashioned:
Article I: The King of Portugal promises, on behalf of himself and his successors, to permanently admit into Portugal British woollen cloth and other woollen manufactures, as was the practice before they were banned by law -- subject to the following condition:

Article II: The Queen of Great Britain shall, on behalf of herself and her successors, be permanently obliged to admit Portuguese wines into Britain. At no time, whether Britain and France are at peace or war, shall Portuguese wines be charged any customs, duties, or fees -- whether imported in pipes, hogsheads, or other containers -- beyond what is charged for the same quantity of French wine, less a one-third reduction. If this one-third duty reduction is ever violated or undermined, the King of Portugal shall have the right to once again ban British woollen cloth and other woollen manufactures.
elegant: Article I: Portugal will permanently readmit British woollens. Article II: In return, Britain will permanently charge Portuguese wines no more than two-thirds the duty on French wines. If Britain breaks this commitment, Portugal may ban British woollens again.
summary: The Methuen Treaty required Portugal to readmit British woollen goods and Britain to tax Portuguese wines at one-third less than French wines. Violation of the wine duty concession would allow Portugal to reimpose its ban on British woollens.
distilled: Portugal agreed to admit British woollens in exchange for Britain taxing Portuguese wines at two-thirds the French wine duty.
notes: Methuen Treaty Articles I and II -- reciprocal trade obligations -- woollen manufactures for wine -- preferential duty rates -- enforcement mechanism through retaliatory prohibition

refashioned:
Article III: The plenipotentiaries promise that their respective sovereigns will ratify this treaty, with ratifications to be exchanged within two months.

Under this treaty, Portugal is bound only to readmit English woollens on the same terms as before the prohibition -- meaning it cannot raise duties above their previous levels. But Portugal is not obliged to give English woollens better terms than those offered to any other nation, such as France or Holland. Britain, by contrast, commits to admitting Portuguese wines at only two-thirds the duty charged on French wines -- the wines most likely to compete with them. The treaty is therefore clearly advantageous to Portugal and disadvantageous to Great Britain.
elegant: Article III covers ratification. Crucially, Portugal merely restores the old duty on British woollens without granting preferential terms, while Britain commits to charging Portuguese wines one-third less than French wines. The treaty clearly favors Portugal over Britain.
summary: While Portugal only restores previous import terms for British woollens without preferential treatment, Britain commits to a permanent one-third duty reduction on Portuguese wines versus French wines. The treaty's terms clearly favor Portugal.
distilled: The Methuen Treaty favored Portugal because Britain made real duty concessions on wine while Portugal merely restored pre-existing terms for British woollens.
notes: Asymmetry of treaty obligations -- Portugal's limited commitment vs. Britain's binding concession -- French wine competition -- analysis of who benefits from trade treaties

refashioned: Despite this asymmetry, the treaty has been celebrated as a masterpiece of English commercial policy. Portugal annually receives from Brazil more gold than its domestic economy can absorb, whether as coin or plate. This surplus is too valuable to sit idle in storage, and since it finds no profitable use at home, it must -- regardless of any prohibition -- be sent abroad and exchanged for goods that have better domestic markets. A large portion comes annually to England, either in payment for English goods or for goods from other European nations whose trade passes through England. Barretti reported that the weekly packet-boat from Lisbon carried, on average, more than 50,000 pounds in gold to England. This figure was probably exaggerated -- it would amount to over 2,600,000 pounds per year, more than Brazil was thought to produce.
elegant: The treaty was praised as commercial genius because Portugal's surplus Brazilian gold -- too large for domestic use -- inevitably flowed to England in exchange for goods. Reportedly 50,000 pounds weekly arrived by packet-boat from Lisbon, though this likely overstates the actual amount.
summary: The Methuen Treaty was celebrated because Portugal's surplus gold from Brazil naturally flowed to England through trade. Reports of 50,000 pounds in gold arriving weekly from Lisbon were likely exaggerated, as this would exceed Brazil's estimated gold output.
distilled: The treaty was praised because Portugal's surplus Brazilian gold naturally flowed to England, though reported amounts were probably exaggerated.
notes: Brazilian gold flows -- Portugal as gold conduit -- Barretti's estimate of weekly gold shipments -- distinction between treaty effects and natural trade patterns -- connects to 4.1 on gold accumulation

refashioned: Some years ago, English merchants grew dissatisfied with the Portuguese crown. Certain privileges that had been granted not by treaty but as voluntary concessions -- likely in exchange for the much greater benefits of British military defense and protection -- were either curtailed or revoked. As a result, the merchants who normally championed the Portugal trade suddenly began portraying it as far less advantageous than commonly believed. They claimed that the vast majority of the annual gold imports were not actually on Britain's account but on behalf of other European nations, and that Portuguese fruits and wines imported into Britain roughly offset the value of British goods sent to Portugal.
elegant: When Portuguese privileges for British merchants were revoked, those same merchants reversed their praise of the trade. They now claimed most gold imports came on behalf of other European nations, and that Portuguese wines and fruits roughly balanced British exports.
summary: When Portugal revoked trading privileges, British merchants who had praised the trade suddenly portrayed it as far less valuable, claiming gold imports mostly served other European nations and that Portuguese wine imports roughly offset British exports.
distilled: British merchants reversed their praise of the Portugal trade when their privileges were revoked, suddenly claiming the gold inflows mostly belonged to other nations.
notes: Self-interested representations by merchants -- shifting narratives about trade value -- Portuguese privileges revoked -- gold imports attributed to third-party accounts -- connects to 4.3 on merchant bias

refashioned:
But even if we suppose that all the gold imports were on Britain's account and amounted to even more than Barretti estimated, this trade would be no more advantageous than any other in which the same value sent out returned an equal value of consumable goods.

Only a tiny fraction of this gold can be assumed to serve as annual additions to Britain's plate or coinage. The rest must be re-exported and exchanged for consumable goods. But if those consumable goods could be purchased directly with English manufactures, it would be more advantageous than first buying Portuguese gold and then using that gold to buy the desired goods. A direct foreign trade is always more efficient than a roundabout one, requiring far less capital to bring the same value of goods to the home market. If less English industry were devoted to producing goods for the Portuguese market, and more to producing goods for markets where Britain's desired consumable goods could be obtained directly, England would benefit more. Procuring both the gold needed for domestic purposes and the desired consumer goods would, through direct trade, require much less capital -- freeing the remainder to stimulate additional industry and increase the nation's total annual output.
elegant: Even if all the gold were on Britain's account, the trade would be no better than any returning equal value in consumable goods. Most gold must be re-exported anyway. Direct trade for consumer goods is always more efficient than the roundabout route of first buying gold, then buying goods with it -- requiring less capital and freeing resources for productive use.
summary: Even granting all gold imports to Britain's account, the Portugal trade offers no special advantage over direct trade in consumable goods. Roundabout trade through gold intermediation wastes capital that could be more productively employed in direct foreign commerce.
distilled: Direct trade for consumable goods is always more efficient than the roundabout route of first acquiring gold and then trading it for what is actually needed.
notes: Direct vs. roundabout trade -- capital efficiency in foreign commerce -- gold as unnecessary intermediary -- opportunity cost of capital -- connects to 4.3 on carrying trade and capital allocation

refashioned: Even if Britain were entirely shut out of the Portugal trade, it would have little difficulty obtaining all the gold it needs for plate, coinage, or foreign trade. Gold, like any other commodity, can always be purchased somewhere by those willing to pay its value. Portugal's surplus gold would still be exported regardless -- if not to Britain, then to some other nation happy to resell it at market price, just as Britain does now. Buying gold directly from Portugal means buying at first hand, whereas purchasing from any other nation except Spain would mean buying secondhand, perhaps at a slightly higher price. But this difference would surely be too trivial to warrant public concern.
elegant: Even without the Portugal trade, Britain could easily obtain gold elsewhere. Gold is a commodity available to any buyer at its market value. Portugal's surplus would still be exported to willing intermediaries. The slight premium of buying secondhand rather than directly would be too trivial to matter.
summary: Britain could obtain its gold needs without the Portugal trade, since gold as a commodity is always available at market price. Portugal's surplus would flow to other nations who would gladly resell it, with only a negligible price difference.
distilled: Gold is a commodity available everywhere at its value, so losing the Portugal trade would impose only a trivial cost on Britain's gold supply.
notes: Fungibility of gold as commodity -- international gold market -- first-hand vs. secondhand purchase -- insignificance of small price differentials -- connects to 4.1 on gold supply

refashioned: It is often said that almost all our gold comes from Portugal, and that with other nations the trade balance is either against us or barely in our favor. But we should recognize that the more gold we import from one country, the less we necessarily import from all others. The effective demand for gold, like that for any commodity, is limited to a certain quantity in every country. If nine-tenths of that quantity comes from one source, only one-tenth remains to be imported from everywhere else. Furthermore, the more gold imported from particular countries beyond what is needed for plate and coinage, the more must be exported elsewhere. The more that the balance of trade -- that most trivial preoccupation of modern policy -- appears favorable with certain countries, the more it must necessarily appear unfavorable with many others.
elegant: The more gold we import from Portugal, the less we need from elsewhere -- demand for gold is limited. Excess gold beyond domestic needs must be re-exported. A favorable trade balance with one country automatically implies unfavorable balances with others, making the whole concept meaningless.
summary: Since national demand for gold is finite, importing more from Portugal simply means importing less from other countries. Surplus gold must be re-exported, so a favorable balance with one nation automatically creates unfavorable balances elsewhere.
distilled: Importing more gold from one country means importing less from others, making bilateral trade balances a meaningless measure of national advantage.
notes: Fixed demand for gold -- zero-sum nature of bilateral balances -- balance of trade as 'most insignificant object of modern policy' -- connects to 4.1 and 4.3 on trade balance fallacy

refashioned: It was based on the foolish notion that England could not survive without the Portugal trade that, toward the end of the recent war, France and Spain -- without claiming any offense or provocation -- demanded that Portugal's king exclude all British ships from his ports and, to enforce this exclusion, accept French or Spanish garrisons. Had the king of Portugal accepted the humiliating terms proposed by his brother-in-law, the king of Spain, Britain would actually have been relieved of a far greater burden than the loss of the Portugal trade: the expense of defending a very weak ally so completely unprepared for self-defense that the full power of England, directed entirely to that purpose, could scarcely have protected him for another campaign. The loss of the Portugal trade would certainly have caused significant disruption for the merchants then engaged in it, who might not have found equally profitable uses for their capital for a year or two. And that, most likely, would have been the full extent of England's inconvenience from this supposedly devastating act of commercial warfare.
elegant: France and Spain tried to exploit the belief that Britain depended on Portugal trade by pressuring Portugal to close its ports. But losing this trade would actually have relieved Britain of the greater burden of defending a weak ally. The only real inconvenience would have been temporary disruption for merchants needing to redeploy their capital.
summary: The belief that Britain could not survive without the Portugal trade was exploited when France and Spain pressured Portugal to close its ports to Britain. In reality, losing the trade would have been a minor inconvenience -- a temporary disruption for affected merchants -- while relieving Britain of the costly burden of defending a weak ally.
distilled: The supposed indispensability of the Portugal trade was a myth; losing it would have been a temporary merchant inconvenience while relieving Britain of expensive alliance obligations.
notes: Geopolitical leverage from trade dependence myths -- Seven Years' War context -- cost of defending weak allies -- temporary vs. permanent trade disruption -- merchant capital redeployment

refashioned: The large annual importation of gold and silver serves neither plate nor coinage primarily, but foreign trade. Roundabout foreign trade can be conducted more efficiently using precious metals than almost any other goods. As universal instruments of commerce, gold and silver are more readily accepted in exchange for all commodities. Their high value relative to their small bulk makes them cheaper to transport back and forth than nearly any other merchandise, and they lose less value in transit. Of all commodities bought in one foreign country solely to be resold in another, none are as convenient as gold and silver. The main advantage of the Portugal trade lies in facilitating Britain's various roundabout foreign trades -- and while this is not a critical advantage, it is certainly a significant one.
elegant: Gold and silver imports serve foreign trade, not plate or coinage. As universally accepted, compact, and durable mediums of exchange, precious metals are ideal for roundabout trade between countries. This facilitation of indirect commerce is the Portugal trade's real -- though not critical -- advantage.
summary: The primary purpose of gold and silver imports is to facilitate roundabout foreign trade, not to increase plate or coinage. Precious metals' universal acceptance, compact value, and durability make them ideal intermediaries, giving the Portugal trade a significant though not essential advantage.
distilled: The real value of the Portugal trade is that gold and silver, being universally accepted and easily transported, facilitate Britain's roundabout foreign commerce.
notes: Gold and silver as trade facilitators -- properties of precious metals for commerce: universal acceptance, compact value, durability -- roundabout vs. direct trade -- connects to 4.1 on functions of money

refashioned:
Any annual addition to the nation's plate or coinage would clearly require only a very small gold and silver importation, and even without direct trade with Portugal, this small quantity could always be obtained somewhere.

Although the goldsmith trade is considerable in Great Britain, the vast majority of new plate sold each year is made from old plate melted down. The net annual addition to the kingdom's total plate is therefore quite small and would require only a minimal annual import of gold and silver.
elegant: The nation's annual need for new plate and coin requires very little gold, easily sourced without the Portugal trade. Most new plate is recycled from old -- the net addition is minimal.
summary: Britain's actual annual need for new gold and silver for plate and coinage is very small, since most new plate is made from melting old plate. This tiny requirement could easily be met without direct Portuguese trade.
distilled: Since most new plate comes from recycled old plate, Britain's actual annual gold import needs are minimal and easily met without Portugal.
notes: Recycling of plate -- minimal net additions to national gold stock -- goldsmith trade practices -- overstated importance of gold imports -- connects to 4.6.8 on gold as intermediary

refashioned: The same is true of coinage. No one believes, I think, that even the greater part of annual coinage -- which for ten years before the recent gold coin reformation averaged over 800,000 pounds per year -- represented a net addition to the money already circulating. In a country where the government pays for coinage, the value of coins at full standard weight can never greatly exceed that of equivalent uncoined metal, since anyone can take bullion to the mint and receive coins back after only a few weeks' delay. Yet in every country, most circulating coins are always somewhat worn or debased below their standard weight. In Great Britain before the recent reformation, this was significantly so: gold coins were more than two percent below standard weight, and silver more than eight percent below.
elegant: Most annual coinage replaces worn coins rather than adding to the money supply. When government-funded coinage is free, coins barely exceed bullion value. Before the reformation, British gold was two percent and silver eight percent below standard weight, driving constant recoinage.
summary: Annual coinage mostly replaces worn and degraded coins rather than adding new money to circulation. Government-funded free coinage means coins are worth little more than their metal content, and before the recent reformation, British coins were significantly below their standard weight.
distilled: Most annual coinage merely replaces worn coins rather than expanding the money supply, since free government coinage keeps coin value close to bullion value.
notes: Coinage as replacement vs. addition -- free coinage and bullion-coin value relationship -- coin degradation: gold -2%, silver -8% -- mint operations and delay -- connects to 4.6.13 on minimal net gold needs

refashioned: If forty-four and a half guineas at full standard weight -- equaling one pound of gold -- could buy barely more than a pound of uncoined gold, then forty-four and a half guineas that were underweight could not buy a full pound, and something had to be added to make up the shortfall. The market price of gold bullion therefore stood not at the mint price of 46 pounds 14 shillings 6 pence, but at roughly 47 pounds 14 shillings, sometimes reaching 48 pounds. Yet even when the majority of coins were in this degraded condition, newly minted guineas at full weight bought no more goods in the market than any other worn guinea. Once mixed into a merchant's cash holdings, fresh coins could not be distinguished from worn ones without more effort than the difference justified. Like any other guinea, they were worth no more than 46 pounds 14 shillings 6 pence.
elegant: Underweight guineas could not buy a full pound of gold at the mint price, pushing bullion prices above 47 pounds. Yet even full-weight new guineas bought no more than worn ones in practice, since merchants could not distinguish them without disproportionate effort.
summary: When coins were degraded, gold bullion traded above the mint price because underweight coins could not purchase their face value in gold. Even newly minted full-weight coins were worth no more than worn ones in commerce, since merchants could not practically sort them.
distilled: Degraded coinage pushed bullion prices above mint prices, while new full-weight coins lost their premium once mixed with worn coins in circulation.
