summary: Population grows with economic development, so despite the devastating impact of conquest on indigenous peoples, the former empires of Mexico and Peru are likely more populous than before, sustained by European agricultural and technological improvements.
distilled: Despite the devastation of conquest, Mexico and Peru are probably more populous now because European technology enabled greater agricultural development.
notes: Population as function of development -- cruel destruction of natives acknowledged -- creole vs. indigenous population -- controversial claim of superiority -- reflects 18th-century European perspectives -- connects to 4.7.32 on technological improvement

refashioned: After Spain's settlements, Portugal's in Brazil is the oldest European colony in America. Since neither gold nor silver mines were found there for a long time, providing little revenue to the crown, Brazil was largely neglected -- and during this period of neglect it grew into a great and powerful colony. While Portugal was under Spanish rule, the Dutch attacked Brazil and seized seven of its fourteen provinces, expecting to conquer the rest. But when Portugal regained independence under the House of Braganza, the Dutch -- enemies of Spain but now friends of Portugal, which was also Spain's enemy -- agreed to leave the unconquered provinces to Portugal, considering the matter hardly worth disputing with such useful allies. The Dutch government soon began oppressing the Portuguese colonists, who, rather than wasting time on complaints, took up arms against their new masters and through their own courage and determination -- with the mother country's tacit consent but no open support -- drove the Dutch out entirely. The Dutch, unable to hold any part of the country, accepted its complete restoration to Portugal. The colony reportedly contains more than six hundred thousand people of Portuguese descent or mixed heritage -- Portuguese, creoles, mulattoes, and people of mixed Portuguese and indigenous ancestry. No other American colony is thought to contain as many people of European extraction.
elegant: Brazil, neglected because it initially yielded no precious metals, grew powerful precisely through that neglect. When the Dutch seized seven provinces, Portuguese colonists fought them off independently. The colony grew to over six hundred thousand people of European descent -- the largest such population in the Americas. Neglect, paradoxically, was its greatest advantage.
summary: Brazil flourished during Portuguese neglect, growing powerful without the burden of metropolitan attention or mining-focused exploitation. When Dutch invaders seized half the colony, Portuguese settlers drove them out through their own initiative. Brazil eventually became the most populous European-descended colony in America.
distilled: Brazil grew powerful precisely because Portuguese neglect -- caused by the absence of gold mines -- allowed the colony to develop freely.
notes: Brazil as case study of beneficial neglect -- House of Braganza restoration -- Dutch invasion and expulsion by colonists -- 600,000+ European-descended population -- largest European population in Americas -- connects to 4.7.30 on attention vs. neglect paradox

refashioned: Toward the end of the fifteenth century and through most of the sixteenth, Spain and Portugal were the two dominant naval powers on the ocean -- Venice's commerce spanned Europe, but its fleet rarely ventured beyond the Mediterranean. Spain, claiming all of America by right of first discovery, could not prevent a rival naval power like Portugal from settling in Brazil, but Spain's fearsome reputation deterred most other nations from establishing themselves anywhere in the Americas. The French who attempted to settle in Florida were massacred by the Spaniards. However, the decline of Spanish naval power following the defeat of the 'Invincible Armada' toward the end of the sixteenth century removed Spain's ability to block other nations' settlements. During the seventeenth century, therefore, England, France, the Netherlands, Denmark, and Sweden -- every great nation with ocean ports -- attempted to establish colonies in the New World.
elegant: Spain and Portugal dominated Atlantic navigation in the 15th-16th centuries, with Spain claiming all of America and terrorizing would-be competitors -- even massacring French settlers in Florida. But the Armada's defeat ended Spanish naval supremacy, and in the 17th century, England, France, Holland, Denmark, and Sweden all established New World colonies.
summary: Spain's naval dominance and claim to all of America deterred other European nations from colonizing until the defeat of the Spanish Armada ended that supremacy. In the seventeenth century, England, France, the Netherlands, Denmark, and Sweden all established American colonies.
distilled: The defeat of the Spanish Armada ended Spain's monopoly on American colonization, opening the New World to English, French, Dutch, Danish, and Swedish settlement.
notes: Spanish naval dominance 15th-16th centuries -- French massacre in Florida -- Invincible Armada defeat ~1588 -- 17th-century colonial expansion by five nations -- Venice limited to Mediterranean -- connects to 4.7.36-41 on individual colonial experiences

refashioned: The Swedes established themselves in New Jersey, and the number of Swedish families still found there clearly demonstrates that this colony would have prospered had it been supported by the mother country. But Sweden neglected it, and it was soon absorbed by the Dutch colony of New York, which itself fell under English control in 1674.
elegant: Sweden's colony in New Jersey would have prospered, as surviving Swedish families attest, but neglect allowed the Dutch to absorb it. New York then passed to England in 1674.
summary: Sweden's neglected colony in New Jersey, which showed clear promise, was absorbed by Dutch New York, which itself later fell to England in 1674.
distilled: Sweden's promising New Jersey colony was lost to Dutch absorption due to metropolitan neglect, and then passed to England in 1674.
notes: Swedish colonization of New Jersey -- absorbed by Dutch New York -- English takeover 1674 -- neglect as colonial death sentence when competitors are active -- connects to 4.7.35 on multi-national colonization

refashioned: The small islands of St. Thomas and Santa Cruz are the only New World territories ever held by Denmark. These settlements were governed by an exclusive trading company with sole rights to buy the colonies' surplus output and supply them with foreign goods -- giving the company both the power and the strongest incentive to exploit them. It could buy cheap and sell dear with impunity. The government of an exclusive merchant company is perhaps the worst form of government for any country. Yet even this could not entirely halt these colonies' progress, though it made growth much slower and weaker. The late king of Denmark dissolved this company, and since then the colonies have prospered greatly.
elegant: Denmark's only colonies -- St. Thomas and Santa Cruz -- were governed by an exclusive company with monopoly buying and selling rights, creating the worst possible government. Yet even this could not stop growth entirely, only slow it. Dissolution of the company brought rapid prosperity.
summary: Denmark's colonies of St. Thomas and Santa Cruz were stunted by governance under an exclusive trading company -- the worst form of colonial administration. Growth accelerated dramatically after the company's dissolution.
distilled: Denmark's colonies prospered only after their exclusive trading company -- the worst possible colonial government -- was dissolved.
notes: Danish colonies: St. Thomas, Santa Cruz -- exclusive company governance as worst form -- company dissolution and subsequent prosperity -- monopoly buying and selling rights -- connects to 4.7.38 on Dutch companies

refashioned:
Dutch settlements in both the West and East Indies were also originally placed under exclusive company governance. Some made considerable progress by historical standards but grew sluggishly compared to most new colonies. Surinam, though substantial, remains inferior to most sugar colonies of other European nations. Nova Belgia, now divided into New York and New Jersey, would likely have grown significant even under Dutch rule, because abundant cheap land is such a powerful engine of prosperity that even the worst government can hardly suppress it entirely, and the great distance from the mother country allowed colonists to partly evade the company's monopoly through smuggling.

Currently, the Dutch company allows all Dutch ships to trade with Surinam upon paying a two and a half percent cargo license fee, reserving only the direct Africa-to-America trade -- essentially the slave trade -- as its exclusive domain. This relaxation of monopoly privileges is probably the main cause of Surinam's current prosperity. Curacao and St. Eustatius, the two principal Dutch islands, are free ports open to ships of all nations. This openness, surrounded by colonies whose ports admit only one nation's ships, has been the great driver of these two barren islands' prosperity.
elegant: Dutch colonies, like Danish ones, suffered under exclusive company rule. Surinam grew but lagged other sugar colonies. Nova Belgia would have prospered under any government thanks to abundant land. The company eventually relaxed its monopoly, boosting Surinam, while Curacao and St. Eustatius prospered as free ports open to all nations amid competitors' closed markets.
summary: Dutch colonies grew slowly under exclusive company governance but improved as monopoly restrictions loosened. Surinam benefited from relaxed trading rules, while Curacao and St. Eustatius thrived as free ports in a region of closed colonial markets, demonstrating that openness drives prosperity.
distilled: Dutch colonies grew slowly under monopoly company rule but prospered as restrictions loosened, with free ports Curacao and St. Eustatius demonstrating the power of trade openness.
notes: Dutch West India Company -- Surinam, Nova Belgia (New York/New Jersey) -- 2.5% license fee as partial liberalization -- slave trade as company monopoly -- Curacao and St. Eustatius as free ports -- openness vs. monopoly as prosperity driver

refashioned: The French colony of Canada spent most of the previous century and part of the current one under exclusive company governance. Under such unfavorable administration, its growth was necessarily very slow compared to other new colonies, but it accelerated significantly after the company was dissolved following the collapse of the Mississippi Scheme. When the English took possession of Canada, they found nearly double the population that Father Charlevoix had reported twenty to thirty years earlier. That Jesuit had traveled throughout the country and had no inclination to understate its importance.
elegant: Canada grew slowly under French exclusive company rule but accelerated after the company's post-Mississippi Scheme dissolution. English conquerors found nearly double the population reported by Charlevoix just twenty to thirty years earlier.
summary: French Canada grew slowly under exclusive company governance but progressed rapidly after the company dissolved following the Mississippi Scheme collapse. English conquerors found the population had nearly doubled within a generation.
distilled: Canada's population nearly doubled within a generation after the exclusive trading company was dissolved following the Mississippi Scheme's collapse.
notes: French Canada under exclusive company -- Mississippi Scheme collapse -- post-company population doubling -- Father Charlevoix's census -- English conquest -- pattern of growth accelerating after company dissolution

refashioned: The French colony of Saint-Domingue was founded by pirates and freebooters who for a long time neither sought France's protection nor acknowledged its authority. When these former outlaws became sufficiently settled to accept French authority, it had to be exercised very gently. During this period of light governance, the colony's population and development grew rapidly. Even the oppression of the exclusive company to which Saint-Domingue was eventually subjected, along with all other French colonies, could slow but not stop this progress. Prosperity resumed as soon as the company's grip was released. Saint-Domingue is now the most important sugar colony in the West Indies, with output reportedly exceeding that of all English sugar colonies combined. France's other sugar colonies are also generally thriving.
elegant: Saint-Domingue, founded by pirates who long rejected French authority, grew rapidly under light governance. Even exclusive company rule could only slow, not stop, its progress. Now the most important West Indian sugar colony, its output reportedly exceeds all English sugar colonies combined.
summary: Saint-Domingue flourished under minimal governance after its pirate founders accepted light French authority. Though temporarily slowed by exclusive company rule, it became the most productive sugar colony in the West Indies, surpassing all English sugar colonies combined.
distilled: Saint-Domingue, founded by pirates under minimal governance, became the most productive sugar colony in the West Indies despite temporary setbacks from exclusive company rule.
notes: Saint-Domingue (Haiti) -- pirate/freebooter origins -- light governance as growth factor -- exclusive company as temporary drag -- most important sugar colony -- output exceeding all English sugar colonies -- connects to 4.7.37-39 on company governance effects

refashioned:
But no colonies have progressed more rapidly than the English ones in North America.

Abundant good land and the freedom to manage their own affairs in their own way appear to be the two great causes of prosperity in all new colonies.
elegant: No colonies have advanced faster than the English in North America. The two great causes of colonial prosperity everywhere are: abundant good land and freedom of self-governance.
summary: English North American colonies progressed faster than any others, driven by the two universal keys to colonial prosperity: abundant good land and freedom of self-governance.
distilled: The English North American colonies progressed faster than any others, propelled by abundant land and self-governance.
notes: English colonial superiority in growth rate -- two key factors: land abundance and self-governance -- summary principle for colonial prosperity -- transition to detailed analysis of English advantages

refashioned: In the abundance of good land, the English colonies of North America, though certainly well-supplied, are inferior to those of Spain and Portugal and no better than some French colonies before the recent war. But English colonial political institutions have been more favorable to land improvement and cultivation than those of any of the other three nations.
elegant: English North American colonies had no more land than Spanish, Portuguese, or French ones. Their advantage lay in superior political institutions that better promoted land improvement and cultivation.
summary: The English colonies' rapid progress came not from superior land endowments -- which were no better than Spanish, Portuguese, or some French colonies -- but from political institutions more favorable to land development.
distilled: English colonies outperformed others not through better land but through political institutions more conducive to agricultural improvement.
notes: Institutional advantage over resource advantage -- English vs. Spanish, Portuguese, French colonial institutions -- political institutions as growth determinant -- transition to four specific English advantages (4.7.43-53)

refashioned: First, the hoarding of uncultivated land, while not entirely prevented, has been more effectively restrained in English colonies than anywhere else. Colonial law requires every landowner to improve and cultivate a certain proportion of his land within a set period, and declares neglected lands available for grant to others. Though not always strictly enforced, this law has had some effect.
elegant: First, English colonies more effectively restrained land hoarding than others. Laws requiring owners to improve lands within set periods, or forfeit them, had meaningful impact even when loosely enforced.
summary: The English colonies' first institutional advantage was laws restraining land hoarding by requiring cultivation within set periods, with unused land reverting to the public grant pool -- effective even when imperfectly enforced.
distilled: English colonies restrained land hoarding through improvement requirements that, even when loosely enforced, promoted cultivation.
notes: First English advantage: anti-engrossment laws -- 'use it or lose it' land policy -- imperfect enforcement still effective -- land hoarding as obstacle to development -- connects to 4.7.46 on engrossment effects

refashioned: Second, Pennsylvania has no right of primogeniture, with land divided equally among all children, as with personal property. In three New England provinces, the eldest child receives only a double share, following the Mosaic law. Even where excessive land accumulation occurs in these provinces, it is likely to be broken up within a generation or two. In the other English colonies, primogeniture does apply as in English law. However, all English colonial land is held by free socage tenure, which facilitates transfer, and holders of large grants generally find it in their interest to sell off most of their land as quickly as possible, retaining only a small annual rent.
elegant: Second, English inheritance laws promoted land distribution. Pennsylvania divided land equally among children; New England gave the eldest only a double share. Even where primogeniture applied, free socage tenure made land easy to sell, and large grantees typically sold off most holdings quickly.
summary: English colonial land distribution was promoted by egalitarian inheritance laws in some colonies and by free socage tenure everywhere, which facilitated land sales. Even large grantees found it profitable to sell off their holdings quickly.
distilled: English colonies promoted land distribution through egalitarian inheritance laws and free socage tenure that made large estates easy to divide and sell.
notes: Second English advantage: inheritance and tenure law -- Pennsylvania equal inheritance -- New England double share (Mosaic law) -- free socage tenure -- incentive for large grantees to subdivide -- connects to 4.7.45 on Spanish/French comparison

refashioned: In the Spanish and Portuguese colonies, the right of majorazgo applies to all great estates carrying noble titles. Such estates pass entirely to one heir and are effectively entailed and inalienable. French colonies follow the Custom of Paris, which is somewhat more favorable to younger children in land inheritance than English law. However, in French colonies, any part of a noble estate that is sold remains subject to a right of redemption by either the lord's heir or the family's heir for a limited period, and all the largest estates are held under such noble tenures, making transfers difficult. In a new colony, though, large uncultivated estates are much more likely to be divided quickly by sale than by inheritance.
elegant: Spanish/Portuguese majorazgo concentrated great estates in single heirs permanently. French noble tenures encumbered sales with redemption rights. Both systems hindered land distribution -- critical in new colonies where rapid division by sale, not slow division by inheritance, drives development.
summary: Spanish majorazgo entailed great estates permanently, and French noble tenures encumbered land sales with redemption rights. Both systems hindered the rapid land distribution that new colonies need, unlike English free socage tenure which facilitated quick sales.
distilled: Spanish entailment and French redemption rights hindered colonial land distribution, unlike English tenure which facilitated the rapid sales new colonies require.
notes: Third-party comparison: Spanish majorazgo, French Custom of Paris -- noble tenure redemption rights -- entailment vs. alienability -- sale vs. inheritance as land distribution mechanism -- connects to 4.7.44 on English advantage

refashioned: As already noted, abundant and cheap land is the principal cause of rapid colonial prosperity. Land hoarding effectively destroys this abundance and cheapness. Beyond that, hoarding uncultivated land is the greatest obstacle to improvement. Labor devoted to land improvement and cultivation produces the greatest and most valuable output for society -- covering not only the workers' wages and the employer's profit, but also rent on the land.
elegant: Cheap, abundant land drives colonial prosperity. Land hoarding destroys this advantage and is the greatest barrier to improvement. Labor invested in land cultivation produces society's most valuable output -- wages, profits, and rent combined.
summary: Land hoarding is doubly destructive: it eliminates the cheap land that drives colonial prosperity and obstructs the land improvement that produces society's most valuable output, yielding wages, profits, and rent simultaneously.
distilled: Land hoarding destroys colonial prosperity by eliminating cheap land and obstructing the agricultural improvement that generates wages, profits, and rent.
notes: Land abundance as prosperity foundation -- engrossment as double harm: eliminates cheap land and blocks improvement -- agricultural labor as most productive: generates wages + profits + rent -- connects to Book 1 on components of price

refashioned:
English colonial labor, being more devoted to land improvement and cultivation, is therefore likely to produce a greater and more valuable output than that of the other three nations, where land hoarding diverts labor toward less productive activities.

Third, the labor of English colonists not only produces more, but thanks to moderate taxation, a greater share of that output belongs to the colonists themselves, available for saving and reinvestment in additional labor. English colonists have never contributed anything toward the mother country's defense or civil government. They have instead been defended almost entirely at Britain's expense -- and the cost of maintaining fleets and armies is incomparably greater than the cost of civil government.
elegant: English colonial labor produces more because it focuses on land cultivation rather than being diverted by land hoarding. Third, moderate taxation means colonists keep more of their output for reinvestment. English colonists have never funded Britain's defense or civil government -- Britain bore those enormous costs entirely.
summary: English colonists produce more through focused land cultivation and keep more through low taxation, since they contribute nothing to Britain's defense or civil government. The mother country bears the enormous military costs entirely, leaving colonists free to reinvest their surplus.
distilled: English colonies produce more through focused land cultivation, keep more through minimal taxation, and reinvest freely since Britain bears all defense costs.
notes: Third English advantage: low taxation -- colonists never contributed to British defense -- military costs vastly exceed civil government costs -- retained surplus as reinvestment capital -- connects to 4.7.48 on civil government costs

refashioned: Colonial civil government expenses have always been very modest, generally limited to reasonable salaries for the governor, judges, and a few other officials, plus maintenance of a few essential public works. Before the current disturbances, Massachusetts Bay's civil government cost about 18,000 pounds per year; New Hampshire and Rhode Island about 3,500 each; Connecticut about 4,000; New York and Pennsylvania about 4,500 each; New Jersey about 1,200; and Virginia and South Carolina about 8,000 each.
elegant: Colonial civil government was remarkably cheap. Before the current troubles, Massachusetts cost 18,000 pounds; most colonies far less -- New Jersey just 1,200 pounds. Government meant paying modest salaries and maintaining essential public works.
summary: English colonial civil government was extremely frugal, with annual costs ranging from 1,200 pounds in New Jersey to 18,000 pounds in Massachusetts, covering only essential salaries and basic public works.
distilled: English colonial civil government costs were remarkably low, ranging from 1,200 to 18,000 pounds annually per colony.
notes: Colonial civil government budgets -- Massachusetts Bay: 18K, New Hampshire/Rhode Island: 3.5K each, Connecticut: 4K, New York/Pennsylvania: 4.5K each, New Jersey: 1.2K, Virginia/South Carolina: 8K each -- connects to 4.7.49 on total costs

refashioned: Nova Scotia and Georgia are partly funded by annual parliamentary grants, but Nova Scotia also pays about 7,000 pounds per year toward its own public expenses, and Georgia about 2,500. All the North American civil establishments combined -- excluding Maryland and North Carolina, for which no exact figures exist -- cost the inhabitants less than 64,700 pounds annually before the current disturbances. This is a remarkable demonstration of how cheaply three million people can be not merely governed but well governed. The most significant government expense -- defense and protection -- has consistently been borne entirely by the mother country.
elegant: All North American colonies combined spent under 64,700 pounds on civil government for three million people -- a remarkable demonstration of cheap, effective governance. The enormous cost of defense fell entirely on Britain.
summary: Total civil government costs for all North American colonies were under 64,700 pounds per year for three million inhabitants, demonstrating that good governance need not be expensive. Britain bore all the far larger costs of defense and military protection.
distilled: Three million North American colonists were well governed for under 64,700 pounds annually -- with Britain bearing all defense costs separately.
notes: Total colonial civil costs: under 64,700 pounds for 3 million people -- 'ever memorable example' of cheap good government -- Nova Scotia and Georgia parliamentary grants -- defense costs borne by mother country -- connects to 4.7.47 on taxation advantage

refashioned: Colonial civil government ceremonies -- receiving a new governor, opening a new assembly -- while appropriately dignified, involve no costly pomp or pageantry. Ecclesiastical governance is equally frugal. Tithes are unknown, and the clergy, far from being numerous, are supported either by modest stipends or voluntary contributions. Spain and Portugal, by contrast, derive revenue from colonial taxation. France has never extracted significant revenue from its colonies, generally spending collected taxes within the colonies themselves.
elegant: English colonial ceremonies are dignified but inexpensive. There are no tithes, and few clergy are modestly supported. Spain and Portugal tax their colonies for revenue; France spends colonial taxes locally but maintains costly administration.
summary: English colonial governance is remarkably frugal in both civil and ecclesiastical matters, with no tithes and modest clergy support. This contrasts with Spain and Portugal, which extract colonial tax revenue, and France, which spends colonial taxes within the colonies but at greater administrative cost.
distilled: English colonies maintain frugal civil and ecclesiastical governance with no tithes, unlike the costly and extractive administrations of Spain, Portugal, and France.
notes: Colonial ceremony and ecclesiastical costs -- no tithes in English colonies -- voluntary clergy support -- Spanish/Portuguese tax extraction -- French local spending of colonial taxes -- connects to 4.7.51 on rival colonial extravagance

refashioned: Colonial governance in all three rival nations is conducted on a much grander and more expensive scale, accompanied by far more costly ceremonial. The sums spent on receiving a new viceroy of Peru, for example, have frequently been enormous. Such ceremonies are not only effective taxes imposed on wealthy colonists for particular occasions; they also instill habits of vanity and extravagance that carry over into everyday life. They are not merely burdensome occasional taxes but help establish permanent habits of equally or more burdensome private luxury and waste.
elegant: Rival colonial governments operate on a far grander, costlier scale. Enormous viceregal ceremonies act as taxes on the rich while cultivating habits of vanity and extravagance -- occasional impositions that breed permanent cultures of private luxury and waste.
summary: Spanish, Portuguese, and French colonial governments are far more expensive than English ones, with ceremonial costs like viceregal receptions acting as de facto taxes that also cultivate wasteful habits of luxury extending far beyond the occasions themselves.
distilled: Expensive colonial ceremonies in rival empires act as both direct taxes and catalysts for permanently wasteful cultures of private luxury.
notes: Viceregal ceremonies as hidden taxation -- culture of extravagance as self-perpetuating 'tax' -- occasional costs breeding permanent habits -- Peru viceroyalty example -- contrast with English colonial frugality

refashioned: In all three rival nations' colonies, the ecclesiastical establishment is also extremely oppressive. Tithes are levied everywhere, with the utmost rigor in Spain and Portugal. Additionally, all these colonies are burdened by vast numbers of mendicant friars whose begging -- licensed and sanctified by religion -- constitutes a heavy tax on the poor, who are carefully taught that giving is a duty and refusing charity a grave sin. On top of all this, the clergy in every one of these colonies are the greatest hoarders of land.
elegant: Rival colonies suffer oppressive ecclesiastical establishments: rigorous tithes (especially in Spanish and Portuguese colonies), swarms of mendicant friars whose religiously sanctioned begging taxes the poor, and clergy who are the greatest land hoarders of all.
summary: The ecclesiastical establishments in Spanish, Portuguese, and French colonies impose triple burdens: rigorous tithes, mendicant friars whose religion-backed begging taxes the poor, and massive clerical land hoarding that restricts development.
distilled: Rival colonial churches impose triple burdens: rigorous tithes, mendicant friars taxing the poor through sanctified begging, and massive land hoarding by clergy.
notes: Ecclesiastical oppression in rival colonies -- tithes most rigorous in Spain/Portugal -- mendicant friars as disguised tax on poor -- religious duty to give as enforcement mechanism -- clergy as land engrossers -- connects to 4.7.46 on land hoarding

refashioned: Fourth, in the disposal of their surplus produce -- what exceeds their own consumption -- the English colonies have been more favored and allowed a more extensive market than those of any other European nation. Every European power has tried, to varying degrees, to monopolize its colonies' commerce: prohibiting foreign ships from trading there and barring colonies from importing European goods except from the mother country. But the specific ways this monopoly has been exercised differ greatly among nations.
elegant: Fourth, English colonies enjoyed broader markets for their surplus than any rivals. All European powers monopolized colonial trade to some degree, banning foreign ships and non-metropolitan imports. But the manner of monopoly varied greatly, and England's was least restrictive.
summary: The fourth English advantage is broader markets for colonial exports. While all European powers monopolized colonial commerce by excluding foreign ships and goods, the English applied this monopoly less restrictively than any other nation.
distilled: English colonies had broader export markets than any rivals because England applied its colonial trade monopoly less restrictively than other nations.
notes: Fourth English advantage: broader colonial markets -- universal colonial trade monopoly -- prohibition of foreign ships and goods -- variation in monopoly enforcement -- transition to comparison of monopoly systems (4.7.54-56)

refashioned:
Some nations handed over their entire colonial commerce to an exclusive company from which colonists were forced to buy all European goods and to which they had to sell all surplus production. The company naturally sought to sell as dearly and buy as cheaply as possible, and to purchase no more surplus than it could resell at very high prices in Europe. Its interest lay not merely in depressing the value of colonial output but often in actively suppressing its growth. Of all possible methods for stunting a new colony's development, an exclusive company is undoubtedly the most effective.

This was Holland's policy, though its company has recently relaxed its exclusive rights in many areas. It was also Denmark's policy until the late king's reign, occasionally France's policy, and -- most remarkably, after all other nations had abandoned it as absurd -- it became Portugal's policy since 1755 for at least two of Brazil's principal provinces: Pernambuco and Maranhao.
elegant: The worst colonial policy is an exclusive trading company that buys all colonial output cheap, sells European goods dear, and actively suppresses colonial production growth. Holland, Denmark, and France all tried this; Portugal absurdly adopted it as recently as 1755 for two Brazilian provinces, after everyone else had abandoned it.
summary: The most effective way to stunt colonial growth is an exclusive trading company that monopolizes both buying and selling. Holland, Denmark, and France used this system, and Portugal adopted it as recently as 1755 for two Brazilian provinces -- after all other nations had recognized its absurdity.
distilled: Exclusive trading companies are the most effective means of stunting colonial growth, yet Portugal adopted this universally abandoned policy as recently as 1755.
notes: Exclusive company as worst colonial policy -- company incentives: buy cheap, sell dear, suppress production -- Holland, Denmark, France, Portugal (1755: Pernambuco, Maranhao) -- policy abandoned then readopted -- connects to 4.7.37-39 on company governance effects

refashioned:
Other nations, without establishing exclusive companies, confined all colonial trade to a single port in the mother country, from which ships could sail only in fleets at specified seasons, or individually with expensive licenses. This policy technically opened colonial trade to all citizens of the mother country, provided they traded from the right port, at the right time, in the right ships. But since the merchants who pooled capital to outfit licensed vessels would naturally coordinate their activities, the trade effectively operated on the same principles as an exclusive company. Their profits were nearly as exorbitant and oppressive -- colonies were poorly supplied and forced to buy at very high and sell at very low prices.

This was Spain's policy until recently, and European goods were reportedly astronomically expensive in Spanish America. In Quito, according to Ulloa, a pound of iron sold for about four shillings sixpence, and a pound of steel for about six shillings ninepence. Since colonies exchange their own produce mainly for European goods, the more they pay for the latter, the less they effectively receive for the former -- the dearness of one being identical to the cheapness of the other. Portugal follows the same policy for all colonies except Pernambuco and Maranhao, where it adopted the even worse exclusive company system.
elegant: Other nations confined colonial trade to a single port, with ships sailing only in seasonal fleets or with expensive licenses. Merchants coordinating these ventures acted like an exclusive company, charging exorbitant prices -- in Quito, iron cost 4s:6d per pound, steel 6s:9d. Spain used this system until recently; Portugal still does, except where it adopted the even worse exclusive company model.
summary: Confining colonial trade to a single port with licensed fleets produced results nearly as bad as exclusive companies: coordinating merchants charged exorbitant prices, with iron in Quito costing 4s:6d per pound. Spain followed this policy for centuries, and Portugal still does for most colonies.
distilled: Restricting colonial trade to single licensed ports created de facto monopolies with exorbitant prices, nearly as oppressive as exclusive trading companies.
notes: Single-port trade restriction -- fleet system and licensing -- de facto monopoly through merchant coordination -- Quito prices: iron 4s:6d, steel 6s:9d per pound (Ulloa) -- Spain's policy, Portugal's current practice -- dearness of imports = cheapness of exports

refashioned:
Other nations allow their subjects to trade freely with their colonies from any port in the mother country, requiring no license beyond standard customs documentation. In this case, the large number and wide distribution of traders makes collusion impossible, and their competition prevents exorbitant profits. Under such a liberal policy, colonies can sell their products and buy European goods at reasonable prices.

Since the dissolution of the Plymouth Company, when English colonies were still in their infancy, this has always been England's policy. It has generally been France's policy too, and consistently so since the dissolution of their Mississippi Company. The profits of English and French colonial trade, while somewhat higher than under fully free international competition, are not exorbitant, and European goods in most colonies of both nations are reasonably priced.
elegant: The best policy opens colonial trade to all merchants from any port, making collusion impossible and prices reasonable. England has followed this approach since the Plymouth Company's dissolution, as has France since the Mississippi Company's end. Both nations' colonial trade earns moderate profits and maintains reasonable prices.
summary: The most beneficial colonial trade policy allows all merchants to trade freely from any port, preventing collusion and keeping prices reasonable. England and France both adopted this liberal approach after dissolving their respective trading companies, resulting in moderate profits and fair prices.
distilled: Free trade from any port, as practiced by England and France, prevents merchant collusion and keeps colonial prices reasonable.
notes: Free trade from all ports -- competition prevents collusion -- England since Plymouth Company dissolution -- France since Mississippi Company dissolution -- moderate profits, reasonable prices -- best colonial trade policy -- connects to 4.7.54-55 comparison

refashioned: Regarding the export of their own surplus production, British colonies are restricted to the mother country's market only for certain specified goods. These commodities, listed in the Navigation Act and subsequent legislation, are called 'enumerated commodities.' Everything else -- the 'non-enumerated commodities' -- may be exported directly to other countries, provided the ships are British or colonial-built, with British subjects making up at least three-quarters of the crew.
elegant: British colonies face export restrictions only on specific 'enumerated commodities' that must go to Britain. All other goods -- 'non-enumerated commodities' -- may be exported directly anywhere, provided ships are British or colonial with predominantly British crews.
summary: British colonial export restrictions apply only to enumerated commodities that must pass through Britain. Non-enumerated goods may be exported directly to any destination in British or colonial ships with mostly British crews.
distilled: Only enumerated commodities must be exported exclusively to Britain; all other colonial goods may be traded directly with any nation.
notes: Navigation Act -- enumerated vs. non-enumerated commodities -- shipping restrictions: British/colonial ships, 3/4 British crew -- partial trade freedom within mercantilist framework -- connects to 4.7.58-61 on specific commodities

refashioned:
Among the non-enumerated commodities are some of America and the West Indies' most important products: all types of grain, lumber, salt provisions, fish, sugar, and rum.

Grain is naturally the first and most essential crop for any new colony. By granting colonies a very extensive market for grain, the law encourages them to expand cultivation far beyond what a thinly settled country would consume, thereby building in advance an abundant food supply for a continually growing population.
elegant: Key non-enumerated commodities include grain, lumber, provisions, fish, sugar, and rum. Allowing colonies extensive grain markets encourages them to cultivate far beyond current needs, building food reserves for rapid population growth.
summary: Major colonial products including grain, lumber, fish, sugar, and rum are non-enumerated and may be freely exported. This is especially important for grain, as broad markets encourage cultivation beyond immediate needs, supporting future population growth.
distilled: Free export of grain and other key commodities encourages colonial cultivation beyond immediate needs, building food reserves for growing populations.
notes: Non-enumerated commodities: grain, lumber, salt provisions, fish, sugar, rum -- grain as primary colonial crop -- extensive markets encourage surplus production -- food security through market incentives -- connects to 4.7.59-61 on other commodities

refashioned: In a country entirely covered with forest, where timber consequently has little or no value, the expense of clearing land is the main obstacle to agricultural development. By providing colonies with a very extensive market for lumber, the law aims to facilitate improvement by raising the price of a commodity that would otherwise be nearly worthless, thereby enabling colonists to profit from what would otherwise be pure cost.
elegant: In forested colonies, clearing land is the main barrier to development. Extensive lumber markets raise the value of what would otherwise be worthless timber, turning the cost of land-clearing into a revenue source.
summary: Allowing free lumber exports transforms the cost of clearing forested colonial land into a revenue opportunity, since broad markets give value to timber that would otherwise be worthless, facilitating agricultural development.
distilled: Free lumber export markets transform the cost of clearing forested land into revenue, facilitating colonial agricultural development.
notes: Lumber as non-enumerated commodity -- forest clearing as development barrier -- market access raises otherwise worthless timber value -- cost-to-revenue transformation through trade policy -- connects to 4.7.58 on grain and 4.7.60 on cattle

refashioned: In a country that is neither half populated nor half cultivated, cattle naturally multiply beyond the inhabitants' needs and are often worth little or nothing. But as previously demonstrated, cattle prices must bear a certain proportion to grain prices before most land can be profitably improved. By granting American cattle -- in all forms, live and dead -- a very extensive market, the law aims to raise the value of a commodity whose high price is essential to agricultural development. The beneficial effects of this freedom are, however, somewhat diminished by the act of 4 George III, chapter 15, which adds hides and skins to the list of enumerated commodities, thereby tending to reduce the overall value of American cattle.
elegant: In underpopulated colonies, cattle multiply beyond local demand and become nearly worthless. Since cattle prices must maintain a proportion to grain prices for land improvement to be viable, extensive export markets are essential. However, the enumeration of hides and skins under 4 George III somewhat undermines this by reducing cattle's total value.
summary: Extensive export markets for American cattle raise prices essential for profitable land improvement, since cattle prices must maintain a certain ratio to grain prices. But this benefit is partly offset by legislation adding hides and skins to enumerated commodities, which reduces cattle's overall value.
distilled: Free cattle export markets raise prices essential for land improvement, but enumerating hides and skins partly undermines this benefit.
notes: Cattle price-grain price ratio for land improvement -- surplus cattle in underpopulated colonies -- 4 George III c.15: hides and skins enumerated -- partial undermining of liberal policy -- connects to Book 1 on cattle-grain price relationships

refashioned: Expanding British shipping and naval power through colonial fisheries is an objective the legislature seems to have pursued almost constantly. These fisheries have accordingly received all the encouragement that free trade can provide, and they have flourished. The New England fishery in particular was, before the recent disturbances, one of the world's most important. The whale fishery, which in Great Britain is carried on with so little success despite extravagant bounties that many believe its total output barely exceeds the annual bounties paid for it, is conducted in New England without any bounty at all yet on a very large scale. Fish is one of the principal commodities with which North Americans trade with Spain, Portugal, and the Mediterranean.
elegant: The legislature consistently promoted colonial fisheries for naval power, granting them full trading freedom. New England's fishery became one of the world's most important. Its whale fishery thrived without bounties, while Britain's bounty-supported whale fishery barely covers its subsidies. Fish became a major North American export to Southern Europe.
summary: Colonial fisheries, promoted for naval power through trade freedom, flourished remarkably. New England's fishery became globally important, and its whale fishery succeeded without bounties -- unlike Britain's heavily subsidized but unproductive one. Fish became a major export to Spain, Portugal, and the Mediterranean.
distilled: New England's fisheries thrived through free trade alone, while Britain's bounty-dependent whale fishery barely justified its subsidies -- demonstrating that freedom outperforms subsidy.
notes: Colonial fisheries and naval power -- New England fishery as world-class -- whale fishery: bounty-free success (New England) vs. bounty-dependent failure (Britain) -- fish exports to Southern Europe and Mediterranean -- freedom vs. subsidy as policy comparison

refashioned: Sugar was originally an enumerated commodity that could only be exported to Great Britain. In 1751, after lobbying by the sugar planters, exportation was permitted to all parts of the world. However, the restrictions attached to this supposed liberty, combined with the high price of sugar in Great Britain, rendered it largely ineffective. Great Britain and her colonies remained virtually the sole market for all sugar produced in the British plantations. Domestic consumption was growing so rapidly that, even though imports had increased substantially over the previous twenty years -- thanks to improvements in Jamaica and the ceded islands -- exports to foreign countries had reportedly barely increased at all.
elegant: Sugar was originally restricted to the British market alone. Though export to other countries was nominally permitted in 1751, the conditions attached and the high domestic price made this freedom meaningless. Britain and her colonies consumed nearly everything the plantations produced, with domestic demand growing so fast that even rising imports barely increased the surplus available for foreign export.
summary: Although sugar exports were theoretically liberalized in 1751, restrictive conditions and booming British demand meant Britain remained virtually the only market for colonial sugar.
distilled: Nominal liberalization of sugar exports in 1751 was rendered meaningless by restrictive conditions and surging British domestic demand.
notes: Enumerated commodities -- goods colonies could only export to Britain. Shows how formal liberalization can be rendered ineffective by accompanying restrictions. Illustrates the gap between policy on paper and policy in practice. Cross-references the mercantilist framework of colonial trade regulation discussed throughout 4.7.

refashioned:
Rum is a crucial commodity in the trade Americans conduct with the coast of Africa, where they exchange it for enslaved people.

If the entire surplus produce of America -- all its grain, salt provisions, and fish -- had been enumerated and thereby forced into the British market, it would have competed too directly with Britain's own domestic produce. It was probably not concern for American interests, but rather jealousy of this competition, that kept these important commodities off the enumeration list. Indeed, not only were they excluded from enumeration, but the importation of all grain except rice, and of all salt provisions, into Great Britain was prohibited under ordinary law.
elegant: Rum was essential to the American slave trade with Africa. Had America's grain, salt provisions, and fish been enumerated and forced into the British market, they would have competed with British domestic production. It was not concern for American welfare but fear of this competition that kept these goods unenumerated -- and even prohibited their import into Britain entirely.
summary: Rum was vital to the American-African slave trade. American grain, salt provisions, and fish were kept off the enumeration list not to protect American interests, but to prevent competition with British domestic producers.
distilled: Key American commodities were excluded from enumeration not to help the colonies but to protect British domestic producers from competition.
notes: Reveals the self-interested logic behind trade classifications -- what appears as colonial liberty was actually domestic protectionism. Rum's role in the triangular slave trade noted matter-of-factly. The distinction between enumerated and non-enumerated commodities is central to understanding colonial trade restrictions. Cross-references 4.7.62 on sugar enumeration.

refashioned: Non-enumerated commodities could originally be exported anywhere in the world. When lumber and rice were temporarily placed on the enumeration list and then removed, their European export was restricted to countries south of Cape Finisterre. By the 6th of George III, chapter 52, all non-enumerated commodities were subjected to this same restriction. The countries south of Cape Finisterre are not manufacturing nations, so Britain was less concerned about colonial ships bringing back manufactures that might compete with British goods.
elegant: Non-enumerated goods were originally exportable worldwide. After lumber and rice were briefly enumerated then freed, their European export was limited to countries south of Cape Finisterre -- eventually a restriction applied to all non-enumerated goods. These southern countries were not manufacturers, so Britain feared no competitive imports in return.
summary: Non-enumerated commodities were eventually restricted to European export only south of Cape Finisterre, because those non-manufacturing countries posed no competitive threat to British industry.
distilled: Even non-enumerated colonial goods were restricted to export only to non-manufacturing European countries that could not compete with British industry.
notes: Cape Finisterre -- the northwestern tip of Spain, used as the dividing line for European trade restrictions. Shows how even "free" colonial trade was carefully managed to avoid any competitive threat to British manufactures. Illustrates the layered nature of mercantilist trade regulation.

refashioned:
Enumerated commodities fall into two categories. First, those that are either unique to America or cannot be produced in the mother country -- including molasses, coffee, cocoa, tobacco, pimento, ginger, whale fins, raw silk, cotton wool, beaver and other furs, indigo, fustic, and other dyeing woods. Second, those that can be and are produced in the mother country, but not in quantities sufficient to meet most of its demand, which is mainly supplied from foreign sources -- including naval stores, masts, yards, bowsprits, tar, pitch, turpentine, pig and bar iron, copper ore, hides, skins, and pot and pearl ashes.

Importing large quantities of the first category could not possibly harm or compete with any domestic product. By confining these to the home market, merchants expected to buy them more cheaply in the plantations and sell them at better profit domestically. They also expected to establish a profitable carrying trade between the plantations and foreign countries, with Great Britain serving as the necessary center -- since these goods had to be imported into Britain first.

Imports of the second category, it was supposed, could be managed so as to compete not with domestically produced equivalents but with those imported from foreign countries. Through appropriate duties, colonial imports could be kept somewhat more expensive than domestic production but considerably cheaper than foreign imports. Confining these goods to the home market was thus intended to discourage the produce not of Great Britain, but of foreign countries with which the balance of trade was believed to be unfavorable.
elegant: Enumerated goods were of two kinds: those unique to America (tobacco, coffee, indigo, furs, etc.) whose import could not harm British production, and those Britain also produced but in insufficient quantities (naval stores, iron, hides, etc.). For the first kind, confining them to Britain let merchants buy cheaply in the colonies, sell profitably at home, and establish a carrying trade with Britain as the mandatory hub. For the second kind, duties could make colonial goods slightly dearer than domestic equivalents but much cheaper than foreign imports -- discouraging not British production but that of rival foreign nations.
summary: Enumerated commodities were either uniquely American products (confined to Britain to create merchant profits and a carrying trade) or goods Britain also produced insufficiently (managed through duties to undercut foreign rather than domestic suppliers).
distilled: Enumerated goods were classified to either create a profitable British carrying trade in uniquely American products or to undercut foreign competitors in goods Britain also produced.
notes: Key taxonomy of enumerated commodities and the distinct mercantilist logic for each category. The carrying trade concept -- Britain as mandatory middleman -- is central to mercantilist strategy. The duty structure for the second category shows sophisticated price management: colonial goods priced between domestic and foreign equivalents. Cross-references balance of trade doctrine critiqued in 4.1-4.3.

refashioned: The prohibition on exporting masts, yards, bowsprits, tar, pitch, and turpentine from the colonies to any country but Great Britain naturally tended to lower timber prices in the colonies, which increased the cost of clearing land -- the principal obstacle to colonial development. However, around 1703, Sweden's pitch and tar company attempted to raise prices on Great Britain by restricting exports to Swedish ships only, at Swedish-set prices and quantities. To counteract this mercantile maneuver and reduce dependence on Sweden and other northern powers, Great Britain introduced a bounty on importing naval stores from America. This bounty raised American timber prices far more than the restriction to the home market had lowered them. Since both measures were enacted simultaneously, their combined effect actually encouraged rather than discouraged land clearing in America.
elegant: Restricting colonial naval stores to the British market lowered timber prices in America, making land clearing more expensive. But when Sweden tried to gouge Britain on pitch and tar around 1703, Britain countered with import bounties on American naval stores. These bounties raised American timber prices far more than the export restriction had lowered them. The combined effect actually encouraged land clearing in the colonies.
summary: Britain's bounties on American naval stores, introduced to counter Swedish price manipulation, more than offset the price-depressing effect of export restrictions, accidentally encouraging colonial land development.
distilled: Bounties on American naval stores, designed to counter Swedish price gouging, inadvertently promoted colonial land clearing by raising timber prices above what export restrictions had lowered them.
notes: Illustrates unintended consequences in trade policy -- two regulations designed for different purposes accidentally produced a beneficial combined effect. The Swedish pitch and tar incident is an early example of commodity cartel behavior. Shows how bounties and restrictions can interact in unpredictable ways. Cross-references the discussion of bounties in 4.5.

refashioned: Though pig and bar iron have been placed among the enumerated commodities, American iron is exempt from the substantial duties imposed on iron imported from other countries. This exemption does more to encourage the building of furnaces in America than the enumeration does to discourage it. No manufacture consumes as much wood as an iron furnace, and none contributes more effectively to clearing a country overgrown with forest.
elegant: Although pig and bar iron are enumerated, American iron is exempt from the heavy duties on foreign iron. This exemption encourages American furnace-building more than enumeration discourages it. Since no industry consumes more wood than iron smelting, this effectively promoted land clearing.
summary: The duty exemption on American iron encouraged furnace construction more than enumeration discouraged it, and since iron smelting consumed enormous quantities of wood, it promoted forest clearing.
distilled: Duty exemptions on American iron encouraged furnace construction that consumed vast quantities of wood, inadvertently promoting colonial land clearing.
notes: Another example of trade regulations producing unintended developmental benefits. Iron smelting as a driver of deforestation and land clearing -- an early observation of industrial environmental impact. The duty differential between American and foreign iron effectively subsidized colonial heavy industry.

refashioned:
The tendency of some of these regulations to raise timber values in America, and thereby facilitate land clearing, was probably neither intended nor understood by the legislature. Their beneficial effects in this regard were accidental -- but no less real for being so.

Completely free trade is permitted among the British colonies of America and the West Indies, in both enumerated and non-enumerated commodities. These colonies have now become so populous and prosperous that each finds in the others a great and extensive market for every part of its produce. Taken together, they form a large internal market for one another's goods.
elegant:
The beneficial effects of these regulations on land clearing were accidental -- neither intended nor understood by the legislature -- but real nonetheless.

Meanwhile, completely free trade exists among the British colonies themselves, both in enumerated and non-enumerated goods. These colonies have become so populous and prosperous that they now constitute a substantial internal market for one another's produce.
summary: Some trade regulations accidentally benefited colonial development. Meanwhile, free trade among the British colonies themselves created a large and thriving internal market.
distilled: Some trade regulations accidentally aided colonial development, while free inter-colonial trade created a substantial internal market among the thriving colonies.
notes: Two important points: (1) policy outcomes can be beneficial without being intentional -- an early recognition of emergent order; (2) free trade among the colonies created an internal market that drove mutual prosperity. The inter-colonial free trade zone contrasts with the heavy regulation of colonial-European trade. Anticipates arguments about the benefits of large integrated markets.

refashioned: England's liberality toward the trade of her colonies has been confined mainly to the market for their raw produce, or at most the very first stage of manufacture. The more advanced or refined manufactures -- even those made from colonial raw materials -- British merchants and manufacturers have chosen to reserve for themselves. They have persuaded the legislature to prevent colonial manufacturing, sometimes through high duties and sometimes through outright prohibitions.
elegant: England's trade liberality toward the colonies extended only to raw materials and the most basic processing. Advanced manufacturing, even of colonial raw materials, was reserved for British producers, who lobbied the legislature to block colonial manufacturing through high duties or outright prohibition.
summary: Britain allowed colonies to export raw materials freely but prohibited or heavily taxed their advanced manufactures, reserving those profits for British merchants and manufacturers.
distilled: Britain permitted colonial trade in raw materials but systematically blocked colonial manufacturing to reserve those profits for British industry.
notes: Central mercantilist principle: colonies supply raw materials, the mother country adds value through manufacturing. This raw-materials-only policy is a defining feature of colonial economic relationships. The lobbying by merchants and manufacturers shows the political economy of trade restrictions -- concentrated interests shaping policy. Cross-references 4.7.71-72 on specific manufacturing prohibitions.

refashioned:
For example, while raw Muscovado sugar from the British plantations pays only 6 shillings 4 pence per hundredweight upon importation, white sugar pays over one pound, and refined sugar in loaves pays over four pounds. When these high duties were imposed, Great Britain was the sole -- and remains the principal -- market for British colonial sugar. These duties amounted to a prohibition, first on refining sugar for any foreign market, and now effectively on refining it for the market that absorbs perhaps nine-tenths of total production.

Accordingly, the sugar refining industry, though it flourished in all the French sugar colonies, has been little developed in any British colony except for local consumption. When Grenada was under French control, virtually every plantation had a sugar refinery. Since it fell to the English, almost all have been abandoned -- as of October 1773, I am told not more than two or three remain on the island. Currently, however, by an indulgence of the customs house, refined sugar reduced from loaves to powder is commonly imported as though it were raw Muscovado.
elegant: Escalating duties on processed sugar -- from 6 shillings on raw Muscovado to over four pounds on refined loaves -- effectively prohibited colonial sugar refining for export. While sugar refining flourished in French colonies, it barely existed in British ones. When Grenada passed from French to English hands, almost every plantation refinery was abandoned. A customs loophole now allows refined sugar ground to powder to pass as raw Muscovado.
summary: Britain's escalating duties on processed sugar effectively prohibited colonial refining for export. Grenada's thriving refineries under France were abandoned under British rule, though a customs loophole partially circumvents the restriction.
distilled: Escalating British duties on refined sugar destroyed colonial refining industries, as demonstrated by the collapse of Grenada's refineries after it passed from French to British control.
notes: Concrete case study of how the duty structure suppressed colonial value-added manufacturing. The Grenada comparison -- thriving refineries under France, abandoned under Britain -- is powerful evidence. The customs loophole (powder as Muscovado) shows how rigid regulations generate evasion. Cross-references 4.7.69 on Britain reserving manufacturing for itself.

refashioned: While Great Britain encourages the production of pig and bar iron in America by exempting them from the duties imposed on imports from other countries, she simultaneously imposes an absolute prohibition on building steel furnaces and slit mills in any American plantation. Britain will not allow her colonists to work in these more refined manufactures even for their own consumption, insisting they purchase all such goods from British merchants and manufacturers.
elegant: Britain encourages basic American iron production through duty exemptions while absolutely prohibiting steel furnaces and slit mills in the colonies. Colonists cannot produce refined iron goods even for their own use -- they must buy them from British manufacturers.
summary: Britain encouraged basic iron production in America but prohibited advanced ironworking like steel furnaces and slit mills, forcing colonists to purchase refined iron goods from British manufacturers.
distilled: Britain promoted basic colonial iron production while absolutely prohibiting advanced ironworking, forcing dependence on British manufacturers for refined iron goods.
notes: Classic colonial manufacturing prohibition -- raw materials encouraged, value-added processing forbidden. The distinction between pig/bar iron (allowed) and steel/slit products (prohibited) shows exactly where Britain drew the manufacturing line. Even consumption for the colonies' own use was prohibited. Cross-references 4.7.67 on iron duty exemptions and 4.7.69 on the general policy of reserving manufacturing.

refashioned: Britain prohibits the transport of hats, wool, and woolen goods produced in America from one province to another -- whether by water, on horseback, or by cart. This regulation effectively prevents the establishment of any manufacture of these goods for sale beyond the immediate locality, confining colonial industry to the coarse household manufactures that a family might make for its own use or for its immediate neighbors in the same province.
elegant: Britain prohibits transporting American-made hats, wool, and woolen goods between provinces by any means -- water, horseback, or cart. This effectively prevents any colonial manufacturing of these goods for distant sale, limiting colonists to crude household production for personal or neighborhood use only.
summary: By prohibiting inter-provincial transport of American-made hats and woolens, Britain prevented any colonial manufacturing for distant sale, confining production to household-scale goods for purely local use.
distilled: Britain's ban on transporting colonial hats and woolens between provinces prevented any manufacturing beyond crude household production for local use.
notes: Extreme example of manufacturing suppression -- not just prohibiting production but prohibiting transport of produced goods. The ban on every mode of transport (water, horse, cart) shows thoroughness. Effectively creates a geographic market fragmentation that makes commercial-scale production economically impossible. Woolens were Britain's most important manufactured export, hence the special protectiveness.

refashioned:
To prohibit a great people from making the most of every part of their own produce, or from employing their capital and labor in whatever way they judge most advantageous to themselves, is a manifest violation of the most sacred rights of mankind. Yet unjust as these prohibitions may be, they have not so far been very harmful to the colonies. Land is still so cheap, and labor consequently so expensive, that colonists can import nearly all advanced manufactures from the mother country more cheaply than they could make them. Even without these prohibitions, their own economic interest would probably have prevented them from establishing such industries in their current stage of development.

As things stand, these prohibitions do not actually constrain colonial industry or prevent it from pursuing any activity it would naturally have undertaken. They are merely impertinent badges of slavery imposed without sufficient reason by the groundless jealousy of the mother country's merchants and manufacturers. In a more advanced stage of development, however, they might become genuinely oppressive and intolerable.
elegant: Prohibiting a people from making the most of their own produce or deploying their capital as they see fit is a clear violation of fundamental rights. Yet these prohibitions have not actually harmed the colonies much -- land is so cheap and labor so dear that importing manufactures is still cheaper than making them locally. The prohibitions are currently just meaningless symbols of subjection, imposed by the groundless jealousy of British merchants. But as the colonies advance, they could become truly oppressive.
summary: Manufacturing prohibitions violate fundamental rights but have not yet harmed the colonies, since cheap land and expensive labor make importing manufactures more economical. These restrictions are currently symbolic badges of subjection that could become genuinely oppressive as the colonies develop.
distilled: Colonial manufacturing prohibitions violate natural rights and, though currently harmless due to the colonies' economic conditions, will become oppressive as they develop.
notes: One of Smith's strongest statements on natural economic rights -- 'the most sacred rights of mankind.' The argument is subtle: the prohibitions are wrong in principle even when harmless in practice, because they represent unjust authority. 'Badges of slavery' is powerful language. The forward-looking warning -- that these restrictions will become oppressive as the colonies develop -- foreshadows the American Revolution. Cross-references the cheap land/dear labor analysis from earlier in 4.7.

refashioned:
As Britain confines some of the most important colonial productions to her own market, she also compensates the colonies with certain advantages in that market. She does this in two ways: first, by imposing higher duties on equivalent products imported from other countries; and second, by granting bounties on colonial imports. The first method gives an advantage to colonial sugar, tobacco, and iron; the second benefits colonial raw silk, hemp, flax, indigo, naval stores, and building timber.

This second method of encouraging colonial produce through import bounties is, as far as I can determine, peculiar to Great Britain. The first method is not unique -- Portugal, for instance, not only imposes higher duties on tobacco from other countries but prohibits its importation entirely under severe penalties.
elegant: Britain compensates colonies for market restrictions by giving their products advantages in the home market -- either through higher duties on competing foreign imports (benefiting colonial sugar, tobacco, and iron) or through bounties on colonial imports (benefiting silk, hemp, indigo, naval stores, and timber). Import bounties appear to be uniquely British; discriminatory duties are common -- Portugal goes further, banning foreign tobacco entirely.
summary: Britain compensated colonies for trade restrictions by giving their products market advantages through higher duties on foreign competitors and import bounties, the latter being a policy apparently unique to Britain.
distilled: Britain partially compensated colonies for market restrictions by imposing higher duties on competing foreign goods and granting import bounties on colonial products.
notes: Two mechanisms of colonial preference: discriminatory tariffs and direct bounties. Smith notes the bounty system as distinctively British policy. Portugal's outright prohibition on foreign tobacco is cited as a more extreme version of the same protectionist logic. This compensatory framework creates a complex web of incentives within the mercantilist system. Cross-references bounty analysis in 4.5.

refashioned:
Regarding the importation of European goods, England has likewise dealt more liberally with her colonies than any other nation.

Great Britain allows a portion of the duty paid on imported foreign goods -- usually at least half, often more, and sometimes all of it -- to be refunded when those goods are re-exported to any foreign country. It was easy to foresee that no independent nation would accept goods loaded with the heavy duties Britain imposes on foreign imports. Without refunding some portion of these duties upon re-export, the carrying trade -- so favored by the mercantile system -- would have been impossible.
elegant: England has treated her colonies more liberally than any other nation regarding European goods imports. Britain refunds a substantial share -- usually half or more -- of import duties when foreign goods are re-exported. Without these drawbacks, no foreign country would buy goods burdened with Britain's heavy import duties, and the carrying trade so prized by mercantilists would collapse.
summary: Britain dealt more liberally with colonial imports of European goods than other nations, refunding substantial portions of import duties on re-exported goods to sustain the carrying trade.
distilled: Britain sustained its valued carrying trade by refunding import duties on foreign goods re-exported to the colonies and other countries.
notes: Drawbacks -- duty refunds on re-exported goods -- were essential to the carrying trade, which mercantilists valued as a source of merchant profit and shipping employment. Without drawbacks, Britain's high protective tariffs would have killed re-export trade entirely. This shows the internal contradictions of mercantilism: protectionist duties require compensating mechanisms to maintain trade flows.

refashioned:
The colonies, however, are by no means independent foreign countries. Having claimed the exclusive right to supply them with all European goods, Great Britain could have forced the colonies -- as other nations did with theirs -- to accept goods loaded with the full domestic duties. Instead, until 1763, the same drawbacks were paid on exports of most foreign goods to the colonies as on exports to any independent country.

In 1763, however, by the 4th of George III, chapter 15, this generous treatment was significantly curtailed. The law provided that no part of the old subsidy duty would be refunded on European or East Indian goods exported to any British colony in America, except for wines, white calicoes, and muslins. Before this law, many foreign goods could be bought more cheaply in the plantations than in the mother country, and some still can.
elegant: Britain could have forced colonies to accept European goods loaded with full domestic duties, as other nations did. Instead, until 1763, the same duty refunds applied to colonial exports as to exports to independent countries. The 1763 act curtailed this, ending drawbacks on the old subsidy for most European and East Indian goods shipped to the colonies -- with exceptions for wines, calicoes, and muslins. Before this change, many foreign goods were cheaper in the colonies than in Britain itself.
summary: Until 1763, Britain generously refunded duties on European goods shipped to the colonies just as for independent countries. The 1763 act curtailed these drawbacks, though some foreign goods remained cheaper in the colonies than in Britain.
distilled: Britain treated colonial re-exports generously until 1763, when drawback refunds on most European goods shipped to the colonies were eliminated.
notes: The 1763 act (4 Geo. III c. 15) marks a tightening of colonial trade policy -- part of the post-Seven Years' War fiscal squeeze that contributed to American discontent. The anomaly that foreign goods could be cheaper in the colonies than in Britain illustrates how drawbacks created arbitrage opportunities. The exceptions (wines, calicoes, muslins) show the political selectivity of trade policy.

refashioned:
It must be observed that the merchants who carry on the colony trade have been the principal advisors behind most of these regulations. We should not be surprised, then, that in many cases their own interest has been prioritized over that of either the colonies or the mother country.

In their exclusive privilege of supplying the colonies with European goods and purchasing colonial surplus produce that did not compete with their own domestic trades, the interest of the colonies was sacrificed to that of these merchants. In allowing the same drawbacks on re-exporting European and East India goods to the colonies as on re-exporting them to independent countries, the interest of the mother country was sacrificed -- even by the mercantilist understanding of national interest.

The merchants' interest was to pay as little as possible for foreign goods sent to the colonies, and therefore to recover as much as possible of the import duties they had advanced. This would let them sell the same quantity at greater profit, or a greater quantity at the same profit. It was likewise in the colonies' interest to get European goods as cheaply and abundantly as possible. But this was not always in the mother country's interest. She frequently suffered both in revenue -- by refunding duties already paid on imports -- and in her manufactures, which were undersold in the colonial market because foreign manufactures could be shipped there so cheaply thanks to the drawbacks. The progress of the British linen industry, it is commonly said, was considerably retarded by drawbacks on re-exported German linen to the American colonies.
elegant: The merchants who conduct the colony trade have been the principal advisors on colonial regulations, so unsurprisingly their interest has often prevailed over that of colonies and mother country alike. Their exclusive supply privilege sacrificed colonial interests. The generous drawbacks on re-exports sacrificed the mother country's interests -- reducing her revenue and allowing foreign manufactures to undersell British goods in colonial markets. Merchants wanted cheap foreign goods and maximum duty refunds; colonies wanted cheap abundant goods. But the mother country lost revenue on refunded duties and saw her manufactures undercut -- the British linen industry was notably retarded by drawbacks on German linen re-exported to America.
summary: Colonial trade regulations primarily served the merchants who advised on them, sacrificing both colonial interests through monopoly and the mother country's interests through generous drawbacks that reduced revenue and allowed foreign goods to undercut British manufactures in colonial markets.
distilled: Colonial trade policy was shaped by merchant self-interest, sacrificing both colonial welfare through monopoly and British national interests through drawbacks that undercut domestic manufactures.
notes: Key political economy insight: those who shape trade policy are those who profit from it. The merchant interest is distinct from both colonial and national interests.
