Drawbacks created a three-way conflict: good for merchants (cheap sourcing), good for colonies (cheap goods), bad for the mother country (lost revenue, undercut manufactures). The German linen example is a concrete case of regulatory harm to domestic industry. Cross-references Smith's broader critique of merchants influencing policy in 4.2-4.3.

refashioned:
Though British colonial trade policy has been dictated by the same mercantilist spirit as that of other nations, it has on the whole been less illiberal and oppressive than any of them.

In everything except foreign trade, the liberty of English colonists to manage their own affairs is complete. It is in every respect equal to that of their fellow citizens at home, and is secured in the same way -- by an elected assembly of the people's representatives, who claim the sole right to impose taxes for the support of the colonial government. The authority of this assembly overawes the executive power. No colonist, however humble or unpopular, has anything to fear from the resentment of the governor or any civil or military officer, so long as he obeys the law.
elegant: British colonial policy, though mercantilist, has been less oppressive than that of any other nation. In all matters except foreign trade, English colonists enjoy complete self-governance, equal to that of citizens at home. Elected assemblies claim the sole right to tax, their authority overawes the executive, and no law-abiding colonist need fear any official's resentment.
summary: British colonial policy, while mercantilist, was the least oppressive of any European power. Colonists enjoyed full self-governance in domestic affairs through elected assemblies with exclusive taxing power and authority over the executive.
distilled: British colonists enjoyed greater domestic self-governance than any other European colonies, with elected assemblies holding sole taxing power and checking executive authority.
notes: Smith distinguishes trade policy (mercantilist) from internal governance (liberal). The colonial assemblies' sole taxing authority -- the principle that was about to trigger the American Revolution -- is presented as a fundamental liberty. 'No taxation without representation' is implicit here. The elected assembly's power over the executive contrasts sharply with absolute colonial governments described in 4.7.81.

refashioned:
The colonial assemblies, though not always perfectly representative of the people -- much like the House of Commons in England -- come closer to genuine representation than their English counterpart. Since the colonial executive either lacks the means to corrupt them, or does not need to because it receives its support from the mother country, the assemblies are generally more responsive to their constituents' wishes.

The colonial councils, which correspond to the House of Lords, are not composed of hereditary nobility. In some colonies, such as three of the New England governments, these councils are not appointed by the king but elected by the people's representatives. No English colony has a hereditary nobility. In all of them, as in all free countries, the descendant of an old colonial family receives more respect than a newcomer of equal merit and fortune -- but this is a matter of respect only, carrying no legal privileges that could burden his neighbors.

Before the current disturbances, the colonial assemblies held not only legislative but also part of the executive power. In Connecticut and Rhode Island, they elected the governor.
elegant: Colonial assemblies, though imperfectly representative like the House of Commons, are generally more responsive to constituents since the executive cannot or need not corrupt them. Colonial councils have no hereditary nobility -- in some New England colonies, they are elected. Old colonial families receive social respect but enjoy no legal privileges. Before the current conflicts, colonial assemblies held both legislative and partial executive power, even electing the governor in Connecticut and Rhode Island.
summary: Colonial assemblies were more responsive to constituents than Parliament because the executive could not corrupt them. With no hereditary nobility and elected councils in some colonies, colonial governance was more democratic than Britain's own system.
distilled: Colonial governance was in many respects more democratic than Britain's, with responsive assemblies, no hereditary nobility, and elected councils in some colonies.
notes: Smith implicitly argues the colonies were more democratic than Britain itself -- assemblies less corruptible, no hereditary aristocracy, elected officials. 'The present disturbances' refers to the American Revolution, dating this passage. The observation that colonial executives lacked the means or motivation to corrupt assemblies is a structural analysis of why colonial democracy worked better. Connecticut and Rhode Island's elected governors represent the most republican end of the spectrum.

refashioned: In the other colonies, the assemblies appointed the revenue officers who collected taxes imposed by those assemblies, and these officers were directly accountable to them. There is therefore more equality among the English colonists than among the inhabitants of the mother country. Their customs are more republican, and their governments -- particularly those of the three New England provinces -- have been more republican as well.
elegant: In other colonies, assemblies appointed and controlled their own tax collectors. The result was greater equality among English colonists than in the mother country, with more republican manners and more republican governments -- especially in the three New England provinces.
summary: Colonial assemblies controlled their own tax collectors, producing greater equality and more republican customs and governments than in Britain, especially in New England.
distilled: English colonies achieved greater equality and more republican governance than the mother country, particularly in New England.
notes: The direct accountability of tax collectors to elected assemblies -- rather than to the crown -- is a crucial structural feature of colonial self-governance. Smith's observation that colonial manners and government were 'more republican' implicitly validates the American republican experiment. The New England colonies as the most republican foreshadows their leading role in the Revolution.

refashioned:
The absolute governments of Spain, Portugal, and France, by contrast, extend directly into their colonies. The discretionary powers that such governments typically delegate to subordinate officers are exercised with even greater violence in the colonies because of the enormous distance from the capital.

Under all absolute governments, there is more liberty in the capital than in the provinces. The sovereign himself generally has neither the interest nor the inclination to pervert justice or oppress the common people. In the capital, his presence restrains his subordinate officers. But in remote provinces, where the people's complaints are unlikely to reach him, those officers can exercise their tyranny with far greater impunity. The European colonies in America are more remote than the most distant provinces of any empire the world had previously known.

The government of the English colonies is perhaps the only one in history that could give perfect security to the inhabitants of so distant a province. The French colonial administration has always been conducted with considerably more gentleness than that of Spain and Portugal -- a superiority consistent with the French national character and with the nature of their government, which, though arbitrary and violent compared to Britain's, is legal and free compared to those of Spain and Portugal.
elegant: Spain, Portugal, and France imposed absolute government on their colonies, where subordinate officers exercised their powers with even more violence than at home due to the vast distance. In absolute states, the sovereign's presence restrains officials in the capital, but remote provinces suffer unchecked tyranny -- and American colonies were more remote than any previous imperial territory. English colonial government is perhaps history's only system capable of securing liberty at such distance. French colonial administration, while less free than British, was considerably gentler than that of Spain and Portugal.
summary: Absolute governments of Spain, Portugal, and France transferred their tyranny to colonies where distance amplified official abuses. Only English colonial governance provided genuine security at such distance, while French administration was gentler than Iberian but still less free than British.
distilled: Only English colonial governance could secure genuine liberty at such vast distances, because absolute colonial governments amplified official tyranny in proportion to their remoteness from the capital.
notes: Important comparative analysis of colonial governance systems. The distance-tyranny relationship is a key insight: absolute power plus geographic remoteness equals amplified oppression. Smith's ranking -- English (free), French (legal but arbitrary), Spanish/Portuguese (tyrannical) -- tracks to colonial economic outcomes. The claim that English colonial governance is historically unique in securing liberty at distance is a strong endorsement. Cross-references 4.7.78-80 on English colonial self-governance.

refashioned: It is in the progress of the North American colonies, however, that the superiority of English policy chiefly appears. The sugar colonies of France have progressed at least as well as, perhaps better than, most English sugar colonies -- and yet the English sugar colonies enjoy a free government similar to that of the North American colonies. But the French sugar colonies are not discouraged from refining their own sugar, as the English ones are. And what is even more important, the nature of the French government naturally produces better management of their enslaved workers.
elegant: The superiority of English policy shows chiefly in North America's progress. French sugar colonies have matched or exceeded English ones, despite the English having freer government. But French colonies were not prohibited from refining sugar, and -- more importantly -- French governance naturally produced better management of enslaved workers.
summary: While English policy excelled in North America, French sugar colonies matched or surpassed English ones because they could refine their own sugar and because French governance produced better management of enslaved workers.
distilled: French sugar colonies outperformed English ones because they were allowed to refine sugar and because French governance produced better management of enslaved laborers.
notes: Smith complicates the simple narrative of English superiority. Free government alone does not guarantee economic success -- the French sugar colonies show that better economic policy (allowing refining) and better labor management can matter more. The observation about slave management connects governance structure to economic outcomes through a disturbing channel. Cross-references 4.7.70 on British sugar refining prohibitions.

refashioned:
In all European colonies, sugar cane is cultivated by enslaved Africans. Europeans, it is believed, cannot endure the labor of digging under the burning West Indian sun, and sugar cultivation as currently practiced is entirely manual -- though many believe the drill plough could be introduced with great advantage.

Just as the profit and success of farming with cattle depends heavily on how well the cattle are managed, the profit and success of cultivation by enslaved labor depends equally on how well those workers are managed. It is generally acknowledged that the French planters are superior to the English in the management of their enslaved workers.
elegant: All European sugar colonies rely on enslaved African labor, since Europeans supposedly cannot endure the tropical fieldwork, and sugar cultivation is entirely manual. Just as farming success depends on good management of livestock, the profitability of slave-based cultivation depends on management of enslaved workers -- and French planters are generally acknowledged as superior to English in this regard.
summary: Sugar cultivation in all European colonies depended on enslaved African labor, and French planters were widely recognized as managing their enslaved workers more effectively than English planters.
distilled: French planters were recognized as superior to English in managing enslaved workers, which directly affected the profitability of sugar cultivation.
notes: Smith's comparison of slave management to livestock management is characteristic of the era's economic framing of slavery. His observation that management quality drives profitability is economically valid but morally jarring. The note that the drill plough might replace hand labor hints at potential mechanization. The assumed inability of Europeans to do tropical fieldwork was used to justify enslaved labor -- Smith reports this belief without fully endorsing or challenging it.

refashioned: The law, insofar as it gives some weak protection to enslaved people against their masters' violence, is likely to be better enforced in a colony with an arbitrary government than in one with a free government. In every country where slavery is established, a magistrate who protects an enslaved person is to some extent interfering in the management of the master's private property. In a free country, where the master may be a member of the colonial assembly or a voter for such a member, the magistrate dares not interfere except with the greatest caution and circumspection.
elegant: Laws protecting enslaved people from their masters' violence are better enforced under arbitrary governments than free ones. Protecting a slave means interfering with a master's property rights, and in free countries where masters hold political power -- as assembly members or voters -- magistrates dare not intervene except with extreme caution.
summary: Slave protection laws are paradoxically better enforced under arbitrary governments, because in free colonies the political power of slaveholding masters deters magistrates from interfering with their 'property rights.'
distilled: Paradoxically, arbitrary governments better protect enslaved people because free governments give slaveholders the political power to deter judicial interference.
notes: A profound paradox: political freedom for masters means less protection for slaves. The magistrate's reluctance to interfere with a politically powerful master's 'property' shows how democratic institutions can entrench oppression when citizenship is restricted. This insight anticipates later analyses of how majority-rule democracy can harm excluded minorities. Cross-references 4.7.81 on the comparison between free and absolute colonial governments.

refashioned:
The respect the magistrate must pay to the master makes it harder to protect the enslaved person. But in a country with a largely arbitrary government -- where it is normal for the magistrate to intervene in the management of private property and even to send a lettre de cachet to those who do not manage it to his liking -- it is much easier for him to extend some protection to enslaved people. Common humanity naturally disposes him to do so.

The magistrate's protection makes the enslaved person less contemptible in the master's eyes, inducing the master to treat the worker with more regard and gentleness. Gentle treatment makes enslaved workers not only more faithful but more intelligent, and therefore doubly more useful. Such workers approach the condition of free servants and may develop integrity and genuine attachment to their master's interests -- virtues that frequently belong to free servants but can never belong to someone who is treated as enslaved people commonly are in countries where the master is perfectly free and secure.
elegant: Under arbitrary government, where magistrates routinely intervene in private affairs, protecting enslaved people is easy and natural humanity disposes them to do so. This protection makes the enslaved less contemptible to masters, who then treat them more gently. Gentle treatment produces workers who are more faithful, more intelligent, and therefore doubly more useful -- approaching the condition of free servants, capable of integrity and genuine loyalty. These virtues are impossible in workers treated as slaves typically are where masters face no constraints.
summary: Under arbitrary governments, magistrates can more easily protect enslaved people, producing a cycle where protection leads to better treatment, which produces more faithful and capable workers approaching the condition of free servants.
distilled: Magisterial protection of enslaved people under arbitrary governments creates a virtuous cycle of better treatment producing more faithful, capable, and productive workers.
notes: Smith traces a causal chain: government protection leads to masters' respect, respect leads to gentle treatment, gentle treatment produces better workers. The lettre de cachet -- an arbitrary royal order -- is cited as enabling benevolent intervention. The argument that better treatment makes workers 'more intelligent' reflects Smith's view that human capacity is shaped by conditions, not fixed by nature. The distinction between treatment that produces free-servant virtues versus slave-condition vices is an implicit argument against the institution itself.

refashioned: That enslaved people fare better under an arbitrary government than under a free one is, I believe, supported by the history of all ages and nations. In Roman history, the first instance of a magistrate intervening to protect an enslaved person from his master's violence comes under the emperors. When Vedius Pollio, in the presence of Augustus, ordered a slave who had committed a minor fault to be cut to pieces and thrown into his fishpond to feed the fish, the emperor indignantly commanded him to emancipate not only that slave but all others in his possession. Under the Republic, no magistrate would have had sufficient authority to protect the slave, much less to punish the master.
elegant: History supports the claim that enslaved people fare better under arbitrary than free governments. The first Roman instance of a magistrate protecting a slave came under the emperors: when Vedius Pollio ordered a slave cut to pieces and fed to his fish for a minor offense, Augustus commanded the emancipation of all his slaves. Under the Republic, no magistrate could have had such authority.
summary: Roman history illustrates that slave protection only emerged under imperial authority -- when Augustus intervened against Vedius Pollio's cruelty -- because no republican magistrate had sufficient power to check a master.
distilled: Roman history confirms that only the emperor's absolute authority could protect slaves from their masters, because republican magistrates lacked the power to intervene.
notes: The Vedius Pollio anecdote (from Seneca, Dio Cassius, and Pliny) serves as historical evidence for the slavery-governance paradox. Augustus's intervention -- emancipating all of Pollio's slaves -- exemplifies how absolute power can be deployed benevolently. The contrast between Republic (masters unchecked) and Empire (emperor can intervene) parallels the contrast between English free colonies and French arbitrary ones. Smith uses this historical analogy to reinforce a disturbing structural insight about freedom and oppression.

refashioned:
It should be noted that the capital which has improved the French sugar colonies, particularly the great colony of Saint-Domingue, has been raised almost entirely from the gradual improvement and cultivation of those colonies themselves. It has been almost wholly the produce of the soil and of the colonists' industry -- or equivalently, the price of that produce, gradually accumulated through good management and reinvested in raising still greater produce.

By contrast, the capital that has improved the English sugar colonies has been largely sent out from England, and is by no means entirely the product of the colonists' own soil and industry. The prosperity of the English sugar colonies has been substantially due to England's great wealth overflowing, as it were, into these colonies. But the prosperity of the French sugar colonies has been entirely due to the good management of the colonists themselves, which must therefore have been superior to that of the English. This superiority has been most evident in the management of their enslaved workers.
elegant: The capital behind French sugar colony prosperity, especially Saint-Domingue, was raised almost entirely from the colonies' own gradual improvement -- produce accumulated through good management and reinvested. English sugar colonies, by contrast, were largely funded by capital sent from wealthy England. French colonial prosperity thus reflects superior management by the colonists themselves, while English prosperity reflects the mother country's overflowing wealth. This French superiority is most visible in the management of enslaved workers.
summary: French sugar colonies prospered through self-generated capital and superior management, while English sugar colonies depended heavily on capital imported from England. The French advantage was most evident in slave management.
distilled: French sugar colonies were more self-sustaining than English ones, generating their own capital through superior management -- especially of enslaved workers -- rather than depending on wealth from the mother country.
notes: Important distinction between self-funded and externally funded growth. French colonies' self-sufficiency in capital formation indicates genuine economic competence, while English colonies' dependence on metropolitan capital suggests less efficient management. Saint-Domingue (Haiti) was the richest colony in the world at this time. The argument that French superiority shows in slave management ties economic performance directly to labor management practices. Cross-references 4.7.82-85 on comparative colonial governance and slave treatment.

refashioned:
Such have been the general outlines of the different European nations' colonial policies.

European policy therefore has very little to boast of, either in the original establishment of the American colonies or, as far as internal governance is concerned, in their subsequent prosperity.
elegant: Such are the general outlines of European colonial policy. Europe has very little to boast of in either the founding or the subsequent prosperity of its American colonies.
summary: European policy deserves little credit for either establishing or fostering the prosperity of the American colonies.
distilled: European colonial policy contributed little to either the founding or the prosperity of the American colonies.
notes: Transitional summary that sets up Smith's indictment of European colonial policy in 4.7.89-93. The claim that Europe deserves little credit for colonial prosperity is a sharp rebuke to mercantilist pride. Distinguishes between colonial establishment and subsequent internal governance as two separate failures.

refashioned: Folly and injustice seem to have been the guiding principles behind the first projects for establishing these colonies: the folly of chasing after gold and silver mines, and the injustice of coveting the lands of a country whose harmless natives, far from ever having injured the people of Europe, had received the first adventurers with every mark of kindness and hospitality.
elegant: The founding of the colonies was guided by folly -- the hunt for gold and silver mines -- and injustice -- the seizure of lands from harmless natives who had welcomed Europeans with kindness and hospitality.
summary: The founding of European colonies was driven by the folly of seeking gold and silver and the injustice of seizing lands from hospitable native peoples who had never harmed Europeans.
distilled: Colonial founding was driven by the folly of gold-hunting and the injustice of dispossessing welcoming native peoples.
notes: One of Smith's strongest moral condemnations in the entire work. 'Folly and injustice' as founding principles -- a comprehensive indictment. The description of natives as 'harmless' who 'received the first adventurers with every mark of kindness and hospitality' places moral blame squarely on European aggressors. The gold and silver obsession connects to Smith's critique of bullionism in 4.1. Cross-references 4.7.1-10 on early colonial motives.

refashioned:
The adventurers who formed some of the later colonies combined the chimerical project of finding gold and silver mines with other motives that were more reasonable and more commendable -- but even these do very little honor to European policy.

The English Puritans, constrained at home, fled to America for freedom and established the four governments of New England. The English Catholics, treated with even greater injustice, established Maryland. The Quakers established Pennsylvania. The Portuguese Jews, persecuted by the Inquisition, stripped of their fortunes, and banished to Brazil, introduced some measure of order and industry among the transported felons and prostitutes by whom that colony was originally populated, and taught them to cultivate sugar cane.

In every one of these cases, it was not the wisdom and policy of European governments but their disorder and injustice that populated and cultivated America.
elegant: Later colonists had more laudable motives than gold-hunting, but these still reflected poorly on European policy. Puritans fled English persecution to found New England; persecuted Catholics established Maryland; Quakers founded Pennsylvania; Portuguese Jews, stripped of everything by the Inquisition, brought order to Brazil's convict settlers. In each case, it was European disorder and injustice -- not wisdom or policy -- that populated and developed America.
summary: Later colonial settlements were founded by groups fleeing European persecution -- Puritans, Catholics, Quakers, Portuguese Jews -- meaning it was Europe's disorder and injustice, not its wise policy, that populated and cultivated America.
distilled: America was populated not by European wisdom but by European injustice, as persecuted groups -- Puritans, Catholics, Quakers, and Jews -- fled to build new societies.
notes: Powerful reversal: Europe's colonies were built by its failures, not its successes. Each founding group represents a different form of European religious persecution. The Portuguese Jews transforming Brazil from a penal colony into a productive sugar economy is a striking example of persecution producing unintended developmental benefits. Smith's point is that colonial policy deserves no credit -- the colonies prospered despite European governments, not because of them.

refashioned: In carrying out some of the most important of these settlements, European governments had as little merit as in originally conceiving them. The conquest of Mexico was not the project of the Spanish council but of a governor of Cuba, and it was achieved by the boldness of the adventurer entrusted with it, despite everything that governor -- who quickly regretted his decision -- could do to obstruct it. The conquerors of Chile and Peru, and of nearly all other Spanish settlements on the American continent, set out with no public encouragement beyond a general permission to make settlements and conquests in the name of the king of Spain. These ventures were entirely at the private risk and expense of the adventurers. The government of Spain contributed almost nothing to any of them. The government of England contributed equally little to establishing some of its most important North American colonies.
elegant: European governments contributed as little to executing colonial settlements as to conceiving them. The conquest of Mexico was a private venture by Cuba's governor, achieved by bold adventurers despite official obstruction. Chile, Peru, and nearly all Spanish continental settlements were privately funded with only nominal royal permission. Spain's government contributed almost nothing -- nor did England's to its most important North American colonies.
summary: European governments contributed almost nothing to actually establishing the colonies. The conquests of Mexico, Peru, and Chile were private ventures at the adventurers' own risk, as were England's most important North American settlements.
distilled: The major colonial establishments were private ventures at the adventurers' own risk and expense, with European governments contributing almost nothing.
notes: Extends the indictment from founding motives to execution -- governments failed at both. Cortes's conquest of Mexico despite the opposition of Cuba's governor Velazquez is a classic case of private enterprise outrunning official authority. The 'general permission' to conquer in the king's name was a minimal legal fiction. Smith builds the case that colonial success owed nothing to government policy and everything to private initiative.

refashioned: Once these settlements were established and had become considerable enough to attract the mother country's attention, the first regulations imposed on them always aimed to secure a monopoly of their commerce -- to confine the colonial market and enlarge the mother country's market at the colonies' expense. The purpose was to dampen and discourage, rather than quicken and promote, the course of colonial prosperity. The different ways in which this monopoly was exercised constitute one of the most essential differences in the colonial policies of the various European nations. The best of these policies, that of England, is only somewhat less illiberal and oppressive than the rest.
elegant: Once colonies became significant enough to attract metropolitan attention, every mother country's first act was to monopolize their commerce -- confining colonial markets and expanding its own at colonial expense, thereby dampening colonial prosperity. The varying methods of exercising this monopoly mark the essential differences between European colonial policies. Even England's policy, the best of them, was merely somewhat less oppressive than the rest.
summary: Every European mother country's first response to colonial success was to monopolize colonial trade at the colonies' expense, dampening their prosperity. England's policy, though the best, was only marginally less oppressive than the others.
distilled: Every European nation responded to colonial prosperity by monopolizing colonial trade to benefit itself at the colonies' expense, with England's policy merely the least oppressive.
notes: Completes the three-part indictment: (1) colonies were founded from folly and injustice, (2) governments contributed nothing to their establishment, (3) once established, governments sought only to exploit them through trade monopoly. 'Dampen and discourage rather than quicken and forward' -- the monopoly's purpose was extraction, not development. England as the least oppressive is faint praise. Cross-references the entire analysis of colonial trade regulation in 4.7.62-77.

refashioned: In what way, then, has European policy contributed to either the original establishment or the present grandeur of the American colonies? In one way, and one way only, it has contributed a great deal. Magna virum mater! -- 'Great mother of men!' Europe bred and formed the people who were capable of achieving such great actions and laying the foundation of so great an empire. No other quarter of the world has a policy capable of forming, or has ever actually formed, such people. The colonies owe to European policy the education and expansive vision of their active and enterprising founders. Some of the greatest and most important colonies, as far as their internal government is concerned, owe it scarcely anything else.
elegant: How has European policy contributed to colonial grandeur? In only one way: Magna virum mater! -- 'Great mother of men!' Europe educated and formed the people capable of such achievements. No other part of the world could have produced such founders. The colonies owe European policy the education and vision of their founders -- and, for many of the greatest colonies, nothing else.
summary: Europe's only genuine contribution to colonial success was producing the educated, enterprising people who founded the colonies. Their internal governance and prosperity owe European policy almost nothing else.
distilled: Europe's sole meaningful contribution to colonial greatness was educating and forming the people capable of building it -- policy contributed virtually nothing beyond that.
notes: The Virgil quotation (Georgics II.174) -- Magna virum mater -- adds classical gravitas to the argument. Smith's conclusion is devastatingly precise: Europe produced great people, but its policy did nothing for them once they arrived. The distinction between producing human capital (education, character) and governing policy is crucial. This passage anticipates modern arguments about institutional vs. human capital determinants of development.

refashioned:
Such are the advantages the colonies of America have derived from European policy.

What, then, are the advantages that Europe has derived from the discovery and colonization of America?
elegant: Those are the advantages the colonies gained from European policy. What has Europe gained from the discovery and colonization of America?
summary: Having assessed what the colonies gained from European policy (very little beyond their founders' education), Smith pivots to ask what Europe gained from the colonies.
distilled: Smith transitions from colonial benefits of European policy to examining what Europe has gained from its colonies.
notes: Pivotal transition point in the argument. The first question (what did colonies gain from Europe?) was answered dismissively. The second question (what did Europe gain from the colonies?) structures the remainder of this section. The implied asymmetry -- Europe gained more than it contributed -- is central to Smith's colonial critique.

refashioned:
These advantages may be divided into two categories: first, the general advantages that Europe as a whole has derived from these great events; and second, the particular advantages that each colonizing country has derived from its own colonies through the authority and dominion it exercises over them.

The general advantages Europe has gained from the discovery and colonization of America consist of two things: first, an increase in the variety of goods it can enjoy; and second, an expansion of its industry.
elegant: Europe's advantages from the colonies are of two kinds: general advantages to Europe as a whole, and particular advantages each colonizing nation derives from its own colonies. The general advantages are twofold: a greater variety of goods to enjoy, and an expansion of European industry.
summary: European advantages from colonization divide into general advantages for all of Europe (more goods and expanded industry) and particular advantages each colonizing nation derives from controlling its own colonies.
distilled: Europe gained generally from colonial trade through increased goods and expanded industry, while individual colonizing nations gained particular advantages from controlling their own colonies.
notes: Establishes the analytical framework for the remainder of the colonial analysis. The distinction between general advantages (shared by all Europe via trade) and particular advantages (exclusive to each colonizing power) is crucial because the monopoly system tries to convert general advantages into particular ones. Cross-references 4.7.99 on how monopoly diminishes the general advantages.

refashioned:
The surplus produce of America imported into Europe furnishes the inhabitants of this great continent with a variety of commodities they could not otherwise have possessed -- some for practical use, some for pleasure, and some for ornament -- and thereby increases their enjoyments.

The discovery and colonization of America has also expanded European industry. It has directly increased the industry of every country that trades with America -- such as Spain, Portugal, France, and England. It has also indirectly increased the industry of countries that do not trade directly with America but send their goods there through intermediaries -- such as Austrian Flanders and some German provinces, which ship considerable quantities of linen and other goods to America through the countries named above. All such countries have gained a more extensive market for their surplus produce and have consequently been encouraged to increase their output.
elegant: American surplus produce gives Europeans commodities for use, pleasure, and ornament they could not otherwise have. The discovery of America has also expanded European industry -- directly for countries trading with America (Spain, Portugal, France, England), and indirectly for those like Austrian Flanders and German provinces that ship goods to America through intermediaries. All have gained larger markets for their surplus produce, encouraging increased output.
summary: America provides Europe with new commodities for use, pleasure, and ornament while expanding European industry both for countries trading directly with America and for those that access the market indirectly through intermediaries.
distilled: America enriched Europe by providing new consumer goods and by expanding markets that encouraged greater industrial output across the continent.
notes: The first concrete benefit: new consumer goods that increase European welfare. The second benefit -- expanded markets -- works through both direct and indirect channels. The indirect channel (German linen shipped via Britain or France to America) shows how colonial trade creates supply chain effects that reach far beyond the colonizing nations. Anticipates modern concepts of trade multipliers and global value chains.

refashioned:
But that these great events should also have encouraged the industry of countries like Hungary and Poland, which may never have sent a single one of their own products to America, is perhaps not so immediately obvious. Yet there can be no doubt that they have done so.

Some American produce is consumed in Hungary and Poland -- there is demand there for sugar, chocolate, and tobacco from the New World. But these goods must be purchased with something that is either the produce of Hungarian and Polish industry, or something purchased with that produce. The commodities of America are new values, new equivalents introduced into Hungary and Poland to be exchanged for the surplus produce of those countries. By being brought there, they create a new and more extensive market for that surplus, raise its value, and thereby encourage its increase.

Even though no Hungarian or Polish product may ever reach America, it may be sold to countries that purchase it with their share of America's surplus produce. Through the circulation of this trade -- originally set in motion by American surplus -- even these distant nations find expanded markets for their goods.
elegant: Even Hungary and Poland, which may never have sent a single product to America, benefit from its discovery. American sugar, chocolate, and tobacco consumed there must be purchased with Hungarian and Polish produce or its equivalent. These American goods create new markets for eastern European surplus, raising its value and encouraging greater output. Even if no Hungarian goods reach America, they can be sold to countries that pay with their share of American produce -- the trade circulation originally set in motion by America reaches everywhere.
summary: Even countries like Hungary and Poland that never traded directly with America benefited because American goods consumed there created new demand for local produce, and the circulation of trade set in motion by American surplus reached all European markets indirectly.
distilled: American trade benefited even non-trading nations like Hungary and Poland by creating new demand chains that circulated through the entire European commercial network.
notes: Elegant demonstration of how trade creates indirect benefits through chains of exchange. The 'new values, new equivalents' concept shows how introducing new goods into an economy stimulates production even in distant, seemingly unconnected sectors. This is an early articulation of general equilibrium effects -- how a shock in one market propagates through an entire economic system. The circulation metaphor anticipates modern analysis of trade multiplier effects.

refashioned:
These great events may even have increased the enjoyments and expanded the industry of countries that never sent any commodities to America and never received any from it. Such countries may have received a greater abundance of goods from other countries whose surplus produce had been augmented by the American trade. This greater abundance must have increased their enjoyments and expanded their industry. More new equivalents of some kind must have been offered to them in exchange for the surplus produce of their industry. A more extensive market must have been created for that surplus, raising its value and encouraging its increase.

The total mass of commodities annually circulating through the great system of European commerce, distributed by its various rotations among all the nations within it, must have been augmented by the entire surplus produce of America. A greater share of this greater total is therefore likely to have fallen to each nation, increasing their enjoyments and expanding their industry.
elegant: Even countries with no direct or indirect American trade may have benefited. They could receive more goods from countries whose output grew thanks to the American trade, expanding their own enjoyments and industry in turn. The total mass of commodities circulating through European commerce has been augmented by America's entire surplus produce. A greater share of this greater total falls to each nation, increasing their welfare and industry.
summary: The American trade expanded the total volume of goods circulating through European commerce, so that even countries with no connection to America benefited from a larger share of a larger total.
distilled: America's surplus produce enlarged the total mass of European commerce, benefiting every nation in the system through a larger share of a greater whole.
notes: Extends the indirect-benefit argument to its logical conclusion: even countries with zero American trade connection benefit because the total pool of European commerce has grown. This is a remarkably modern understanding of how global trade expansion raises all boats. The 'great circle of European commerce' metaphor frames the continent as a single integrated trading system. Anticipates concepts of positive-sum trade and general equilibrium.

refashioned:
The exclusive trade of the mother countries tends to diminish, or at least to hold down below their natural level, both the enjoyments and the industry of all nations in general, and of the American colonies in particular. It is a dead weight on one of the great engines driving most of the world's economic activity.

By making colonial produce more expensive everywhere else, the monopoly reduces consumption, thereby cramping colonial industry. Countries that enjoy less because they pay more, and produce less because they receive less for their output, are doubly harmed. By making the produce of other countries more expensive in the colonies, the monopoly similarly cramps the industry of those countries and the consumption of the colonies.

The monopoly is a clog that, for the supposed benefit of a few particular countries, burdens the pleasures and encumbers the industry of all others -- but harms the colonies most of all. It not only excludes other countries as much as possible from one particular market, but confines the colonies as much as possible to one particular market. The difference between being excluded from one market when all others are open, and being confined to one market when all others are closed, is enormous.

The surplus produce of the colonies is the original source of all the increased enjoyment and industry that Europe derives from America, and the exclusive trade of the mother countries makes this source far less abundant than it would otherwise be.
elegant: The mother countries' exclusive trade is a dead weight on global commerce. By making colonial produce dearer everywhere, it reduces consumption and cramps colonial industry. By making other countries' goods dearer in the colonies, it cramps those countries' industry too. It is a clog that burdens all nations for the supposed benefit of a few -- but harms the colonies most, because there is an enormous difference between being excluded from one market while others remain open, and being confined to one market while all others are shut. Since colonial surplus is the source of all the benefits Europe derives from America, the monopoly makes that source far less abundant than it would naturally be.
summary: The mother countries' trade monopoly acts as a dead weight on global commerce, reducing consumption and industry everywhere. It harms the colonies most by confining them to a single market while other nations merely lose access to one market among many. The monopoly diminishes the very colonial surplus that is the source of Europe's benefits from America.
distilled: Colonial trade monopolies act as a dead weight on global commerce, harming everyone but especially the colonies, whose confinement to a single market diminishes the surplus that benefits all of Europe.
notes: Central to Smith's anti-monopoly argument. The 'dead weight' metaphor anticipates the modern economic concept of deadweight loss. The asymmetry argument is powerful: exclusion from one market is mild when others are open, but confinement to one market when all others are closed is devastating. The self-defeating nature of monopoly is highlighted -- by reducing the colonial surplus, it diminishes the very source of benefits it was supposed to secure. Cross-references the general/particular advantage distinction from 4.7.95.

refashioned: The particular advantages each colonizing country derives from its own colonies are of two kinds: first, the common advantages that any empire derives from subject provinces; and second, the peculiar advantages supposed to result from provinces as distinctive in nature as the European colonies of America.
elegant: Each colonizing country's advantages from its colonies are twofold: the common advantages any empire derives from subject provinces (military force and revenue), and the peculiar advantages expected from such distinctive territories as the American colonies.
summary: Colonizing countries derive two types of advantages from their colonies: the standard benefits any empire gains from subject provinces, and the special benefits unique to American colonial territories.
distilled: Colonial advantages divide into the standard imperial benefits of military force and revenue, and the special benefits supposedly unique to American colonies.
notes: Sets up the analytical distinction between generic imperial benefits (military and fiscal) and the special American colonial benefits (trade monopoly). The word 'supposed' for the peculiar advantages signals Smith's skepticism. Cross-references 4.7.101-104 which examine each type in detail.

refashioned: The common advantages any empire derives from subject provinces are, first, military force for its defense, and second, revenue for its civil government. The Roman colonies furnished both. The Greek colonies sometimes furnished military force but seldom any revenue. They rarely acknowledged themselves subject to the mother city -- they were generally her allies in war but very seldom her subjects in peace.
elegant: Empires normally gain two things from subject provinces: military force and revenue. Roman colonies provided both. Greek colonies sometimes provided military force but rarely revenue -- they were usually allies in war, not subjects in peace.
summary: Empires normally gain military force and revenue from subject provinces. Roman colonies provided both, while Greek colonies typically served as military allies but not revenue sources or political subjects.
distilled: The standard imperial benefits from colonies are military force and revenue -- Rome obtained both, Greece usually only the first.
notes: Historical framework using Roman and Greek precedents. The Greek colonies' independence -- allies rather than subjects -- anticipates the American colonists' attitude toward Britain. The distinction between wartime alliance and peacetime subjection is relevant to the emerging American crisis. Cross-references earlier discussion of ancient colonies in 4.7.1-20.

refashioned: The European colonies of America have never furnished any military force for the defense of the mother country. Their own military force has never been sufficient even for their own defense, and in the various wars in which the mother countries have been engaged, defending the colonies has generally required a very considerable diversion of the mother country's military resources. In this respect, all European colonies without exception have been a source of weakness rather than strength to their mother countries.
elegant: American colonies have never provided military force for their mother countries' defense. Their own defense has always required significant diversion of metropolitan military resources. In this respect, every European colony without exception has been a source of weakness, not strength.
summary: European colonies in America never contributed military force to the mother country and instead drained its military resources for their own defense, making all colonies a net source of military weakness.
distilled: American colonies were a military liability to every European mother country, requiring defensive resources while contributing none.
notes: First standard imperial benefit assessed: military force. The verdict is unambiguous -- net negative for every European power. This contradicts mercantilist arguments that colonies strengthen the empire. The colonial defense burden is an often-overlooked cost of empire. Cross-references 4.7.101 on normal imperial benefits.

refashioned: Only the colonies of Spain and Portugal have contributed any revenue toward the defense of the mother country or the support of its civil government. The taxes levied on other European colonies -- particularly those of England -- have seldom equaled the peacetime expenditure on them, and never come close to covering wartime costs. Such colonies have therefore been a source of expense rather than revenue to their respective mother countries.
elegant: Only Spain and Portugal have received any revenue from their colonies. English colonial taxes have never matched even peacetime costs, let alone wartime expenses. Most European colonies have been a net fiscal drain on their mother countries.
summary: Only Spanish and Portuguese colonies contributed revenue to their mother countries. English and other colonies were net fiscal drains, with tax revenues falling short of peacetime costs and far short of wartime expenditures.
distilled: Most European colonies, especially English ones, were net fiscal drains -- their tax revenue never covered even peacetime costs, let alone wars.
notes: Second standard imperial benefit assessed: revenue. Again net negative for most powers. The English colonies' failure to generate net revenue is particularly significant given the contemporaneous dispute over colonial taxation (Stamp Act, etc.). The fiscal deficit of colonial governance undermines the entire economic case for empire. Cross-references 4.7.101-102.

refashioned:
The advantages of these colonies to their mother countries therefore consist entirely in the peculiar benefits supposedly resulting from such distinctive provinces as the American colonies. The exclusive trade, it is acknowledged, is the sole source of all these peculiar advantages.

Because of this exclusive trade, all enumerated commodities from the English colonies -- for example -- can be sent only to England. Other countries must then buy them from her. These goods must therefore be cheaper in England than anywhere else, contributing more to English enjoyments and encouraging English industry more than any other country's. For every part of her own surplus produce that England exchanges for these enumerated commodities, she gets a better price than other countries can get for their equivalent goods. English manufactures, for instance, will purchase a greater quantity of colonial sugar and tobacco than the manufactures of other countries can. Insofar as English manufactures and those of other countries both compete to be exchanged for colonial goods, this price advantage gives English industry an encouragement beyond what competitors can enjoy.

The exclusive trade therefore diminishes or at least suppresses the enjoyments and industry of countries that do not possess the monopoly, while giving an evident advantage to those that do.
elegant: The only real advantages of colonies lie in the exclusive trade, which is the sole source of all peculiar colonial benefits. Because enumerated goods must pass through England first, they are cheaper there than anywhere else -- increasing English enjoyments and giving English industry a price advantage over competitors. English manufactures buy more colonial sugar and tobacco than equivalent foreign manufactures can. The exclusive trade thus gives monopoly-holding countries an advantage by suppressing the industry and enjoyments of all others.
summary: The sole advantage colonies provide beyond standard imperial benefits comes from the trade monopoly. By forcing all enumerated goods through England, the monopoly makes them cheaper there, giving English industry a price advantage over foreign competitors while suppressing the industry of non-monopoly countries.
distilled: The only distinctive benefit of colonies comes from the trade monopoly, which advantages the monopoly-holder's industry by making colonial goods cheaper there than anywhere else.
notes: Pivotal passage: having shown that colonies provide neither military strength nor revenue, Smith argues the only remaining benefit is the trade monopoly. The price advantage mechanism is clear: forced routing through England makes colonial goods cheaper there, giving English manufactures better terms of trade. But this 'advantage' works by suppressing others, not by creating value -- a distinction developed in 4.7.105. Cross-references the enumeration system from 4.7.62-65.

refashioned: This advantage, however, will perhaps be found to be relative rather than absolute -- giving superiority to the country that enjoys it by depressing the industry and output of other countries, rather than by raising its own above what they would naturally reach under free trade.
elegant: This advantage is relative rather than absolute: it works by depressing other countries' industry, not by raising the monopoly-holder's above its natural free-trade level.
summary: The monopoly provides only a relative advantage, achieved by depressing competitors rather than genuinely raising the monopoly-holder's industry above its free-trade potential.
distilled: The colonial trade monopoly provides only a relative advantage gained by harming others, not an absolute advantage that raises the monopolist's own output.
notes: Critical distinction between relative and absolute advantage. A relative advantage that comes from depressing others is zero-sum or negative-sum -- contrasted with an absolute advantage that represents genuine improvement. This insight is foundational to Smith's case against mercantilism: the system achieves apparent superiority only by making others worse off, not by making yourself genuinely better off. Cross-references 4.7.106 for the detailed tobacco example.

refashioned:
The tobacco of Maryland and Virginia, for example, certainly comes cheaper to England than to France, thanks to England's monopoly -- and England commonly sells a considerable portion to France. But had France and all other European countries always been allowed free trade with Maryland and Virginia, colonial tobacco might by now have become cheaper than it actually is, not only for all those other countries but for England as well.

With a market so much more extensive than what the monopoly currently provides, tobacco production would probably have expanded enough to reduce plantation profits to their natural level -- roughly equal to corn plantation profits, which they supposedly still exceed. The price of tobacco might well have fallen somewhat below its current level. An equal quantity of English or other countries' goods might have purchased more tobacco in Maryland and Virginia, and therefore sold there at a better price.

Insofar as tobacco's cheapness and abundance could increase enjoyments or expand industry, free trade would probably have produced both effects to a greater degree than the current system. England would not have had any advantage over other countries in this case -- she might have bought tobacco somewhat cheaper and sold her goods somewhat dearer, but no more so than any other country could have done. She might have gained an absolute advantage but would certainly have lost a relative one.
elegant: England's tobacco monopoly makes colonial tobacco cheaper for England than France. But under free trade, tobacco might be cheaper still for everyone -- including England. A much larger market would have expanded production until profits fell to normal levels, lowering prices further. England would have bought cheaper tobacco and sold dearer goods -- but so would every other country. She would have gained an absolute advantage while losing her relative one.
summary: England's tobacco monopoly gives her cheaper tobacco than rivals get. But under free trade, expanded production would likely have made tobacco cheaper for everyone, including England. She would have gained in absolute terms while losing her relative advantage over competitors.
distilled: Free trade in tobacco would likely have made it cheaper for everyone including England, providing a greater absolute benefit while eliminating England's relative advantage from monopoly.
notes: The tobacco case study concretely illustrates the relative vs. absolute advantage distinction. Under monopoly: England gets cheap tobacco relative to France. Under free trade: everyone gets even cheaper tobacco -- England included. The monopoly sacrifices absolute welfare for relative positioning. This is a devastating argument against protectionism: you harm yourself in absolute terms to maintain an artificial edge over competitors. The profit-normalization mechanism (expanded markets drive profits to natural levels) is a key Smithian concept.

refashioned: In order to obtain this relative advantage in the colony trade -- in order to execute the invidious and malignant project of excluding other nations from any share of it -- there are strong reasons to believe that England has not only sacrificed part of the absolute advantage she might have derived from the trade, but has also subjected herself to both an absolute and a relative disadvantage in almost every other branch of trade.
elegant: To gain this relative advantage -- to execute the malignant project of excluding other nations from colonial trade -- England has probably sacrificed not only absolute gains from the colony trade itself, but subjected herself to absolute and relative disadvantages in nearly every other branch of trade.
summary: England's pursuit of relative advantage through colonial trade monopoly has likely cost her absolute gains from that trade and created disadvantages in nearly every other branch of commerce.
distilled: England's colonial monopoly sacrificed absolute gains from colonial trade and created disadvantages across nearly all other branches of commerce.
notes: 'Invidious and malignant project' -- some of Smith's strongest language against monopoly policy. The argument is that monopoly does not merely sacrifice absolute advantage in the colonial trade (as shown in 4.7.106) but actively damages all other trades. This broadens the indictment from the colonial sector to the entire economy. Cross-references 4.7.108-110 for the detailed mechanism.

refashioned:
When the Navigation Act gave England a monopoly of the colony trade, the foreign capital previously employed in it was necessarily withdrawn. English capital, which had previously handled only part of the trade, now had to carry on the whole. The capital that had supplied colonies with only some of their European goods now had to supply them with everything -- but it could not do so, and the goods it did supply were necessarily sold at very high prices. The capital that had previously purchased only part of the colonial surplus now had to buy the whole -- but it could not buy the whole at anything near the old price, so whatever it did buy, it bought very cheaply.

In this situation -- where the merchant sold very dear and bought very cheap -- profits were necessarily very great, far above the ordinary level. This exceptionally high profit inevitably drew capital away from other branches of trade. But as this shift gradually increased competition in the colony trade, it diminished competition in all other trades. As it gradually lowered colony trade profits, it raised profits in all other branches, until all profits settled at a new, higher general level than before.
elegant: When the Navigation Act monopolized colonial trade, foreign capital withdrew and English capital had to handle everything alone. It could not supply all colonial needs, so goods sold dear; it could not buy all colonial surplus, so it bought cheap. This created abnormally high profits that drew capital from other trades. As capital flowed into the colony trade, competition decreased in other trades, raising their profit rates too -- until all profits settled at a new, universally higher level.
summary: The Navigation Act's monopoly forced English capital alone to handle all colonial trade, creating abnormally high profits that drew capital from other sectors. This reduced competition economy-wide, raising the general profit rate above its natural level.
distilled: The colonial trade monopoly created abnormally high profits that drew capital from other sectors, raising the general rate of profit across the entire British economy.
notes: Key mechanism: monopoly creates super-profits in one sector that draw capital from all others, raising the economy-wide profit rate. This is a general equilibrium argument -- distortion in one market propagates to all markets through capital reallocation. The Navigation Act (1651/1660) is identified as the instrument. The dynamic process (gradual capital flow, gradual profit equalization) shows sophisticated understanding of adjustment mechanisms. Cross-references 2.4 on natural profit rates and capital allocation.

refashioned:
This double effect -- drawing capital from all other trades and raising the rate of profit somewhat higher than it would otherwise have been across all trades -- was not only produced by the monopoly when it was first established but has continued to be produced by it ever since.

First, the monopoly has been continually drawing capital from all other trades into the colonial trade.
elegant: The monopoly's double effect -- draining capital from other trades and elevating profit rates economy-wide -- was not a one-time event at the monopoly's establishment but has continued operating ever since. The monopoly continually draws capital away from all other trades.
summary: The monopoly's capital-draining and profit-inflating effects are not temporary but ongoing, continuously redirecting capital from other trades into colonial commerce.
distilled: The colonial monopoly continuously drains capital from other trades and inflates profit rates economy-wide, not merely at its establishment but perpetually.
notes: Important clarification: the distortionary effects of monopoly are not transitional adjustments but permanent features. As long as the monopoly exists, it continues pulling capital toward the colonial trade and away from other sectors. This counters any argument that the initial disruption would naturally correct itself over time. Sets up the detailed analysis of each effect in 4.7.110-114.

refashioned:
Though Great Britain's wealth has increased greatly since the Navigation Act, it has not increased in the same proportion as colonial wealth. But a country's foreign trade naturally grows in proportion to its wealth, and its surplus produce in proportion to its total output. Since Great Britain monopolized virtually all of what might be called the colonies' foreign trade, while her own capital had not grown at the same pace as that trade, she could not carry it on without continually withdrawing capital from other sectors and withholding from them a great deal more that would otherwise have gone their way.

Since the Navigation Act, accordingly, the colony trade has continually expanded while many other branches of foreign trade -- particularly trade with Europe -- have been continually shrinking. British manufactures for export, instead of being adapted to the nearby European market or the more distant Mediterranean one, have mostly been redirected to the still more distant colonial market -- the market where Britain has a monopoly, rather than the one where she faces many competitors.

The causes of decline in other branches of foreign trade, which writers like Sir Matthew Decker have attributed to excessive taxation, high labor costs, or increasing luxury, can all be found in the overgrowth of the colony trade. Britain's mercantile capital, though very large, is not infinite. Though it has grown greatly since the Navigation Act, it has not grown in the same proportion as the colony trade. That trade could not possibly have been carried on without drawing capital from other branches, nor without some decay in those other branches.
elegant: Britain's wealth has grown since the Navigation Act but not as fast as colonial wealth. Since Britain monopolized virtually all colonial foreign trade while her capital grew more slowly, she could only expand colonial commerce by draining capital from other sectors. The colony trade has continually expanded while trade with Europe and the Mediterranean has decayed. British manufactures have been redirected from nearby competitive markets to the distant monopoly market. The causes others attribute to decline in European trade -- excessive taxation, high wages, luxury -- all trace to the overgrowth of the colony trade draining capital from finite British mercantile resources.
summary: Britain's colonial trade has grown faster than her capital, forcing continuous diversion of resources from European and Mediterranean trade to the colonial monopoly market. The decay of other foreign trade branches attributed to taxes and wages actually stems from this capital drain.
distilled: The colonial trade monopoly drained capital from Britain's European and Mediterranean commerce, causing the decay that others wrongly attribute to high taxes, wages, or luxury.
notes: Smith reattributes the decline of British European trade from conventional explanations (taxes, wages, luxury) to the structural distortion of monopoly. Sir Matthew Decker (1679-1749) was a prominent economic writer. The key insight is that finite capital forced a trade-off: colonial expansion came at the direct expense of other trade branches. The shift from competitive markets (Europe) to monopoly markets (colonies) reduced British commercial dynamism. Cross-references 4.7.108 on the capital-draining mechanism.

refashioned: It must be observed that England was already a great trading country, with very large and growing mercantile capital, not only before the Navigation Act established the colonial trade monopoly, but before that trade was even significant. During the Dutch war under Cromwell, England's navy was superior to Holland's. In the war that broke out early in Charles II's reign, it was at least equal -- perhaps superior -- to the combined navies of France and Holland. This naval superiority would scarcely appear greater today, at least if the Dutch navy were to bear the same proportion to Dutch commerce now that it did then.
elegant: England was already a great trading nation with large and growing mercantile capital before the Navigation Act or the colony trade became significant. Under Cromwell, her navy surpassed Holland's; under Charles II, it matched or exceeded the combined navies of France and Holland. Such naval supremacy would scarcely be greater today in proportion to trade.
summary: England was already a major trading power with a navy rivaling Holland and France before the Navigation Act or the colony trade became significant, proving her commercial strength predated the monopoly.
distilled: England's commercial greatness and naval supremacy predated both the Navigation Act and the colony trade, disproving claims that the monopoly created them.
notes: Historical evidence against the claim that the colony trade created British commercial power. England's naval supremacy under Cromwell and Charles II predates any significant colonial trade. This undermines the mercantilist argument that colonial monopoly was responsible for British greatness. The Dutch comparison is pointed -- Holland's commercial success without equivalent colonial monopoly is implicitly noted.

refashioned: This great naval power could not have been produced by the Navigation Act in either of those wars. During the first war, the Act had only just been conceived. By the outbreak of the second, it had been fully enacted, but no part of it could yet have had any considerable effect -- least of all the provision establishing exclusive colonial trade. Both the colonies and their trade were insignificant then compared to what they are now. Jamaica was an unhealthy wilderness, barely inhabited and less cultivated. New York and New Jersey were still in Dutch possession, and half of Saint Kitts belonged to the French.
elegant: The Navigation Act could not have produced England's naval power in either war. In the first, the Act had barely been conceived; in the second, though enacted, it had not had time to take effect. Both the colonies and their trade were then insignificant. Jamaica was an unhealthy wilderness, New York and New Jersey were Dutch, and half of Saint Kitts was French.
summary: The Navigation Act could not have caused England's early naval supremacy because the Act was too new to have taken effect, and the colonies themselves were insignificant -- Jamaica was a wilderness, and key territories were still Dutch and French.
distilled: England's naval power predated any possible effect of the Navigation Act, since the colonies were too small and the Act too recent to have mattered.
notes: Detailed historical refutation of the claim that colonial monopoly built British naval power. The chronological argument is precise: the Act was enacted in 1651/1660, and the relevant wars were 1652-54 and 1665-67 -- far too soon for colonial trade effects. The geographical details (Dutch New York, French Saint Kitts, uninhabited Jamaica) emphasize how insignificant the colonies were at the time. Cross-references 4.7.111.

refashioned:
Antigua, the two Carolinas, Pennsylvania, Georgia, and Nova Scotia had not yet been settled. Virginia, Maryland, and New England had been planted, and though they were thriving colonies, there was probably not a single person in Europe or America at that time who foresaw or even suspected the rapid progress they would later make in wealth, population, and development. Barbados, in short, was the only British colony of any significance whose condition then resembled its present state.

The colonial trade, of which England enjoyed only a part for some time after the Navigation Act -- since the Act was not strictly enforced for several years -- could not at that time have caused England's great trade or the naval power it supported.
elegant: Antigua, the Carolinas, Pennsylvania, Georgia, and Nova Scotia were not yet settled. Virginia, Maryland, and New England, though thriving, had not yet given any hint of their future progress. Only Barbados resembled its present condition. The colonial trade -- which England only partly controlled even after the Navigation Act, since enforcement lagged for years -- could not have caused England's trade or naval power.
summary: Most major British colonies were either unsettled or small when England's commercial greatness was already established. Only Barbados was significant, and even the Navigation Act was not strictly enforced for years after passage.
distilled: Most British colonies barely existed when England's commercial power was already established, proving the colony trade could not have been its cause.
notes: Completes the historical refutation. The list of unplanted colonies (Antigua, Carolinas, Pennsylvania, Georgia, Nova Scotia) drives home how minimal the colonial footprint was. The lax enforcement of the Navigation Act further weakens any causal link. Smith's conclusion is that European trade, not colonial trade, built England's commercial power. Cross-references 4.7.111-112.

refashioned: The trade that supported England's great naval power at that time was her European trade, and particularly the Mediterranean trade. But the share Great Britain currently holds of that trade could not support any such great naval power. Had the growing colony trade been left open to all nations, whatever share might have fallen to Britain -- and a very considerable share probably would have -- would all have been an addition to the great European trade she already possessed. Because of the monopoly, the expansion of colonial trade has not so much added to Britain's pre-existing trade as completely changed its direction.
elegant: The trade that built England's naval power was European, especially Mediterranean. Britain's current share of that trade could not sustain such power. Had colonial trade been left open, Britain's share of it would have supplemented her existing European trade. Instead, the monopoly did not add to her trade but redirected it -- replacing European commerce with colonial commerce.
summary: England's naval power was built on European trade, not colonial. The monopoly redirected rather than expanded British commerce, replacing European trade with colonial trade instead of adding to it.
distilled: The colonial monopoly did not add to Britain's European trade base but merely redirected it, replacing European commerce with colonial commerce.
notes: Crucial distinction: the monopoly caused a redirection, not an expansion, of British trade. Under free trade, the colony trade would have been purely additive to existing European commerce. Under monopoly, it substituted for European trade. This is a net loss because the European trade was older, more established, and had faster returns. The Mediterranean trade reference connects to Britain's historical commercial foundation. Cross-references 4.7.110 on the decay of European trade.

refashioned:
Second, the monopoly has necessarily kept the rate of profit in all branches of British trade higher than it would have been if all nations had been allowed free trade with the British colonies.

The monopoly drew a larger proportion of British capital into the colony trade than would naturally have gone there, while expelling all foreign capital. This reduced the total capital employed in colonial trade below what it would have been under free trade. By reducing capital competition in that branch, it raised profits there. By also reducing British capital competition in all other branches, it raised British profits everywhere. Whatever the state of British mercantile capital at any point since the Navigation Act, the monopoly must have kept the ordinary rate of British profit higher than it otherwise would have been -- in colonial trade and in all other trades alike. If the ordinary rate of British profit has fallen considerably since the Navigation Act, as it certainly has, it must have fallen even lower without the monopoly keeping it artificially elevated.
elegant: Second, the monopoly necessarily raised profit rates across all British trade. By drawing excess British capital into colonial trade while excluding foreign capital, it reduced total capital in that trade below free-trade levels, raising profits there. By simultaneously reducing British capital in other trades, it raised profits everywhere else too. Whatever the state of British capital at any point, the monopoly must have kept profits artificially above their natural level across the entire economy. Even the considerable fall in British profit rates since the Navigation Act would have been even greater without the monopoly propping them up.
summary: The colonial monopoly raised profit rates across all British trade by reducing capital competition in the colony trade (through foreign exclusion) and in all other trades (through capital diversion), keeping profits artificially above their natural level.
distilled: The colonial monopoly artificially elevated British profit rates economy-wide by reducing capital competition in both colonial and non-colonial trades.
notes: Second major effect of monopoly: economy-wide profit inflation. The mechanism works through capital allocation -- monopoly misallocates capital, reducing competition in every sector. The observation that profit rates fell despite the monopoly propping them up suggests how much lower they would naturally have gone. Higher profit rates are presented as harmful (contrary to mercantilist assumptions), because they represent inefficiency and misallocation. Cross-references 4.7.108-109 on capital diversion and 2.4 on natural profit rates.

refashioned:
Whatever raises the ordinary rate of profit above its natural level in any country necessarily subjects that country to both an absolute and a relative disadvantage in every branch of trade where it does not hold a monopoly.

It subjects her to an absolute disadvantage because, in such trades, her merchants cannot earn the higher profits without selling dearer than they otherwise would -- both the foreign goods they import and the domestic goods they export. The country must buy dearer and sell dearer, buy less and sell less, enjoy less and produce less than she otherwise would.
elegant: Any artificial elevation of the profit rate creates absolute and relative disadvantages in all non-monopoly trades. The absolute disadvantage: merchants must charge higher prices on both imports and exports to earn inflated profits. The country buys dearer, sells dearer, buys less, sells less, enjoys less, and produces less than it otherwise would.
