summary: Artificially high profit rates create an absolute disadvantage in non-monopoly trades by forcing higher prices on both imports and exports, reducing the quantity of goods a country can buy, sell, enjoy, and produce.
distilled: Artificially inflated profit rates create an absolute disadvantage by raising prices on all non-monopoly trade, reducing a country's purchasing power and output.
notes: Explains why inflated profits are harmful -- they function like a tax on all non-monopoly commerce. The chain of consequences (buy dearer, sell dearer, buy less, sell less, enjoy less, produce less) systematically traces the damage. This contradicts the intuition that higher profits are always good for the economy. Cross-references 4.7.115 on how monopoly inflates profits economy-wide.

refashioned: It subjects her to a relative disadvantage because, in such branches of trade, it sets other countries -- which are not burdened by the same absolute disadvantage -- either further above her or less far below her than they otherwise would be. It enables other countries to both enjoy more and produce more in proportion to what she enjoys and produces. It makes their superiority greater, or their inferiority less, than it would otherwise be. By raising the price of her produce above its natural level, it enables foreign merchants to undersell her in foreign markets, gradually pushing her out of almost every branch of trade in which she does not hold a monopoly.
elegant: The relative disadvantage: countries not burdened by inflated profits can produce and trade more efficiently in proportion. Their superiority grows or their inferiority shrinks. Britain's artificially high prices enable foreign merchants to undersell her in foreign markets, gradually pushing her out of every trade where she lacks a monopoly.
summary: The relative disadvantage of inflated profits is that unburdened competitors can undersell the monopoly-holding country in all non-monopoly foreign markets, gradually displacing her from those trades.
distilled: Artificially inflated profits enable foreign competitors to undersell the monopoly-holding country in every market where it lacks a monopoly, creating a growing relative disadvantage.
notes: The relative disadvantage compounds the absolute one: not only does the monopoly-holder produce and trade less, but competitors gain ground precisely because of her artificial cost inflation. This creates a vicious cycle -- the more the monopoly raises domestic profits, the less competitive the country becomes abroad. The phrase 'justle her out' captures the gradual displacement from competitive markets. Cross-references 4.7.116 on absolute disadvantage.

refashioned: Our merchants frequently complain that high British wages cause their manufactures to be undersold in foreign markets, but they say nothing about high profits. They complain about the extravagant earnings of other people while remaining silent about their own. Yet the high profits of British capital may contribute as much, and in some cases perhaps more, to raising the price of British manufactures as the high wages of British labor.
elegant: Merchants blame high British wages for being undersold abroad but say nothing about high profits. They complain of others' extravagant earnings while silent about their own. Yet high profits may raise British manufacturing costs as much as -- or more than -- high wages.
summary: Merchants blame high wages for their lack of competitiveness abroad while ignoring high profits, which may contribute equally or more to inflated manufacturing costs.
distilled: Merchants blame wages for high manufacturing costs while ignoring their own high profits, which may contribute equally or more to the problem.
notes: Classic Smithian critique of merchant self-serving rhetoric. The asymmetry is pointed: wages are 'extravagant' when earned by others, but profits are never mentioned. Smith identifies a systematic bias in economic discourse where capital-owners frame labor costs as the problem while their own returns escape scrutiny. This anticipates modern debates about the relative contribution of wages vs. profits to cost competitiveness. Cross-references 1.9-11 on wages, profits, and rent.

refashioned:
It is in this way that British capital has been partly drawn and partly driven from most branches of trade in which Britain does not hold a monopoly -- particularly from the European trade and that of the Mediterranean countries.

It has been partly drawn from these trades by the attraction of superior profits in the colony trade, as that trade has continually expanded and the capital carrying it on has been continually insufficient for the next year's needs.
elegant: British capital has been both drawn and driven from most non-monopoly trades, especially European and Mediterranean commerce. It has been drawn by the lure of superior profits in the ever-expanding colony trade, whose growing demands perpetually outstrip the capital available.
summary: British capital has been pulled from European and Mediterranean trade by the lure of higher colonial profits, with the colony trade's growth perpetually outstripping available capital.
distilled: British capital has been attracted away from European trade by the perpetually higher profits of the ever-expanding colonial trade.
notes: Distinguishes two forces: capital is 'drawn' (attracted by higher colonial profits) and 'driven' (pushed out of other trades by competitive disadvantage). The perpetual insufficiency of capital for the colony trade creates a continuous pull mechanism -- the trade always needs more capital than it has, maintaining above-normal returns that drain other sectors. Cross-references 4.7.108-110.

refashioned:
It has also been partly driven from these trades by the competitive advantage that Britain's high profit rate gives to other countries in every branch where Britain lacks a monopoly.

Just as the monopoly drew British capital from other trades into the colony trade, it also forced foreign capital into those other trades -- capital that would never have entered them had it not been expelled from the colony trade. In those other branches, the monopoly diminished the competition of British capital and thereby raised British profit rates. Conversely, it increased the competition of foreign capital and lowered foreign profit rates. In both ways, the monopoly subjected Great Britain to a relative disadvantage in all other trades.
elegant: British capital has also been driven from non-monopoly trades because high British profit rates give foreign competitors an advantage. The monopoly simultaneously pushed foreign capital out of colonial trade and into other branches, where it increased foreign competition while British competition decreased. British profits rose while foreign profits fell in these sectors -- creating a double relative disadvantage for Britain in all non-monopoly commerce.
summary: The monopoly drove British capital from non-monopoly trades by inflating domestic costs, while simultaneously pushing displaced foreign capital into those same trades, creating a double relative disadvantage -- less British and more foreign competition in every non-colonial sector.
distilled: The colonial monopoly doubly disadvantaged Britain in non-colonial trades by withdrawing British capital and simultaneously pushing foreign capital into those sectors.
notes: Elegant analysis of the two-sided displacement effect: monopoly not only draws British capital away from competitive trades but pushes foreign capital into them. The result is a double blow -- less British competition and more foreign competition in every non-monopoly sector. This explains why the colonial monopoly systematically undermined British competitiveness in European markets. The symmetry of the argument is characteristic of Smith's analytical style.

refashioned: It may perhaps be argued that the colony trade is more advantageous to Great Britain than any other, and that the monopoly, by forcing a larger proportion of British capital into this trade than would naturally have gone there, has directed capital toward the most advantageous possible employment.
elegant: It might be argued that the colony trade is Britain's most advantageous trade, and that the monopoly helpfully directed more capital toward this best possible employment than the market would have.
summary: The counterargument is that colonial trade is Britain's most advantageous trade, so the monopoly that directs extra capital there is actually beneficial.
distilled: The counterargument claims the monopoly is beneficial because it directs capital toward Britain's most advantageous trade.
notes: Smith introduces the strongest possible defense of the monopoly in order to refute it. This is a steelman argument: even if the colony trade is the best trade, forcing capital there is still harmful. The refutation follows in 4.7.122-126, based on the frequency-of-returns analysis. A good example of Smith's dialectical method -- presenting and then demolishing opposing arguments.

refashioned:
The most advantageous employment of any capital to the country where it belongs is that which maintains the greatest quantity of productive labor there and increases the annual produce of its land and labor the most. But the quantity of productive labor that any capital employed in foreign trade can maintain is exactly proportional to the frequency of its returns, as was shown in the second book.

A capital of a thousand pounds employed in foreign trade with annual returns can maintain as much productive labor as a thousand pounds can support for a year. If the returns come twice or three times a year, it can maintain productive labor equivalent to two or three thousand pounds for a year. Foreign trade with a neighboring country is therefore generally more advantageous than trade with a distant one, because returns are more frequent. Similarly, as also shown in the second book, a direct foreign trade is generally more advantageous than a roundabout one.
elegant: The most advantageous use of capital is that which maintains the most productive labor and maximizes annual output. In foreign trade, the productive labor a capital can support is exactly proportional to how frequently it returns. A thousand pounds returning annually supports as much labor as a thousand pounds for a year; returning twice yearly, it supports the equivalent of two thousand. Therefore, trade with nearby countries (faster returns) is more advantageous than distant trade, and direct trade is better than roundabout trade.
summary: Capital's value to the domestic economy depends on how frequently it returns -- trade with nearby countries returns faster and therefore supports more productive labor than distant trade, and direct trade surpasses roundabout trade.
distilled: Capital's domestic benefit depends on the frequency of its returns, making trade with nearby countries more valuable than distant trade and direct trade more valuable than roundabout trade.
notes: Reintroduces the frequency-of-returns principle from Book 2 as the key metric for evaluating trade. This is the analytical tool Smith uses to demolish the claim that colonial trade is the most advantageous. The turnover rate of capital determines how much domestic labor it can employ -- a fundamental insight. The nearby vs. distant and direct vs. roundabout distinctions set up the critique in 4.7.123-126. Cross-references 2.5 on capital turnover and productive labor.

refashioned: But the monopoly of the colony trade, insofar as it has affected the employment of British capital, has in all cases forced some of it from foreign trade with neighboring countries to trade with more distant ones, and in many cases from direct foreign trade to roundabout trade.
elegant: The colonial trade monopoly has in all cases forced British capital from nearby to distant trade, and in many cases from direct to roundabout trade -- the opposite of what capital returns analysis prescribes.
summary: The monopoly has forced British capital from the more advantageous nearby and direct foreign trades into the less advantageous distant and roundabout colonial trade.
distilled: The colonial monopoly systematically redirected British capital from faster-returning nearby trade to slower-returning distant and roundabout colonial trade.
notes: Applies the frequency-of-returns principle to the colonial monopoly. The monopoly does exactly the opposite of what optimal capital allocation requires: it moves capital from fast-returning nearby trade to slow-returning distant trade, and from direct trade to roundabout trade. This concise paragraph is the hinge of the entire argument. Cross-references 4.7.122 on returns frequency and 4.7.124-126 for detailed examples.

refashioned:
First, the monopoly has in all cases forced some British capital from foreign trade with nearby countries to trade with more distant ones.

It has forced capital from the European and Mediterranean trade to the much more distant trade with America and the West Indies, where returns are necessarily less frequent -- not only because of the greater distance but because of the particular circumstances of those countries. New colonies, as already noted, are always short of capital. Their capital is always much less than what they could profitably employ in developing their land. They therefore have a constant demand for more capital than they possess, and to make up the shortfall, they try to borrow as much as they can from the mother country -- to whom they are consequently always in debt.
elegant: First, the monopoly forced British capital from nearby European and Mediterranean trade to distant American and West Indian trade, where returns are less frequent due to both greater distance and colonial circumstances. New colonies are perpetually short of capital -- their investment opportunities far exceed their resources -- so they constantly borrow from the mother country, remaining perpetually in its debt.
summary: The monopoly redirected British capital from the fast-returning European trade to slow-returning colonial trade, where distance and chronic colonial capital shortages made returns less frequent and colonies perpetually indebted to the mother country.
distilled: The monopoly shifted British capital from fast-returning European trade to slow-returning colonial trade, where chronic capital shortages kept the colonies perpetually indebted.
notes: Details the first distortion: geographic redirection. Returns are slower from colonial trade for two reasons: (1) sheer distance, and (2) colonies' chronic capital shortage means they operate on credit, further delaying returns. The perpetual indebtedness of colonies to the mother country is an important structural feature -- it means capital deployed in colonial trade is effectively locked up for long periods. Cross-references 4.7.25-35 on colonial capital scarcity and 4.7.122-123 on returns frequency.

refashioned: The most common way the colonies accumulate this debt is not by borrowing from wealthy people in the mother country on formal bonds -- though they sometimes do this too -- but by running up arrears with their trade correspondents who supply them with European goods, to whatever extent those correspondents will allow. Their annual payments frequently amount to no more than a third, and sometimes an even smaller fraction, of what they owe. The entire capital that correspondents advance to them is therefore seldom returned to Britain in less than three years, and sometimes not in less than four or five.
elegant: Colonies accumulate debt mainly not through formal bonds but by running up arrears with their trade suppliers, who allow them extended credit. Annual payments often cover only a third or less of what is owed. The capital advanced by British correspondents is seldom fully returned in less than three years, sometimes taking four or five.
summary: Colonial debt accumulates primarily through trade credit with suppliers rather than formal bonds, with annual payments covering only a fraction of what is owed and full capital return taking three to five years.
distilled: Colonial trade credit extends return times to three to five years, as colonies' annual payments cover only a fraction of their accumulated supplier debts.
notes: Provides concrete data on how slow colonial trade returns actually are: 3-5 years for full capital turnover. Compare this to European trade returns of roughly one year. The trade credit mechanism (running up arrears with correspondents) is the practical channel through which colonial capital scarcity delays returns. This is not borrowing in the formal sense but an informal credit relationship embedded in commercial practice. Cross-references 4.7.124 on colonial capital scarcity.

refashioned:
A British capital of a thousand pounds, for example, that returns to Great Britain only once every five years, can keep in constant employment only one-fifth of the British productive labor it could maintain if it returned annually. Instead of supporting a thousand pounds' worth of labor for a year, it can support only two hundred pounds' worth.

The planter, through the high prices he pays for European goods, through interest on long-dated bills, and through commissions on renewing shorter-dated ones, no doubt makes up -- and probably more than makes up -- for all the losses his correspondent suffers from this delay. But though he compensates his correspondent, he cannot compensate Great Britain. In a trade with very distant returns, the merchant's profit may be as great as or greater than in one with frequent returns, but the advantage to the country where he resides -- the quantity of productive labor constantly maintained there, the annual output of its land and labor -- must always be much less.

That the returns of the American trade, and still more those of the West Indian trade, are generally not only more distant but more irregular and uncertain than those of any European or Mediterranean trade, I imagine everyone with experience of these different branches will readily agree.
elegant: Capital returning once in five years employs only one-fifth the productive labor it could with annual returns -- a thousand pounds supports only two hundred pounds' worth of labor. The colonial planter may compensate his British correspondent through high prices, interest, and commissions, but he cannot compensate Great Britain. The merchant's profit may be as high in distant as in nearby trade, but the country's benefit -- productive labor maintained and annual output -- must always be less. The returns from American trade, and still more from West Indian trade, are notoriously more distant, irregular, and uncertain than European or Mediterranean returns.
summary: Capital invested in the slow-returning colonial trade supports far less domestic productive labor than the same capital would in fast-returning European trade. Though individual merchants may profit equally from distant trade, the national economy loses because less labor is maintained.
distilled: Slow colonial trade returns mean the same capital supports far less domestic productive labor than it would in faster-returning European trade, even if individual merchant profits are comparable.
notes: Central quantitative insight: capital returning once in five years supports only 20% of the productive labor that annually returning capital supports. The distinction between merchant profit (may be equal) and national benefit (definitely less) is critical -- profitable for the merchant does not mean advantageous for the country. This merchant-vs-nation divergence is a recurring Smithian theme. The high prices, interest, and commissions that compensate merchants represent a transfer from colonies to merchants, not a benefit to Britain. Cross-references 2.5 on capital turnover and productive labor, and 4.7.122-124 on returns frequency.

refashioned:
Second, the monopoly of the colony trade has in many cases forced some British capital from direct foreign trade into roundabout trade.

Among the enumerated commodities that can be sent only to Great Britain, several are produced in quantities that far exceed British consumption, so a portion must be re-exported to other countries. This necessarily forces some British capital into roundabout foreign trade. Maryland and Virginia, for example, annually send Great Britain upward of ninety-six thousand hogsheads of tobacco, while British consumption is said to be no more than fourteen thousand. The remaining eighty-two thousand hogsheads must therefore be re-exported to France, Holland, and the countries around the Baltic and Mediterranean seas.
elegant: Second, the monopoly has forced British capital from direct into roundabout trade. Many enumerated commodities vastly exceed British consumption and must be re-exported. Maryland and Virginia send 96,000 hogsheads of tobacco to Britain annually, but British consumption is only 14,000 -- so 82,000 hogsheads must be re-exported to France, Holland, and Baltic and Mediterranean markets.
summary: The monopoly forces Britain into roundabout trade because many enumerated commodities, especially tobacco, vastly exceed domestic consumption. Of 96,000 hogsheads received annually, 82,000 must be re-exported.
distilled: The monopoly forces Britain into inefficient roundabout trade because enumerated goods like tobacco vastly exceed domestic consumption and must be re-exported.
notes: The tobacco statistics are striking: Britain consumes only 15% of the tobacco it is forced to import (14,000 of 96,000 hogsheads). The remaining 85% must be re-exported, converting what could be direct colony-to-foreign-country trade into a roundabout colony-to-Britain-to-foreign-country route. This is pure waste of capital turnover time -- goods pass through Britain unnecessarily, adding to transit time and reducing the frequency of returns. Cross-references 4.7.123 on roundabout vs. direct trade.

refashioned:
The portion of British capital that brings these eighty-two thousand hogsheads to Great Britain, re-exports them to other countries, and brings back goods or money in return, is employed in a roundabout foreign trade. It is necessarily forced into this employment in order to dispose of this enormous surplus.

To estimate how many years it takes for this entire capital to return to Britain, we must add the return time from the secondary destination to the already lengthy return time from America. If in the direct American trade the full capital frequently does not return in less than three or four years, the full capital employed in this roundabout trade is unlikely to return in less than four or five years.
elegant: The capital that imports 82,000 hogsheads to Britain, re-exports them, and brings back returns is trapped in roundabout trade. To calculate total return time, add the secondary country's return delay to the already slow American returns. If direct American returns take three to four years, roundabout returns take four to five.
summary: Capital used to import surplus tobacco into Britain, re-export it, and collect returns is trapped in roundabout trade with return times of four to five years, even longer than the already slow three to four years of direct American trade.
distilled: Roundabout colonial trade extends already slow capital returns from three-four years to four-five years by adding the delay of re-exporting surplus goods through Britain.
notes: Quantifies the cost of roundabout trade: adding one to two years onto already slow 3-4 year returns. The cumulative effect is that capital can be tied up for half a decade -- compared to roughly annual returns in European trade. This means the same capital supports approximately one-fifth the productive labor it would in European trade. The forced re-export of 82,000 hogsheads is pure deadweight inefficiency caused by the enumeration system. Cross-references 4.7.125-126 on colonial return times.

refashioned:
If direct colonial trade can keep in constant employment only a third or fourth of the domestic productive labor that annually returning capital could maintain, roundabout trade can keep in employment only a fourth or fifth. At some outports, credit is commonly given to the foreign buyers of re-exported tobacco. At the port of London, however, tobacco is normally sold for ready money -- the rule is 'weigh and pay.' At London, therefore, the final returns of the roundabout trade are delayed beyond the American return only by the time the goods sit unsold in the warehouse -- though they may sometimes sit there long enough.

Had the colonies not been confined to the British market for their tobacco, very little more would probably have come to Britain than what was needed for domestic consumption.
elegant: If direct colonial trade employs only a third or fourth of the labor that annually returning capital supports, roundabout trade employs only a fourth or fifth. At London, re-exported tobacco sells for cash ('weigh and pay'), so the extra delay is only warehouse storage time -- though that can be long. At outports, trade credit extends delays further. Without the monopoly, Britain would probably have imported only enough tobacco for her own consumption.
summary: Roundabout colonial trade supports only a fourth or fifth of the productive labor that European trade could sustain with the same capital. Without the monopoly forcing all tobacco through Britain, she would likely have imported only what she consumed domestically.
distilled: Roundabout colonial trade employs only a fraction of the productive labor that the same capital would support in European trade, and without monopoly compulsion, Britain would import only her own tobacco consumption.
notes: The 'weigh and pay' rule at London shows that even the most efficient re-export channel adds delays. The counterfactual is key: without the monopoly, Britain would import 14,000 hogsheads for domestic use rather than 96,000, freeing vast amounts of capital from roundabout trade. The productive labor comparison (a fourth or fifth vs. full employment) quantifies the enormous waste of the monopoly system. Cross-references 4.7.127-128.

refashioned:
The goods that Great Britain currently purchases for her own consumption with the surplus tobacco she re-exports to other countries, she would in that case probably have purchased directly with the produce of her own industry or manufactures. Those manufactures, instead of being almost entirely adapted to one great market as at present, would probably have been fitted to a great number of smaller markets.

Instead of one great roundabout foreign trade, Great Britain would probably have conducted many small direct foreign trades. Because of the faster returns, a fraction of the capital currently employed in the roundabout trade -- perhaps only a third or fourth -- might have been sufficient to conduct all those small direct trades. That smaller capital might have kept in constant employment an equal quantity of British productive labor and equally supported the annual output of British land and labor.

All the purposes of this trade being accomplished by a much smaller capital, there would have been a large surplus available for other uses: to improve lands, increase manufactures, and extend British commerce. Coming into competition with other British capital in all these different employments, it would have reduced the rate of profit across the board, and thereby given Great Britain a competitive superiority over other countries even greater than what she currently enjoys.
elegant: Without the monopoly, Britain would have bought with her own manufactures what she now buys with re-exported tobacco surplus. Her manufactures would have been fitted to many small markets rather than one large one. Many small direct trades would have replaced one great roundabout trade. Because of faster returns, perhaps a third or fourth of the current capital would have sufficed to maintain equal productive labor. The freed capital could have improved land, expanded manufactures, and extended commerce -- reducing profit rates through increased competition and giving Britain an even greater competitive advantage than she currently holds.
summary: Without the monopoly, Britain would have conducted many small direct trades instead of one great roundabout trade. Faster returns would have required far less capital to maintain the same output, freeing surplus capital for domestic improvements that would have given Britain an even greater competitive advantage.
distilled: Replacing the monopoly's roundabout trade with many direct trades would free three-quarters of the capital to improve the domestic economy, giving Britain a greater competitive advantage than the monopoly provides.
notes: The positive counterfactual: what would free trade look like? Many small direct trades replacing one great roundabout trade. The capital savings are enormous -- three-quarters freed for domestic investment. The liberated capital would reduce profit rates through competition (which Smith considers beneficial). The irony is sharp: the monopoly that supposedly strengthens Britain actually prevents her from achieving even greater superiority. Cross-references 4.7.127-129 on roundabout trade inefficiency.

refashioned:
The monopoly of the colony trade has also forced some British capital from all foreign trade into a carrying trade -- and consequently from supporting British industry to supporting partly the industry of the colonies and partly that of other countries.

For example, the goods purchased annually with the surplus eighty-two thousand hogsheads of re-exported tobacco are not all consumed in Great Britain. Part of them -- German and Dutch linen, for instance -- is sent back to the colonies for their consumption. The British capital that first buys the tobacco and then purchases this linen is necessarily withdrawn from supporting British industry and employed entirely in supporting the industry of the colonies and the countries that supply them.
elegant: The monopoly has also forced British capital from foreign trade into a carrying trade -- supporting colonial and foreign industry rather than British. Some goods purchased with re-exported tobacco surplus, like German and Dutch linen, are shipped back to the colonies. The British capital behind this sequence supports colonial consumption and German/Dutch production, not British industry.
summary: The monopoly diverts British capital into carrying trade that supports colonial and foreign industry rather than British industry, as when tobacco surplus is traded for German linen that is then shipped to the colonies.
distilled: The colonial monopoly forces British capital into carrying trade that supports foreign and colonial industry rather than domestic British industry.
notes: Third type of trade distortion: not just nearby-to-distant and direct-to-roundabout, but foreign-trade-to-carrying-trade. The carrying trade is the least beneficial to the home country because it supports no domestic industry at all -- British capital is merely the intermediary between colonial tobacco and German linen, with British labor getting none of the productive employment. The German linen example concretely shows capital flowing: tobacco to Germany, linen to colonies, nothing to British workers. Cross-references 2.5 on the hierarchy of trade types.

refashioned:
The monopoly of the colony trade, moreover, by forcing such a disproportionate share of British capital toward it, seems to have completely upset the natural balance that would otherwise have prevailed among the different branches of British industry. British industry, instead of being adapted to many different markets, has been principally suited to one great market. British commerce, instead of flowing through many small channels, has been taught to run through one great channel.

This has made the entire system of British industry and commerce more precarious and less secure than if output had been directed toward a greater variety of markets. In her present condition, Great Britain resembles one of those unhealthy bodies in which some vital organs are overgrown, making them susceptible to dangerous disorders that rarely afflict bodies in which all parts are properly proportioned. A small blockage in that great blood vessel, which has been artificially swollen beyond its natural size and through which an unnatural proportion of the country's industry and commerce has been forced to circulate, is very likely to produce the most dangerous disorders in the entire body politic.
elegant: By directing a disproportionate share of capital toward colonial trade, the monopoly has destroyed the natural balance among British industries. Instead of many small markets and channels, British commerce has been funneled into one great channel. This makes the entire system precarious and insecure -- like an unhealthy body with overgrown vital organs, susceptible to dangerous disorders. A small blockage in this artificially swollen blood vessel could produce catastrophic consequences for the whole body politic.
summary: The colonial monopoly has concentrated British industry and commerce into a single great channel, destroying the natural diversification that would make the economy resilient. Like a body with overgrown organs, any disruption to this single channel threatens catastrophic consequences.
distilled: The colonial monopoly dangerously concentrated British commerce into a single channel, creating systemic vulnerability where any disruption could prove catastrophic to the entire economy.
notes: Smith's medical metaphor is powerful and prescient: an economy concentrated in a single sector is like a body with hypertrophied organs -- vulnerable to systemic failure from any small shock. This anticipates modern concepts of economic diversification, systemic risk, and 'too big to fail.' The 'natural balance' disrupted by monopoly is Smith's concept of an economy finding its own optimal allocation through market forces. The blood vessel metaphor specifically warns about what would happen if colonial trade were suddenly disrupted -- as was in fact happening with the American Revolution.

refashioned:
The prospect of a rupture with the colonies has accordingly struck the people of Great Britain with more terror than they ever felt from a Spanish Armada or a French invasion. This terror, whether well or ill founded, drove the repeal of the Stamp Act, making it a popular measure at least among the merchants.

In the total exclusion from the colonial market, even if it lasted only a few years, most merchants foresaw a complete halt to their trade; most master manufacturers, the utter ruin of their businesses; and most workers, the end of their employment. A rupture with any continental neighbor, though also likely to interrupt trade and employment for some people, is contemplated without any such general alarm.
elegant: The threat of colonial rupture has terrified the British more than any Spanish Armada or French invasion. This terror drove the Stamp Act's repeal. Merchants foresaw total trade stoppage, manufacturers saw ruin, and workers saw unemployment from even temporary colonial market exclusion. A rupture with any European neighbor, though also disruptive, causes no comparable panic.
summary: The prospect of losing colonial markets terrified Britain more than any military threat, driving the Stamp Act's repeal. This panic demonstrated how dangerously dependent the British economy had become on a single trade channel.
distilled: Britain's greater terror at losing colonial markets than at any military invasion demonstrated the dangerous economic dependence created by the trade monopoly.
notes: Smith's argument comes to life with the American crisis. The Stamp Act repeal (1766) was driven by merchant terror, not principle -- a concrete example of how economic concentration creates political vulnerability. The comparison to the Spanish Armada (1588) and French invasion threats dramatically illustrates the disproportionate fear. The asymmetry (colonial rupture vs. European rupture) perfectly validates the 'overgrown blood vessel' metaphor from 4.7.132. This was written during the actual crisis -- Smith is analyzing events in real time.

refashioned:
When blood circulation is blocked in smaller vessels, it easily redirects into larger ones without causing dangerous disorder. But when it is blocked in the larger vessels, convulsions, apoplexy, or death are the immediate and unavoidable consequences.

If even one of those overgrown manufactures which have been artificially inflated -- whether by bounties or by monopoly of the home and colonial markets -- encounters some small interruption in its activity, it frequently causes a mutiny and disorder alarming to the government and embarrassing even to the legislature. How great, therefore, would be the disorder and confusion that must necessarily follow from a sudden and complete halt to so great a proportion of our principal manufactures?
elegant: Blocked circulation in small vessels causes no harm; blocked circulation in the great vessels brings convulsions, apoplexy, or death. If even one artificially inflated industry encounters a small disruption, it causes alarming mutiny and disorder. How catastrophic, then, would be a sudden complete halt to so great a proportion of Britain's principal manufactures?
summary: Just as blocked circulation in major blood vessels causes death while minor blockages are harmless, disruption to Britain's artificially concentrated industries causes disproportionate social and political upheaval.
distilled: The dangerous concentration of British industry means that any disruption to the colonial trade channel threatens economic convulsion and social upheaval on a catastrophic scale.
notes: Extends the medical metaphor to its conclusion: systemic risk from concentration. The reference to 'mutiny and disorder' from small disruptions in individual artificially inflated industries provides empirical grounding -- Smith likely refers to specific episodes of worker unrest. The rhetorical question at the end drives home the scale of risk from colonial rupture. Cross-references 4.7.132-133 on concentration risk.

refashioned:
Some moderate and gradual relaxation of the laws granting Great Britain exclusive colonial trade, until it is rendered substantially free, seems to be the only remedy that can permanently deliver her from this danger. Only this can enable or even compel her to withdraw capital from this overgrown sector and redirect it, though with less profit, toward other employments. Only by gradually shrinking one branch of industry while gradually expanding all others can the different branches be restored to the natural, healthy, and proper proportion that perfect liberty naturally establishes and that only perfect liberty can maintain.

To open the colony trade all at once to all nations might cause not merely temporary inconvenience but permanent loss to most of those currently engaged in it. The sudden loss of employment even for just the ships that import the eighty-two thousand surplus hogsheads of tobacco might alone be felt severely.

Such are the unfortunate effects of all mercantile system regulations. They not only introduce very dangerous disorders into the body politic, but disorders that are often difficult to remedy without causing, at least temporarily, still greater disorders. In what manner the colony trade ought gradually to be opened -- which restraints should be removed first and which last, and how the natural system of perfect liberty and justice ought gradually to be restored -- we must leave to the wisdom of future statesmen and legislators to determine.
elegant: Only a moderate, gradual opening of colonial trade can save Britain from this danger -- enabling her to withdraw capital from the overgrown sector and redistribute it, restoring the natural balance that only perfect liberty can establish and maintain. Opening trade all at once would cause permanent damage to those currently engaged in it. This is the curse of mercantilist regulation: it creates disorders that are difficult to cure without temporarily causing worse ones. The exact sequence of liberalization -- which restraints to remove first -- must be left to future statesmen.
summary: Only gradual trade liberalization can safely restore Britain's economic balance. Sudden opening would cause severe harm, but the current system creates increasingly dangerous concentration. The proper sequence of liberalization must be determined by future policymakers.
distilled: Only gradual liberalization of colonial trade can safely restore the natural economic balance that monopoly has destroyed, since sudden opening would cause severe disruption.
notes: Smith's practical reform prescription: gradualism, not shock therapy. The recognition that removing bad regulations can itself cause harm is a sophisticated policy insight -- anticipating modern debates about economic transition. 'Perfect liberty naturally establishes' the proper balance -- the invisible hand at work. The admission that Smith himself cannot specify the optimal liberalization sequence shows intellectual humility. The 'disorders difficult to remedy without causing greater disorders' captures the reform dilemma. This passage has been influential in debates about deregulation, trade liberalization, and economic transition (e.g., post-Soviet reforms).

refashioned:
Five different unforeseen and unexpected events have fortunately combined to prevent Great Britain from feeling the full impact of the total exclusion -- now lasting over a year since December 1, 1774 -- from a very important branch of colonial trade: that with the twelve associated provinces of North America.

First, the colonies drained Britain of all goods suited to their market as they prepared for their non-importation agreement. Second, the extraordinary demand from the Spanish treasure fleet has this year drained Germany and northern Europe of many commodities, particularly linen, that normally compete with British manufactures even in the British market. Third, the peace between Russia and Turkey has created extraordinary demand from the Turkish market, which had been poorly supplied while a Russian fleet cruised in the Archipelago. Fourth, demand from northern Europe for British manufactures has been increasing year after year for some time. Fifth, the recent partition and subsequent pacification of Poland has this year added extraordinary demand from that great country to the growing northern European demand.

All except the fourth of these events are transitory and accidental. If exclusion from this important branch of colonial trade continues much longer, it may still cause considerable distress. But since the distress will come on gradually, it will be felt much less severely than if it had come all at once -- and in the meantime, Britain's industry and capital may find new directions and employments, preventing this distress from ever reaching any considerable height.
elegant: Five lucky coincidences have cushioned Britain from the worst effects of losing the North American trade since December 1774: the colonies' pre-embargo stockpiling drained British goods; the Spanish fleet drained competing European goods; the Russo-Turkish peace opened the Turkish market; northern European demand for British goods has been growing; and the partition of Poland opened a new market. Only the fourth is permanent -- the rest are temporary. Prolonged exclusion may yet cause distress, but gradual onset allows industry and capital to adapt and find new directions.
summary: Five coincidental events -- colonial pre-embargo purchasing, Spanish fleet demand, Russo-Turkish peace, growing northern European demand, and the partition of Poland -- have temporarily cushioned Britain from the impact of losing North American trade since 1774.
distilled: Five lucky coincidences have temporarily shielded Britain from the economic impact of losing North American colonial trade, but prolonged exclusion may still cause significant distress.
notes: Remarkable real-time economic analysis, written during the American Revolution. Smith lists five specific cushioning factors, four of which are temporary -- showing the contingent nature of Britain's apparent resilience. The December 1774 date refers to the Continental Congress's non-importation agreement. The partition of Poland (1772) and Russo-Turkish peace (1774) as factors show how interconnected European commerce was. Smith's prediction that gradual onset allows adaptation echoes his gradualist reform prescription in 4.7.135.

refashioned:
The monopoly of the colony trade, therefore, insofar as it has redirected British capital, has in all cases shifted it from nearby foreign trade to more distant trade; in many cases from direct foreign trade to roundabout trade; and in some cases from all foreign trade into carrying trade. In every case, the monopoly has redirected capital from a channel where it would have maintained a greater quantity of productive labor to one where it maintains a much smaller quantity.

By fitting so great a part of British industry and commerce to one particular market, the monopoly has also rendered the entire system more precarious and less secure than if output had been directed to a greater variety of markets.
elegant: The monopoly has systematically redirected British capital in three harmful ways: from nearby to distant trade (always), from direct to roundabout trade (often), and from foreign trade to carrying trade (sometimes). In every case, capital moved from maintaining more productive labor to maintaining less. By concentrating British commerce on a single market, the monopoly has made the entire economic system precarious and insecure.
summary: The colonial monopoly has systematically redirected British capital from more to less productive channels -- nearby to distant, direct to roundabout, and foreign trade to carrying trade -- while dangerously concentrating the economy on a single market.
distilled: The colonial monopoly systematically shifted British capital into less productive channels while dangerously concentrating the entire economy on a single market.
notes: Concise summary of the three-fold capital distortion analyzed in 4.7.124-131. The hierarchy is clear: (1) always shifts from nearby to distant, (2) often shifts from direct to roundabout, (3) sometimes shifts from all foreign trade to mere carrying trade. Each step is progressively more harmful. The concentration risk warning echoes 4.7.132. This paragraph serves as a recapitulation before the final verdict on whether the colony trade is net beneficial.

refashioned: We must carefully distinguish between the effects of the colony trade itself and the effects of the monopoly of that trade. The former are always and necessarily beneficial; the latter are always and necessarily harmful. But the beneficial effects of the trade itself are so great that the colony trade, even though subject to a monopoly and despite the harmful effects of that monopoly, remains on the whole beneficial -- and greatly beneficial -- though considerably less so than it would otherwise be.
elegant: The colony trade itself is always beneficial; the monopoly of that trade is always harmful. But the trade's benefits are so great that even burdened by monopoly, colonial trade remains greatly beneficial on the whole -- just much less so than it would be under free trade.
summary: Smith draws a sharp distinction: the colony trade itself is always beneficial, while the monopoly of that trade is always harmful. The trade's benefits outweigh the monopoly's costs, but the colony trade would be far more beneficial without the monopoly.
distilled: The colony trade is always beneficial and the monopoly always harmful, but trade benefits outweigh monopoly costs -- making the colony trade greatly beneficial despite, not because of, the monopoly.
notes: This is Smith's most concise and important distinction in the entire colonial analysis: trade good, monopoly bad. The colony trade is beneficial IN SPITE of the monopoly, not because of it. This separates the natural benefits of expanded markets (general advantages) from the artificial distortions of monopoly (particular advantages). The formulation 'always and necessarily' for both sides shows these are structural truths, not contingent observations. This framing structures the entire argument and points toward the policy conclusion: keep the trade, eliminate the monopoly.

refashioned:
In its natural and free state, the colony trade opens a great though distant market for the surplus produce of British industry that exceeds the demand of nearer European and Mediterranean markets. In its free state, the colony trade does not draw any produce away from those existing markets but encourages Britain to continually increase her surplus by presenting new equivalents to exchange for it.

In its free state, the colony trade increases the quantity of productive labor in Great Britain without altering the direction of labor previously employed there. Under free trade, competition from all other nations would prevent the rate of profit from rising above the normal level in either the new market or the new employment. The new market would create, as it were, new produce for its own supply; and that new produce would form new capital for the new employment, drawing nothing from existing activities.
elegant: Under free trade, the colony trade opens a great distant market for British surplus that exceeds European demand -- without drawing produce from existing markets, but by encouraging Britain to increase her surplus through new exchange opportunities. Free colonial trade would increase productive labor without redirecting it, as international competition would keep profits at normal levels. The new market would generate its own new produce and new capital, drawing nothing from existing economic activities.
summary: Under free trade, colonial commerce would expand the market for British surplus without distorting existing trades, as competition would keep profits normal and the new market would generate its own capital rather than drawing from other sectors.
distilled: Free colonial trade would expand markets for British surplus without distorting existing commerce, as competition would keep profits normal and the new market would be self-sustaining.
notes: Smith's positive vision of what free colonial trade would look like. Three key features: (1) purely additive to existing trade, not substitutive; (2) no distortion of capital allocation or profit rates; (3) self-sustaining -- new markets create their own capital. This is the counterfactual against which the monopoly's damage is measured. The competition mechanism is crucial: all nations trading freely prevents any artificial profit elevation. Cross-references 4.7.105-106 on absolute vs. relative advantage under free trade.

refashioned:
The monopoly of the colony trade, by contrast, excludes the competition of other nations and thereby raises the rate of profit in both the new market and the new employment. This draws produce from the old market and capital from the old employment. The avowed purpose of the monopoly is to augment our share of the colony trade beyond what it would naturally be -- if it did not do this, there would be no reason for having a monopoly.

But whatever forces a greater proportion of a country's capital into a branch of trade with slower and more distant returns than most other trades, necessarily reduces the total quantity of productive labor annually maintained, reduces the total annual output of land and labor, and keeps down the revenue of the country's inhabitants below what it would naturally reach. It thereby diminishes their capacity to accumulate. The monopoly not only prevents capital from maintaining as much productive labor as it otherwise would at any given time, but prevents it from growing as fast as it otherwise would, and consequently from supporting a still greater quantity of productive labor in the future.
elegant: The monopoly does the opposite of free trade: by excluding competition, it raises profit rates, drawing produce from old markets and capital from old employments. Its avowed purpose is to increase Britain's colonial trade share beyond its natural level. But forcing capital into slow-returning trade reduces productive labor, annual output, and national revenue below their natural levels. This diminishes accumulation capacity -- the monopoly not only suppresses current productive labor but slows the capital growth that would support even more labor in the future.
summary: The colonial monopoly raises profits by excluding competition, drawing capital from efficient sectors into slow-returning colonial trade. This reduces current productive labor and output while slowing capital accumulation, creating a compound drag on future economic growth.
distilled: The colonial monopoly suppresses current productive labor by diverting capital to slow-returning trade, and compounds the damage by slowing capital accumulation that would support future growth.
notes: The compound growth effect is the most damaging consequence: monopoly not only reduces current output but slows the rate of capital accumulation, creating an ever-widening gap between actual and potential output over time. This is a dynamic, not just static, efficiency loss. The 'avowed purpose' of the monopoly -- increasing one country's share -- is shown to be self-defeating when the mechanism involves slower returns. Cross-references 4.7.139 on the free-trade counterfactual and 4.7.115-116 on profit rate distortion.

refashioned:
The natural good effects of the colony trade, however, more than counterbalance the bad effects of the monopoly for Great Britain, so that the trade, even as currently conducted, is not only advantageous but greatly advantageous. The new market and new employment opened by the colony trade are of much greater extent than the portion of the old market and old employment lost to the monopoly. The new produce and new capital created by the colony trade maintain a greater quantity of productive labor in Great Britain than what was displaced by the diversion of capital from faster-returning trades.

If the colony trade, even as currently conducted, is advantageous to Great Britain, it is not by means of the monopoly but in spite of it.
elegant: Despite the monopoly's harm, the colony trade's natural benefits outweigh its costs -- the new markets and employment are vastly larger than what was lost through capital diversion. More productive labor is maintained by the new trade than was displaced from faster-returning sectors. If the colony trade is advantageous, it is not because of the monopoly but in spite of it.
summary: The colony trade's natural benefits vastly exceed the monopoly's costs: new markets and employment outweigh displaced activity. The trade is greatly advantageous to Britain, but solely in spite of the monopoly, not because of it.
distilled: The colony trade is greatly advantageous to Britain despite the monopoly, because its new markets and employment vastly exceed what the monopoly displaced from other sectors.
notes: Smith's final verdict on the colony trade: net positive, but only because the trade itself is so valuable that it overcomes the monopoly's damage. The last line -- 'not by means of the monopoly but in spite of it' -- is the definitive statement. This conclusion has been one of the most influential in the history of economic thought, establishing the template for subsequent free-trade arguments: trade good, trade restrictions bad. Cross-references 4.7.138 on the trade/monopoly distinction.

refashioned:
It is for manufactured goods, rather than raw produce, that the colony trade opens a new market. Agriculture is the natural business of all new colonies -- the cheapness of land makes it more profitable than anything else. Colonies therefore abound in raw produce; instead of importing it, they typically have a large surplus to export. In new colonies, agriculture draws hands from all other activities or keeps them from entering other occupations. Few hands can be spared for necessary manufactures, and none for ornamental ones. Colonists find it cheaper to buy most manufactures from other countries than to make them themselves.

The colony trade therefore encourages European industry mainly by supporting European manufactures. The manufacturers to whom colonial trade gives employment constitute a new market for the produce of European land -- and the most advantageous of all markets: the home market for Europe's grain, cattle, bread, and meat is thus greatly extended by means of the trade to America.
elegant: The colony trade opens markets mainly for manufactures, not raw produce. New colonies focus on agriculture because cheap land makes it most profitable -- they export raw materials and import manufactures. Colonial trade therefore stimulates European manufacturing, whose workers in turn create the most valuable possible market: expanded home demand for European agricultural produce -- grain, cattle, bread, and meat.
summary: Colonial trade primarily benefits European manufactures, since colonies focus on agriculture and import manufactured goods. This manufacturing employment in turn expands the domestic market for European agricultural produce.
distilled: Colonial trade primarily stimulates European manufacturing, which in turn expands the domestic market for European agriculture -- a virtuous cycle of industrial and agricultural growth.
notes: Important insight about the composition of colonial trade benefits: manufactures, not agriculture, gain the new market. The causal chain is: colonies demand manufactures from Europe, which employs European workers, who demand European food, which benefits European agriculture. This is an early analysis of multiplier effects and the distinction between direct and indirect economic benefits. The observation that the home market for food is 'the most advantageous of all markets' connects to Smith's hierarchy of markets from Book 2.

refashioned: But the monopoly of colonial trade with populous and thriving colonies is not by itself sufficient to establish or even maintain manufactures in any country, as the examples of Spain and Portugal clearly demonstrate. Both were manufacturing countries before they acquired any significant colonies. Since gaining the richest and most fertile colonies in the world, both have ceased to be manufacturing nations.
elegant: The monopoly of colonial trade alone cannot establish or maintain manufactures, as Spain and Portugal prove. Both were manufacturing countries before acquiring the richest colonies in the world -- and both ceased to be so afterward.
summary: Spain and Portugal demonstrate that colonial trade monopoly alone cannot sustain manufacturing -- both were manufacturing nations before their colonies and ceased to be so afterward.
distilled: Spain and Portugal prove that colonial trade monopoly is insufficient to sustain manufacturing, since both lost their manufacturing base after acquiring the richest colonies in the world.
notes: Devastating counterexample to the mercantilist claim that colonial monopoly strengthens domestic manufacturing. Spain and Portugal had the most valuable colonial monopolies in the world yet deindustrialized -- proving that monopoly is not just insufficient but potentially harmful to manufacturing. This sets up the analysis in 4.7.144 of what additional factors caused their decline. The 'richest and most fertile in the world' makes the failure of monopoly theory all the more striking.

refashioned: In Spain and Portugal, the harmful effects of the monopoly, aggravated by other causes, have perhaps nearly overwhelmed the natural benefits of the colony trade. These additional causes include: other monopolies of various kinds; the degradation of gold and silver values below levels prevailing in most other countries; exclusion from foreign markets through improper export taxes; the narrowing of the domestic market through even more improper taxes on transporting goods within the country; and above all, the irregular and partial administration of justice that often protects the rich and powerful debtor from his injured creditor, and which makes the industrious part of the nation afraid to produce goods for the consumption of haughty and powerful men to whom they dare not refuse credit and from whom repayment is entirely uncertain.
elegant: In Spain and Portugal, additional problems have compounded the monopoly's damage until the natural benefits of colonial trade are nearly overwhelmed: multiple other monopolies, devalued gold and silver, improper export taxes, internal trade barriers, and above all, a corrupt justice system that protects powerful debtors from their creditors. This last failing makes productive people afraid to extend credit to the powerful, choking the economy's circulatory system.
summary: Spain and Portugal's colonial trade benefits were overwhelmed by compounding problems: multiple monopolies, currency devaluation, export taxes, internal trade barriers, and above all, a corrupt justice system that protected powerful debtors and deterred productive economic activity.
distilled: Spain and Portugal's colonial benefits were overwhelmed by multiple monopolies, trade barriers, and above all a corrupt justice system that protected powerful debtors and paralyzed productive commerce.
notes: Comprehensive diagnosis of Spanish and Portuguese economic failure. The hierarchy of causes is revealing: Smith places corrupt justice administration -- protecting powerful debtors -- 'above all' other factors. This is consistent with his view that secure property rights and impartial justice are the most fundamental prerequisites for economic development. The fear of extending credit to powerful debtors who will not repay is a vivid illustration of how judicial corruption destroys commerce. Cross-references 4.7.143 and anticipates the institutional economics tradition.

refashioned:
In England, by contrast, the natural good effects of the colony trade, assisted by other favorable causes, have largely overcome the harmful effects of the monopoly. These causes include: the general liberty of trade, which despite some restrictions is at least equal to, perhaps greater than, that of any other country; the liberty of exporting almost all domestically produced goods to almost any foreign country free of duty; and what is perhaps even more important, the complete freedom to transport goods from one part of the country to any other without giving any account to any public office, without being subject to any questioning or examination.

But above all, it is the equal and impartial administration of justice that makes the rights of the humblest British subject respectable to the greatest, and that, by securing to every person the fruits of his own industry, provides the greatest and most effective encouragement to every sort of industry.
elegant: In England, favorable conditions have helped the colony trade's natural benefits overcome the monopoly's damage: general trade liberty, duty-free export of domestic goods, unrestricted internal commerce, and above all, the equal and impartial administration of justice. This last factor -- making the rights of the humblest citizen respectable to the greatest, and securing to every person the fruits of their own industry -- provides the most powerful encouragement to all economic activity.
summary: England's colonial trade benefits overcame monopoly damage thanks to general trade freedom, unrestricted internal commerce, and above all, impartial justice that secures property rights for all citizens regardless of status.
distilled: England overcame the monopoly's harmful effects through trade liberty, free internal commerce, and above all, impartial justice that secured property rights for all citizens equally.
notes: The mirror image of 4.7.144 on Spain and Portugal. England's advantages are the exact opposites of Iberian weaknesses: free trade vs. multiple monopolies, free internal transport vs. internal barriers, impartial justice vs. corrupt courts. The phrase 'the rights of the meanest British subject respectable to the greatest' is one of Smith's most celebrated statements on the rule of law. The hierarchy again places justice 'above all' other factors -- consistent with Smith's fundamental view that secure property rights and impartial law enforcement are the foundation of prosperity.

refashioned: If the manufactures of Great Britain have advanced, as they certainly have, thanks to the colony trade, it has not been by means of the monopoly but in spite of it. The monopoly's effect has been not to increase the quantity of British manufactures but to alter their quality and direction -- adapting to a market with slow and distant returns what would otherwise have been adapted to one with frequent and near returns. The result has been to divert British capital from employment that would have maintained a greater quantity of manufacturing industry to one that maintains a much smaller quantity -- thereby diminishing rather than increasing the total volume of British manufacturing.
elegant: British manufacturing has advanced through colonial trade despite the monopoly, not because of it. The monopoly did not increase manufacturing quantity but merely redirected it -- from markets with fast returns to markets with slow returns. This diverted capital from more productive to less productive employment, actually diminishing the total volume of British manufacturing.
summary: British manufacturing advanced despite the monopoly, not because of it. The monopoly merely redirected manufacturing toward slow-returning colonial markets, diverting capital from more productive employment and actually reducing total manufacturing output.
distilled: The colonial monopoly did not increase British manufacturing but merely redirected it toward less productive, slow-returning markets, actually reducing total manufacturing volume.
notes: Restatement of the core conclusion with specific application to manufacturing. The monopoly's effect was qualitative (redirecting output) not quantitative (increasing output). The direction of redirection -- from fast to slow returns -- means less capital turnover, less employment, and therefore less total manufacturing. This contradicts the mercantilist claim that monopoly builds industrial capacity. Cross-references 4.7.138 and 4.7.141 on the trade vs. monopoly distinction.

refashioned:
The monopoly of the colony trade, therefore, like all the other mean and malignant expedients of the mercantile system, depresses the industry of all other countries -- but chiefly that of the colonies -- without in the least increasing, and on the contrary diminishing, the industry of the country in whose favor it is established.

The monopoly prevents the capital of that country, whatever its current extent, from maintaining as much productive labor as it otherwise would and from generating as much revenue for its industrious inhabitants. But since capital can only be increased by savings from revenue, the monopoly, by reducing revenue, necessarily slows the growth of capital. It therefore hinders capital not only from currently maintaining as much productive labor as it otherwise would, but from growing fast enough to maintain even greater amounts of productive labor in the future. The monopoly must necessarily have rendered one great original source of revenue -- the wages of labor -- less abundant at all times than it otherwise would have been.
elegant: The colonial trade monopoly, like all mercantilist expedients, depresses the industry of all countries -- especially the colonies -- while actually diminishing, not increasing, the industry of the monopoly-holding country itself. By reducing revenue below its natural level, the monopoly slows capital accumulation, which means less productive labor now and slower growth of productive labor in the future. The wages of labor -- a fundamental source of revenue -- have been permanently suppressed.
summary: The colonial monopoly depresses industry everywhere, especially in the colonies, while actually diminishing the monopoly-holder's own industry. By reducing revenue and slowing capital accumulation, it suppresses both current productive labor and future growth, permanently lowering wages.
distilled: The colonial monopoly harms everyone -- depressing colonial industry most, reducing the monopoly-holder's own industry, slowing capital accumulation, and permanently suppressing wages.
notes: 'Mean and malignant expedients' -- Smith's harshest characterization of mercantilist policies. The compound growth argument is the most devastating critique: monopoly reduces revenue, which reduces savings, which reduces capital growth, which reduces future productive labor -- a vicious cycle with permanently expanding costs. The identification of wages as the primary casualty directly challenges the mercantilist claim that monopoly benefits the nation. Workers pay the price for merchant profits. Cross-references 4.7.140 on the accumulation-suppressing effect.

refashioned:
By raising the rate of mercantile profit, the monopoly discourages land improvement. The profit of improvement depends on the difference between what land currently produces and what it could produce with a certain investment of capital. If this difference yields a greater return than the same capital could earn in commerce, capital will flow toward land improvement. If the return is less, commercial ventures will draw capital away from land improvement.

Whatever raises the rate of mercantile profit either reduces the superiority of agricultural returns or increases their inferiority -- in one case preventing capital from flowing to land improvement, and in the other actively drawing it away. By discouraging improvement, the monopoly necessarily slows the natural growth of another great original source of revenue: the rent of land.

By raising the profit rate, the monopoly also keeps the market rate of interest higher than it would otherwise be. But land prices, relative to the rent they yield, necessarily fall as interest rates rise and rise as interest rates fall. The monopoly therefore hurts the interest of the landlord in two ways: by slowing the natural increase of his rent, and by depressing the price he would get for his land relative to that rent.
elegant: By raising mercantile profit rates, the monopoly discourages land improvement -- capital flows to commerce instead of agriculture whenever mercantile returns exceed agricultural returns. This slows the growth of rent, another fundamental revenue source. The monopoly also raises interest rates, which depresses land prices relative to rent. Landlords are thus doubly harmed: slower rent growth and lower land valuations.
summary: The colonial monopoly discourages land improvement by raising mercantile profit rates above agricultural returns, slowing rent growth. It also raises interest rates, depressing land prices. Landlords suffer both slower-growing rents and lower land values.
distilled: The colonial monopoly harms landlords doubly by diverting capital from land improvement (slowing rent growth) and raising interest rates (depressing land prices).
notes: Extends the damage analysis to rent and land values -- the second of Smith's three 'original sources of revenue' (wages, rent, profits). The mechanism is clear: artificially high mercantile profits raise the opportunity cost of agricultural investment, diverting capital away from land improvement. The interest rate connection adds a second channel of harm: higher interest rates mean lower capitalized land values. Both channels harm the same group -- landlords -- who are not merchants and thus gain nothing from the monopoly while suffering its costs. Cross-references 1.11 on rent and 2.4 on the relationship between profits and interest.

refashioned: The monopoly does raise the rate of mercantile profit and thereby increases somewhat the gains of our merchants. But because it obstructs the natural growth of capital, it tends to diminish rather than increase the total revenue that the country's inhabitants derive from the profits of stock. A small profit upon a great capital generally yields a greater total revenue than a great profit upon a small one. The monopoly raises the rate of profit, but it prevents the sum total of profit from rising as high as it otherwise would.
elegant: The monopoly raises the profit rate, increasing individual merchant gains. But by obstructing capital growth, it actually reduces total national profit revenue -- because a small rate of profit on a large capital base produces more total revenue than a high rate on a stunted one. The monopoly raises the rate but suppresses the sum.
summary: While the monopoly raises the profit rate for individual merchants, it reduces total national profit revenue by stunting capital growth -- since a lower rate on a larger capital base would generate more total profit.
distilled: The monopoly raises the profit rate but reduces total profit revenue by stunting capital growth, since a small rate on a large capital produces more total profit than a high rate on a small one.
notes: Completes the damage analysis for the third original source of revenue -- profits. The rate vs. sum distinction is crucial: merchants see higher individual profit rates and celebrate, but the nation receives less total profit because the capital base is smaller than it would be. This is a sophisticated insight into the difference between margins and volumes. All three sources of revenue (wages, rent, profits) are now shown to be reduced by the monopoly. Cross-references 4.7.147 on wages and 4.7.148 on rent.

refashioned: All three original sources of revenue -- the wages of labor, the rent of land, and the profits of stock -- the monopoly renders much less abundant than they would otherwise be. To promote the narrow interest of one small class of men in one country, the monopoly harms the interest of all other classes of men in that country and of all people in all other countries.
elegant: The monopoly diminishes all three original sources of revenue -- wages, rent, and profits -- below their natural levels. To serve the narrow interest of one small class of men in one country, it harms every other class in that country and every person in every other country.
summary: The colonial monopoly suppresses all three sources of national revenue -- wages, rent, and profits -- to serve the narrow interest of one small merchant class at the expense of everyone else, both domestically and internationally.
distilled: The monopoly suppresses wages, rent, and profits alike -- harming all classes in all countries to benefit one small class of merchants.
notes: Devastating summation: all three revenue sources (wages from 4.7.147, rent from 4.7.148, profits from 4.7.149) are reduced by monopoly. The political economy conclusion is equally sharp: the monopoly benefits 'one little order of men' at the expense of literally everyone else in every country. This is Smith's most concentrated indictment of concentrated interests shaping policy for private gain at public cost. The phrase 'one little order of men' emphasizes the absurd disproportion between the few beneficiaries and the many who are harmed.

refashioned: It is solely by raising the ordinary rate of profit that the monopoly has proved, or could prove, advantageous to any one particular class of men. But besides all the harmful effects to the country already described as necessarily resulting from a higher profit rate, there is one more that is perhaps the most fatal of all, and which experience suggests is inseparable from high profits. A high rate of profit seems everywhere to destroy the frugality that, in other circumstances, is natural to the merchant's character. When profits are high, that sober virtue seems superfluous, and expensive luxury seems better suited to the merchant's affluent situation.
elegant: The monopoly benefits only one class and only through raising profit rates. But beyond all the economic damage already described, high profits produce perhaps the most fatal effect of all: they destroy merchant frugality. When profits are high, thrift seems unnecessary and extravagant luxury seems appropriate to the merchant's prosperity.
summary: Beyond its economic damage, the monopoly's most fatal effect may be the destruction of merchant frugality -- high profits encourage luxury and extravagance, undermining the thrift that drives capital accumulation.
distilled: The monopoly's most fatal effect may be destroying merchant frugality, as high profits encourage luxury and extravagance that undermine the saving essential to capital accumulation.
notes: Smith introduces a behavioral/moral dimension to the monopoly critique. High profits corrupt the character of merchants, destroying the 'parsimony' (thrift) that is the engine of capital accumulation. This is an early analysis of how economic incentives shape character -- anticipating behavioral economics. The argument that prosperity can undermine the virtues that created it is a recurring theme in moral philosophy. 'Perhaps the most fatal of all' -- Smith considers this moral corruption worse than the purely economic damage. Cross-references 2.3 on parsimony and accumulation.

refashioned:
The owners of the great mercantile capitals are necessarily the leaders and conductors of every nation's entire industry. Their example has a far greater influence on the manners of the whole industrious population than that of any other class. If the employer is attentive and frugal, the worker is very likely to be so too. But if the master is dissolute and disorderly, the servant who shapes his work to the pattern his master prescribes will shape his life to the example his master sets.

Accumulation is thus prevented in the hands of those who are naturally the most disposed to accumulate. The funds destined for the maintenance of productive labor receive no increase from the revenue of those who ought naturally to be adding to them the most.
elegant: Great merchants are the leaders and exemplars of every nation's industry. If employers are frugal, workers follow suit; if masters are dissolute, servants imitate them. When high profits destroy merchant thrift, accumulation is prevented in the very hands most naturally disposed to save. The funds for maintaining productive labor receive no augmentation from those who should be augmenting them most.
summary: Merchants set the behavioral standard for the entire working population. When high profits make merchants extravagant, their example spreads throughout society, preventing capital accumulation by the very class that should be saving and investing the most.
distilled: High profits corrupt merchant behavior, and since merchants set the example for all workers, this extravagance spreads through society, preventing capital accumulation by those best positioned to drive it.
notes: Smith extends the moral corruption argument through a social influence mechanism: merchants as role models for the entire workforce.
