This is an early analysis of how elite behavior shapes social norms -- anticipating modern research on inequality and social capital. The argument that dissolute employers produce dissolute workers connects economic incentives to cultural outcomes. The capital accumulation failure is doubly damaging: the wealthy both fail to save and teach others not to save. Cross-references 4.7.151 on high profits destroying frugality and 2.3 on the role of parsimony in economic growth.

refashioned: The capital of the country, instead of increasing, gradually dwindles away, and the quantity of productive labor maintained in it grows less and less with every passing day. Have the exorbitant profits of the merchants of Cadiz and Lisbon augmented the capital of Spain and Portugal? Have they alleviated the poverty, or promoted the industry, of those two impoverished countries? Such has been the scale of mercantile extravagance in those two trading cities that those exorbitant profits, far from augmenting the general capital of the country, seem scarcely to have been sufficient even to maintain the capitals upon which they were earned. Foreign capitals are every day intruding themselves more and more into the trade of Cadiz and Lisbon.
elegant: National capital dwindles and productive labor declines. Have the exorbitant profits of Cadiz and Lisbon merchants augmented Spanish and Portuguese capital? Have they reduced poverty or promoted industry? No -- mercantile extravagance has been so great that these enormous profits have barely maintained the capitals that generated them. Foreign capitals increasingly dominate the trade of Cadiz and Lisbon.
summary: The exorbitant profits of Spanish and Portuguese merchants have not increased national capital, reduced poverty, or promoted industry. Mercantile extravagance has consumed these profits, and foreign capital increasingly dominates Iberian trade.
distilled: Spain and Portugal prove that exorbitant merchant profits, consumed by extravagance rather than reinvested, actually erode national capital and cede commercial dominance to foreign competitors.
notes: The clinching empirical case: Cadiz and Lisbon as proof that high monopoly profits destroy rather than build national wealth. The rhetorical questions are devastating -- profits that should have enriched two nations barely maintained themselves. Foreign capital 'intruding' into Iberian trade is the final indignity: monopoly profits not only failed to grow domestic capital but created a vacuum filled by foreigners. This completes the behavioral argument of 4.7.151-152: high profits breed extravagance, extravagance destroys accumulation, destroyed accumulation invites foreign displacement. Cross-references 4.7.143-144 on Spain and Portugal as examples of monopoly failure.

refashioned: It is precisely to drive out those foreign capitals from a trade that their own resources grow increasingly insufficient to handle that the Spanish and Portuguese keep tightening the suffocating restrictions of their absurd monopoly. Compare the business culture of Cadiz and Lisbon with that of Amsterdam, and you will immediately see how differently high and low profit rates shape the conduct and character of merchants. The merchants of London have not yet generally become such extravagant grandees as those of Cadiz and Lisbon, but neither are they generally such attentive and frugal burghers as those of Amsterdam. London merchants are thought to be considerably richer than most of the former group, though not quite as rich as many of the latter. Their profit rate is typically much lower than that of the Iberian merchants and considerably higher than that of the Dutch. "Easy come, easy go," as the proverb says, and the typical level of spending everywhere seems to be regulated not so much by one's actual ability to spend as by the perceived ease of acquiring money to spend.
elegant: Spain and Portugal keep tightening their colonial trade monopoly precisely because foreign capital increasingly fills the gap their own resources cannot cover. Compare Cadiz's extravagance with Amsterdam's frugality and you see how profit rates shape merchant character. London merchants fall between both extremes in wealth and spending habits. The universal pattern holds: spending follows not actual wealth but the perceived ease of getting money. Easy come, easy go.
summary: Spain and Portugal tighten their colonial monopoly to exclude foreign capital they increasingly depend on. Comparing merchant cultures in Cadiz, Amsterdam, and London reveals that high profit rates breed extravagance while lower rates encourage frugality. Spending habits are governed by the perceived ease of acquiring money, not actual wealth.
distilled: High monopoly profits breed merchant extravagance, while competitive markets foster frugality -- spending follows perceived ease of gain, not actual wealth.
notes: Merchant culture and profit rates -- comparative commercial behavior across Cadiz, Lisbon, Amsterdam, London -- colonial monopoly distortions -- cross-reference to 4.7.100-153 on colonial monopoly effects -- "easy come, easy go" as economic behavioral principle

refashioned:
The single advantage that the monopoly delivers to one class of people is, in many different ways, harmful to the general interest of the country.

To found a great empire for the sole purpose of creating a captive customer base may at first appear to be a project suited only to a nation of shopkeepers. In reality, however, it is a project entirely unsuited to a nation of shopkeepers but perfectly suited to a nation whose government is controlled by shopkeepers. Only such statesmen are capable of imagining they will profit from spending the blood and treasure of their fellow citizens to found and maintain such an empire. Say to an actual shopkeeper: "Buy me a fine estate, and I will always purchase my clothes from your shop, even if I must pay more than I would elsewhere" -- you will not find him eager to accept the offer.
elegant: The monopoly's benefit to one class harms the nation overall. Founding an empire merely to create captive customers seems a scheme fit for a nation of shopkeepers -- yet it actually suits only a nation governed by shopkeepers. No real shopkeeper would buy someone an estate just to secure their custom at above-market prices. Only statesmen influenced by merchant interests could imagine spending their citizens' blood and treasure on such a bargain.
summary: The colonial monopoly benefits one merchant class at the nation's expense. Smith argues that building an empire to create captive customers is a project not for actual shopkeepers -- who would recognize its poor return -- but for governments controlled by merchant interests willing to spend public blood and treasure.
distilled: Building an empire to create captive customers serves only the merchant class that controls government, not the nation or any rational shopkeeper.
notes: Famous "nation of shopkeepers" passage -- critique of mercantilist imperialism -- public cost vs. private benefit of colonial monopoly -- rent-seeking through political influence -- cross-reference to 4.7.154 on monopoly harms

refashioned: But if someone else were to buy you such an estate, the shopkeeper would be most grateful to your benefactor if he required you to purchase all your clothes from that shop. England acquired for some of her subjects -- those who found themselves uncomfortable at home -- a great estate in a distant country. The purchase price was remarkably small: instead of the thirty years' purchase that represents the standard price of land today, it amounted to little more than the cost of the various expeditions that first discovered the territory, surveyed the coast, and took a nominal possession of the country.
elegant: If someone else buys you an estate and obliges you to shop exclusively at one store, the shopkeeper profits without investing anything. England similarly acquired a vast colonial estate for a pittance -- barely the cost of the expeditions that discovered and claimed the territory -- far below the standard thirty years' purchase price of land.
summary: Smith extends his shopkeeper analogy: England acquired its American colonies at minimal cost -- just the expense of exploration and nominal possession -- far below the normal price of land, yet merchants demanded exclusive trading rights over these colonies they had not paid for.
distilled: England acquired its American colonies cheaply through exploration costs alone, yet merchants claimed exclusive trading rights over territory they never purchased.
notes: Colonial acquisition costs vs. monopoly claims -- shopkeeper analogy continued -- thirty years' purchase as standard land valuation -- cross-reference to 4.7.155

refashioned: The land was fertile and vast. The settlers, having plenty of good ground to work and being initially free to sell their produce wherever they chose, became within roughly thirty to forty years (between 1620 and 1660) such a numerous and thriving population that English shopkeepers and traders sought to secure a monopoly over their commerce. Without claiming to have paid any part of either the original acquisition cost or the subsequent expense of improvement, these traders petitioned Parliament to confine the American settlers to their shop: first, for buying all the European goods they needed, and second, for selling all the parts of their own produce that these traders found it profitable to purchase.
elegant: The colonists, free to trade as they pleased, became numerous and prosperous within thirty to forty years. English merchants then petitioned Parliament to monopolize colonial commerce -- forcing Americans to buy exclusively from England and sell exclusively to English traders -- despite having contributed nothing to the costs of settlement or development.
summary: American colonists thrived between 1620 and 1660 when free to trade openly. English merchants, having paid nothing toward colonial acquisition or development, successfully petitioned Parliament to monopolize both the supply of European goods to the colonies and the purchase of colonial produce.
distilled: English merchants secured a monopoly over thriving American colonial trade despite contributing nothing to the costs of settlement or development.
notes: Timeline of colonial trade freedom (1620-1660) -- rent-seeking by English merchants -- Navigation Acts origins -- monopoly imposed without investment -- cross-reference to 4.7.155-156 shopkeeper analogy

refashioned: The merchants did not find it convenient to purchase every part of colonial produce. Some colonial goods, if imported into England, would have competed with trades they already conducted at home. Those particular products, therefore, they were willing to let the colonists sell wherever they could -- the farther away the better. For this reason, they proposed that the colonial market for such goods should be restricted to countries south of Cape Finisterre. A clause in the famous Navigation Act established this thoroughly shopkeeper-minded proposal into law.
elegant: Merchants only monopolized colonial products that did not compete with their domestic trades. Products that might undercut English manufactures could be sold by colonists only to distant markets south of Cape Finisterre. This self-serving arrangement was codified in the Navigation Act.
summary: English merchants selectively monopolized colonial products, excluding those that would compete with their domestic business. Colonial goods that threatened English manufactures could only be sold to distant markets south of Cape Finisterre, a restriction enshrined in the Navigation Act.
distilled: The Navigation Act codified merchants' self-serving arrangement: monopolize profitable colonial goods while restricting competing products to distant markets.
notes: Navigation Acts -- Cape Finisterre trade restriction -- selective monopoly to protect domestic manufactures -- shopkeeper mentality in legislation -- enumerated commodities concept

refashioned: Maintaining this monopoly has been the principal -- or more accurately, the sole -- end and purpose of the authority that Great Britain claims over her colonies. The exclusive trade is supposed to constitute the great advantage of these provinces, which have never provided either revenue or military force for the support of civil government or the defense of the mother country. The monopoly is the primary badge of their dependence and the only fruit yet harvested from that dependence. Whatever expense Great Britain has incurred in maintaining this relationship has really been spent to uphold this monopoly.
elegant: The trade monopoly is the sole purpose and only benefit of Britain's colonial dominion. The colonies have never contributed revenue or military force to the mother country. The monopoly marks their dependence, and every expense Britain has borne in maintaining colonial rule has ultimately served to protect that monopoly alone.
summary: Smith argues that maintaining the trade monopoly is the only real purpose of British colonial authority. The colonies provide neither revenue nor military support, and all expenses of colonial governance are ultimately spent to uphold the exclusive trade arrangement.
distilled: The colonial trade monopoly is both the sole purpose and only fruit of British dominion, yet it costs more to maintain than it returns.
notes: Colonial monopoly as sole purpose of empire -- colonies as net fiscal drain -- monopoly as badge of dependency -- cross-reference to 4.7.155-158 on monopoly origins

refashioned: The expense of maintaining the colonies' peacetime military establishment, before the current troubles began, included the pay of twenty infantry regiments, the cost of artillery, stores, and extraordinary provisions needed to supply them, and the expense of a very considerable naval force constantly maintained to guard the immense coastline of North America and the West Indian islands against smuggling vessels from other nations. This entire peacetime establishment was charged to British revenue, and it represented only the smallest part of what colonial dominion has actually cost the mother country.
elegant: Before the current troubles, the colonial peace establishment cost Britain twenty regiments, artillery and stores, and a substantial navy guarding the vast American and West Indian coastlines against smugglers. All this was charged to British revenue -- and it was the smallest part of what empire has actually cost.
summary: The peacetime colonial military establishment -- twenty regiments, artillery, and a large navy patrolling against smugglers -- was entirely funded by British revenue. Yet Smith emphasizes this was only the smallest portion of the total cost of maintaining colonial dominion.
distilled: The colonial peacetime military establishment, though entirely funded by Britain, represented only a fraction of the true cost of empire.
notes: Cost accounting of empire -- twenty regiments, naval patrols -- peacetime establishment as minimum cost -- smuggling enforcement costs -- cross-reference to 4.7.159 on monopoly as sole purpose

refashioned: To know the full cost, we must add to the annual peacetime establishment expense the interest on all the sums that Great Britain has spent on colonial defense, treating the colonies as provinces subject to her dominion. In particular, we must add the entire cost of the recent war and a large portion of the war that preceded it. The recent war was entirely a colonial conflict, and its full expense -- wherever in the world it was incurred, whether in Germany or the East Indies -- should rightly be charged to the colonial account. That expense exceeded ninety million pounds sterling, counting not only the new debt contracted but also the additional two-shilling land tax and the sums annually borrowed from the sinking fund.
elegant: The full cost of colonial dominion includes interest on all defense spending, the entire cost of the last war (a purely colonial conflict), and much of the war before it. The last war alone cost over ninety million pounds -- including new debt, additional land taxes, and sinking fund borrowings -- regardless of whether the money was spent in Germany or the East Indies.
summary: Smith calculates the true cost of colonial empire by adding the interest on all colonial defense spending to peacetime expenses. The Seven Years' War, which was entirely a colonial conflict, cost over ninety million pounds sterling in new debt, additional taxes, and sinking fund diversions.
distilled: The Seven Years' War alone cost Britain over ninety million pounds -- a purely colonial conflict whose full expense should be charged against the supposed benefits of monopoly.
notes: Seven Years' War as colonial conflict -- ninety million pounds total cost -- sinking fund diversions -- cost accounting of empire -- land tax increases -- cross-reference to 4.7.160 on peacetime costs

refashioned: The Spanish war that began in 1739 was primarily a colonial conflict. Its main objective was to prevent the search of colonial ships carrying on contraband trade with the Spanish Main. This entire expense is, in reality, a bounty paid to support a monopoly. The declared purpose was to encourage manufactures and increase British commerce, but its actual effect was to raise mercantile profit rates and enable merchants to divert a larger proportion of their capital into a trade with slower and more distant returns than most other branches of commerce. These are two outcomes that, if a bounty could have prevented them, might perhaps have been well worth preventing.
elegant: The 1739 Spanish war was a colonial conflict fought over contraband trade. Its entire cost amounts to a bounty paid to maintain the monopoly. The supposed purpose was to encourage manufactures, but the real effect was to raise merchant profits and divert capital into slow-returning colonial trade -- outcomes a bounty should have prevented, not promoted.
summary: The 1739 war with Spain was a colonial conflict whose costs effectively subsidized the trade monopoly. Rather than encouraging manufactures as claimed, it raised merchant profit rates and diverted capital into slow-returning colonial trade.
distilled: The 1739 Spanish war was a colonial conflict whose entire cost served as a public bounty to maintain private monopoly profits.
notes: War of Jenkins' Ear (1739) -- contraband trade with Spanish Main -- war costs as monopoly subsidy -- capital misallocation into slow-return trades -- cross-reference to 4.7.160-161 on imperial costs

refashioned:
Under the present system of management, Great Britain derives nothing but loss from colonial dominion.

To suggest that Great Britain should voluntarily surrender all authority over her colonies -- letting them elect their own officials, enact their own laws, and make peace and war as they see fit -- would be to propose something that no nation has ever done or ever will do. No nation has ever willingly given up dominion over any province, however troublesome to govern and however meager the revenue compared to the cost. Such sacrifices, though frequently in the national interest, are always mortifying to national pride. Perhaps more importantly, they always conflict with the private interests of the governing class, who would lose control over many positions of trust and profit and many opportunities for acquiring wealth and status that even the most turbulent and unprofitable province provides. The most visionary idealist would scarcely propose such a measure with any real hope of its adoption. Yet if it were adopted, Great Britain would not only be immediately freed from the entire annual cost of the colonial peace establishment but could negotiate a trade treaty that would secure free trade more beneficial to the general public -- though less profitable for merchants -- than the current monopoly. By parting as friends, the colonies' natural affection for the mother country, which our recent conflicts have nearly extinguished, would quickly revive. This might dispose them not only to respect such a commercial treaty for centuries but to favor us in war as well as trade, transforming them from turbulent and fractious subjects into our most faithful, affectionate, and generous allies. The same parental affection and filial respect that once existed between the Greek colonies and their mother cities might be restored between Great Britain and her colonies.
elegant: Britain gains nothing but loss from colonial dominion. Yet no nation voluntarily surrenders provinces -- not because retention serves the public interest, but because it serves national pride and the private interests of the governing class who profit from colonial patronage. If Britain did release the colonies, she would save the entire peace establishment cost and could secure a free trade treaty more beneficial to the public than the current monopoly. Parting as friends would revive colonial affection, potentially yielding faithful allies rather than rebellious subjects -- just as Greek colonies maintained bonds with their mother cities.
summary: Smith argues Britain profits nothing from colonial dominion but acknowledges no nation voluntarily surrenders territory because it injures national pride and the private interests of the governing class. If Britain did release the colonies, the savings and a free trade agreement would benefit the public more than the monopoly, and the colonies would become willing allies rather than resentful subjects.
distilled: Britain derives only loss from colonial rule, yet national pride and the governing class's private interests prevent the rational solution of voluntary separation and free trade.
notes: Voluntary decolonization argument -- national pride vs. national interest -- governing class patronage incentives -- free trade vs. monopoly benefits -- Greek colonial model -- prophetic passage written during American Revolution -- cross-reference to 4.7.159-162 on costs of empire

refashioned: For any province to be truly advantageous to the empire it belongs to, it should provide enough peacetime revenue not only to cover the full cost of its own peace establishment but also to contribute its proportional share to the general government of the empire. Every province necessarily adds to the expense of general government, so if any particular province fails to contribute its share, an unequal burden falls on other parts of the empire. By the same logic, the extraordinary wartime revenue each province contributes should bear the same proportion to total imperial wartime revenue as its ordinary peacetime contribution bears to total peacetime revenue. That Britain's colonies contribute neither ordinary nor extraordinary revenue in this proportion is obvious. The monopoly is supposed to compensate for this deficit by increasing the private revenue of British citizens and thereby enabling them to pay higher taxes. But as I have tried to show, the monopoly -- though a very heavy tax on the colonies -- actually diminishes rather than increases the revenue of the great body of the people, and therefore diminishes rather than increases their ability to pay taxes. Moreover, the particular class of men whose revenue the monopoly increases cannot be taxed beyond the proportion of other classes, as I shall attempt to demonstrate in the following book. No special revenue can therefore be drawn from this particular class.
elegant: A province should contribute enough revenue to cover its own governance and its share of imperial expenses in both peace and war. Britain's colonies contribute neither. The monopoly supposedly compensates by enriching British citizens who then pay more taxes, but it actually diminishes national income -- and the merchant class it enriches cannot be taxed disproportionately. The colonies thus remain a net fiscal drain with no mechanism to recover costs.
summary: Smith argues that provinces should contribute proportionally to imperial expenses in both peace and war. Britain's colonies fail entirely in this regard. The supposed compensation -- that the monopoly enriches British citizens who then pay more taxes -- is false because the monopoly actually reduces national income, and the merchant class it benefits cannot be taxed beyond normal proportions.
distilled: Britain's colonies contribute no proportional revenue to imperial expenses, and the trade monopoly supposedly compensating for this actually diminishes national income rather than increasing it.
notes: Provincial fiscal obligations to empire -- proportional contribution principle -- monopoly as regressive tax -- merchant class untaxable beyond proportion -- cross-reference to Book V on taxation -- cross-reference to 4.7.100-153 on monopoly reducing national income

refashioned:
The colonies may be taxed either by their own assemblies or by the Parliament of Great Britain.

That the colonial assemblies could ever be managed to raise from their constituents sufficient public revenue -- not only to maintain their own civil and military establishments but also to pay their proper share of general imperial government expenses -- seems highly improbable. It took a long time before even the English Parliament, operating directly under the sovereign's eye, could be brought under such management or made sufficiently generous in its grants for supporting even England's own civil and military establishments. This was only achieved by distributing among individual members of Parliament a substantial share of the offices or patronage arising from those establishments. But the colonial assemblies' distance from the sovereign, their number, their geographical dispersion, and their varied constitutions would make them extremely difficult to manage in the same way, even if the sovereign had the same tools available -- which he does not. It would be absolutely impossible to distribute among the leading members of all colonial assemblies enough offices or patronage from the general imperial government to induce them to sacrifice their local popularity and tax their constituents for a government whose benefits would flow almost entirely to strangers. The unavoidable ignorance of the home administration about the relative importance of different members in these different assemblies -- the inevitable offenses given and blunders committed in attempting to manage them this way -- makes such a system of management altogether impractical.
elegant: Colonial assemblies are unlikely ever to tax their constituents enough to cover both local and imperial expenses. Even the English Parliament only became cooperative through patronage distribution -- offices and appointments shared among its members. Colonial assemblies are too distant, too numerous, too dispersed, and too varied in constitution for such management. No distribution of imperial patronage could induce colonial leaders to sacrifice local popularity for a distant government whose benefits flow to strangers.
summary: Smith argues colonial assemblies cannot be managed to raise sufficient revenue for both local and imperial needs. The English Parliament itself only became fiscally cooperative through patronage distribution, but colonial assemblies are too distant, numerous, and dispersed for such management, and no amount of imperial patronage could overcome their reluctance.
distilled: Colonial assemblies cannot be managed to raise adequate imperial revenue because the patronage system that made the English Parliament cooperative is impractical across distant, dispersed colonial legislatures.
notes: Parliamentary management through patronage -- colonial assemblies vs. English Parliament -- distance and dispersal as governance obstacles -- principal-agent problems in imperial administration -- cross-reference to 4.7.164 on colonial fiscal obligations

refashioned: Colonial assemblies, moreover, cannot be considered proper judges of what is necessary for the defense and support of the whole empire. They are not entrusted with that responsibility, it is not their business, and they have no regular means of obtaining the relevant information. A provincial assembly, like a local parish council, may judge very well concerning the affairs of its own district but has no proper means of judging the affairs of the entire empire. It cannot even properly assess the proportion that its own province bears to the whole empire, or its relative wealth and importance compared to other provinces, because those other provinces are not under its inspection. Only the assembly that inspects and oversees the affairs of the entire empire can judge what is necessary for imperial defense and support, and in what proportion each part should contribute.
elegant: Colonial assemblies cannot judge imperial defense needs -- they lack the responsibility, the information, and the perspective. Like parish councils, they understand local affairs but cannot assess their province's relative weight within the empire. Only an assembly overseeing the whole empire can determine what each part should contribute to common defense and support.
summary: Colonial assemblies lack the authority, information, and perspective to judge imperial defense needs or their province's proportional contribution. Only an empire-wide assembly can make such determinations, just as only a central body -- not a parish council -- can assess the needs of an entire nation.
distilled: Colonial assemblies, like parish councils, can judge local affairs but lack the information and perspective to assess imperial defense needs or proportional contributions.
notes: Information asymmetry in imperial governance -- parish council analogy -- subsidiarity principle -- only empire-wide assembly can assess defense needs -- cross-reference to 4.7.165 on colonial assembly limitations

refashioned: It has therefore been proposed that colonies be taxed by requisition: Parliament would determine the total sum each colony should pay, while the provincial assembly would assess and collect it in whatever way best suited local circumstances. Under this arrangement, matters concerning the whole empire would be decided by the assembly overseeing the whole empire, while each colony's internal affairs would still be managed by its own assembly. Though the colonies would have no representatives in Parliament, experience suggests the parliamentary requisitions would not be unreasonable. Parliament has never shown the slightest inclination to overtax those parts of the empire without parliamentary representation. The islands of Guernsey and Jersey, with no means of resisting parliamentary authority, are taxed more lightly than any part of Great Britain. Parliament has never demanded from the colonies anything approaching a fair proportion of what British subjects at home pay. Furthermore, if colonial contributions rose and fell in proportion to the land tax, Parliament could not tax the colonies without simultaneously taxing its own constituents, giving the colonies a form of virtual representation.
elegant: Under taxation by requisition, Parliament would set each colony's total contribution while provincial assemblies determined collection methods. Imperial matters would remain with Parliament; local affairs with colonial assemblies. Historical evidence suggests Parliament would not overburden unrepresented territories -- Guernsey and Jersey are taxed more lightly than Britain itself. If colonial contributions tracked the land tax, Parliament could not tax colonies without also taxing its own constituents, creating virtual representation.
summary: Smith describes the requisition proposal: Parliament sets each colony's tax obligation while colonial assemblies handle collection. He argues Parliament would not overtax unrepresented colonies, citing Guernsey and Jersey as evidence, and notes that linking colonial contributions to the land tax would create a form of virtual representation.
distilled: Taxation by requisition -- where Parliament sets totals and colonial assemblies collect -- could work fairly, since Parliament has never overtaxed unrepresented territories like Guernsey and Jersey.
notes: Taxation by requisition proposal -- virtual representation concept -- Guernsey and Jersey precedent -- land tax linkage -- separation of imperial and local authority -- cross-reference to 4.7.165-166 on colonial assembly limitations

refashioned: There are precedents for empires in which different provinces are not taxed uniformly but where the sovereign determines each province's total contribution, sometimes assessing and collecting it directly and sometimes leaving it to provincial authorities. In some French provinces, the king both imposes and collects whatever taxes he sees fit, while in others he simply demands a certain sum and leaves it to the provincial states to assess and collect it as they choose. Under the requisition scheme, the British Parliament would stand in roughly the same position relative to the colonial assemblies as the French king does relative to the states of those provinces that still retain the privilege of their own assemblies -- the French provinces generally considered to be the best governed.
elegant: Precedents exist for differentiated provincial taxation. In France, the king directly taxes some provinces while others -- considered the best governed -- are given a total to raise as their own states see fit. Under taxation by requisition, Parliament would stand in the same relation to colonial assemblies as the French king to these self-governing provinces.
summary: Smith cites the French model where some provinces are directly taxed while others -- considered the best governed -- raise assigned sums through their own assemblies. Parliamentary requisition would place Britain in an analogous position relative to the colonies.
distilled: The French system of differentiated provincial taxation -- where some provinces raise assigned sums through their own assemblies -- provides a precedent for colonial taxation by requisition.
notes: French provincial taxation model -- pays d'etats vs. pays d'election -- comparative imperial governance -- best-governed provinces retain fiscal autonomy -- cross-reference to 4.7.167 on requisition proposal

refashioned: Yet even under this scheme, while the colonies would have no just reason to fear their share of the public burden would ever exceed fair proportion, Great Britain might justly fear it would never reach that proportion. Parliament has not, for some time, held the same established authority in the colonies that the French king enjoys in those French provinces that retain their own assemblies. Unless the colonial assemblies were managed far more skillfully than they ever have been -- and without favorable dispositions they are unlikely to cooperate -- they could easily find pretexts for evading or rejecting even the most reasonable parliamentary requisitions. Suppose a French war breaks out and ten million pounds must be raised immediately to defend the heart of the empire. This sum must be borrowed against the credit of some parliamentary fund pledged to pay the interest. Parliament proposes to raise part through a tax levied in Great Britain and part through requisitions to the various colonial assemblies in America and the West Indies. Would lenders readily advance money against a fund partly dependent on the goodwill of all those distant assemblies, far from the theater of war and sometimes considering themselves barely affected by it? Lenders would probably advance no more than what the British tax alone could be expected to cover.
elegant: Though colonies need not fear disproportionate taxation by requisition, Britain should fear never collecting its fair share. Parliament lacks the authority the French king holds over self-governing provinces. Colonial assemblies could easily evade reasonable requisitions. In a war requiring immediate borrowing, lenders would not trust a fund partly dependent on distant assemblies' goodwill -- they would advance only what the British domestic tax guaranteed.
summary: Smith identifies the fatal weakness of taxation by requisition: while colonies would not be overtaxed, Britain could never collect a fair share because colonial assemblies would evade contributions. Wartime borrowing against such uncertain revenue would be impossible, since lenders would trust only the domestic British tax portion.
distilled: Taxation by requisition would fail because colonial assemblies could evade contributions, making wartime borrowing against their uncertain revenue impossible.
notes: Requisition scheme's fatal flaw -- credibility problem for government borrowing -- colonial assemblies' evasion incentives -- wartime fiscal emergency scenarios -- cross-reference to 4.7.167-168 on requisition proposal

refashioned: The whole burden of war debt would in this way fall, as it always has, upon Great Britain alone -- upon a part of the empire, not the whole. Great Britain is perhaps the only state in history that has expanded its empire while only increasing its expenses without ever augmenting its resources. Other states have generally shifted the major cost of imperial defense onto their subject and subordinate provinces. Great Britain has allowed her subject provinces to shift nearly the entire cost of defense onto her. To put Great Britain on an equal footing with her own colonies -- which the law has treated as subject and subordinate -- it seems necessary, under the requisition scheme, that Parliament should have some means of enforcing its requisitions if the colonial assemblies attempt to evade or reject them. What those enforcement mechanisms might be is not easy to conceive, and no one has yet explained them.
elegant: War debts would fall entirely on Britain, as they always have. Britain is uniquely the only empire in history that has expanded while only increasing expenses without augmenting resources -- allowing subordinate provinces to shift defense costs onto the mother country rather than the reverse. For requisition to work, Parliament would need enforcement mechanisms against uncooperative colonial assemblies, but no one has explained what those could be.
summary: Smith observes that Britain is historically unique in having expanded its empire while only increasing expenses, never resources -- the opposite of all other empires. Under the requisition scheme, Parliament would need some enforcement mechanism against colonial assemblies that evade their obligations, but no one has proposed a workable one.
distilled: Britain is the only empire in history that expanded while only increasing expenses, and the requisition scheme offers no enforcement mechanism against colonial evasion.
notes: Britain as uniquely costly empire -- historical comparison with other empires -- enforcement problem in requisition -- colonial cost-shifting onto mother country -- cross-reference to 4.7.169 on requisition weaknesses

refashioned: If Parliament were ever fully established in the right to tax the colonies independently of their assemblies' consent, those assemblies' importance would immediately end, along with the importance of all the leading men of British America. People desire a share in public affairs chiefly for the importance it gives them. The stability of every free government depends on the power of the leading men -- the natural aristocracy of every country -- to preserve or defend their respective importance. The entire dynamic of domestic politics and ambition consists of these leading men's continual attacks on each other's importance and defense of their own. The leading men of America, like those everywhere, wish to preserve their importance. They feel -- or imagine -- that if their assemblies (which they proudly call parliaments and consider equal in authority to the British Parliament) were degraded to become mere administrative agents of that Parliament, their importance would largely be destroyed. They have therefore rejected the proposal of taxation by parliamentary requisition and, like other ambitious and proud men, have chosen to draw the sword in defense of their own importance.
elegant: If Parliament gained the unchallenged right to tax colonies, colonial assemblies -- and their leading men -- would lose all importance. People seek public office chiefly for the status it confers, and free government depends on leading men defending their importance. American leaders, who consider their assemblies equal to Parliament, rejected requisition rather than accept degradation to mere administrators. Like ambitious men everywhere, they chose to fight rather than surrender their standing.
summary: Smith explains that direct parliamentary taxation would destroy colonial assemblies' importance and with it the status of America's leading men. Since political ambition and free government both depend on leaders preserving their importance, American leaders rejected parliamentary requisition and chose armed resistance rather than accept subordination.
distilled: American leaders chose armed revolution over parliamentary taxation because accepting it would have destroyed their assemblies' authority and their own political importance.
notes: Political importance as motivation -- natural aristocracy concept -- colonial assemblies as quasi-parliaments -- American Revolution as defense of status -- psychology of political ambition -- cross-reference to 4.7.169-170 on requisition problems

refashioned: Toward the decline of the Roman Republic, the allies of Rome who had borne the principal burden of defending and extending the empire demanded admission to full Roman citizenship. When refused, the Social War broke out. During that war, Rome granted these privileges to most of the allies, one by one, as each detached itself from the general confederacy. Similarly, Parliament insists on taxing the colonies, and they refuse to be taxed by a Parliament in which they have no representation. If Great Britain were to offer each colony that separated from the general confederacy a proportional number of parliamentary representatives -- corresponding to its contribution to imperial revenue, with representation increasing as contributions grew -- subject to the same taxes but compensated with equal trading freedom, then a new path to importance and a more dazzling object of ambition would open before the leading men of each colony. Instead of scrambling for the petty prizes of colonial faction, they might hope to win some of the great prizes from the wheel of British political life. Unless this or some similar method is found to preserve the importance and satisfy the ambition of America's leading men, they are unlikely ever to submit voluntarily. We should consider that every drop of blood shed in forcing them is the blood of those who are -- or whom we wish to be -- our fellow citizens. Those who believe our colonies can be easily conquered by force alone are deluding themselves.
elegant: Rome's allies fought the Social War when denied citizenship; Rome ended it by granting citizenship individually to those who defected. Britain faces an analogous situation. If each colony that submitted were given parliamentary representation proportional to its tax contribution -- with equal trading rights -- colonial leaders would gain access to the great prizes of imperial politics rather than scrambling for petty colonial ones. Without some way to satisfy American leaders' ambition, voluntary submission is impossible, and forced conquest means shedding the blood of our own fellow citizens.
summary: Smith draws a parallel between the Roman Social War and the American conflict: Rome's allies fought for citizenship rights, just as colonists resist taxation without representation. He proposes proportional parliamentary representation for colonies that contribute taxes, arguing this would redirect colonial leaders' ambitions toward imperial politics. Without satisfying their ambition, voluntary submission is impossible and military conquest would mean killing fellow citizens.
distilled: Proportional parliamentary representation for tax-contributing colonies could redirect American leaders' ambitions from colonial faction to imperial politics, avoiding a war that sheds the blood of fellow citizens.
notes: Roman Social War parallel -- representation proportional to taxation -- ambition redirection strategy -- "no taxation without representation" -- futility of military conquest -- blood of fellow citizens argument -- cross-reference to 4.7.171 on political importance

refashioned: The individuals who currently direct the Continental Congress feel a degree of importance that perhaps the greatest subjects in Europe can scarcely match. From shopkeepers, tradesmen, and lawyers, they have become statesmen and legislators, engaged in designing a new form of government for an extensive empire that they expect -- and which indeed seems very likely -- to become one of the greatest and most formidable the world has ever seen. Perhaps five hundred people who act directly under the Continental Congress, and five hundred thousand who act under those five hundred, all feel a proportionate rise in their own importance. Almost every individual of the governing party in America currently occupies, in his own mind, a station superior not only to anything he had held before but to anything he had ever expected to hold. Unless some new object of ambition is offered either to him or to his leaders, if he has the ordinary spirit of a man, he will die in defense of that station.
elegant: Continental Congress members -- former shopkeepers, tradesmen, and lawyers -- now feel greater importance than Europe's greatest subjects. They are designing a government for what promises to become one of history's most formidable empires. Every individual in the American governing party now occupies a station beyond anything previously imagined. Without some new object of ambition to redirect them, they will die defending their newfound importance.
summary: Smith observes that Continental Congress members have been transformed from ordinary merchants and lawyers into statesmen designing a potentially great empire. This unprecedented rise in status, felt by every level of the American governing party, means they will fight to the death to preserve their new importance unless offered an alternative object of ambition.
distilled: American revolutionary leaders, elevated from tradesmen to statesmen designing a new empire, will die defending their unprecedented rise in status unless offered an alternative ambition.
notes: Continental Congress members' transformation -- psychological power of status elevation -- cascade of importance through governing hierarchy -- prediction of formidable American empire -- cross-reference to 4.7.171-172 on political ambition

refashioned: President Henault has remarked that we now read with pleasure the accounts of many small events during the Catholic League which, when they occurred, were probably not considered particularly newsworthy. But at the time, he says, every man fancied himself important, and the countless memoirs from that period were mostly written by people who took pleasure in recording and magnifying events in which they imagined themselves to have been significant actors. How stubbornly the city of Paris defended itself on that occasion -- what a terrible famine it endured rather than submit to the best and later most beloved of all French kings -- is well known. Most of the citizens, or those who led them, fought in defense of their own importance, which they foresaw would end the moment the old government was restored. Our colonies, unless they can be persuaded to consent to a union, will very likely defend themselves against the best of all mother countries as stubbornly as Paris defended itself against one of the best of kings.
elegant: Henault observed that during the Catholic League, every participant fancied himself important and wrote memoirs magnifying his role. Paris endured terrible famine rather than submit to Henry IV because its citizens fought to preserve their political importance. American colonies will defend themselves against Britain with equal stubbornness unless persuaded to accept a union -- people fight hardest when defending their own status.
summary: Smith cites Henault's observation about the Catholic League: Paris endured famine rather than submit to Henry IV because citizens fought to preserve their political importance. He predicts the American colonies will resist Britain with equal determination unless offered a union, since people defend their status most fiercely.
distilled: Just as Paris endured famine rather than surrender its leaders' political importance to Henry IV, America will resist Britain unless offered a union that preserves colonial leaders' status.
notes: Catholic League analogy -- Paris siege under Henry IV -- President Henault reference -- defense of political status -- prediction about American resistance -- cross-reference to 4.7.172-173 on ambition and resistance

refashioned: The concept of political representation was unknown in ancient times. When the citizens of one state were granted citizenship in another, their only way to exercise that right was to travel in person to vote and deliberate with the citizens of that other state. Admitting the majority of Italy's inhabitants to Roman citizenship completely destroyed the Roman Republic. It became impossible to distinguish Roman citizens from non-citizens. No tribe could identify its own members. Any mob could infiltrate the popular assemblies, drive out the actual citizens, and decide the republic's affairs as though they were legitimate participants. But if America were to send fifty or sixty new representatives to Parliament, the doorkeeper of the House of Commons would have no difficulty distinguishing members from non-members. Though the Roman constitution was necessarily destroyed by the union with Italy's allied states, there is not the slightest probability that the British constitution would be harmed by union with the colonies. On the contrary, that constitution would be completed by it and seems imperfect without it. The assembly that deliberates on the affairs of every part of the empire ought to have representatives from every part. I do not claim such a union could be easily achieved or that great difficulties might not arise in its execution. But I have heard of no difficulties that appear truly insurmountable. The principal obstacles arise not from the nature of things but from the prejudices and opinions of people on both sides of the Atlantic.
elegant: Ancient representation required physical presence, so admitting all Italians to Roman citizenship destroyed the Republic -- assemblies were overrun by unidentifiable crowds. But modern representation through elected members eliminates this problem. Fifty or sixty American representatives in Parliament would pose no identification difficulties. Union with the colonies would not harm the British constitution but complete it, since an empire's deliberative assembly should represent every part. The obstacles are not insurmountable -- they arise from prejudice, not the nature of things.
summary: Smith argues that modern representative government -- unlike ancient direct democracy -- makes imperial union feasible. While admitting all Italians to Roman citizenship destroyed the Republic through unmanageable assemblies, American representatives in Parliament would strengthen rather than weaken the British constitution. The obstacles to union are prejudice, not practical impossibility.
distilled: Modern representative government makes British-American union feasible -- unlike Rome's destruction by direct citizenship, parliamentary representation would complete rather than undermine the British constitution.
notes: Ancient vs. modern representation -- Roman Republic destroyed by Italian citizenship -- parliamentary representation as solution -- British constitution "completed" by colonial representation -- obstacles are prejudice not substance -- cross-reference to 4.7.172 on proportional representation

refashioned: We on this side of the Atlantic fear that the multitude of American representatives would upset the constitutional balance, increasing either the influence of the Crown or the force of democracy excessively. But if the number of American representatives were proportional to American tax contributions, then the number of people to be managed would increase in exact proportion to the means of managing them, and vice versa. The monarchical and democratic elements of the constitution would, after union, stand in exactly the same relative balance as before.
elegant: The fear that American representatives would upset the constitutional balance is unfounded. If representation is proportional to taxation, the number of people to manage increases exactly in proportion to the means of managing them. The balance between monarchy and democracy would remain unchanged after union.
summary: Smith addresses the fear that American representatives would upset Britain's constitutional balance between monarchy and democracy. If representation is proportional to taxation, the balance of political forces would remain exactly the same after union as before.
distilled: American representation proportional to taxation would preserve the exact constitutional balance between monarchy and democracy.
notes: Constitutional balance concerns -- proportional representation preserves equilibrium -- monarchy vs. democracy balance -- political fears of colonial inclusion -- cross-reference to 4.7.175 on union proposal

refashioned: People on the other side of the Atlantic fear that distance from the seat of government might expose them to many oppressions. But their parliamentary representatives, whose number should be considerable from the outset, would easily protect them from all oppression. Distance would not much weaken the representative's dependence on his constituents -- he would still understand that he owed his seat and all its consequent status to their goodwill. It would therefore be in his interest to cultivate that goodwill by denouncing, with all the authority of a legislator, any outrage committed by civil or military officers in those remote parts of the empire. Americans might also comfort themselves with a reasonable expectation: their distance from government would not last very long. Given the rapid progress of that country in wealth, population, and development, within perhaps little more than a century the revenue from American taxation might exceed that from British taxation. The seat of empire would then naturally shift to the part of the empire contributing most to its general defense and support.
elegant: Americans fear oppression from distant government, but substantial parliamentary representation would protect them effectively. Representatives would remain dependent on colonial voters for their seats and would vigorously champion their constituents' interests. Moreover, America's rapid growth in wealth and population means that within a century, American tax revenue might exceed Britain's -- at which point the seat of empire would naturally shift to America.
summary: Smith addresses American fears of distant oppression by arguing that substantial parliamentary representation would protect colonial interests. He makes the remarkable prediction that America's rapid economic growth could lead to American tax revenue exceeding Britain's within a century, at which point the imperial capital would naturally move across the Atlantic.
distilled: American representatives would protect against distant oppression, and America's rapid growth might shift the seat of empire westward within a century as colonial revenue surpasses Britain's.
notes: Remarkable prediction of American economic supremacy -- seat of empire following revenue -- representative accountability over distance -- prophetic vision of American growth -- cross-reference to 4.7.175-176 on union feasibility

refashioned: The discovery of America and the discovery of the sea route to the East Indies via the Cape of Good Hope are the two greatest and most important events recorded in human history. Their consequences have already been enormous, but in the short period of two to three centuries since these discoveries, the full extent of their consequences cannot yet be seen. What benefits or misfortunes for humanity may ultimately result from these great events, no human wisdom can foresee. By connecting the most distant parts of the world -- enabling them to relieve each other's needs, increase each other's enjoyments, and stimulate each other's industry -- their general tendency would seem to be beneficial. Yet for the natives of both the East and West Indies, all the commercial benefits that may have resulted from these events have been overwhelmed by the dreadful misfortunes they have caused. These misfortunes, however, seem to have arisen from accident rather than from anything inherent in the events themselves. At the time these discoveries were made, European military superiority happened to be so overwhelming that Europeans could commit every sort of injustice in those remote countries with impunity. In time, perhaps, the natives of those countries may grow stronger, or Europeans may grow weaker, and the inhabitants of all the world's different regions may achieve that equality of power which, by inspiring mutual fear, alone can restrain the injustice of independent nations into some respect for each other's rights. Nothing seems more likely to establish this equality of power than the mutual exchange of knowledge and improvements that extensive global commerce naturally -- or rather necessarily -- carries with it.
elegant: The discovery of America and the Cape route to the East Indies are history's two greatest events, whose full consequences remain unseen after only two or three centuries. By connecting distant parts of the world, they tend toward mutual benefit through relieved wants, increased enjoyments, and stimulated industry. Yet for natives of both Indies, commercial benefits have been buried under dreadful misfortunes -- not inherent in the discoveries but caused by Europe's accidental military superiority enabling unchecked injustice. Eventually, the global exchange of knowledge that commerce naturally carries may equalize power among nations, and mutual fear may establish respect for rights where justice alone cannot.
summary: Smith calls the discovery of America and the Cape route to the East Indies the two greatest events in human history. While their tendency toward connecting distant peoples is beneficial, European military superiority turned them into instruments of injustice for indigenous peoples. Smith hopes that global commerce's natural spread of knowledge will eventually equalize power among nations, creating mutual restraint.
distilled: The discoveries of America and the Cape route are history's greatest events, beneficial in tendency but catastrophic for indigenous peoples due to European military superiority -- a disparity that global commerce may eventually correct.
notes: Two greatest events in history -- globalization's double-edged nature -- European military superiority as accident of timing -- indigenous suffering -- equality of power through knowledge exchange -- commerce as civilizing force -- remarkably prescient on globalization

refashioned: In the meantime, one of the principal effects of those discoveries has been to elevate the mercantile system to a degree of splendor and glory it could never otherwise have achieved. The mercantile system aims to enrich a nation through trade and manufactures rather than through the improvement and cultivation of land -- through the industry of towns rather than of the countryside. But as a consequence of those discoveries, European commercial towns, instead of serving as manufacturers and carriers for only a small portion of the world (the Atlantic coast of Europe and the countries around the Baltic and Mediterranean), have become manufacturers for the numerous and thriving cultivators of America, and carriers -- and in some respects manufacturers too -- for nearly all the different nations of Asia, Africa, and America. Two new worlds have been opened to their industry, each far greater and more extensive than the old one, and the market of one of them growing still larger every day.
elegant: These discoveries elevated the mercantile system to unprecedented splendor. European commercial towns, once manufacturers and carriers for a small portion of the world, now serve the thriving cultivators of America and trade with nearly all nations of Asia, Africa, and America. Two new worlds have opened to their industry, each larger than the old, with one market still growing.
summary: The great discoveries transformed European commercial towns from manufacturers and carriers for a small coastal region into suppliers for the entire world. The mercantile system gained unprecedented reach and splendor by opening two new worlds to European industry, with the American market continually expanding.
distilled: The discoveries of America and the East Indies elevated the mercantile system by transforming European towns from regional manufacturers into suppliers for two vast new worlds.
notes: Mercantile system's expansion through discovery -- European towns as global manufacturers and carriers -- two new worlds of commerce -- expanding American market -- cross-reference to 4.7.178 on discovery consequences

refashioned: The countries that possess American colonies and trade directly with the East Indies enjoy the entire outward show and splendor of this great commerce. Other countries, however, despite all the jealous restrictions intended to exclude them, frequently enjoy a greater share of its real benefits. The colonies of Spain and Portugal, for example, give more real encouragement to the industry of other countries than to that of Spain and Portugal themselves. In the single article of linen, consumption in those colonies reportedly amounts to more than three million pounds sterling annually (though I do not vouch for the exact figure). But this enormous consumption is supplied almost entirely by France, Flanders, Holland, and Germany. Spain and Portugal furnish only a small part of it. The capital that supplies the colonies with this vast quantity of linen is distributed annually among and provides income to the inhabitants of those other countries. Only the profits are spent in Spain and Portugal, where they help support the extravagant spending of the merchants of Cadiz and Lisbon.
elegant: Colonial powers enjoy the show and splendor of colonial commerce, but other nations often capture more real benefit. Spanish and Portuguese colonies stimulate other countries' industries more than their own -- nearly all the three million pounds of linen consumed annually in those colonies comes from France, Flanders, Holland, and Germany. The capital and employment stay in those supplying countries; only the profits reach Spain and Portugal to fund merchant extravagance in Cadiz and Lisbon.
summary: Despite monopolistic restrictions, countries without colonies often benefit more from colonial trade than the colonial powers themselves. Spain and Portugal's colonies consume vast quantities of linen supplied by France, Holland, and Germany, distributing capital and employment to those countries while only profits reach the Iberian merchants.
distilled: Colonial trade restrictions give monopoly powers the splendor of commerce but other nations the substance, as Spain's colonies are largely supplied by France, Holland, and Germany.
notes: Show vs. substance in colonial trade -- linen trade example (three million sterling) -- Spain and Portugal as middlemen -- real benefits flowing to supplying nations -- Cadiz and Lisbon merchant extravagance -- cross-reference to 4.7.154 on merchant spending

refashioned: Even the regulations by which each nation tries to secure exclusive trade with its own colonies are frequently more harmful to the favored country than to the countries they are meant to exclude. The unjust oppression of other countries' industry rebounds, so to speak, upon the oppressors and crushes their own industry more than it does that of others. Under these regulations, for example, the Hamburg merchant must ship his linen destined for America to London first, and must also bring back through London the tobacco he wants for the German market, since he can neither ship directly to America nor import directly from there. This probably forces him to sell the linen somewhat cheaper and buy the tobacco somewhat dearer than he otherwise would, reducing his profits. However, in this Hamburg-to-London trade, he receives his capital returns much more quickly than in a direct trade with America, even assuming (which is far from the case) that American payments were as punctual as London's. In this restricted trade, therefore, his capital can continuously employ a much greater quantity of German industry than would be possible in the direct trade from which he is excluded. Though this forced employment may be less profitable for him personally, it cannot be less beneficial to his country. The opposite is true for the London merchant. The colonial monopoly naturally draws his capital into an employment that may be more profitable to him personally but, because of its slow returns, is less beneficial to his country.
elegant: Colonial trade restrictions often harm the monopoly-holding nation more than the excluded ones. A Hamburg merchant forced to trade with America through London gets faster capital returns than direct American trade would provide, employing more German industry despite lower personal profits. But the London merchant, drawn by the monopoly into slow-returning colonial trade, diverts capital from employments more beneficial to Britain. The intended victims of restriction benefit from faster turnover while the monopolists suffer from slower returns.
summary: Smith demonstrates that colonial trade restrictions paradoxically harm the monopoly power more than the excluded nations. The Hamburg merchant, forced through London, gets faster returns that employ more German industry. The London merchant, attracted by monopoly profits, ties up capital in slow colonial trade that serves Britain less well than faster domestic alternatives.
distilled: Colonial trade monopolies backfire: excluded nations benefit from faster capital returns in alternative trades, while the monopoly power suffers from capital locked in slow-returning colonial commerce.
notes: Monopoly as self-harm -- Hamburg merchant example -- capital turnover rates -- speed of returns vs. profit rates -- London merchant drawn into slow colonial trade -- cross-reference to 4.7.100-153 on monopoly effects on capital allocation

refashioned: After all the unjust attempts by every European country to monopolize the entire advantage of trade with its own colonies, no country has managed to monopolize anything except the expense of supporting those colonies in peacetime and defending them in wartime under the oppressive authority it claims over them. Every country has fully monopolized the costs and inconveniences of colonial possession. The benefits of colonial trade it has been forced to share with many other countries.
elegant: Despite every attempt to monopolize colonial trade, European powers have succeeded only in monopolizing the costs -- peacetime support and wartime defense. The commercial benefits they have been forced to share with other nations.
summary: No European power has successfully monopolized the benefits of colonial trade, only its costs. Every nation has claimed full ownership of the expenses of colonial governance and defense while being forced to share the actual commercial advantages with other countries.
distilled: European colonial powers have monopolized only the costs of empire while being forced to share the commercial benefits with other nations.
notes: Monopoly of costs, not benefits -- summary of colonial trade argument -- costs fully retained, benefits widely shared -- cross-reference to 4.7.159-162 on imperial costs vs. benefits

refashioned: At first glance, the monopoly of America's great commerce naturally seems like an acquisition of the highest value. To the undiscerning eye of reckless ambition, it presents itself amid the confused scramble of politics and war as a dazzling prize worth fighting for. Yet the very quality that makes this object so dazzling -- the immense scale of the commerce -- is precisely what makes monopolizing it harmful. It causes one particular type of employment, which is inherently less advantageous to the country than most other employments, to absorb a much larger proportion of national capital than would naturally flow to it.
elegant: The monopoly of American trade appears dazzling precisely because the commerce is so vast. But this immense scale is what makes the monopoly harmful -- it draws a disproportionate share of national capital into a trade that is inherently less advantageous than most alternatives.
summary: The apparent splendor of the American trade monopoly is actually the source of its harm. The sheer scale of the commerce makes it a dazzling political prize, but that same scale means the monopoly absorbs far more national capital than would naturally flow into a trade whose returns are inherently less advantageous than alternatives.
distilled: The dazzling scale of American trade makes its monopoly appear valuable but actually causes it to absorb disproportionate national capital into a less advantageous employment.
notes: Dazzle of scale conceals harm -- monopoly as capital misallocator -- inherently less advantageous distant trade -- cross-reference to 4.7.182 on monopoly of costs

refashioned: As shown in the second book, the mercantile capital of every country naturally seeks the employment most advantageous to that country. If employed in the carrying trade, the country becomes a hub for the goods of all countries whose trade that capital handles. But the owner of that capital naturally wants to sell as many of those goods as possible domestically, saving himself the trouble, risk, and expense of re-exporting. He will therefore gladly sell goods at home not only at a much lower price but with somewhat smaller profit than he might earn by shipping them abroad. He naturally tries to convert his carrying trade into a foreign trade of consumption. If his capital is then employed in a foreign trade of consumption, he will for the same reason try to sell as much as possible at home of the domestic goods he collects for export, thereby converting his foreign trade of consumption into a domestic trade. The mercantile capital of every country thus naturally gravitates toward nearby rather than distant employment, toward trades with frequent returns rather than slow ones, toward trades that support the greatest amount of productive labor at home, and toward the employment that is ordinarily most advantageous to the country. It naturally avoids the opposite in each case.
elegant: Capital naturally seeks the most advantageous nearby employment. A merchant in the carrying trade prefers selling goods domestically to save on re-export costs. A merchant in foreign trade prefers selling at home what he gathers for export. Capital thus naturally gravitates from distant to near employment, from slow returns to fast, from less to more domestic productive labor -- always toward what best serves the country.
summary: Smith describes how mercantile capital naturally gravitates toward the most advantageous domestic employment. Merchants in carrying trade try to sell domestically; those in foreign trade try to convert exports into domestic sales. Capital naturally favors near over distant trades, fast over slow returns, and maximum domestic productive employment.
distilled: Capital naturally gravitates from distant to near employment, from slow to fast returns, and toward maximum domestic productive labor -- always seeking the most advantageous use for the country.
notes: Natural capital allocation -- carrying trade to foreign trade to domestic trade progression -- capital's preference hierarchy: near over distant, fast over slow returns -- domestic productive labor maximization -- cross-reference to Book II on capital employment

refashioned: However, if in any of those distant employments that are ordinarily less advantageous, profit rises somewhat above the level needed to offset the natural preference for nearer trades, this higher profit will draw capital away from nearer employments until profits across all trades return to their proper level. This temporarily elevated profit is evidence that, in the current circumstances of society, those distant trades are somewhat understocked relative to other trades, and that the society's capital is not distributed in the most efficient manner across all its different employments.
elegant: When distant trades earn above-normal profits, capital flows from nearer trades until all profits equalize. This temporary premium signals that distant trades are understocked and capital is inefficiently distributed across the economy.
summary: Above-normal profits in distant trades naturally attract capital from nearer ones until profits equalize across all sectors. Such a profit differential signals that distant trades are understocked and that society's capital is not optimally distributed.
distilled: Above-normal profits in distant trades signal capital misallocation and naturally attract investment until profits equalize across all sectors.
notes: Profit equalization mechanism -- capital flowing to understocked trades -- signal function of above-normal profits -- efficient capital distribution -- cross-reference to 4.7.184 on natural capital allocation

refashioned: This profit differential is evidence that something is being bought too cheaply or sold too dearly, and that some particular class of citizens is being oppressed -- either by paying more or receiving less than is consistent with the equality that ought to prevail among all classes and that naturally does prevail. Although the same amount of capital can never support as much productive labor in a distant employment as in a nearby one, a distant employment may be just as necessary for society's welfare as a nearby one. The goods that the distant trade deals in may be essential for carrying on many of the nearer trades.
elegant: Above-normal distant trade profits indicate someone is being overcharged or underpaid -- a violation of the equality that should prevail among citizens. While distant trades employ less domestic labor than near ones, they may be essential to society, providing goods needed by the nearer trades themselves.
summary: Abnormal profit differentials between trades indicate that some class of citizens is being exploited. Though distant trades employ less domestic labor per unit of capital, they may be essential to society by supplying goods needed for nearer trades.
distilled: Abnormal trade profits signal exploitation of some citizen class, yet distant trades -- though less productive domestically -- may supply goods essential to nearer trades.
notes: Profit differentials as exploitation indicators -- equality among citizen classes -- distant trades' essential role in supply chains -- productive labor differences by trade distance -- cross-reference to 4.7.185 on profit equalization

refashioned: But if the profits of those dealing in such goods are above their proper level, those goods will be sold above their natural price, and everyone engaged in nearer trades will be more or less harmed by this inflated price. Their interest therefore requires that some capital be withdrawn from those nearer trades and directed toward the distant one, in order to bring its profits down to their proper level and the prices of its goods to their natural level. In this special case, the public interest requires that capital be redirected from ordinarily more advantageous employments to one that is ordinarily less advantageous. And in this special case, the natural interests and inclinations of individuals coincide exactly with the public interest, just as they do in all ordinary cases, leading people to voluntarily shift capital from near to distant trades.
elegant: When distant trade profits are excessive, their goods are overpriced and nearer trades suffer. The public interest then requires capital to flow from near to distant trades to normalize profits and prices. In this case, as in all ordinary cases, private interests naturally align with public interests -- individuals voluntarily redirect capital where it is most needed.
summary: When distant trade profits are abnormally high, the resulting overpriced goods harm nearer trades. The public interest requires capital to shift from near to distant trades to normalize prices. Smith emphasizes that private self-interest naturally drives this reallocation, aligning with the public good in both ordinary and extraordinary circumstances.
distilled: Private self-interest naturally directs capital from over-supplied near trades to under-supplied distant ones, aligning individual incentives with the public need for price normalization.
notes: Natural price mechanism -- self-interest aligning with public interest -- capital reallocation from near to distant trades -- invisible hand principle applied -- cross-reference to 4.7.185-186 on profit equalization

refashioned: It is thus that the private interests and passions of individuals naturally lead them to direct their capital toward the employments ordinarily most advantageous to society. But if this natural preference causes too much capital to concentrate in those employments, the resulting fall in their profits and the rise in profits elsewhere immediately prompts people to correct this misallocation. Without any intervention of law, therefore, the private interests and passions of individuals naturally lead them to divide and distribute society's total capital among all its different employments as nearly as possible in the proportion most beneficial to the whole society.
elegant: Private interest naturally directs capital toward the most socially advantageous employments. When over-investment in any sector depresses its profits, capital naturally redistributes to maintain the optimal balance. Without any legal intervention, self-interest alone distributes society's capital in the proportion most beneficial to all.
summary: Smith articulates his central insight: private self-interest naturally distributes capital across all sectors in the proportion most beneficial to society. When any sector attracts too much capital, falling profits automatically redirect investment elsewhere, maintaining optimal allocation without legal intervention.
distilled: Without any legal intervention, private self-interest naturally distributes society's capital across all sectors in the proportion most beneficial to the whole.
notes: Core invisible hand argument -- self-regulating capital allocation -- profit signals as natural guidance -- no legal intervention needed -- cross-reference to 4.7.187 on natural alignment of private and public interest -- foundational passage of free market theory
