refashioned: All the various regulations of the mercantile system necessarily distort this natural and most advantageous distribution of capital to some degree. But those concerning the trades with America and the East Indies distort it more than any others, because those two great trades absorb more capital than any other two branches of commerce. The regulations that cause this distortion differ in the two trades, however. Monopoly is the primary instrument of both, but it operates differently in each case. Indeed, monopoly of one kind or another seems to be the only instrument the mercantile system employs.
elegant: All mercantile regulations distort the natural distribution of capital, but those governing American and East Indian trade cause the greatest distortion because these trades absorb the most capital. Both rely on monopoly as their instrument, though the monopoly operates differently in each case. Monopoly is, indeed, the mercantile system's sole engine.
summary: Mercantile regulations distort the natural capital distribution, with American and East Indian trade regulations causing the greatest distortion due to their enormous capital absorption. Both rely on monopoly, though of different types. Smith concludes that monopoly in various forms is the mercantile system's only real instrument.
distilled: The mercantile system's regulations distort natural capital allocation, with American and East Indian trade monopolies causing the greatest distortion by absorbing the most capital.
notes: Monopoly as sole instrument of mercantile system -- American and East Indian trades as greatest distortions -- different types of monopoly -- transition to East India Company analysis -- cross-reference to 4.7.188 on natural capital distribution

refashioned: In the American trade, every nation tries to monopolize the entire market of its own colonies by excluding all other nations from direct trade with them. For most of the sixteenth century, the Portuguese tried to manage East Indian trade the same way, claiming exclusive sailing rights in the Indian seas on the grounds that they had first discovered the route. The Dutch still exclude all other European nations from direct trade with their spice islands. These monopolies are clearly directed against all other European nations, who are thereby not only shut out from a trade they might usefully have entered but are also forced to buy the goods of that trade at somewhat higher prices than if they could import them directly from the producing countries.
elegant: In American trade, each nation excludes others from its colonial market. Portugal claimed exclusive Indian Ocean navigation rights in the sixteenth century; the Dutch still bar Europeans from their spice islands. These monopolies harm excluded nations doubly: they cannot enter potentially profitable trades, and they must pay higher prices for goods they cannot import directly.
summary: Each European nation monopolizes trade with its own American colonies. Portugal claimed exclusive Indian Ocean rights, and the Dutch still exclude Europeans from their spice islands. These monopolies harm excluded nations by both closing potentially profitable trades to them and forcing them to pay higher import prices.
distilled: Colonial trade monopolies exclude other European nations from profitable commerce and force them to pay inflated prices for goods they cannot import directly.
notes: Types of colonial monopoly -- Portuguese Indian Ocean claims -- Dutch spice island exclusion -- double harm: closed markets and inflated prices -- cross-reference to 4.7.189 on different monopoly types

refashioned: Since the decline of Portuguese power, however, no European nation has claimed exclusive sailing rights in the Indian seas, whose principal ports are now open to all European ships. Yet in every European country except Portugal (and recently France), the East India trade has been granted to an exclusive company. This type of monopoly is established against the very nation that creates it. The majority of that nation's people are not only excluded from a trade they might profitably enter but are also forced to pay higher prices for East India goods than they would if the trade were open to all their countrymen. Since the English East India Company was established, for example, other English inhabitants have had to pay, in the price of East India goods, not only whatever extraordinary profits the Company has earned through its monopoly but also the cost of all the extraordinary waste inevitably caused by the fraud and mismanagement inherent in running such a large enterprise. The absurdity of this second type of monopoly is therefore much more obvious than that of the first.
elegant: Since Portugal's decline, Indian Ocean ports are open to all European ships, yet every country except Portugal and France has given its East India trade to an exclusive company. Unlike colonial monopolies directed at foreigners, this monopoly is directed against the nation's own citizens -- excluding them from trade and forcing them to pay inflated prices that cover both monopoly profits and the company's inevitable waste and mismanagement. This self-inflicted monopoly is far more absurd than the colonial type.
summary: Unlike colonial monopolies that exclude foreign nations, East India Company monopolies are directed against the monopoly-granting nation's own citizens. English consumers pay not only the Company's monopoly profits but also the costs of waste and mismanagement inherent in such large enterprises. Smith finds this self-inflicted monopoly far more absurd than the colonial variety.
distilled: East India Company monopolies are directed against a nation's own citizens, forcing them to pay both monopoly profits and the costs of corporate waste and mismanagement.
notes: Two types of monopoly: anti-foreign vs. anti-domestic -- East India Company as self-inflicted harm -- monopoly profits plus waste costs -- corporate mismanagement inherent in exclusive companies -- cross-reference to 4.7.190 on colonial monopoly type

refashioned:
Both types of monopoly distort the natural distribution of society's capital to some degree, but they do not always distort it in the same way.

Monopolies of the first kind -- colonial trade monopolies -- always attract a larger proportion of society's capital to the particular trade than would flow there naturally.
elegant: Both monopoly types distort capital distribution, but differently. Colonial monopolies always attract more capital to the protected trade than would flow there naturally.
summary: Both colonial monopolies and exclusive company monopolies distort capital allocation, but in different directions. Colonial monopolies consistently draw more capital into the protected trade than natural market forces would.
distilled: Colonial trade monopolies invariably attract more capital to the protected trade than natural market forces would direct there.
notes: Two monopoly types contrasted -- colonial monopoly always over-attracts capital -- capital distortion analysis -- cross-reference to 4.7.190-191 on the two types

refashioned: Monopolies of the second kind -- exclusive company monopolies -- may sometimes attract capital toward their particular trade and sometimes repel it, depending on circumstances. In poor countries, they naturally attract more capital than would otherwise flow there. In rich countries, they naturally repel a good deal of capital that would otherwise enter the trade.
elegant: Exclusive company monopolies have variable effects: in poor countries they attract more capital than would otherwise flow to the trade, while in rich countries they repel capital that would naturally enter it.
summary: Unlike colonial monopolies which always attract excess capital, exclusive company monopolies have different effects depending on a country's wealth. In poor countries they attract capital into the trade; in rich countries they repel capital that would naturally have entered.
distilled: Exclusive company monopolies attract capital in poor countries but repel it in rich ones, with opposite effects depending on the host nation's wealth.
notes: Variable effects of exclusive companies -- poor vs. rich country distinction -- capital attraction vs. repulsion -- cross-reference to 4.7.192 on monopoly types

refashioned: Poor countries like Sweden and Denmark would probably never have sent a single ship to the East Indies without an exclusive company. Establishing such a company necessarily encourages adventurers. The monopoly protects them from all competitors in the home market, and they compete on equal terms with other nations' traders in foreign markets. The monopoly guarantees them large profits on a considerable volume of goods and the chance of considerable profit on a great volume. Without such extraordinary encouragement, the small-capital traders of such poor countries would probably never have risked their limited resources on so distant and uncertain a venture as the East India trade must naturally have appeared to them.
elegant: Poor countries like Sweden and Denmark needed exclusive companies to venture into East Indian trade at all. The monopoly encouraged adventurers by guaranteeing home market protection and the prospect of large profits. Without it, traders with small capitals would never have risked so distant and uncertain a venture.
summary: Smith acknowledges that exclusive companies served a purpose in poor countries like Sweden and Denmark, where traders with limited capital would never have risked the distant and uncertain East India trade without the security of monopoly protection and guaranteed home market profits.
distilled: Exclusive East India companies were necessary in poor countries like Sweden and Denmark, where small-capital traders needed monopoly protection to risk distant and uncertain ventures.
notes: Exclusive companies justified in poor countries -- Sweden and Denmark examples -- risk mitigation through monopoly -- small capital traders' rational hesitation -- exception to general anti-monopoly argument -- cross-reference to 4.7.193 on variable effects

refashioned: A rich country like Holland, by contrast, would probably send many more ships to the East Indies under free trade than it actually does. The limited capital of the Dutch East India Company probably drives away from that trade many large mercantile capitals that would otherwise enter it. Holland's mercantile capital is so enormous that it is constantly overflowing -- sometimes into foreign public funds, sometimes into loans to foreign traders and adventurers, sometimes into the most roundabout foreign trades, and sometimes into the carrying trade. With all nearby employments fully stocked and every investment placed that can earn a tolerable profit, Dutch capital necessarily flows toward the most distant employments. If the East India trade were completely free, it would probably absorb the greater part of this surplus capital. The East Indies offer a market for European manufactures, for gold and silver, and for various American products that is larger and more extensive than Europe and America combined.
elegant: Rich Holland would trade far more with the East Indies under free competition. The Dutch East India Company's limited capital actually drives away many large merchants who could profitably enter the trade. With all nearby investments saturated, Holland's surplus capital overflows into foreign funds, loans, and roundabout trades instead of flowing to the vast East Indian market -- which exceeds Europe and America combined.
summary: In contrast to poor countries, the Dutch East India Company's monopoly actually restricts trade in wealthy Holland. With all domestic investments saturated, surplus Dutch capital overflows into less productive foreign outlets rather than entering the enormous East Indian market, which offers more opportunities than Europe and America combined.
distilled: In rich Holland, the East India Company's monopoly restricts trade by driving surplus capital into less productive foreign investments instead of the vast East Indian market.
notes: Rich country monopoly restricts trade -- Holland's overflowing capital -- domestic investment saturation -- East Indian market larger than Europe and America combined -- Dutch East India Company as constraint -- cross-reference to 4.7.193-194 on rich vs. poor country effects

refashioned: Every distortion of the natural distribution of capital is necessarily harmful to the society where it occurs, whether by repelling capital from a trade it would naturally enter or by attracting capital to a trade it would not. If Holland's East India trade would be larger without an exclusive company, that country must suffer a considerable loss from having capital excluded from the most suitable employment for that market. Similarly, if Sweden's and Denmark's East India trade would be smaller -- or more likely, would not exist at all -- without an exclusive company, those two countries must also suffer from having capital drawn into an employment somewhat unsuited to their present circumstances. It would be better for them, perhaps, to buy East India goods from other nations, even at a somewhat higher price, rather than divert such a large portion of their small capital to so distant a trade with such slow returns -- a trade in which that capital can support so little productive labor at home, where productive labor is so much needed, where so little is accomplished, and where so much remains to be done.
elegant: Any distortion of natural capital allocation harms society -- whether by repelling capital from trades it should enter or attracting it to trades it should not. Holland loses by having capital excluded from its natural East Indian trade. Sweden and Denmark lose by diverting scarce capital to distant, slow-returning trade when their domestic economies desperately need productive labor. Such countries would be better off buying East India goods from others, even at higher prices.
summary: Smith argues that all capital allocation distortions are harmful. Holland's monopoly excludes capital from naturally profitable trade, while Sweden's and Denmark's monopolies divert scarce capital from needed domestic employment into distant, slow-returning trade. Poor countries would be better served buying East India goods at marked-up prices than misallocating their limited capital.
distilled: Capital distortions harm all countries: rich ones lose by excluding capital from natural trades, while poor ones lose by diverting scarce domestic capital into unsuitable distant ventures.
notes: Universal harm of capital distortion -- rich vs. poor country harms differ in kind -- opportunity cost of distant trade for poor countries -- productive labor needs at home -- buy goods vs. divert capital tradeoff -- cross-reference to 4.7.194-195 on Sweden, Denmark, and Holland

refashioned: Even if a country cannot conduct direct East India trade without an exclusive company, it does not follow that such a company should be established there. It only follows that such a country ought not, in its present circumstances, to trade directly with the East Indies. That exclusive companies are not generally necessary for conducting East India trade is sufficiently demonstrated by the experience of the Portuguese, who dominated nearly the entire trade for more than a century without any exclusive company.
elegant: A country's inability to trade directly with the East Indies without an exclusive company does not justify creating one -- it simply means the country should not yet trade there directly. Portugal proved exclusive companies are unnecessary by dominating East Indian trade for over a century without one.
summary: Smith argues that if a country cannot sustain direct East India trade without a monopoly company, the solution is not to create one but to refrain from direct trade entirely. Portugal's century-long dominance of the trade without any exclusive company proves such organizations are unnecessary.
distilled: If a country cannot trade with the East Indies without a monopoly company, it should not trade there at all -- as Portugal's century of dominance without one proves.
notes: Against exclusive companies even as temporary measures -- Portugal's century without exclusive company -- market readiness principle -- countries should trade only when naturally capable -- cross-reference to 4.7.194-196 on company effects

refashioned: It has been argued that no private merchant could have enough capital to maintain agents and factors in the various East Indian ports needed to assemble cargoes for his occasional ships. Without such capability, the difficulty of finding cargo might cause his ships to miss their return season, and the expense of such long delays would not only consume the entire profit of the venture but often cause considerable losses. This argument, however, if it proved anything at all, would prove that no great branch of trade could be conducted without an exclusive company -- which is contradicted by the experience of every nation.
elegant: The argument that no individual merchant could afford factors in East Indian ports -- and would therefore suffer costly delays finding cargoes -- proves too much. If valid, it would mean no great trade could operate without an exclusive company, which every nation's experience contradicts.
summary: Smith dismantles the argument that exclusive companies are needed because individual merchants cannot afford agents in distant ports. If this argument were valid, it would prove that no major trade could operate without monopoly companies -- a conclusion contradicted by universal experience.
distilled: The argument that individual merchants cannot afford distant agents proves too much -- if valid, no major trade could exist without exclusive companies, which experience contradicts.
notes: Reductio ad absurdum of exclusive company defense -- agent network argument -- individual vs. company capital -- experience of all nations contradicts monopoly necessity -- cross-reference to 4.7.197 on Portuguese success without company

refashioned: There is no great branch of trade in which any single merchant's capital is sufficient to carry on all the subordinate branches necessary to support the principal one. But when a nation is ready for a great branch of trade, some merchants naturally direct their capital toward the principal branch and others toward the subordinate ones. Though all the different branches are thereby conducted, it very seldom happens that they are all conducted by the capital of one single merchant. If a nation is ready for the East India trade, a portion of its capital will naturally divide itself among all the different branches of that trade. Some merchants will find it in their interest to reside in the East Indies and employ their capital there in assembling goods for the ships sent out by other merchants who remain in Europe.
elegant: No single merchant can fund all branches of a major trade, but when a nation is ready for one, different merchants naturally specialize in different branches. If a nation is mature enough for East Indian trade, some merchants will naturally reside in the East Indies to assemble cargoes while others remain in Europe to dispatch ships. The trade organizes itself through natural specialization.
summary: Smith argues that major trades naturally organize themselves through specialization -- no single merchant needs to fund all branches. When a nation is ready for East Indian trade, some merchants will naturally reside abroad to assemble cargoes while others remain in Europe, eliminating the supposed need for an exclusive company.
distilled: Major trades naturally organize through merchant specialization across branches, eliminating the need for any exclusive company to coordinate them.
notes: Natural division of labor in trade -- merchant specialization across branches -- East Indian resident merchants -- market readiness triggers natural organization -- cross-reference to 4.7.198 on individual merchant capabilities

refashioned: The settlements that various European nations have established in the East Indies, if taken from the exclusive companies that currently own them and placed under the sovereign's direct protection, would make residence there both safe and easy, at least for merchants of the particular nations that own those settlements. If the amount of capital that naturally tends toward the East India trade is insufficient at any given time to conduct all its branches, that is simply proof that the country is not yet ready for that trade. It would do better to buy East India goods for a while at higher prices from other European nations than to import them directly. What the country might lose from paying higher prices would seldom equal the loss it would sustain by diverting a large portion of its capital from other employments more necessary, more useful, or more suited to its circumstances than direct East India trade.
elegant: If colonial settlements were transferred from exclusive companies to sovereign protection, they would provide safe bases for free merchants. If a country's natural capital flow is insufficient for East Indian trade, this proves it is not ready -- it should buy from others at higher prices rather than divert capital from more suitable domestic employments. The higher price is cheaper than the opportunity cost of misallocated capital.
summary: Smith proposes transferring colonial settlements from exclusive companies to sovereign protection to facilitate free trade. If a country's natural capital flow cannot sustain East Indian trade, it should simply buy goods from other nations at premium prices rather than misallocate capital from more productive domestic uses.
distilled: Countries unready for direct East Indian trade should buy goods at premium prices from others rather than misallocate scarce capital, while settlements should be transferred from companies to sovereign protection.
notes: Settlement transfer from companies to sovereign -- market readiness indicator -- opportunity cost of capital misallocation -- buying at premium vs. diverting capital -- cross-reference to 4.7.196-199 on capital allocation

refashioned: Though Europeans possess many considerable settlements on the African coast and in the East Indies, they have not yet established in either region the kind of numerous and thriving colonies they built on the islands and continent of America. Africa, as well as several East Indian countries, is inhabited by peoples who were by no means as weak and defenseless as the unfortunate Americans. In proportion to the natural fertility of their lands, they were also much more numerous.
elegant: Europeans established thriving colonies in America but not in Africa or the East Indies, where indigenous peoples were far stronger, better defended, and more numerous in proportion to their lands' fertility than the vulnerable Americans.
summary: European colonization succeeded in America but failed to produce comparable settlements in Africa or the East Indies because the indigenous populations there were much stronger, better able to defend themselves, and far more numerous relative to their lands' fertility than the Americans.
distilled: Europeans colonized America successfully but not Africa or the East Indies, where indigenous peoples were far stronger, more numerous, and better able to resist.
notes: Comparative colonization success -- African and East Indian resistance -- indigenous military capacity -- population density differences -- American vulnerability -- cross-reference to 4.7.178 on European military superiority

refashioned: The most primitive nations of Africa and the East Indies were shepherding peoples; even the Hottentots were pastoralists. But the natives of every part of America except Mexico and Peru were hunters, and the difference in population that the same territory can support between shepherds and hunters is enormous. In Africa and the East Indies, it was therefore much harder to displace the natives and extend European plantations across the original inhabitants' lands. Furthermore, as already noted, the nature of exclusive companies is unfavorable to the growth of new colonies, and this has probably been the principal cause of the limited progress Europeans have made in the East Indies.
elegant: African and East Indian peoples were pastoralists who could sustain much larger populations than the hunter-gatherer Americans (except in Mexico and Peru), making them far harder to displace. Additionally, exclusive trading companies -- inherently hostile to colonial growth -- were probably the main reason for Europe's limited East Indian settlement.
summary: Smith explains limited European colonization in Africa and the East Indies by two factors: indigenous pastoralist populations were much denser and harder to displace than American hunter-gatherers, and exclusive trading companies, which are inherently unfavorable to colony growth, dominated European activity in those regions.
distilled: Denser pastoralist populations resisted European displacement more effectively than American hunter-gatherers, while exclusive trading companies further hindered colonial growth in Africa and the East Indies.
notes: Pastoralist vs. hunter-gatherer population density -- Mexico and Peru exceptions -- exclusive companies as colonial growth inhibitor -- Hottentots as pastoralists -- cross-reference to 4.7.201 on comparative colonization

refashioned: The Portuguese conducted trade with both Africa and the East Indies without any exclusive companies, and their settlements at Congo, Angola, and Benguela on the African coast, and at Goa in the East Indies -- though much depressed by superstition and bad government of every kind -- bear some resemblance to American colonies and are partly inhabited by Portuguese families established there for several generations. The Dutch settlements at the Cape of Good Hope and at Batavia are currently the most considerable European colonies in either Africa or the East Indies, and both are fortunate in their geographical situation.
elegant: Portugal traded with Africa and the East Indies without exclusive companies, and its long-established settlements at Congo, Angola, Benguela, and Goa -- despite bad governance -- resemble American colonies. The Dutch settlements at the Cape of Good Hope and Batavia are currently the most significant European colonies in those regions, both benefiting from exceptional geographic positions.
summary: Portuguese settlements in Africa and India, established without exclusive companies, developed into multi-generational communities resembling American colonies, though hampered by poor governance. The Dutch settlements at the Cape of Good Hope and Batavia became the most significant European colonies in these regions, aided by their advantageous locations.
distilled: Portuguese settlements in Africa and India grew into lasting communities without exclusive companies, while Dutch settlements at the Cape and Batavia thrived due to exceptional geographic advantages.
notes: Portuguese success without exclusive companies -- Congo, Angola, Benguela, Goa -- multi-generational settlements -- Dutch Cape Colony and Batavia -- geographic advantage -- bad governance and superstition as obstacles -- cross-reference to 4.7.197 on Portuguese experience

refashioned: The Cape of Good Hope was inhabited by people almost as primitive and quite as incapable of defending themselves as the natives of America. Moreover, it serves as the halfway point between Europe and the East Indies, where nearly every European ship stops on both outward and return voyages. Supplying those ships with fresh provisions, fruit, and sometimes wine alone provides an extensive market for the colony's surplus produce. What the Cape of Good Hope is between Europe and the East Indies, Batavia is among the principal East Indian countries. It lies on the most frequented route between India, China, and Japan, roughly midway along it. Nearly all ships sailing between Europe and China also call at Batavia. Beyond all this, it serves as the center and principal market of what is called the country trade of the East Indies -- not only the trade carried on by Europeans but also that conducted by native Indians. Vessels from China, Japan, Tonkin, Malacca, Cochin-China, and Celebes are frequently seen in its port.
elegant: The Cape of Good Hope thrived because its weak indigenous population offered no resistance, and every European ship stopped there for provisions on the route to the East Indies. Batavia occupied an equally strategic position as the midpoint between India, China, and Japan, and became the hub of both European and native Asian trade -- visited by ships from China, Japan, Tonkin, Malacca, Cochin-China, and Celebes.
summary: Both the Cape Colony and Batavia owed their success to exceptional geographic positions. The Cape was a mandatory provisioning stop on the Europe-to-East-Indies route with a vulnerable indigenous population. Batavia sat at the crossroads of Asian trade routes between India, China, and Japan, serving as the hub for both European and native Asian commerce.
distilled: The Cape Colony and Batavia thrived as strategic waypoints on global trade routes -- the Cape provisioning Europe-bound ships, Batavia serving as the hub of all Asian commerce.
notes: Strategic geographic advantage -- Cape as halfway house to East Indies -- Batavia as Asian trade hub -- country trade of East Indies -- native Indian, Chinese, Japanese commerce -- provisioning market -- cross-reference to 4.7.203 on Dutch settlements

refashioned:
Such advantageous positions enabled both colonies to overcome all the obstacles that the oppressive character of exclusive companies may have imposed on their growth. They enabled Batavia to overcome the additional disadvantage of perhaps the most unhealthy climate in the world.

The English and Dutch companies, though they have established no considerable colonies except the two just mentioned, have both made significant conquests in the East Indies. But the way they both govern their new subjects reveals the natural character of exclusive companies most clearly. In the spice islands, the Dutch are said to burn all the spices that a productive season yields beyond what they expect to sell in Europe at what they consider a sufficient profit. On islands where they have no settlements, they pay a premium to those who collect the young blossoms and green leaves of clove and nutmeg trees -- trees that grow naturally there but which this savage policy has now reportedly almost completely exterminated. Even on islands where they have settlements, they have reportedly greatly reduced the number of these trees.
elegant: Geographic advantage allowed both colonies to overcome the obstacles of exclusive company governance -- Batavia even survived the world's most unhealthy climate. But the companies' true character shows in their governing methods: the Dutch burn surplus spices to maintain prices, pay islanders to destroy young clove and nutmeg trees on unsettled islands, and have drastically reduced spice production even where they have settlements. This savage policy has nearly exterminated naturally growing spice trees.
summary: While geographic advantage enabled the Cape Colony and Batavia to overcome exclusive company mismanagement, the companies' governance elsewhere reveals their destructive nature. The Dutch deliberately burn surplus spices, pay to destroy clove and nutmeg trees on unsettled islands, and reduce production on settled ones -- a savage policy of artificial scarcity to maintain monopoly prices.
distilled: The Dutch East India Company's deliberate destruction of spice trees and burning of surplus crops to maintain monopoly prices reveals the savage and destructive nature of exclusive company governance.
notes: Dutch spice destruction policy -- artificial scarcity to maintain prices -- clove and nutmeg tree extermination -- Batavia's unhealthy climate -- exclusive company governance as inherently destructive -- Moluccas -- cross-reference to 4.7.203-204 on company settlements

refashioned: If production even on their own islands exceeded what suited their market, the Dutch suspect the natives might find ways to sell some of it to other nations. The best way to secure their monopoly, they believe, is to ensure that no more grows than what they themselves can carry to market. Through various forms of oppression, they have reduced the population of several Moluccan islands to barely enough to supply fresh provisions and other necessities to their own insignificant garrisons and the occasional ships that arrive for cargoes of spices. Under Portuguese rule, however, those islands were reportedly quite well populated.
elegant: The Dutch ensure their spice monopoly by limiting production to what they alone can sell, fearing any surplus might reach other nations through native intermediaries. Through systematic oppression, they have reduced the Moluccas' population to barely enough to supply their small garrisons -- islands that were well populated under Portuguese rule.
summary: The Dutch maintain their spice monopoly by reducing production to match their own capacity and depopulating the Moluccan islands through systematic oppression. Populations that were considerable under Portuguese rule have been reduced to barely enough to supply the Dutch garrisons with provisions.
distilled: The Dutch depopulated the Moluccas through systematic oppression to prevent any spice surplus from reaching other nations, reducing thriving populations to subsistence levels.
notes: Depopulation as monopoly strategy -- Moluccan population reduction -- comparison with Portuguese era -- artificial scarcity through population control -- exclusive company oppression -- cross-reference to 4.7.205 on spice destruction

refashioned: The English company has not yet had time to establish an equally destructive system in Bengal, but the direction of their governance has been exactly the same. It was not uncommon, I am reliably informed, for the chief -- meaning the senior clerk of a trading post -- to order a peasant to plow up a rich field of poppies and plant it with rice or another grain. The ostensible reason was to prevent food shortages, but the real reason was to give the chief an opportunity to sell at a better price a large quantity of opium he happened to have on hand. On other occasions, the order was reversed: a productive rice field was plowed up to make room for a poppy plantation when the chief anticipated extraordinary opium profits.
elegant: The English East India Company has not yet matched Dutch destructiveness in Bengal, but the tendency is identical. Company chiefs routinely ordered peasants to plow up poppy fields for rice -- not to prevent famine but to inflate opium prices for their own stock. When opium prices were rising, they ordered the reverse: destroying rice fields for poppy plantations. Production was manipulated entirely for private gain.
summary: The English East India Company's governance in Bengal follows the same destructive pattern as the Dutch in the Moluccas. Company officials routinely forced peasants to switch between poppy and rice cultivation, not for public welfare but to manipulate opium prices for their personal profit -- plowing up whichever crop best served their private speculations.
distilled: English East India Company officials in Bengal forced peasants to destroy crops and switch between opium and rice cultivation purely to manipulate prices for their personal profit.
notes: English East India Company in Bengal -- opium trade manipulation -- peasant crop coercion -- private profit disguised as famine prevention -- parallels with Dutch Moluccas policy -- cross-reference to 4.7.205-206 on Dutch destruction

refashioned: The Company's servants have on several occasions attempted to establish monopolies in their own favor over some of the most important branches not only of the foreign trade but also of the inland trade of the country. If allowed to continue, they would inevitably have tried to restrict production of the commodities they had monopolized -- not merely to the quantity they could purchase themselves but to what they could expect to sell at whatever profit they deemed sufficient.
elegant: Company servants repeatedly attempted to monopolize both foreign and domestic trade branches. Left unchecked, they would inevitably have restricted production to only what they could profitably sell -- extending monopoly control from trade to production itself.
summary: East India Company servants attempted to monopolize important branches of both foreign and domestic trade in India. Smith argues that unchecked, this would inevitably lead them to restrict production to match only their own profitable sales capacity.
distilled: Company servants' monopoly ambitions extended from controlling trade to restricting production itself, limiting output to only what they could sell at their desired profit level.
notes: Company servants' private monopolies -- foreign and inland trade -- production restriction as monopoly extension -- unchecked power trajectory -- cross-reference to 4.7.207 on crop manipulation

refashioned:
Within a century or two, the English Company's policy would probably have proven as completely destructive as the Dutch.

Nothing, however, could be more directly contrary to the real interest of these companies, considered as sovereigns of the countries they have conquered, than this destructive plan. In nearly all countries, the sovereign's revenue is derived from the people's revenue. The greater the people's revenue -- the greater the annual produce of their land and labor -- the more they can afford to pay the sovereign. It is therefore in the sovereign's interest to maximize that annual produce. This is particularly true of a sovereign whose revenue, like that of Bengal's ruler, derives mainly from a land rent, which necessarily corresponds to the quantity and value of what the land produces. Both quantity and value depend on market extent. Production will always roughly match consumption by those who can afford to pay for it, and the price they pay will always reflect the intensity of their competition. It is therefore in such a sovereign's interest to open the most extensive possible market for the country's produce, to allow the most perfect freedom of commerce to maximize the number and competition of buyers, and to abolish not only all monopolies but all restrictions on the transportation of domestic produce within the country, its export abroad, or the import of goods for which it can be exchanged. This approach is most likely to increase both the quantity and value of that produce, and consequently the sovereign's own share -- his own revenue.
elegant: The English Company's policy would have become as destructive as the Dutch within a century or two -- yet nothing could more directly contradict these companies' interests as sovereigns. A sovereign's revenue derives from the people's revenue, which depends on maximizing production and trade. A ruler dependent on land rents, like Bengal's, should open the broadest possible market, maximize buyer competition, and abolish all monopolies and trade restrictions. This maximizes production, its value, and consequently the sovereign's revenue. The companies' policies as merchants directly undermine their interests as rulers.
summary: Smith argues that the East India Companies' destructive trade policies directly contradict their interests as sovereign rulers. Since sovereign revenue derives from the people's prosperity, a ruler -- especially one dependent on land rents like Bengal's -- should maximize markets, encourage competition, and abolish monopolies and trade restrictions to increase production and thus tax revenue.
distilled: East India Companies' monopolistic trade policies directly contradict their interests as sovereigns, since maximizing production through free trade would maximize the land rents from which their revenue derives.
notes: Sovereign interest vs. merchant interest -- land rent revenue maximization -- free trade as sovereign policy -- Bengal land rents -- production depends on market extent -- buyer competition maximizes value -- foundational argument for free trade governance -- cross-reference to 4.7.207-208 on destructive policies

refashioned: But a company of merchants, it seems, is incapable of seeing itself as a sovereign even after becoming one. They still regard buying and selling as their primary business, and by a strange absurdity, they treat sovereignty as merely an appendage to commerce -- something to be made subservient to it, a tool for buying more cheaply in India and thus selling more profitably in Europe. To this end, they try to exclude all competitors from the markets of their subject countries, thereby reducing the surplus produce of those countries to barely enough to supply their own demand -- or what they can expect to sell in Europe at what they consider a reasonable profit. Their commercial habits thus draw them, almost inevitably though perhaps unconsciously, to prefer the small and temporary profit of the monopolist to the great and permanent revenue of the sovereign. This would gradually lead them to treat their subject countries much as the Dutch treat the Moluccas. The East India Company's interest as sovereign requires that European goods sold in their Indian territories should be as cheap as possible and Indian goods bought there as expensive as possible. But their interest as merchants is the exact opposite. As sovereigns, their interest is identical to the country's interest. As merchants, it is directly opposed.
elegant: Merchant companies cannot think like sovereigns even when they become ones. They treat sovereignty as a tool for cheaper buying and more profitable selling, excluding competitors from subject markets and reducing production to match their own demand. Commercial habits lead them to prefer monopoly's small temporary profit over sovereignty's great permanent revenue -- inevitably treating subject countries as the Dutch treat the Moluccas. As sovereigns, their interest aligns with the governed country's; as merchants, it is directly opposed.
summary: Smith identifies the fundamental contradiction of merchant-sovereign companies: they cannot stop thinking like merchants. They use sovereign power to exclude competitors and restrict production for monopoly profits, when their sovereign interest requires the opposite -- cheap European imports and expensive Indian exports to maximize trade. As sovereigns, their interest matches the country's; as merchants, it is directly opposed.
distilled: Trading companies that become sovereigns cannot escape merchant thinking -- they use sovereign power for monopoly profits that directly contradict their governing interest in maximizing their subjects' prosperity.
notes: Merchant vs. sovereign identity conflict -- sovereignty as appendage to commerce -- Dutch Moluccas parallel -- short-term monopoly profit vs. long-term sovereign revenue -- structural impossibility of merchant governance -- cross-reference to 4.7.209 on sovereign interest in free trade

refashioned: If the governance of such companies from Europe is essentially and perhaps incurably flawed, their administration in India is even worse. That administration necessarily consists of a council of merchants -- a no doubt respectable profession, but one that in no country carries the kind of authority that naturally commands the people's willing obedience. Such a council can enforce obedience only through the military force that accompanies it, making their government necessarily military and despotic. Yet their real business remains that of merchants: to sell European consigned goods as dearly as possible and buy Indian goods as cheaply as possible, and consequently to exclude all rivals from their particular market. The administration's character, so far as it concerns the company's trade, mirrors the home directorate's character. It tends to make government subservient to monopoly interests and consequently to suppress the natural growth of the country's surplus production to barely what the company demands.
elegant: Company administration in India is even worse than its European direction. A council of merchants commands no natural authority and must rule through military force -- making governance despotic. Yet they remain merchants at heart: selling European goods dear, buying Indian goods cheap, excluding all competitors. Government becomes the instrument of monopoly, suppressing production to match the company's demand alone.
summary: Company governance in India is necessarily despotic because merchant councils command no natural authority and must rely on military force. Their primary business remains commercial -- buying cheap and selling dear while excluding competitors -- making government subservient to monopoly interests and suppressing the natural growth of Indian production.
distilled: East India Company governance is necessarily despotic -- merchant councils lacking natural authority rule by military force while making government an instrument of trade monopoly.
notes: Military despotism from commercial governance -- merchants lack sovereign authority -- government subservient to monopoly -- production suppression -- administration mirrors directorate -- cross-reference to 4.7.210 on merchant-sovereign contradiction

refashioned: All members of the administration also trade on their own account, and it is futile to prohibit them from doing so. It is completely foolish to expect that the clerks of a great counting house ten thousand miles away -- almost entirely beyond oversight -- would simply obey their masters' orders to cease all personal business, abandon forever all hope of making a fortune with the means at their disposal, and content themselves with the moderate salaries their masters allow -- salaries that can seldom be increased since they are already as large as the company's real trade profits can support. Under such circumstances, prohibiting servants from private trading has hardly any effect other than enabling senior servants to oppress junior ones who have fallen out of favor, using the pretext of enforcing the master's rules.
elegant: Prohibiting company servants from private trading is futile -- clerks ten thousand miles from oversight will not surrender fortune-making opportunities for moderate salaries that already consume most trade profits. The only real effect of such prohibitions is to give senior servants a weapon for oppressing juniors under the pretense of enforcing company rules.
summary: Smith dismisses prohibitions on company servants' private trading as completely impractical. Clerks operating ten thousand miles from supervision will not abandon fortune-making for meager salaries. The only real effect is to empower senior servants to oppress juniors under pretense of enforcing rules.
distilled: Prohibiting company servants' private trade is futile at ten thousand miles' distance -- it only empowers senior servants to oppress juniors under pretense of rule enforcement.
notes: Principal-agent problem at imperial distance -- futility of prohibiting private trade -- moderate salaries vs. fortune-making opportunities -- internal oppression disguised as compliance -- cross-reference to 4.7.211 on administration character

refashioned: The servants naturally try to establish the same monopoly for their private trade as exists for the company's public trade. If permitted to act freely, they would establish this monopoly openly and directly by prohibiting all others from trading in their chosen commodities -- and this is perhaps the best and least oppressive way of establishing it. But if prohibited from doing this by orders from Europe, they will nonetheless try to establish the same monopoly secretly and indirectly, in a way that is far more destructive to the country. They will employ the full authority of government and pervert the administration of justice to harass and ruin anyone who interferes with any branch of commerce they choose to conduct through agents, whether concealed or simply not publicly acknowledged.
elegant: Company servants inevitably seek to monopolize their private trade. If allowed to do so openly -- by prohibiting competitors -- this is actually the least harmful approach. When prohibited from open monopoly by European orders, they create covert monopolies that are far more destructive: using government authority and corrupting justice to ruin anyone who competes with their hidden commercial agents.
summary: Company servants inevitably seek private trade monopolies. Open monopoly, though harmful, is the least destructive form. When European orders prohibit it, servants establish covert monopolies that are far worse -- deploying government authority and corrupting the justice system to destroy any competitor interfering with their secretly managed commerce.
distilled: When prohibited from open trade monopolies, company servants create covert ones that are far more destructive -- corrupting government and justice to crush competitors through hidden agents.
notes: Open vs. covert monopoly -- covert monopoly more destructive -- corruption of justice system -- government authority perverted for private commerce -- hidden agents -- cross-reference to 4.7.212 on futility of trading prohibitions

refashioned: The servants' private trade naturally extends to a much greater variety of goods than the company's public trade. The company's public trade is limited to trade with Europe and covers only part of the country's foreign commerce. But the servants' private trade can extend to all the different branches of both inland and foreign commerce. The company's monopoly can only stunt the natural growth of the surplus production that would be exported to Europe under free trade. But the servants' monopoly tends to stunt the natural growth of every product they choose to deal in -- both what is meant for domestic consumption and what is destined for export -- and consequently to degrade the country's entire agricultural system and reduce its population. It tends to reduce the quantity of every type of produce, including the necessities of life, whenever the servants choose to deal in them, to whatever those servants can afford to buy and expect to sell at their desired profit.
elegant: The servants' private trade monopoly is far more extensive and harmful than the company's public trade monopoly. The company monopoly only stunts exports to Europe. But servants deal in all branches -- inland and foreign, domestic consumption and export. Their monopoly degrades the entire agricultural system, reduces population, and restricts even the production of life's necessities to whatever they can profitably buy and sell.
summary: Company servants' private trade monopoly is far more destructive than the company's official monopoly. While the company restricts only exports to Europe, servants monopolize across all inland and foreign trade, degrading the entire agricultural system, reducing population, and restricting production of even basic necessities to match their personal profit targets.
distilled: Servants' private trade monopoly surpasses the company's in destructiveness -- extending to all commerce, degrading agriculture, reducing population, and restricting even necessities to their personal profit targets.
notes: Private monopoly scope exceeds company monopoly -- inland and foreign trade affected -- agricultural degradation -- population reduction -- necessity goods restricted -- cross-reference to 4.7.213 on covert monopolies

refashioned: The nature of their position also makes the servants more inclined to ruthlessly prioritize their own interests over those of the country they govern than their masters would be. The country belongs to their masters, who cannot entirely ignore the interests of what is theirs. But it does not belong to the servants. The masters' real interest, if they could understand it, is the same as the country's, and it is mainly from ignorance and the narrowness of commercial prejudice that they ever oppress it. But the servants' real interest is by no means the same as the country's, and even perfect information would not necessarily end their oppression. The regulations sent from Europe, though frequently weak, have usually been well-intentioned. More intelligence, and perhaps less good intention, has sometimes characterized those established by the servants in India. It is a very peculiar form of government in which every member of the administration wishes to leave the country as soon as possible, and whose interest -- the day after he has departed with his entire fortune -- would be perfectly indifferent if the whole country were swallowed by an earthquake.
elegant: Servants are structurally more exploitative than their masters. The masters own the country and cannot entirely ignore its welfare; their oppression stems from ignorance. The servants' interest, however, genuinely diverges from the country's -- perfect information would not end their exploitation. European regulations are well-meaning but weak; Indian regulations show more intelligence but less good intention. It is a government where every administrator wants to leave as soon as possible, and the day after departing with his fortune, would not care if an earthquake swallowed the whole country.
summary: Smith explains why company servants are structurally more oppressive than their directors. Directors at least own the country and are mainly ignorant rather than malicious. Servants' interests genuinely diverge from the governed country's, making them exploitative regardless of their knowledge. Smith memorably describes it as a government where every official plans to leave and would not care if an earthquake destroyed everything after his departure.
distilled: Company servants are structurally more exploitative than their masters because their interests genuinely diverge from the governed country's -- every official plans to leave with his fortune and would not care if the country were destroyed afterward.
notes: Structural exploitation vs. ignorant oppression -- ownership aligns interest partially -- servants' interest permanently divergent -- earthquake metaphor for administrator indifference -- principal-agent problem -- European regulations well-meaning but weak -- cross-reference to 4.7.212-214 on servant behavior

refashioned:
I do not intend, by anything I have said here, to cast any unfair aspersion on the general character of the East India Company's servants, much less on any particular individuals. It is the system of government -- the position in which they are placed -- that I mean to criticize, not the character of those who have operated within it. They acted as their situation naturally directed, and those who have complained loudest about them would probably not have acted better themselves. In war and diplomacy, the councils of Madras and Calcutta have on several occasions conducted themselves with a resolution and decisive wisdom that would have honored the Roman Senate in its finest days. Yet the members of those councils had been trained in professions very different from war and politics. Their situation alone, without special education, experience, or even precedent, seems to have formed in them all at once the great qualities required, inspiring both abilities and virtues they could not have known they possessed. If on some occasions their position has moved them to acts of genuine magnanimity that could hardly have been expected, we should not be surprised if on others it has prompted them to exploits of a rather different character.

Such exclusive companies are therefore nuisances in every respect: always more or less harmful to the countries in which they are established, and destructive to those unfortunate enough to fall under their government.
elegant: This criticism targets the system, not the individuals. Company servants acted as their situation directed -- their loudest critics would have done no better. The councils of Madras and Calcutta have shown resolution and wisdom rivaling the Roman Senate, demonstrating qualities their merchant training never provided. If circumstances can inspire unexpected magnanimity, they can equally inspire less admirable conduct. Exclusive companies are nuisances in every respect -- harmful to their home countries and destructive to those they govern.
summary: Smith carefully distinguishes his critique of the system from criticism of individuals. He praises company servants' impressive military and diplomatic achievements, noting that circumstances alone forged qualities their training never provided. But the same circumstances that produce magnanimity also produce exploitation. He concludes that exclusive companies are universally harmful -- to their home countries and destructive to those they govern.
distilled: The system, not the individuals, is to blame -- the same circumstances that inspire company servants' magnanimity also enable their exploitation, making exclusive companies nuisances harmful to all.
notes: System vs. individual critique -- Madras and Calcutta councils praised -- Roman Senate comparison -- situational virtue and vice -- concluding judgment on exclusive companies -- cross-reference to 4.7.205-215 on company governance

refashioned: Though the encouragement of exports and the discouragement of imports are the two great engines by which the mercantile system proposes to enrich every country, for certain commodities it seems to follow the opposite plan: discouraging exports and encouraging imports. Its ultimate goal, however, it claims, is always the same -- to enrich the country through a favorable trade balance. It discourages the export of raw materials and tools of manufacturing in order to give domestic workers an advantage, enabling them to undersell foreign competitors in every market. By restraining the export of a few inexpensive commodities, it aims to generate a much larger and more valuable export of finished goods. It encourages the import of raw materials so that domestic workers can process them more cheaply, thereby preventing a greater and more valuable importation of manufactured goods. I do not find in our statute book, however, any encouragement given to importing the tools of trade. When manufactures have reached a certain level, making those tools becomes itself a major industry. Encouraging their importation would interfere too much with the interests of those domestic manufacturers. Such importation, rather than being encouraged, has frequently been prohibited. The importation of wool cards, for example, except from Ireland or as wreck or prize goods, was prohibited by the statute of Edward IV, a prohibition renewed by Elizabeth and made permanent by subsequent laws.
elegant: The mercantile system generally promotes exports and restricts imports, but for raw materials and manufacturing tools it reverses course -- restricting their export to give domestic manufacturers a competitive advantage, and encouraging the import of raw materials for cheaper domestic processing. Tools are an exception: once a country's manufacturing reaches sufficient scale, toolmaking becomes its own major industry, and tool imports are actually prohibited to protect it. The goal remains the same -- a favorable trade balance through more valuable finished exports.
summary: Smith introduces Chapter 8 by explaining that the mercantile system reverses its usual export-promotion policy for raw materials and manufacturing tools. It restricts their export to advantage domestic manufacturers and encourages raw material imports for cheaper processing. Manufacturing tools are a special case -- once domestic toolmaking becomes significant, their import is actually prohibited.
distilled: The mercantile system reverses its usual policy for raw materials -- restricting their export and encouraging their import to advantage domestic manufacturers while prohibiting tool imports to protect domestic toolmakers.
notes: Chapter 4.8 introduction -- mercantile system's reverse policy for raw materials -- export restrictions on materials and tools -- import encouragement for raw materials -- tool import prohibition (wool cards) -- Edward IV and Elizabeth statutes -- cross-reference to 4.1-4.7 on general mercantile system

refashioned:
The importation of raw manufacturing materials has sometimes been encouraged by exempting them from the duties imposed on other goods, and sometimes by granting bounties.

The importation of sheep's wool from several countries, cotton from all countries, undressed flax, most dyeing drugs, most undressed hides from Ireland or the British colonies, seal skins from the British Greenland fishery, and pig and bar iron from the British colonies, along with several other raw materials, has been encouraged by exemption from all duties when properly entered at the custom house. The private interests of our merchants and manufacturers may have extracted these exemptions from the legislature, along with most of our other commercial regulations. They are, however, perfectly just and reasonable. If they could be extended to all other raw materials consistently with the needs of the state, the public would certainly benefit.
elegant: Raw material imports are encouraged through duty exemptions or bounties. Wool, cotton, flax, dyeing drugs, hides, seal skins, and colonial iron all enter duty-free when properly declared. Though merchants likely lobbied for these exemptions alongside other self-serving regulations, these particular measures are actually just and reasonable -- the public would benefit if they were extended to all raw materials.
summary: Smith notes that raw material imports are encouraged through duty exemptions and bounties. He lists various duty-free items including wool, cotton, flax, and colonial iron. While acknowledging these exemptions were probably lobbied for by self-interested merchants, he considers them genuinely just and beneficial -- a rare case where mercantile interests align with the public good.
distilled: Duty-free importation of raw materials like wool, cotton, and colonial iron is one of the rare mercantile regulations that is actually just and would benefit the public if extended further.
notes: Duty exemptions for raw materials -- Smith approves of these regulations -- rare alignment of merchant interest with public good -- list of duty-free materials -- lobbying acknowledged but outcome praised -- cross-reference to 4.8.1 on raw material import policy

refashioned: The greed of our great manufacturers, however, has in some cases stretched these exemptions well beyond what can justly be considered raw materials. By the 24th George II, chapter 46, a small duty of only one penny per pound was imposed on imported foreign brown linen yarn, replacing the much heavier duties it had previously borne: sixpence per pound on sail yarn, one shilling per pound on all French and Dutch yarn, and two pounds, thirteen shillings, and fourpence per hundredweight on all spruce or Muscovia yarn. But our manufacturers were not long satisfied with even this reduction. By the 29th of the same king, chapter 15 -- the same law that granted a bounty on exporting British and Irish linen priced under eighteen pence per yard -- even this small duty on importing brown linen yarn was removed entirely.
elegant: Manufacturers extended raw material exemptions beyond actual raw materials. Linen yarn duties were first drastically reduced from as much as two pounds thirteen shillings per hundredweight to just one penny per pound, then eliminated entirely by the same law that granted linen export bounties. Manufacturers' appetite for cheaper inputs proved insatiable.
summary: Smith shows how manufacturers exploited raw material exemptions by extending them to semi-processed goods like linen yarn. Heavy duties on imported yarn were first drastically reduced, then eliminated entirely. Manufacturers' insatiable demand for cheaper inputs pushed the definition of 'raw materials' well beyond its proper bounds.
distilled: Manufacturers stretched raw material exemptions to cover semi-processed goods like linen yarn, progressively eliminating duties to secure ever-cheaper inputs.
notes: Manufacturers expanding definition of raw materials -- linen yarn duty reductions and elimination -- 24th and 29th George II statutes -- progressive lobbying success -- cross-reference to 4.8.2 on duty exemptions

refashioned: In the various operations necessary for preparing linen yarn, considerably more labor is employed than in the subsequent operation of weaving linen cloth from that yarn. Not to mention the work of flax growers and flax dressers, at least three or four spinners are needed to keep one weaver constantly employed. More than four-fifths of the total labor needed to produce linen cloth goes into making the yarn. But our spinners are poor people -- mostly women, scattered across all parts of the country, without support or protection.
elegant: Preparing linen yarn requires far more labor than weaving it into cloth -- at least three or four spinners for every weaver, accounting for over four-fifths of total production labor. But spinners are poor, scattered women without support or political protection.
summary: Smith notes that spinning yarn requires far more labor than weaving cloth -- over four-fifths of total linen production labor. Yet spinners are mostly poor women scattered across the country without organized support or political influence, making them vulnerable to exploitation by the manufacturers who employ them.
distilled: Spinning accounts for over four-fifths of linen production labor but is performed by poor, scattered, unprotected women -- making spinners vulnerable to manufacturer exploitation.
notes: Labor distribution in linen production -- spinning vs. weaving -- four-fifths ratio -- female labor vulnerability -- scattered workers lack political power -- power asymmetry between spinners and manufacturers -- cross-reference to 4.8.3 on linen yarn duties

refashioned: It is not from the sale of the spinners' work but from the sale of the complete fabric of the weavers that our great master manufacturers make their profits. As it is in their interest to sell the finished product as dearly as possible, so it is in their interest to buy their raw materials as cheaply as possible. By extracting from the legislature bounties on exporting their own linen, heavy duties on importing all foreign linen, and a total prohibition on domestic consumption of some types of French linen, they work to sell their own goods as dear as possible. By encouraging the importation of foreign linen yarn -- thereby bringing it into competition with domestically spun yarn -- they work to buy the labor of the poor spinners as cheap as possible. They are equally intent on keeping down the wages of their own weavers as the earnings of the poor spinners. It is by no means for the benefit of the workers that they try either to raise the price of finished goods or to lower the price of raw materials.
elegant: Master manufacturers profit from the finished product, not the spinning. They lobby for export bounties on linen, import duties on foreign cloth, and prohibition of some French linen -- all to sell dear. Simultaneously, they encourage foreign yarn imports to compete with domestic spinners -- buying their labor cheap. They suppress both spinners' earnings and weavers' wages. Their regulations serve manufacturer profits, not worker welfare.
summary: Smith reveals how manufacturers exploit both ends of production: they lobby for protections that raise finished goods prices while simultaneously encouraging foreign yarn imports that depress spinner earnings. Their goal is to maximize the gap between selling price and input cost -- serving their own profits at the expense of both spinners and weavers.
distilled: Manufacturers lobby to sell finished linen dear through protections while buying yarn cheap through foreign competition, squeezing both spinners' and weavers' earnings for their own profit.
notes: Manufacturer exploitation of labor at both ends -- export bounties and import duties on finished goods -- foreign yarn imports suppress spinner wages -- workers bear cost of manufacturer lobbying -- cross-reference to 4.8.4 on spinner vulnerability

refashioned:
It is the industry carried on for the benefit of the rich and powerful that our mercantile system principally encourages. The industry carried on for the benefit of the poor and vulnerable is too often either neglected or actively oppressed.

Both the bounty on linen exports and the exemption from import duty on foreign yarn -- originally granted for only fifteen years but twice extended -- expire at the end of the parliamentary session following June 24, 1786.
elegant: The mercantile system principally encourages industry that benefits the rich and powerful while neglecting or oppressing industry that benefits the poor. The linen export bounty and foreign yarn duty exemption, originally granted for fifteen years and twice extended, expire after the parliamentary session following June 24, 1786.
summary: Smith delivers a pointed summary: the mercantile system systematically favors the industry of the rich and powerful while neglecting or oppressing that of the poor. He notes that both the linen bounty and yarn duty exemption, originally temporary, were extended twice and are set to expire in 1786.
distilled: The mercantile system principally encourages industry benefiting the rich while neglecting or oppressing industry benefiting the poor.
notes: Class critique of mercantile system -- rich vs. poor industry -- temporary regulations repeatedly extended -- 1786 expiry date -- linen bounty and yarn exemption -- cross-reference to 4.8.4-5 on spinner exploitation -- key passage on distributional effects

refashioned:
The encouragement given to raw material imports through bounties has been mainly confined to imports from the American plantations.

The first bounties of this kind were those granted around the beginning of the century on importing naval stores from America. This category included timber suitable for masts, yards, and bowsprits, as well as hemp, tar, pitch, and turpentine. The bounty of one pound per ton on masting timber and six pounds per ton on hemp was extended to imports from Scotland as well. Both bounties continued at the same rate until they expired: the hemp bounty on January 1, 1741, and the masting timber bounty at the end of the parliamentary session following June 24, 1781.
elegant: Import bounties for raw materials went mainly to American colonial goods. The first such bounties, granted around 1700, covered naval stores from America: mast timber, hemp, tar, pitch, and turpentine. The timber and hemp bounties were extended to Scottish imports as well. Both expired without renewal -- hemp in 1741, masting timber in 1781.
summary: Smith traces the history of raw material import bounties, which were largely confined to American colonial products. The first, granted around 1700 for naval stores including timber and hemp, were also extended to Scottish imports. Both eventually expired without renewal.
distilled: Raw material import bounties were mainly confined to American colonial goods, beginning with naval stores bounties around 1700 that eventually expired without renewal.
notes: Import bounty history -- naval stores from America -- masting timber and hemp -- bounties extended to Scotland -- expiry dates: hemp 1741, timber 1781 -- colonial preference in bounty policy -- cross-reference to 4.8.1-2 on import encouragement

refashioned: The bounties on importing tar, pitch, and turpentine underwent several changes during their existence. Originally, the bounty on tar was four pounds per ton, on pitch the same, and on turpentine three pounds per ton. The tar bounty of four pounds was later restricted to tar prepared in a particular manner; the bounty on other good, clean, merchantable tar was reduced to two pounds four shillings per ton. The pitch bounty was likewise reduced to one pound, and that on turpentine to one pound ten shillings per ton.
elegant: Bounties on tar, pitch, and turpentine were repeatedly modified. The original four-pound tar bounty was restricted to tar prepared in a specific way, with other tar reduced to two pounds four shillings. Pitch fell to one pound and turpentine to one pound ten shillings per ton.
summary: The bounties on tar, pitch, and turpentine were progressively reduced from their original levels. The tar bounty was split based on preparation method, with standard tar receiving a lower rate, while pitch and turpentine bounties were both substantially reduced.
distilled: Bounties on tar, pitch, and turpentine were progressively reduced and refined, with tar bounties differentiated by preparation method.
notes: Naval stores bounty modifications -- tar bounty differentiation by preparation -- progressive rate reductions -- tar, pitch, turpentine specific rates -- cross-reference to 4.8.7 on naval stores bounties

refashioned: The second bounty on importing raw manufacturing materials was granted by the 21st George II, chapter 30, for importing indigo from the British plantations. When plantation indigo was worth three-fourths the price of the best French indigo, it was entitled to a bounty of sixpence per pound. This bounty, like most others, was granted only for a limited period. It was continued by several extensions but reduced to fourpence per pound, and was allowed to expire at the end of the parliamentary session following March 25, 1781.
elegant: The second raw material bounty covered indigo from British plantations, paying sixpence per pound when colonial indigo reached three-fourths the value of the best French indigo. Later reduced to fourpence, it expired in 1781 after several extensions.
summary: The second import bounty targeted colonial indigo production, offering sixpence per pound when it reached a quality threshold relative to French indigo. Despite several extensions, the bounty was reduced to fourpence and eventually allowed to expire in 1781.
distilled: The colonial indigo bounty, pegged to a quality threshold relative to French indigo, was gradually reduced and allowed to expire in 1781.
notes: Indigo bounty from British plantations -- quality threshold tied to French indigo price -- progressive reduction and expiry -- 21st George II -- cross-reference to 4.8.7-8 on bounty series

refashioned: The third bounty of this kind was granted -- at roughly the time we were beginning to alternately court and quarrel with our American colonies -- by the 4th George III, chapter 26, for importing hemp or undressed flax from the British plantations. This bounty was granted for twenty-one years, from June 24, 1764 to June 24, 1785. For the first seven years, the rate was eight pounds per ton; for the second seven years, six pounds; and for the third seven years, four pounds. It was not extended to Scotland, whose climate -- though hemp is occasionally grown there in small quantities and of inferior quality -- is not well suited to that crop. Such a bounty on importing Scottish flax to England would have been too great a discouragement to flax cultivation in the southern part of the United Kingdom.
elegant: The third bounty, granted amid growing tensions with the American colonies, covered hemp and undressed flax from British plantations for twenty-one years at declining rates: eight pounds, then six, then four pounds per ton. It excluded Scotland to avoid discouraging southern English flax cultivation.
summary: The third import bounty covered colonial hemp and flax at rates declining over twenty-one years from eight to four pounds per ton. Granted during the period of growing American tensions, it excluded Scotland to protect domestic English flax production.
distilled: The colonial hemp and flax bounty, granted amid American tensions, declined from eight to four pounds per ton over twenty-one years while excluding Scotland to protect English cultivation.
notes: Hemp and flax bounty -- 4th George III -- declining rate structure -- Scotland excluded -- protection of English flax growing -- timing amid colonial tensions -- cross-reference to 4.8.7-9 on bounty series

refashioned: The fourth bounty of this kind was granted by the 5th George III, chapter 45, for importing wood from America. It was granted for nine years, from January 1, 1766 to January 1, 1775. During the first three years, the rate was one pound per hundred and twenty good deals, and twelve shillings per load of fifty cubic feet of other squared timber. For the second three years: fifteen shillings for deals and eight shillings for other squared timber. For the third three years: ten shillings for deals and five shillings for other squared timber.
elegant: The fourth bounty covered American timber imports for nine years at declining rates: one pound per 120 deals initially, falling to ten shillings, with squared timber declining from twelve shillings to five shillings per load of fifty cubic feet.
summary: The fourth import bounty targeted American timber, covering both deals and squared timber at rates that declined over three three-year periods from 1766 to 1775.
distilled: The American timber bounty ran for nine years at declining rates for both deals and squared timber, from 1766 to 1775.
notes: Timber bounty from America -- 5th George III -- deals and squared timber rates -- declining three-year periods -- nine-year duration -- cross-reference to 4.8.7-10 on bounty series

refashioned: The fifth bounty of this kind was granted by the 9th George III, chapter 38, for importing raw silk from the British plantations. It was granted for twenty-one years, from January 1, 1770 to January 1, 1791. For the first seven years, the rate was twenty-five pounds per hundred pounds of value; for the second seven, twenty pounds; for the third seven, fifteen pounds. Silk production requires so much hand labor, and labor is so expensive in America, that even this generous bounty, I am told, was unlikely to produce any significant results.
elegant: The fifth bounty covered raw silk from British plantations at generous declining rates -- twenty-five, twenty, then fifteen pounds per hundred pounds of value over twenty-one years. Even so, America's high labor costs meant the bounty was unlikely to produce significant silk production, since silk manufacture is extremely labor-intensive.
summary: The fifth bounty targeted colonial silk production at generous declining rates over twenty-one years. Smith notes that even this substantial encouragement was unlikely to succeed because silk production is extremely labor-intensive and American labor costs were far too high.
distilled: Even generous bounties on colonial raw silk were unlikely to succeed because America's high labor costs made labor-intensive silk production uneconomic.
notes: Raw silk bounty -- 9th George III -- high American labor costs defeat bounty -- labor intensity of silk production -- bounty futility when economic fundamentals are wrong -- cross-reference to 4.8.7-11 on bounty series
