refashioned: The sixth bounty of this kind was granted by the 11th George III, chapter 50, for importing pipe, hogshead, and barrel staves and headings from the British plantations. It was granted for nine years, from January 1, 1772 to January 1, 1781. For the first three years, the rate for a certain quantity of each was six pounds; for the second three years, four pounds; for the third three years, two pounds.
elegant: The sixth bounty covered barrel staves and headings from British plantations for nine years at declining rates: six pounds, then four, then two pounds per specified quantity.
summary: The sixth import bounty targeted barrel staves and headings from British plantations, running for nine years at rates declining from six to two pounds per specified quantity.
distilled: The barrel staves bounty from British plantations ran for nine years at rates declining from six to two pounds.
notes: Barrel staves and headings bounty -- 11th George III -- pipe, hogshead, barrel staves -- declining rates over three three-year periods -- cross-reference to 4.8.7-12 on bounty series

refashioned: The seventh and final bounty of this kind was granted by the 19th George III, chapter 37, for importing hemp from Ireland. It was granted on the same terms as the hemp bounty from America -- for twenty-one years from June 24, 1779 to June 24, 1800, divided into three seven-year periods at the same declining rates as the American bounty. However, unlike the American bounty, it did not extend to undressed flax, which would have been too great a discouragement to British flax cultivation. When this bounty was granted, the British and Irish legislatures were in scarcely better humor with each other than the British and American had been previously. This concession to Ireland, one hopes, has been granted under more fortunate circumstances than all those to America. The same commodities that received bounties when imported from America were subject to considerable duties when imported from anywhere else. American colonial interests were treated as identical to the mother country's. Whatever money was sent to them, it was said, returned through the balance of trade, so Britain could never be made poorer by spending on them. They were ours in every respect, and spending on them was like improving our own property and employing our own people. It is unnecessary to say more to expose the folly of a system that bitter experience has now sufficiently exposed. Had our American colonies truly been a part of Great Britain, these bounties might have been considered production bounties -- still subject to all the objections bounties always face, but to no others.
elegant: The seventh and final bounty covered Irish hemp at the same declining rates as the American hemp bounty, though excluding undressed flax to protect British cultivation. Granted during British-Irish tensions, it hopefully fares better than American bounties. Smith notes that colonial goods received bounties while the same goods from elsewhere bore heavy duties -- all based on the now-exposed folly that colonial spending always returned through the trade balance. Had the colonies truly been part of Britain, these bounties would have been ordinary production subsidies subject only to the usual objections.
summary: The final raw material bounty covered Irish hemp on the same terms as the American bounty, excluding undressed flax. Smith observes that colonial goods received bounties while identical goods from elsewhere were heavily taxed, based on the mercantilist fiction that colonial spending always returned through trade. Bitter experience with America has exposed this folly.
distilled: The final bounty covered Irish hemp while Smith notes that the entire colonial bounty system rested on the now-exposed mercantilist fiction that spending on colonies always returned through the trade balance.
notes: Irish hemp bounty -- seventh and final raw material bounty -- British-Irish tensions -- colonial goods favored over identical foreign goods -- mercantilist fiction of trade balance returns -- American experience exposes the folly -- cross-reference to 4.8.7-13 on bounty series -- cross-reference to 4.5 on bounties generally

refashioned:
The export of manufacturing materials is sometimes discouraged by absolute prohibitions and sometimes by high duties.

Our woolen manufacturers have been more successful than any other group of workers in persuading the legislature that the nation's prosperity depends on the success of their particular industry. They have obtained not only a monopoly against consumers through an absolute prohibition on importing foreign woolen cloth, but also a monopoly against sheep farmers and wool growers through a similar prohibition on exporting live sheep and wool. The severity of many revenue laws is justly criticized for imposing heavy penalties on actions that were perfectly innocent before being declared crimes by statute. But the cruelest of our revenue laws, I will venture to say, are mild and gentle compared to some of those that the lobbying of our merchants and manufacturers has extracted from the legislature to support their own absurd and oppressive monopolies. Like the laws of Draco, these laws may be said to be written in blood.
elegant: Export of raw materials is discouraged by prohibitions or high duties. Woolen manufacturers secured the most extreme protections: import prohibition on foreign cloth plus export prohibition on live sheep and wool -- monopolies against both consumers and producers. The resulting laws are crueler than the harshest revenue statutes: like Draco's laws, they are written in blood.
summary: Smith introduces the export prohibition on manufacturing materials, focusing on the woolen industry's extraordinary lobbying success. Manufacturers obtained monopolies against both consumers (banning foreign cloth imports) and producers (banning sheep and wool exports). Smith compares the resulting penal laws to those of Draco -- written in blood.
distilled: Woolen manufacturers obtained monopolies against both consumers and producers through brutal export and import prohibitions whose penalties Smith compares to the blood-written laws of Draco.
notes: Woolen industry lobbying -- dual monopoly against consumers and producers -- Draco comparison -- laws written in blood -- export prohibition on wool and sheep -- severity of manufacturer-driven legislation -- cross-reference to 4.8.1 on export restrictions

refashioned: By the 8th of Elizabeth, chapter 3, anyone who exported sheep, lambs, or rams faced, for the first offense, forfeiture of all goods forever, a year's imprisonment, and then having his left hand cut off in a market town on market day to be nailed up publicly. For the second offense, he was to be judged a felon and executed. The purpose of this law seems to have been to prevent the propagation of English sheep breeds in foreign countries. By the 13th and 14th of Charles II, chapter 18, the exportation of wool was made a felony, and the exporter was subjected to the same penalties and forfeitures as any other felon.
elegant: Under Elizabeth, exporting sheep meant forfeiting all property, a year's imprisonment, and having one's left hand publicly severed and nailed up on a market day -- with execution for repeat offenders. Under Charles II, exporting wool was made a felony punishable by death. The purpose was to prevent English sheep breeds from reaching foreign countries.
summary: Smith catalogues the savage penalties for exporting sheep and wool: under Elizabeth, first offenders lost all property and had their left hand publicly severed and displayed; second offenders were executed. Under Charles II, wool exportation was made a capital felony.
distilled: English law punished sheep exportation with public hand amputation and execution for repeat offenders, and made wool export a capital felony -- all to protect the woolen monopoly.
notes: 8th Elizabeth on sheep export -- public hand amputation -- death penalty for repeat offenders -- 13th and 14th Charles II -- wool export as felony -- breed protection purpose -- extreme penalties for trade offenses -- cross-reference to 4.8.15 on laws written in blood

refashioned: For the honor of national humanity, one hopes that neither of these statutes was ever actually enforced. The first, as far as I know, has never been directly repealed, and the legal authority Serjeant Hawkins seems to consider it still in force. It may, however, be regarded as effectively repealed by the 12th of Charles II, chapter 32, section 3, which -- without explicitly removing the older penalties -- imposed a new penalty of twenty shillings for every sheep exported or attempted to be exported, together with forfeiture of the sheep and the owner's share of the ship. The second statute was expressly repealed by the 7th and 8th of William III, chapter 28, section 4, which declared that since the severity of making wool export a felony had actually prevented effective prosecution, the felony provision should be repealed.
elegant: Neither savage statute was likely ever enforced. The sheep export law was effectively superseded by Charles II's milder penalty of twenty shillings per sheep. The wool felony was expressly repealed under William III because the very severity of the penalty prevented effective prosecution -- courts would not convict when execution was the consequence.
summary: Smith notes that these extreme penalties were likely never enforced. The sheep export law was effectively replaced by a milder fine under Charles II, while the wool felony was formally repealed under William III precisely because its severity prevented prosecution -- juries refused to convict when execution was the penalty.
distilled: The savage sheep and wool export penalties were never effectively enforced -- excessive severity actually prevented prosecution, leading to their effective or formal repeal.
notes: Enforcement failure of extreme penalties -- severity prevents prosecution -- Serjeant Hawkins legal opinion -- effective vs. formal repeal -- 12th Charles II replaces Elizabeth -- 7th and 8th William III repeals felony -- perverse effects of excessive punishment -- cross-reference to 4.8.16 on original penalties

refashioned: The penalties that remain under the milder statutes, or that survive from earlier laws not repealed, are still severe enough. Besides forfeiting the goods, the exporter incurs a penalty of three shillings for every pound weight of wool exported or attempted to be exported -- roughly four or five times the value. Any merchant convicted of this offense is permanently barred from collecting any debt or account owed to him. Whatever the size of his fortune, and whether or not he can pay these heavy penalties, the law intends to ruin him completely. But since the morals of the general public are not yet as corrupt as those who devised this statute, no one has ever, to my knowledge, taken advantage of this debt-collection prohibition. If the convicted person cannot pay the penalties within three months after judgment, he is to be transported for seven years; if he returns before that term expires, he faces felony penalties without benefit of clergy. The ship owner, if he knew of the offense, forfeits all interest in the ship and its furnishings. The master and crew, if they knew, forfeit all goods and chattels and suffer three months' imprisonment -- extended to six months for the master by a subsequent statute.
elegant: Even the milder surviving penalties are severe: three shillings per pound weight (four to five times the wool's value), forfeiture of goods, and permanent disqualification from collecting debts -- designed to ruin the offender completely. If unable to pay within three months, the offender faces seven years' transportation; returning early means execution without benefit of clergy. Ship owners forfeit their vessels; masters face six months' imprisonment. The law's authors intended total financial destruction.
summary: Even after the most extreme penalties were removed, wool export penalties remain severe: fines of four to five times the wool's value, permanent disqualification from debt collection, and potential transportation for seven years with death for early return. Ship owners, masters, and crew all face additional penalties. The law aims at complete financial ruin of offenders.
distilled: Even the milder wool export penalties aim at complete financial ruin: fines of four to five times the wool's value, debt collection disqualification, and seven years' transportation with death for premature return.
notes: Surviving penalties still severe -- three shillings per pound (4-5x value) -- debt collection disqualification -- seven years transportation -- death without benefit of clergy for early return -- ship owner, master, crew penalties -- law designed for total ruin -- cross-reference to 4.8.16-17 on penalty history

refashioned: To prevent exportation, the entire inland wool trade is burdened with very heavy and oppressive restrictions. Wool cannot be packed in any box, barrel, cask, case, chest, or other container -- only in packs of leather or pack-cloth, which must be marked on the outside with the words WOOL or YARN in letters at least three inches tall, on pain of forfeiting the goods and packaging plus eight shillings per pound weight, payable by the owner or packer. Wool cannot be loaded on any horse or cart or carried by land within five miles of the coast except between sunrise and sunset, on pain of forfeiture of the wool, horses, and carriages. The hundred (administrative district) nearest the coast through which the wool is carried or exported forfeits twenty pounds if the wool is worth less than ten pounds, or triple the value plus triple costs if it is worth more, with prosecution required within the year. The fine is enforced against any two inhabitants, whom the local sessions must reimburse by assessing the other inhabitants, as in cases of robbery. If anyone settles with the hundred for less than the full penalty, he is imprisoned for five years, and any other person may bring prosecution. These regulations apply throughout the entire kingdom.
elegant: Inland wool trade is strangled by oppressive restrictions: wool must be packed only in leather or pack-cloth marked WOOL or YARN in three-inch letters; it cannot be transported within five miles of the coast except during daylight; the entire local administrative district is fined for any wool that passes through for export -- with the fine assessed against inhabitants as in robbery cases. Anyone settling for less than full penalties faces five years' imprisonment. These rules apply nationwide.
summary: Smith details the suffocating inland regulations on wool: mandatory packaging and labeling, prohibition on transport near coasts except during daylight, and collective punishment of entire local districts for any wool that passes through for export. These regulations, applying nationwide, treat wool transport as something approaching a criminal conspiracy.
distilled: Inland wool regulations impose mandatory labeling, restrict transport near coasts to daylight hours, and collectively punish entire local districts for wool passing through for export.
notes: Inland trade restrictions on wool -- mandatory packaging and labeling -- five-mile coastal exclusion zone -- collective punishment of hundreds -- robbery-style assessment on inhabitants -- oppressive surveillance system -- cross-reference to 4.8.15-18 on wool export penalties

refashioned: In the counties of Kent and Sussex, the restrictions are even more burdensome. Every wool owner within ten miles of the sea coast must submit a written account to the nearest customs officer within three days of shearing, reporting the number of fleeces and their storage location. Before moving any fleeces, he must provide similar notice of the number, weight, and the buyer's name and address, as well as the intended destination. No one within fifteen miles of the sea in those counties can purchase wool without posting a bond to the king guaranteeing that none of the purchased wool will be resold to anyone else within fifteen miles of the sea. If any wool is found being carried toward the coast without having been properly registered and bonded, it is forfeited and the offender also pays three shillings per pound weight. If anyone stores unregistered wool within fifteen miles of the sea, it is seized and forfeited. If the owner claims it after seizure, he must post security with the exchequer guaranteeing that if he loses at trial he will pay triple costs in addition to all other penalties.
elegant: Kent and Sussex face even harsher restrictions: wool owners near the coast must report all fleeces within three days of shearing; all sales and movements must be pre-notified with buyer details; purchasers within fifteen miles of the sea must bond against resale in the coastal zone; unregistered wool found moving coastward is forfeited with additional fines; and anyone claiming seized wool must guarantee triple costs if they lose at trial.
summary: In Kent and Sussex, wool regulations are even more oppressive: mandatory reporting within three days of shearing, pre-notification of all movements and sales, bonds against coastal resale, forfeiture of unregistered wool moving toward the coast, and triple costs for unsuccessful legal challenges to seizures.
distilled: Kent and Sussex imposed the most extreme wool surveillance: mandatory shearing reports, pre-notification of all movements, purchase bonds against coastal resale, and triple costs for contesting seizures.
notes: Kent and Sussex special restrictions -- three-day shearing report -- fifteen-mile coastal zone -- purchase bonds -- triple costs for contesting seizure -- intensified surveillance near coast -- cross-reference to 4.8.19 on nationwide inland restrictions

refashioned: When such restrictions govern inland trade, we can be certain the coastal trade is not left very free either. Every wool owner who carries or causes to be carried any wool to any coastal port for sea transport to another port must first register it at the departure port, listing the weight, marks, and number of packages, before bringing the wool within five miles of that port -- on pain of forfeiture of wool, horses, carts, and carriages, plus all the penalties under existing wool export laws. This law (1st William III, chapter 32) is so indulgent as to allow a person to carry his wool home from the place of shearing even if it is within five miles of the sea, provided that within ten days of shearing and before moving the wool, he certifies to the nearest customs officer the true number of fleeces and their storage location, and gives three days' notice before any removal. A bond must be posted that wool being transported by coast will be landed at the specific port named in the outward entry. If any part is unloaded without a customs officer present, not only is the wool forfeited as with other goods, but the additional penalty of three shillings per pound weight also applies.
elegant: Coastal wool trade is equally restricted: all wool must be registered before coming within five miles of any port, with bonds guaranteeing delivery to the named destination port. Even carrying wool home from shearing near the coast requires customs certification within ten days and three days' notice before any movement. Landing wool without an officer present triggers both forfeiture and the standard three-shilling-per-pound penalty.
summary: The coastal wool trade faces restrictions matching the inland ones: pre-registration before approaching any port, bonds guaranteeing specific destinations, customs certification even for carrying wool home from shearing, and forfeiture plus standard penalties for landing without customs supervision.
distilled: Coastal wool transport requires pre-registration, bonds for specific destinations, and customs supervision at landing -- with forfeiture and three-shilling penalties for any deviation.
notes: Coastal trade restrictions -- 1st William III -- registration before approaching ports -- bonds for destination compliance -- limited exception for carrying wool home -- customs officer presence required at landing -- cross-reference to 4.8.19-20 on inland restrictions

refashioned: Our woolen manufacturers, to justify their demand for such extraordinary restrictions, confidently asserted that English wool was of a uniquely superior quality; that other countries' wool could not be made into any tolerable fabric without some mixture of English wool; that fine cloth could not be produced without it; and that therefore, if English wool exports could be totally prevented, England could monopolize nearly the entire world's woolen trade and, having no rivals, could sell at whatever price she pleased, quickly amassing incredible wealth through the most favorable trade balance. This doctrine, like most doctrines confidently asserted by a substantial number of people, was and continues to be believed implicitly by a much larger number -- by nearly everyone either unfamiliar with the wool trade or who has not investigated the matter specifically. It is, however, entirely false that English wool is in any way necessary for making fine cloth. In fact, English wool is entirely unsuited for it. Fine cloth is made exclusively from Spanish wool. English wool cannot even be mixed with Spanish wool without spoiling and degrading the fabric to some degree.
elegant: Manufacturers claimed English wool was uniquely essential for fine cloth production, and that an export ban would give England a global woolen monopoly at any price. This widely believed doctrine is entirely false. Fine cloth is made exclusively from Spanish wool -- English wool actually degrades any fabric it is mixed into. The supposed basis for all these oppressive regulations was a complete fabrication.
summary: Smith demolishes the manufacturers' foundational claim that English wool was uniquely essential for fine cloth production. This doctrine, widely believed by those unfamiliar with the trade, is entirely false: fine cloth is made exclusively from Spanish wool, and English wool actually degrades any fabric it is blended with. The entire apparatus of oppressive wool regulations rests on a fabrication.
distilled: The manufacturers' claim that English wool was uniquely essential for fine cloth was entirely false -- fine cloth requires Spanish wool exclusively, and English wool actually degrades the fabric.
notes: Manufacturers' false claim about English wool quality -- fine cloth from Spanish wool only -- English wool actually degrades fabric -- widely believed falsehood -- entire regulatory apparatus built on misinformation -- cross-reference to 4.8.15-21 on wool regulations based on this claim

refashioned: As shown earlier in this work, the effect of these regulations has been to depress the price of English wool not only below what it would naturally be today but well below what it actually was in the time of Edward III. The price of Scottish wool, when it became subject to the same regulations after the Union, reportedly fell by about half. The very careful and knowledgeable author of the Memoirs of Wool, the Reverend Mr. John Smith, observes that the price of the best English wool in England is generally lower than what considerably inferior wool commonly sells for in the Amsterdam market. Depressing the price of this commodity below its natural and proper level was the openly declared purpose of these regulations, and there seems to be no doubt they achieved their intended effect.
elegant: These regulations successfully depressed English wool prices below both their natural level and their historical level under Edward III. Scottish wool prices fell by half after the Union brought them under the same rules. The best English wool now sells below the price of inferior wool in Amsterdam. Price depression was the regulations' explicit goal, and they achieved it.
summary: Smith confirms that wool regulations achieved their stated purpose of depressing prices. English wool fell below both its natural price and its historical price under Edward III. Scottish wool halved in price after the Union. The best English wool now sells for less than inferior wool in Amsterdam -- exactly the intended effect.
distilled: Wool export regulations achieved their explicit goal of depressing prices -- English wool fell below historical levels and now sells for less than inferior Dutch wool.
notes: Wool price depression confirmed -- below Edward III levels -- Scottish wool halved after Union -- Rev. John Smith's Memoirs of Wool -- Amsterdam price comparison -- regulations achieved intended price depression -- cross-reference to 4.8.22 on false quality claims justifying regulations

refashioned: This price reduction, one might think, should have substantially reduced the annual production of wool -- not necessarily below historical levels, but below what it would have reached under current conditions of improvement had a free and open market allowed prices to rise to their natural level. I am inclined to believe, however, that the quantity of annual production has not been much affected by these regulations, though perhaps slightly. Wool production is not the primary purpose of sheep farming. The sheep farmer expects his profit mainly from the price of the carcass, not the fleece, and the average carcass price will generally compensate for any deficiency in the average fleece price. As observed earlier in this work, any regulation that tends to lower the price of wool or raw hides below its natural level must, in an improved and cultivated country, tend to raise the price of butcher's meat.
elegant: Though depressed wool prices might be expected to reduce production, the effect has been modest. Sheep farmers profit mainly from carcass sales, not fleeces, and lower wool prices are compensated by higher meat prices. In an improved country, depressing wool prices below natural levels necessarily raises butcher's meat prices -- production quantity is thus largely maintained through this compensating mechanism.
summary: Smith argues that despite depressed wool prices, production has not fallen significantly because sheep farmers profit mainly from carcass sales, not fleeces. Lower wool prices are naturally compensated by higher meat prices in an improved economy, maintaining farmers' overall returns and thus their production incentives.
distilled: Depressed wool prices have not significantly reduced production because sheep farmers profit mainly from carcass sales, and lower fleece prices are compensated by higher meat prices.
notes: Wool production resilience despite price depression -- carcass vs. fleece profit -- compensating price mechanism -- improved country dynamics -- joint product pricing -- cross-reference to Book I on raw produce prices -- cross-reference to 4.8.23 on price depression

refashioned: The price of all cattle raised on improved and cultivated land must be sufficient to pay the rent the landlord and the profit the farmer expects from such land. If it is not, they will soon stop raising cattle. Whatever part of this price is not covered by the wool and the hide must therefore be covered by the carcass. The less paid for one, the more must be paid for the other. How this total price is divided among the different parts of the animal is irrelevant to landlords and farmers, as long as the full price is paid to them. In an improved and cultivated country, therefore, their interests as landlords and farmers are not much affected by such regulations, though their interests as consumers may be affected by the resulting rise in food prices. Following this reasoning, depressed wool prices are unlikely to cause any significant reduction in annual wool production -- except insofar as raising the price of mutton may somewhat reduce demand for and consequently production of that particular type of butcher's meat. Even this effect is probably not very significant.
elegant: Cattle prices on improved land must cover both rent and profit. If wool and hide prices fall, carcass prices must rise to compensate -- the division among animal products is irrelevant to farmers as long as total revenue is maintained. Depressed wool prices thus barely affect production, except that higher mutton prices may slightly reduce demand for that meat. The net effect on wool output is negligible.
summary: Smith explains the compensating mechanism: since total livestock revenue must cover rent and profit, any reduction in wool and hide prices is offset by higher carcass prices. Farmers are indifferent to how revenue is distributed among animal products. The only indirect effect on wool production comes through slightly reduced mutton demand due to higher meat prices.
distilled: Lower wool prices are offset by higher carcass prices in improved countries, leaving farmers' total revenue and wool production incentives largely unchanged.
notes: Joint product pricing mechanism -- total revenue must cover rent and profit -- farmer indifference to revenue division -- mutton demand as indirect channel -- compensating price movements -- cross-reference to 4.8.24 on production resilience

refashioned: Though the effect on the quantity of annual production may not have been very significant, the effect on quality might be thought necessarily much greater. The degradation in the quality of English wool -- if not below historical levels, then at least below what it would naturally have reached given current improvement and cultivation -- should presumably be roughly proportional to the price depression. Since quality depends on the breed, pasture, and management and cleanliness of sheep throughout the entire growth of the fleece, the attention devoted to these factors would naturally correspond to the return the fleece price is likely to provide for that labor and expense. However, the condition of the fleece depends heavily on the health, growth, and size of the animal: the same attention needed to improve the carcass largely suffices to improve the fleece as well. Despite the price depression, English wool quality has reportedly improved considerably during the present century. The improvement might have been greater if prices had been better, but low prices, though they may have slowed improvement, certainly have not prevented it.
elegant: Though quality should theoretically suffer more than quantity from depressed prices, English wool quality has actually improved during the present century. The same care that improves the carcass -- breed, pasture, health management -- also improves the fleece. Low prices may have slowed quality improvement but have not prevented it, since carcass value motivates the same attention that benefits wool quality.
summary: Smith addresses the expected quality degradation from depressed wool prices, noting that English wool has actually improved during the century despite low prices. The care needed for better carcasses -- breed, pasture, and animal health -- also improves wool quality, so the carcass incentive sustains quality improvement even when fleece prices are artificially depressed.
distilled: English wool quality improved despite depressed prices because the same care that improves carcass value -- breed, pasture, and animal health -- also improves fleece quality.
notes: Wool quality improvement despite price depression -- joint production of fleece and carcass quality -- breed, pasture, management factors -- carcass incentive maintains wool quality -- cross-reference to 4.8.24-25 on production resilience

refashioned: The severity of these regulations therefore seems to have affected neither the quantity nor the quality of annual wool production as much as might have been expected -- though I believe quality was probably affected somewhat more than quantity. On the whole, the interest of the wool growers, though certainly harmed to some degree, seems to have been much less damaged than one might have imagined.
elegant: These harsh regulations affected wool production less than expected -- quality probably suffered more than quantity, but overall, wool growers' interests were less damaged than might have been imagined.
summary: Smith concludes that the oppressive wool regulations had less impact on both quantity and quality of production than might be expected, with quality suffering somewhat more than quantity. Wool growers' interests, while certainly harmed, were less damaged than one might have imagined.
distilled: The oppressive wool regulations affected production quantity and quality less than expected, with wool growers' interests less damaged than imagined thanks to compensating carcass prices.
notes: Summary assessment of wool regulation effects -- quality more affected than quantity -- grower interests less damaged than expected -- compensating mechanisms -- cross-reference to 4.8.24-26 on production resilience analysis

refashioned:
These considerations, however, do not justify the absolute prohibition of wool exports. They do fully justify the imposition of a substantial export tax.

To deliberately harm the interest of any one class of citizens for no other purpose than to promote the interest of another class is clearly contrary to the justice and equality of treatment that the sovereign owes to all classes of subjects. The prohibition certainly harms, to some degree, the interest of the wool growers for no purpose other than to promote the interest of the manufacturers.
elegant: While these findings do not justify absolute export prohibition, they do justify a substantial export tax. Deliberately harming one class to benefit another violates the sovereign's duty of equal treatment. The wool export prohibition plainly harms growers solely to benefit manufacturers.
summary: Smith draws his policy conclusion: the limited damage to wool production does not justify an absolute export ban but does justify an export tax. He grounds this in a principle of justice: deliberately harming one class of citizens solely to benefit another violates the sovereign's obligation to treat all subjects equally.
distilled: Wool export prohibition violates the sovereign's duty of equal treatment among citizens -- a substantial export tax would be justified, but an absolute ban that harms growers solely for manufacturers' benefit is not.
notes: Policy conclusion: tax not prohibition -- sovereign's duty of equal treatment -- justice principle applied to trade regulation -- grower vs. manufacturer interests -- proportionality in regulation -- cross-reference to 4.8.15-27 on wool regulation analysis

refashioned: Every class of citizens is obligated to contribute to the support of the sovereign or the commonwealth. A tax of five, or even ten shillings, on the exportation of every tod of wool would generate very considerable revenue for the sovereign. It would harm the interest of the wool growers somewhat less than the prohibition, since it would probably not depress the price quite as much. It would still provide a sufficient advantage to manufacturers, because even though they might not buy wool quite as cheaply as under the prohibition, they would still buy it at least five or ten shillings cheaper than any foreign manufacturer could, who would also have to pay for freight and insurance. It is hard to imagine a tax that could produce such considerable revenue for the sovereign while causing so little inconvenience to anyone.
elegant: A five or ten shilling tax per tod on wool exports would generate substantial sovereign revenue while harming growers less than prohibition, since it would depress prices less severely. Manufacturers would still enjoy a five to ten shilling advantage over foreign competitors who must also pay freight and insurance. It is hard to imagine a tax producing so much revenue with so little inconvenience.
summary: Smith proposes replacing the wool export prohibition with a five to ten shilling tax per tod. This would generate substantial revenue, harm growers less than prohibition, maintain a competitive advantage for domestic manufacturers, and create minimal inconvenience -- an almost ideal tax in Smith's estimation.
distilled: A moderate wool export tax would generate substantial revenue, harm growers less than prohibition, maintain manufacturers' competitive advantage, and cause minimal inconvenience -- an almost ideal tax.
notes: Wool export tax proposal -- five to ten shillings per tod -- revenue generation -- less harmful than prohibition -- manufacturers retain freight and insurance advantage -- near-ideal tax qualities -- practical policy recommendation -- cross-reference to 4.8.28 on justice principle -- cross-reference to Book V on taxation principles

refashioned: The prohibition on wool exports, despite all its penalties, does not actually prevent wool from being exported. Everyone knows it is smuggled out in large quantities. The enormous price gap between the domestic and foreign markets creates such a powerful incentive for smuggling that no severity of law can stop it. This illegal export benefits no one but the smuggler. A legal export subject to a tax would generate revenue for the government -- thereby reducing the need for other, perhaps more burdensome taxes -- and could prove beneficial to every citizen.
elegant: Wool export bans fail because the price gap between home and foreign markets makes smuggling irresistible. Illegal export benefits only smugglers. Legal, taxed exports would generate government revenue and benefit everyone.
summary: Export prohibitions on wool are ineffective because price differentials create overwhelming incentives to smuggle. Legalizing exports with a tax would benefit both government revenue and citizens generally.
distilled: Wool export bans merely create smuggling; taxed legal exports would benefit everyone.
notes: Classic Smith argument: prohibition creates black markets -- connects to his broader case that bans drive activity underground rather than eliminating it. The revenue argument anticipates modern debates about legalizing and taxing prohibited goods. Cross-reference 4.8.1-4.8.29 on wool export restrictions.

refashioned: The export of fuller's earth -- a clay thought necessary for preparing and cleaning woolen cloth -- has been subjected to nearly the same penalties as wool exports. Even tobacco-pipe clay, though recognized as a different material from fuller's clay, has been placed under the same prohibitions and penalties, simply because the two resemble each other and fuller's clay might sometimes be disguised as tobacco-pipe clay for export.
elegant: Fuller's earth, used in wool processing, faces the same export penalties as wool itself. Even tobacco-pipe clay -- acknowledged as different -- is banned because it resembles fuller's clay and could serve as a disguise for smuggling it.
summary: Export restrictions extend beyond wool to related materials like fuller's clay, and even to visually similar but distinct substances like tobacco-pipe clay, out of fear they might be used to circumvent the ban.
distilled: Export bans on wool extend absurdly to similar-looking clays, illustrating how prohibitions expand beyond their original scope.
notes: Illustrates regulatory creep -- bans on one product expand to cover adjacent or merely similar products. Fuller's earth was essential to the 'fulling' process of thickening woolen cloth. Shows how mercantilist regulation generated increasingly absurd extensions.

refashioned: Under Charles II, the export of both raw hides and tanned leather -- except as finished boots, shoes, or slippers -- was prohibited. This gave bootmakers and shoemakers a monopoly not only against cattle graziers but against tanners as well. Through later statutes, tanners managed to exempt themselves from this monopoly by paying a modest tax of one shilling per hundredweight of tanned leather. They also secured a drawback of two-thirds of the excise duties on their product, even when exported without further processing. All leather manufactures can now be exported duty-free, with exporters entitled to a full excise drawback. But graziers remain subject to the old monopoly. Graziers, scattered across the countryside, cannot easily organize to impose monopolies on others or to free themselves from monopolies imposed on them. Manufacturers, concentrated in large numbers in cities, can do so easily. Even cattle horns are prohibited from export -- giving the trivial trades of horn-workers and comb-makers a monopoly against the graziers.
elegant: Leather export bans gave bootmakers a monopoly against both graziers and tanners. Tanners eventually bought their way out through lobbying, but graziers -- scattered across the countryside and unable to organize -- remain trapped. Urban manufacturers, concentrated in cities, easily combine to secure privileges. Even cattle horns are banned from export, favoring trivial trades over raw material producers.
summary: Export restrictions on leather created layered monopolies favoring urban manufacturers. Tanners escaped through political organization, but dispersed rural graziers could not. This illustrates how concentrated urban interests dominate scattered rural ones in securing trade privileges.
distilled: Leather export bans show how concentrated urban manufacturers easily secure monopolies against dispersed rural producers who cannot organize to resist.
notes: Key insight on political economy of lobbying: geographic concentration enables collective action. Anticipates Mancur Olson's logic of collective action by two centuries. The horn and comb-maker example shows how even trivial industries capture monopoly privileges. Cross-reference Book I on division of labor concentrating workers in cities.

refashioned: Restrictions on exporting partially manufactured goods -- whether through outright bans or export taxes -- are not unique to the leather trade. As long as anything remains to be done to make a commodity ready for final use, our manufacturers insist on doing it themselves. Woolen yarn and worsted are banned from export under the same penalties as raw wool. Even white cloth is subject to an export duty, giving dyers a monopoly against clothiers. The clothiers might have resisted this, except that most of the leading clothiers are themselves also dyers. Watch-cases, clock-cases, and dial-plates have been prohibited from export as well. Our clock-makers and watch-makers, it appears, are unwilling to let foreign competition raise the price of these components.
elegant: Export restrictions on semi-finished goods pervade every industry. Manufacturers demand the exclusive right to complete every stage of production. Yarn, white cloth, and watch components are all restricted. Dyers hold a monopoly over clothiers -- who tolerate it because most leading clothiers are also dyers. Each trade blocks exports of its inputs to suppress foreign competition.
summary: Export restrictions apply to semi-finished goods across all industries, not just leather. Manufacturers at each stage of production seek monopolies over their inputs, banning or taxing exports of anything not yet fully processed.
distilled: Every manufacturing trade seeks to ban exports of its partially finished inputs, creating cascading monopolies at each stage of production.
notes: Illustrates the cascading logic of mercantilism -- each production stage demands protection, creating a chain of monopolies. The clothier-dyer overlap shows how vertical integration mutes political opposition. Cross-reference 4.8.32 on leather. The watch-case example extends the pattern to precision manufacturing.

refashioned: Under old statutes from Edward III, Henry VIII, and Edward VI, the export of all metals was prohibited. Only lead and tin were excepted, probably because Britain had such great abundance of them that they formed a major part of the kingdom's trade. To encourage mining, a statute under William and Mary exempted iron, copper, and mundic metal made from British ore. The export of all copper bars -- foreign as well as British -- was later permitted under William III. However, the export of unmanufactured brass, gun-metal, bell-metal, and shroff metal remains prohibited. All brass manufactures may be exported duty-free.
elegant: Old statutes banned all metal exports except abundant lead and tin. Later laws gradually exempted iron, copper, and British-ore metals to encourage mining. Yet unmanufactured brass and specialty metals remain banned, while finished brass goods export freely -- the familiar pattern of protecting manufacturers over raw material producers.
summary: Metal export bans have been gradually relaxed over centuries, with exceptions carved out for abundant metals and those made from British ore. The pattern remains: raw and semi-processed metals face restrictions while finished manufactures export freely.
distilled: Metal export bans illustrate the gradual but incomplete liberalization of trade restrictions, always favoring finished manufactures over raw materials.
notes: Historical survey of metal export policy from Edward III through William III -- spanning roughly 1350-1700. Mundic metal is a copper-arsenic alloy. The progression shows mercantilist policy adapting pragmatically while maintaining its core logic of restricting raw material exports.

refashioned:
Where the export of manufacturing materials is not banned outright, it is often subjected to heavy duties.

Under George I, the export of all British manufactured goods that had previously been taxed was made duty-free. However, the following items were excepted: alum, lead, lead-ore, tin, tanned leather, copperas, coals, wool, cards, white woolen cloths, lapis calaminaris, skins of all sorts, glue, rabbit hair or wool, hare's wool, hair of all sorts, horses, and litharge of lead. Apart from horses, every item on this list is either a raw material, a partially finished product that could be considered material for further manufacturing, or an instrument of trade. The statute kept all these items subject to whatever old duties had ever been imposed on them -- the old subsidy plus one percent outward duty.
elegant: Where raw material exports are not banned, they face heavy duties. A George I statute freed all finished British manufactures from export duties -- but specifically excepted raw materials, semi-finished goods, and trade instruments, keeping them subject to all prior duties. The pattern is consistent: finished goods export freely while their inputs remain taxed.
summary: A statute under George I removed export duties on finished manufactures but deliberately maintained them on raw materials, semi-finished goods, and instruments of trade. This codified the mercantilist principle of freeing finished exports while restricting inputs.
distilled: British law freed finished manufactures from export duties while deliberately maintaining duties on all raw materials and semi-finished inputs.
notes: The exception list reads as a catalog of 18th-century industrial inputs. Lapis calaminaris is calamine (zinc ore), used in brass production. Copperas is iron sulfate, used in dyeing. The statute codifies the mercantilist hierarchy: cheap inputs for domestic manufacturers, finished goods for export revenue.

refashioned: Under the same statute, a large number of foreign dyeing drugs were exempted from all import duties. Each of them, however, was then subjected to a modest duty on re-export. Our dyers, it seems, thought it in their interest to encourage imports of these materials by removing all duties, but also in their interest to discourage re-exports by imposing a small tax. This piece of mercantile cleverness, however, most likely defeated its own purpose. It inevitably made importers more cautious, ensuring they brought in only what the domestic market needed. As a result, the home market was always likely to be more thinly supplied, and these materials were always likely to be somewhat more expensive than they would have been if re-export had been as unrestricted as import.
elegant: Dyers secured duty-free imports of foreign dyeing drugs while imposing a small re-export duty -- hoping to keep supplies cheap at home while discouraging foreign competitors from accessing them. But this cleverness backfired: importers brought in only what the home market required, making domestic supplies scarcer and more expensive than free re-export would have allowed.
summary: British dyers arranged duty-free imports of dyeing materials but taxed their re-export, hoping to secure cheap domestic supply. This backfired by discouraging importers from bringing in surplus quantities, keeping the home market thinly supplied and prices higher than necessary.
distilled: Taxing re-exports of duty-free imports backfires by discouraging surplus importation, leaving the domestic market scarcer and more expensive.
notes: A precise example of unintended consequences in trade policy. The dyers' scheme shows how export restrictions on imported goods reduce the incentive to import generously. Connects to Smith's broader theme that mercantile 'ingenuity' routinely defeats its own purpose by distorting market incentives.

refashioned: Under the above-mentioned statute, gum senega (or gum arabic), listed among the enumerated dyeing drugs, could be imported duty-free, subject only to a trivial re-export duty of threepence per hundredweight. At that time, France held an exclusive trade with the Senegal region -- the main source of these gums -- so the British market could not easily be supplied directly from the source. Therefore, under George II, gum senega was allowed to be imported from any part of Europe -- contrary to the general rules of the Navigation Acts. However, since the law did not intend to encourage this roundabout trade, it imposed a duty of ten shillings per hundredweight on such imports, with no drawback available upon re-export.
elegant: Gum senega could be imported duty-free from its source, but France controlled the Senegal trade, so Britain allowed imports from any European port instead -- contrary to the Navigation Acts. However, a ten-shilling duty was imposed on this indirect trade, with no re-export drawback, revealing the tension between pragmatic supply needs and mercantilist principles.
summary: Britain allowed gum senega imports from European middlemen when France controlled the direct source, but imposed a heavy duty on this indirect trade to signal disapproval of the workaround. The episode illustrates mercantilist policy bending under practical necessity while maintaining ideological resistance.
distilled: Britain reluctantly permitted indirect imports of gum senega from Europe while punishing the workaround with heavy duties, revealing mercantilism's tension between ideology and necessity.
notes: Gum senega (gum arabic) was essential for textile dyeing and finishing. The Senegal region was the primary global source. This episode shows the Navigation Acts bending under supply pressure -- a pragmatic exception hedged with punitive duties. Cross-reference Chapter 4.7 on colonial trade restrictions.

refashioned: The war that began in 1755 gave Britain the same exclusive trade with the Senegal region that France had previously enjoyed. As soon as peace was made, British manufacturers moved to exploit this advantage by establishing a monopoly for themselves against both the producers and importers of gum senega. Under George III, exports of gum senega from British Africa were confined to Great Britain, subjected to the same restrictions as enumerated colonial commodities from America and the West Indies. Import duty was set at just sixpence per hundredweight, but re-export duty was set at the enormous rate of one pound ten shillings per hundredweight. The manufacturers intended to force all production into Britain so they could buy it at their own price, and to make re-export so expensive as to effectively prohibit it. Their greed, however, as on many other occasions, defeated itself. The enormous duty created such an incentive for smuggling that large quantities were clandestinely exported -- probably to manufacturing countries across Europe, especially Holland -- not only from Britain but directly from Africa. As a result, the re-export duty was eventually reduced to five shillings per hundredweight.
elegant: After Britain won France's Senegal trade, manufacturers imposed a minimal import duty on gum senega but an enormous re-export duty -- aiming to monopolize supply at artificially low prices. Their greed defeated itself: the duty gap incentivized massive smuggling to Holland and other manufacturing countries. The re-export duty eventually had to be slashed.
summary: British manufacturers exploited wartime territorial gains to monopolize gum senega by setting trivial import duties alongside prohibitive re-export duties. The resulting smuggling was so extensive that the government was forced to reduce the re-export duty dramatically.
distilled: Manufacturers' attempt to monopolize gum senega through prohibitive re-export duties backfired by generating massive smuggling, forcing the government to lower the duty.
notes: The 1755 war is the Seven Years' War. Pattern repeats from 4.8.30: prohibitive duties create smuggling incentives that defeat the policy's purpose. 'Their avidity disappointed itself of its object' -- Smith's recurring phrase for mercantile overreach. Holland as a smuggling destination reflects its role as Europe's commercial hub.

refashioned: In the official book of rates used for calculating the old subsidy, beaver skins were valued at six shillings and eightpence each, and the various duties levied on their import before 1722 amounted to one-fifth of this rate -- sixteen pence per skin. Almost all of this was refunded upon re-export, except for half the old subsidy (just twopence). This import duty on such an important manufacturing material was considered too high, so in 1722 the rate was reduced to two shillings and sixpence, bringing the import duty down to sixpence, of which only half was refundable upon re-export. The same war that secured the Senegal trade also put the main beaver-producing country under British control. Since beaver skins were among the enumerated commodities, exports from America were confined to the British market. Manufacturers quickly saw their opportunity: in 1764, the import duty on beaver skins was slashed to just one penny, but the export duty was raised to sevenpence per skin, with no drawback of the import duty. At the same time, a duty of eighteen pence per pound was imposed on exporting beaver wool, while the import duty on beaver wool -- fourpence to fivepence per piece when imported by British ships -- was left unchanged.
elegant: Beaver skin import duties were repeatedly lowered to supply British manufacturers cheaply, while export duties were raised to trap supply within Britain. After the war put beaver country under British control, manufacturers slashed import duty to a penny but raised export duty to sevenpence -- a textbook case of using colonial conquest to build manufacturing monopolies through asymmetric tariff policy.
summary: The history of beaver skin duties shows manufacturers progressively lowering import duties while raising export duties, especially after colonial conquest put the main source under British control. The goal was always to secure cheap inputs domestically while blocking foreign competitors from accessing the same supply.
distilled: Beaver skin tariff history shows how manufacturers used colonial conquest and asymmetric duties to monopolize cheap raw material supply.
notes: The 'same successful war' is the Seven Years' War (1756-1763), which gave Britain control of Canada -- the primary beaver source. Enumerated commodities were colonial goods that could only be shipped to Britain. The import-export duty asymmetry is a deliberate tool of industrial policy. Cross-reference 4.8.38 on gum senega for the same pattern.

refashioned: Coal can be considered both a manufacturing material and an instrument of trade. Accordingly, heavy duties have been imposed on its export -- amounting in 1783 to more than five shillings per ton, or more than fifteen shillings per chaldron by Newcastle measure. In most cases, this exceeds the original value of the coal at the pit or even at the shipping port for export.
elegant: Coal, serving as both raw material and trade instrument, faces export duties exceeding its value at the mine or port -- a tax of more than 100% on the commodity itself.
summary: Export duties on coal exceed the commodity's original value at the mine, making coal exports among the most heavily taxed of all British trade goods.
distilled: Coal export duties exceed the commodity's pit-head value, effectively doubling its cost for foreign buyers.
notes: A chaldron was a unit of coal measure (roughly 25-26 hundredweight by Newcastle measure). The duty exceeding the commodity's base value represents an extreme case of export taxation -- effectively a prohibitive tariff. Coal was critical both as fuel for manufacturing and as ships' ballast.

refashioned: The export of actual instruments of trade, however, is typically restricted not by heavy duties but by outright prohibition. Under William III, the export of knitting frames or engines for making gloves or stockings was prohibited, with penalties including forfeiture of the equipment plus a forty-pound fine -- half to the king, half to the informer. Similarly, under George III, the export of any utensils used in the cotton, linen, woolen, or silk manufactures was prohibited, with penalties of forfeiture plus two hundred pounds from the offender, and another two hundred pounds from the ship's master who knowingly allowed such equipment to be loaded.
elegant: Trade instruments face outright export prohibitions, not mere duties. Knitting frames, textile manufacturing utensils, and similar equipment cannot be exported at all, under penalties including forfeiture and fines of up to two hundred pounds -- imposed on both the exporter and the ship's captain who allows loading.
summary: While raw materials face export duties, actual manufacturing tools and equipment are subject to absolute export prohibitions backed by severe penalties on both exporters and ship captains.
distilled: Manufacturing equipment faces outright export bans -- a step beyond the duties imposed on raw materials -- revealing the mercantilist hierarchy of restrictions.
notes: The escalation from duties to absolute prohibition reflects the perceived importance of manufacturing technology. Penalties on ship captains create enforcement through the supply chain. The knitting frame was among the most advanced textile technologies of the era. Cross-reference 4.8.42-4.8.44 on restrictions extending to skilled workers themselves.

refashioned: When such severe penalties were imposed on exporting the dead instruments of trade, it was hardly to be expected that the living instrument -- the skilled worker -- would be allowed to leave freely. Under George I, anyone convicted of enticing a British manufacturer's worker to go abroad to practice or teach his trade faced, for the first offense, a fine of up to one hundred pounds plus three months' imprisonment until the fine was paid. For the second offense: a fine at the court's discretion plus twelve months' imprisonment. Under George II, these penalties were increased: five hundred pounds per worker enticed and twelve months' imprisonment for the first offense; one thousand pounds and two years' imprisonment for the second.
elegant: Having banned the export of manufacturing equipment, the law logically extended to banning the export of skilled workers themselves -- 'the living instrument.' Enticing a British artisan to work abroad carried fines escalating from one hundred to one thousand pounds, plus imprisonment -- treating human knowledge as national property.
summary: British law treated skilled workers as national assets whose emigration must be prevented. Penalties for enticing artisans abroad escalated dramatically over successive statutes, reaching one thousand pounds and two years' imprisonment.
distilled: Having banned the export of manufacturing tools, Britain logically extended the prohibition to skilled workers themselves, treating human expertise as state property.
notes: The phrase 'living instrument' versus 'dead instruments' is Smith's own -- a pointed rhetorical contrast. These anti-emigration laws treating workers as quasi-property parallel restrictions on serf mobility in continental Europe. Foreshadows Smith's argument in 4.8.45 about the contradiction with 'liberty of the subject.' Cross-reference 4.8.43-4.8.44 for further restrictions.

refashioned: Under the earlier of these two statutes, if it could be proven that anyone had been enticing an artisan to emigrate, or that an artisan had promised or contracted to go abroad for such purposes, the artisan could be compelled to post a security bond -- at the court's discretion -- guaranteeing he would not leave the country. He could be imprisoned until he provided such security.
elegant: If an artisan was merely suspected of planning to emigrate, he could be forced to post a bond guaranteeing he would stay, and imprisoned until he did so -- preventive detention for the crime of intending to leave.
summary: Courts could compel artisans merely suspected of planning to emigrate to post security bonds, imprisoning them until they complied -- essentially preventive detention for the intention to leave the country.
distilled: Artisans could be imprisoned for merely intending to leave the country until they posted bonds guaranteeing they would stay.
notes: This is preventive restraint -- punishment for intention rather than action. The security bond system effectively made emigration financially impossible for most skilled workers. Represents the most coercive end of mercantilist labor policy, treating workers as bound to the nation.

refashioned: If any artisan went abroad and was found practicing or teaching his trade in a foreign country, and if -- upon being warned by a British minister or consul abroad, or by one of the king's secretaries of state -- he did not return to Britain within six months and permanently reside there afterward, the penalties were devastating. He was declared incapable of receiving any legacy in Britain, of serving as executor or administrator of any estate, or of acquiring any land by inheritance, gift, or purchase. He forfeited all his lands, goods, and personal property to the king. He was declared an alien in every respect and placed entirely outside the king's protection.
elegant: An artisan who practiced his trade abroad and refused to return within six months of official warning was stripped of all property rights, inheritance, and legal standing in Britain -- declared an alien in every respect and placed outside the law's protection. The state treated emigration of skilled workers as a form of treason.
summary: Artisans who practiced their trade abroad and failed to return within six months of warning faced total civil death: forfeiture of all property, loss of inheritance rights, and declaration as aliens without legal protection.
distilled: Artisans who worked abroad and refused to return were stripped of all property, rights, and legal standing -- effectively declared outlaws.
notes: The penalties amount to civil death -- a punishment historically reserved for treason or the most serious felonies. 'Put out of the king's protection' means the person had no legal recourse in British courts. This extreme response reveals how seriously mercantilist policy treated the outflow of technical knowledge. Connects to 4.8.45's critique of these laws as violations of liberty.

refashioned:
It is hardly necessary, I think, to point out how completely such regulations contradict the liberty of the subject -- something we claim to value so highly, but which, in this case, is plainly sacrificed to the petty interests of our merchants and manufacturers.

The supposed purpose of all these regulations is to expand our own manufactures -- not by improving them, but by crushing those of our neighbors and eliminating the inconvenient competition of foreign rivals. Our master manufacturers believe it reasonable that they alone should monopolize the talent of all their countrymen. Though they try to confine knowledge of their trades to as few people as possible -- by limiting apprentice numbers and requiring long apprenticeships -- they are still unwilling to let any of this small number go abroad to teach foreigners.
elegant: These regulations flatly contradict the liberty we claim to cherish, sacrificing it to manufacturers' petty interests. The goal is not to improve domestic industry but to suppress foreign competition. Manufacturers want to monopolize their countrymen's skill -- restricting who can learn each trade while forbidding those who do learn it from teaching foreigners.
summary: Restrictions on artisan emigration blatantly violate the liberty Britain claims to prize, serving only to protect manufacturers from foreign competition. The strategy is not to improve domestic industry but to suppress rivals by hoarding technical knowledge.
distilled: Anti-emigration laws sacrifice the liberty of the subject to manufacturers' desire to monopolize technical knowledge and suppress foreign competition.
notes: One of Smith's most forceful rhetorical passages -- 'the boasted liberty of the subject' is ironic, given the near-feudal constraints on workers. The dual strategy of limiting apprentices domestically while banning emigration creates artificial scarcity of skilled labor. This is Smith's transition to the great conclusion of Chapter 4.8. Cross-reference Book I, Chapter 10 on apprenticeship restrictions.

refashioned:
Consumption is the sole end and purpose of all production. The interest of the producer deserves attention only insofar as it is necessary for promoting the interest of the consumer.

This principle is so self-evident that it would be absurd to try to prove it. Yet in the mercantile system, the consumer's interest is almost constantly sacrificed to the producer's. The system treats production, not consumption, as the ultimate goal of all industry and commerce.
elegant: Consumption is the sole purpose of all production -- the producer's interest matters only insofar as it serves the consumer. This is self-evident, yet the mercantile system constantly sacrifices consumers to producers, treating production itself as the ultimate goal.
summary: Smith states his foundational principle: consumption is the sole purpose of production. The mercantile system inverts this by treating production as the end goal and systematically sacrificing consumer interests to producer interests.
distilled: Consumption is the sole purpose of production, yet mercantilism inverts this by systematically sacrificing consumer interests to those of producers.
notes: One of the most quoted passages in the Wealth of Nations -- a foundational principle of consumer welfare economics. 'Consumption is the sole end and purpose of all production' becomes the criterion against which all trade policy is judged. This consumer-sovereignty principle anticipates modern welfare economics and antitrust thinking. The passage serves as Smith's thesis statement for evaluating the entire mercantile system.

refashioned: In the restrictions on importing foreign goods that compete with domestic products, the consumer's interest is clearly sacrificed to the producer's. It is entirely for the producer's benefit that consumers are forced to pay the higher prices that such monopolies almost always create.
elegant: Import restrictions on competing foreign goods sacrifice the consumer to the producer. Consumers pay higher monopoly prices entirely for the producer's benefit.
summary: Import restrictions exemplify the sacrifice of consumer interests, forcing consumers to pay monopoly-inflated prices solely to benefit domestic producers.
distilled: Import restrictions force consumers to pay monopoly prices for the sole benefit of domestic producers.
notes: Applies the consumer-sovereignty principle from 4.8.46 to import restrictions -- the first of four specific applications. The word 'monopoly' is deliberate: Smith treats all trade restrictions as forms of monopoly. Cross-reference Chapters 4.1-4.3 on import restrictions.

refashioned: It is entirely for the producer's benefit that bounties are granted on the export of certain goods. The consumer at home is forced to pay two taxes: first, the direct tax needed to fund the bounty; and second, the even larger indirect tax created by the resulting increase in the domestic price of the commodity.
elegant: Export bounties benefit producers alone while imposing a double burden on consumers: the tax that funds the bounty, and the higher domestic prices the bounty creates.
summary: Export bounties force domestic consumers to bear a double cost -- the tax funding the bounty and the inflated domestic prices that result -- entirely for the benefit of producers.
distilled: Export bounties impose a double tax on consumers -- funding the bounty directly and suffering inflated domestic prices -- solely to benefit producers.
notes: Second application of the consumer-sovereignty principle to bounties. The 'double tax' insight is important: consumers pay both the explicit tax and the implicit tax of higher prices. Cross-reference Chapter 4.5 on bounties for the detailed analysis.

refashioned: Under the famous commercial treaty with Portugal, British consumers are prevented by duties from buying wine from a neighboring country and are forced to buy it instead from a distant country -- even though the distant country's wine is acknowledged to be of worse quality. Consumers must submit to this inconvenience so that British producers can export their goods to the distant country on more favorable terms than they would otherwise enjoy. Consumers also bear whatever price increase this forced export creates in the domestic market.
elegant: The Portugal treaty forces British consumers to buy inferior wine from a distant country instead of better wine from a neighbor -- all so producers can export to Portugal on favorable terms. Consumers bear both worse quality and higher domestic prices.
summary: The Methuen Treaty with Portugal exemplifies the sacrifice of consumer interests: British consumers are forced to buy inferior Portuguese wine instead of superior French wine, so that British producers can enjoy preferential export terms to Portugal.
distilled: The Portugal wine treaty forces consumers to accept worse wine at higher prices so that producers can enjoy favorable export terms.
notes: The 'famous treaty' is the Methuen Treaty of 1703, which gave Portuguese wines preferential tariff treatment over French wines in exchange for Portugal admitting British woolens. The 'neighbouring country' is France; the 'distant country' is Portugal. Cross-reference Chapter 4.6 on treaties of commerce. A concrete example of consumer welfare sacrificed to producer interests.

refashioned: But in the system of laws governing our American and West Indian colonies, the consumer's interest has been sacrificed to the producer's with even more extravagant waste than in all our other commercial regulations combined. A vast empire has been established for the sole purpose of creating a captive market of customers forced to buy from our producers. For the slight price advantage this monopoly gives our producers, domestic consumers have been saddled with the entire cost of maintaining and defending that empire. In the last two wars alone, more than two hundred million pounds have been spent and a new debt of more than one hundred seventy million contracted -- on top of everything spent for the same purpose in earlier wars. The interest on this debt alone exceeds not only the total extra profit from the colonial trade monopoly, but the entire value of that trade -- indeed, the total value of all goods annually exported to the colonies.
elegant: The colonial system represents the most extravagant sacrifice of consumers to producers. A vast empire was built solely to create captive customers. For the modest price advantage this monopoly gives producers, consumers bear the full cost of imperial defense -- over two hundred million pounds and one hundred seventy million in new debt from the last two wars alone. The interest on this debt exceeds the total value of all colonial trade.
summary: The American and West Indian colonial system is the most extreme example of producer interests overriding consumer interests. A vast empire was created to generate captive markets, but the cost of defending it far exceeds the total value of the colonial trade it was designed to protect.
distilled: The colonial empire was built to create captive markets for producers, but its defense costs vastly exceed the entire value of colonial trade.
notes: Smith's most devastating fiscal critique of the colonial system. The 'two last wars' are the Seven Years' War (1756-1763) and the American Revolutionary War (ongoing when Smith wrote). The debt figures demonstrate that empire was a net loss for Britain as a whole, even if profitable for specific merchants. Cross-reference Chapter 4.7 on colonial trade. This passage influenced anti-imperialist thought for centuries.

refashioned: It is not difficult to determine who designed this entire mercantile system. It certainly was not the consumers, whose interests have been entirely neglected. It was the producers, whose interests have been so carefully protected. And among producers, our merchants and manufacturers have been by far the principal architects. In the regulations discussed in this chapter, the interest of manufacturers has received the most particular attention -- sacrificing not only consumers but also other classes of producers.
elegant: The mercantile system was designed not by neglected consumers but by the producers it protects -- especially merchants and manufacturers, its principal architects. The regulations in this chapter show manufacturers' interests favored even at the expense of other producers.
summary: Smith identifies the architects of the mercantile system as merchants and manufacturers, whose interests it consistently prioritizes -- not only over consumers but over other classes of producers as well.
distilled: The mercantile system was designed by and for merchants and manufacturers, whose interests it protects at everyone else's expense.
notes: Smith's conclusion to Chapter 4.8 -- a political economy argument about whose interests shape trade policy. The distinction between manufacturers and other producers (graziers, farmers) echoes 4.8.32 on collective action. This is Smith's clearest statement of regulatory capture. Cross-reference 4.2.43 on merchants and manufacturers as the architects of the system.

refashioned:
The agricultural systems of political economy will not require as long an explanation as the mercantile system has demanded.

The system that treats land's produce as the sole source of every country's revenue and wealth has, as far as I know, never been adopted by any nation. It exists only in the theories of a few highly learned and ingenious thinkers in France. It would hardly be worthwhile to examine at length the errors of a system that has never done, and probably never will do, any real harm anywhere in the world. I shall try, however, to explain as clearly as I can the main outlines of this very ingenious system.
elegant: The agricultural system -- which treats land as the sole source of national wealth -- has never been adopted by any nation and exists only in the theories of a few brilliant French thinkers. Since it has never done any real harm, a brief examination of its main principles will suffice.
summary: Smith introduces the Physiocratic school, a French economic theory treating agricultural produce as the only true source of national wealth. He notes it has never been adopted in practice and thus requires less extensive critique than the mercantile system.
distilled: The Physiocratic system, treating land as the sole source of wealth, exists only in French theory and has never been adopted by any nation.
notes: Introduces Chapter 4.9 on the Physiocrats (the 'Economists'). Smith treats them with more respect than the mercantilists -- 'very ingenious' -- because they at least got the direction of error right (favoring production over hoarding). The 'few men of great learning' refers primarily to Quesnay and his followers. Smith knew many of them personally during his visit to France in 1764-1766.

refashioned: Colbert, the famous minister of Louis XIV, was a man of integrity, great industry, and detailed knowledge -- experienced and sharp in examining public accounts, with abilities well suited to introducing order into government revenue collection and expenditure. Unfortunately, this minister had fully embraced the prejudices of the mercantile system -- a system of restraint and regulation by nature, and thus naturally appealing to a diligent, methodical administrator accustomed to regulating government departments and establishing checks and controls to keep each within its proper sphere.
elegant: Colbert, Louis XIV's capable finance minister, was perfectly suited to imposing order on government accounts -- and for precisely that reason, he embraced the mercantile system's love of restraint and regulation. A meticulous bureaucrat naturally gravitates toward an economic philosophy built on control.
summary: Smith explains how Colbert's administrative temperament -- methodical, controlling, detail-oriented -- naturally drew him to the mercantile system, which is fundamentally a system of regulation and restraint.
distilled: Colbert's bureaucratic temperament made the mercantile system's regulatory approach instinctively appealing to him.
notes: Jean-Baptiste Colbert (1619-1683) was Louis XIV's Controller-General of Finances. 'Colbertism' became synonymous with French mercantilism. Smith's portrait is sympathetic but diagnostic -- showing how personality shapes policy preference. The insight that bureaucrats prefer systems requiring bureaucratic control anticipates public choice theory.

refashioned: Colbert tried to regulate the industry and commerce of a great country the way one would regulate government departments. Instead of allowing every person to pursue his own interest in his own way -- under the liberal plan of equality, liberty, and justice -- he bestowed extraordinary privileges on certain industries while imposing equally extraordinary restraints on others. Like other European ministers, he was disposed to favor urban industry over rural industry; but to support the towns, he was willing even to depress the countryside. To keep provisions cheap for city dwellers and thereby encourage manufactures and foreign trade, he prohibited the export of grain entirely, cutting off farmers from every foreign market for their most important product. This prohibition, combined with France's ancient provincial restrictions on moving grain between provinces and the arbitrary, degrading taxes levied on farmers in nearly every province, discouraged agriculture far below where it would naturally have risen given France's fertile soil and favorable climate.
