The resulting depression was felt throughout the country, and many inquiries into its causes were launched. One prominent cause appeared to be Colbert's institutional preference for urban industry over rural.
elegant: Colbert regulated France's economy like a government bureau -- granting extraordinary privileges to some industries while crushing others. He favored towns over countryside, banning grain exports entirely to keep urban food prices low. Combined with provincial trade barriers and degrading rural taxes, this depressed French agriculture far below what its fertile soil and climate could sustain. The resulting agricultural decline prompted widespread inquiry, pointing to Colbert's urban bias as a central cause.
summary: Colbert's policies systematically favored urban manufacturing over agriculture by banning grain exports, maintaining provincial trade barriers, and imposing degrading taxes on farmers. This depressed French agriculture far below its natural potential and eventually provoked the intellectual reaction that became Physiocracy.
distilled: Colbert's systematic favoritism toward urban manufacturing over agriculture depressed French farming and provoked the Physiocratic reaction.
notes: Critical context for understanding why Physiocracy arose in France specifically -- as a reaction to Colbertism's anti-agricultural bias. The grain export prohibition was a cornerstone of French mercantilist policy. 'The liberal plan of equality, liberty, and justice' previews Smith's own ideal. Provincial trade barriers (internal tariffs) were a major French economic problem until the Revolution. Cross-reference 4.9.4 on the overcorrection.

refashioned: If the rod is bent too far one way, says the proverb, you must bend it equally far the other way to make it straight. The French philosophers who proposed the system treating agriculture as the sole source of national wealth and revenue seem to have adopted this proverbial wisdom. Just as Colbert's plan had certainly overvalued urban industry relative to rural industry, their system appears to have undervalued it just as certainly.
elegant: The Physiocrats overcorrected. If Colbert bent the rod too far toward urban industry, they bent it equally far toward agriculture -- undervaluing manufacturing and trade just as much as Colbert had undervalued farming.
summary: The Physiocratic system was an overcorrection to Colbert's urban bias. Where mercantilism had overvalued manufacturing, Physiocracy undervalued it by the same degree, swinging from one extreme to the other.
distilled: Physiocracy overcorrected for Colbert's anti-agricultural bias by undervaluing manufacturing just as severely.
notes: The proverb about bending the rod captures Smith's recurring insight that intellectual reactions tend to overcorrect. Smith positions himself as the balanced middle between mercantilism (pro-manufacturing) and Physiocracy (pro-agriculture). This framing device structures his entire evaluation of the Physiocratic system.

refashioned: The Physiocrats divide the people who contribute to a country's annual production into three classes. The first is the class of landowners. The second is the class of farmers and agricultural laborers, whom they honor with the special title of 'the productive class.' The third is the class of artisans, manufacturers, and merchants, whom they demean with the humiliating label of 'the barren or unproductive class.'
elegant: The Physiocrats divide society into three classes: landowners, farmers (honored as 'the productive class'), and artisans, manufacturers, and merchants (stigmatized as 'the barren or unproductive class').
summary: Physiocratic theory divides society into landowners, productive farmers, and supposedly unproductive artisans and merchants -- a classification that elevates agriculture and denigrates all other economic activity.
distilled: Physiocracy divides society into landowners, productive farmers, and supposedly barren artisans and merchants.
notes: The three-class model is central to Physiocratic thought. The terminology is telling: 'productive' vs. 'barren' reflects the belief that only agriculture creates a net surplus (produit net). Smith's use of 'honour' and 'humiliating' signals his skepticism. Cross-reference 4.9.29 where Smith critiques the 'barren' label directly.

refashioned: The class of landowners contributes to annual production through the money they occasionally spend on improving their land -- on buildings, drainage, enclosures, and other improvements that they either create or maintain. These improvements enable farmers to produce more with the same capital and consequently to pay higher rent. This increased rent can be considered the interest or profit due to the landowner on the capital he has invested in improving his land. In the Physiocratic system, such expenditures are called 'ground expenses' (depenses foncieres).
elegant: Landowners contribute to production by investing in land improvements -- buildings, drainage, enclosures -- that enable farmers to produce more and pay higher rent. The increased rent is the return on this investment, which the Physiocrats call 'ground expenses.'
summary: In Physiocratic theory, landowners contribute to annual production by investing in land improvements that increase agricultural output and rent. The return on these investments is called 'ground expenses.'
distilled: Landowners contribute to production by investing in land improvements that raise agricultural output and generate increased rent.
notes: Smith is presenting Physiocratic terminology faithfully before critiquing it. 'Depenses foncieres' (ground expenses) is Quesnay's term. The idea that landowner investment raises productivity and thus rent anticipates Ricardo's theory of rent, though Ricardo's framework differs significantly.

refashioned: Farmers contribute to annual production through what the Physiocrats call 'original expenses' and 'annual expenses.' Original expenses include farming equipment, livestock, seed, and the maintenance of the farmer's family, servants, and animals during at least the first year of occupancy -- before any return can be received from the land. Annual expenses include seed, wear and tear on equipment, and yearly maintenance of servants, animals, and that portion of the farmer's family engaged in cultivation. After paying rent, the farmer's remaining produce must be sufficient, first, to repay his original expenses within a reasonable time along with ordinary profits; and second, to repay his annual expenses each year with ordinary profits as well. These two types of expenses represent the farmer's working and fixed capital. Unless both are regularly restored with a reasonable profit, the farmer cannot sustain his business compared to other occupations and will, in his own interest, abandon farming as soon as possible. The portion of produce needed to keep the farmer in business should be considered a fund sacred to agriculture. If the landlord violates this -- by demanding excessive rent -- he inevitably reduces his own land's output, and within a few years disables the farmer from paying not just the excessive rent but even the reasonable rent the land could otherwise have yielded.
elegant: Farmers invest two types of capital: 'original expenses' (equipment, livestock, seed, first-year maintenance) and 'annual expenses' (yearly seed, equipment repair, labor maintenance). Both must be repaid with ordinary profits, or farmers will abandon agriculture for better-paying occupations. The produce needed to sustain farming is sacred -- if landlords violate it by demanding excessive rent, they destroy their own land's productivity and future rental income.
summary: The Physiocrats identify two types of farming capital -- original startup costs and annual operating costs -- both of which must be recovered with profit for farming to remain viable. Excessive rent demands by landlords destroy the very agricultural productivity that generates their income.
distilled: Farming requires both startup and annual capital that must be recovered with profit; landlords who demand excessive rent destroy the productivity that generates their own income.
notes: Depenses primitives (original expenses) correspond roughly to fixed capital; depenses annuelles (annual expenses) to circulating capital -- categories Smith develops in Book II. The 'sacred fund' concept anticipates modern ideas about sustainable yield and the importance of maintaining productive capacity. The warning about rack-renting destroying long-term productivity connects to Book III on agricultural development.

refashioned: The rent that properly belongs to the landlord is nothing more than the net produce remaining after fully paying all the necessary expenses of raising the total crop. It is because farmers' labor, beyond covering all these necessary expenses, yields a net surplus of this kind that the Physiocrats distinguish this class with the honorable title of 'the productive class.' Their original and annual expenses are called 'productive expenses' because, beyond replacing their own value, they generate the annual reproduction of this net surplus.
elegant: Rent is the net surplus remaining after all farming costs are covered. Farmers earn the title 'productive class' because their labor produces this surplus beyond mere cost recovery -- their expenses are 'productive' because they generate new value above their own replacement.
summary: In Physiocratic theory, rent represents the net surplus after all agricultural costs. Farmers are called 'productive' because their labor generates value beyond mere cost recovery, unlike other classes whose labor only replaces its own expense.
distilled: The Physiocrats call farmers 'productive' because their labor generates a net surplus -- rent -- beyond replacing their own costs.
notes: The 'produit net' (net product) is the central concept of Physiocratic economics. Only agriculture generates this surplus; all other activities merely transform or transfer existing value. This is the foundation for the Physiocratic policy of taxing only land rent (the 'impot unique'). Smith will challenge this distinction in 4.9.29-4.9.36.

refashioned: The ground expenses -- what the landlord spends on improving his land -- are also honored in this system with the label 'productive expenses.' Until these expenses, along with ordinary profits, have been fully repaid through the increased rent they generate, that increased rent should be regarded as sacred and untouchable -- exempt from both church tithes and royal taxation. If it is taxed prematurely, the church discourages the very land improvements that would increase its own future tithes, and the king discourages improvements that would increase his own future tax revenue. Therefore, in a well-ordered system, since ground expenses eventually reproduce their own value and additionally generate a net surplus, they too are classified as productive expenses.
elegant: Landlord investments in land improvement are also 'productive expenses' in the Physiocratic system. Until these investments are fully repaid through higher rent, that rent should be exempt from tithes and taxes -- because taxing improvements prematurely discourages the very investments that would increase future church and state revenues.
summary: The Physiocrats argue that landlord investments in land improvement should be temporarily exempt from taxation until they are repaid, since premature taxation discourages the improvements that would generate greater future revenue for both church and state.
distilled: Taxing land improvements before they are repaid discourages the very investments that would increase future government and church revenue.
notes: The argument for tax exemption on improvement capital anticipates Henry George's distinction between taxing land values versus improvement values. The 'sacred and inviolable' language reflects Physiocratic reverence for agricultural investment. The practical policy implication -- don't tax improvements prematurely -- remains relevant in modern development economics and property tax design.

refashioned: The landlord's ground expenses, together with the farmer's original and annual expenses, are the only three types of expenditure that the Physiocratic system considers productive. All other expenses, and all other classes of people -- even those commonly regarded as the most productive -- are in this framework treated as entirely barren and unproductive.
elegant: Only three types of spending qualify as productive in Physiocratic theory: landlord improvements, farmer startup costs, and farmer operating costs. Everything else -- including the work of those commonly thought most productive -- is classified as barren.
summary: The Physiocratic system recognizes only three categories of productive expenditure, all related to agriculture. All other economic activities and classes are considered unproductive, regardless of their apparent contribution.
distilled: Physiocracy classifies only agricultural expenditures as productive, treating all other economic activity as barren.
notes: This stark binary -- productive agriculture versus barren everything else -- is the claim Smith will systematically dismantle in 4.9.29-4.9.36. The phrase 'even those who in the common apprehensions of men are regarded as the most productive' signals Smith's disagreement while still presenting the Physiocratic view fairly.

refashioned: Artisans and manufacturers, in particular -- whose industry is commonly thought to add enormously to the value of raw materials -- are represented in this system as an entirely barren and unproductive class. Their labor, it is argued, merely replaces the capital that employs them along with its ordinary profits. That capital consists of the materials, tools, and wages advanced by their employer, and it constitutes the fund for their employment and maintenance. The employer's profit is the fund for his own maintenance. Since he advances to his workers the materials, tools, and wages they need, he also advances to himself what he needs to live -- generally proportioned to the profit he expects from the price of their work. Unless that price repays both his workers' maintenance and his own, along with the cost of materials and tools, the venture does not repay its full expense. The profits of manufacturing capital are therefore not, like rent, a net surplus remaining after all costs. The farmer's capital yields both profit and rent to another person; the manufacturer's capital yields only profit. The expense of employing artisans and manufacturers merely continues the existence of its own value without producing any new value -- it is therefore barren and unproductive. The expense of employing farmers, on the other hand, produces a new value beyond replacing its own costs: the landlord's rent. It is therefore a productive expense.
elegant: The Physiocrats argue that manufacturing labor merely replaces the capital invested in it -- materials, tools, wages, and the employer's maintenance -- without generating any surplus beyond. Unlike farming, which yields both profit and rent (a net surplus to the landlord), manufacturing yields only profit sufficient to cover costs. Manufacturing expense merely perpetuates its own value; agricultural expense creates new value.
summary: In Physiocratic theory, manufacturing labor is unproductive because it only replaces the capital invested in it without generating any net surplus. Farming, by contrast, yields both profit to the farmer and rent to the landlord -- a genuine net addition to wealth that manufacturing cannot match.
distilled: The Physiocrats classify manufacturing as unproductive because it merely replaces invested capital, unlike farming which generates a net surplus in the form of rent.
notes: This is the core Physiocratic argument Smith is setting up to refute. The distinction hinges on the 'produit net' -- the surplus above all costs. Smith will argue in 4.9.29-4.9.31 that this distinction is invalid because manufacturing does add value to existing stock. The logical structure -- farmer yields profit plus rent, manufacturer yields only profit -- is formally correct but economically misleading, as Smith will show.

refashioned: Mercantile capital is equally barren and unproductive in this system, just like manufacturing capital. It merely continues the existence of its own value without producing anything new. The merchant's profits are simply the repayment of the maintenance he advances to himself while his capital is employed -- they are only the repayment of part of the expense of employing it.
elegant: Mercantile capital, like manufacturing capital, is classified as barren -- merely continuing its own value without creating new wealth. Merchants' profits simply repay their own maintenance costs during the period of employment.
summary: The Physiocrats extend their 'unproductive' classification to mercantile capital as well, arguing that trade merely circulates existing value without generating any net surplus.
distilled: Mercantile capital, like manufacturing, is classified as unproductive in Physiocratic theory because it merely circulates existing value.
notes: Extends the unproductive classification from manufacturing to trade. The Physiocratic view of commerce as mere circulation -- adding no value -- anticipates Marxist critiques of merchant capital, though arriving at opposite policy conclusions. Smith's refutation in 4.9.29-4.9.36 covers both manufacturing and mercantile capital.

refashioned: The labor of artisans and manufacturers, according to this view, never adds anything to the total annual value of a country's raw produce. It greatly increases the value of particular parts of it, certainly. But the consumption that this labor requires is precisely equal to the value it adds, so the total value is never increased at any moment. A lace-maker, for example, might raise the value of a penny's worth of flax to thirty pounds -- appearing to multiply it seven thousand times over. But in reality, he adds nothing to the total value of annual raw production. Making that lace may take two years of labor. The thirty pounds he receives is nothing more than the repayment of subsistence he has consumed over those two years. The value he adds to the flax each day, month, or year merely replaces the value of what he has consumed during that same period. At no point does he add anything to the total annual value of the country's raw output -- the portion he continually consumes always equals the value he continually produces. The extreme poverty of most workers in this expensive but trivial trade confirms that the price of their work does not, in ordinary cases, exceed the value of their subsistence. The work of farmers and country laborers is different: the landlord's rent is a value that their labor continually produces over and above completely replacing all the expenses of their employment and their employer's.
elegant: The Physiocrats argue that manufacturing labor adds nothing to total national output because the worker's consumption equals his production. A lace-maker may multiply flax's value seven-thousandfold, but his thirty-pound product merely repays two years of subsistence consumed. The poverty of such workers confirms this -- their earnings barely cover their maintenance. Only farm labor generates a surplus (rent) above the full cost of employment.
summary: Physiocratic theory holds that manufacturing adds nothing to total national output because workers consume as much as they produce. The lace-making example illustrates this: apparent value multiplication merely repays the worker's subsistence. Only agricultural labor generates a genuine surplus beyond all costs.
distilled: Manufacturing labor appears to create enormous value but merely replaces workers' subsistence costs, generating no surplus beyond its own expenses, unlike agriculture which produces rent.
notes: The lace example is Quesnay's own -- a deliberately extreme case of apparent value creation that the Physiocrats classify as value neutral. Smith will refute this argument in 4.9.31 by showing it conflates flow and stock concepts. The poverty observation is empirically accurate for 18th-century lace workers but does not prove the theoretical point. Cross-reference 4.9.31 for Smith's counterargument.

refashioned:
Artisans, manufacturers, and merchants can increase the wealth of their society only through saving -- or as this system calls it, 'privation': depriving themselves of some portion of the funds meant for their own subsistence. They reproduce nothing but those funds annually. Unless they save part of them each year, society's wealth cannot grow through their industry at all. Farmers, by contrast, can fully enjoy everything allocated to their own subsistence and still increase society's wealth, because their labor produces a net surplus beyond their own needs -- and increases in this surplus necessarily increase the nation's wealth.

Nations composed largely of landowners and farmers, like France or England, can therefore grow rich through industry and enjoyment. Nations composed chiefly of merchants, artisans, and manufacturers, like Holland and Hamburg, can grow rich only through parsimony and self-denial. These different circumstances naturally produce different national characters: the former cultivate liberality, frankness, and good fellowship; the latter tend toward narrowness, meanness, and a selfish disposition averse to social pleasure.
elegant: The Physiocrats argue that merchants and manufacturers can increase wealth only by saving, since their labor merely replaces its own costs. Farmers can enjoy their full income while still growing national wealth through the net surplus their labor generates. Agricultural nations like France grow rich through productivity and enjoyment; commercial nations like Holland can grow rich only through parsimony -- producing different national characters accordingly.
summary: Physiocratic theory holds that commercial nations can grow wealthy only through saving, while agricultural nations grow wealthy through productive surplus. This leads to a cultural claim: agricultural societies cultivate generosity and sociability, while commercial societies breed narrowness and selfishness.
distilled: The Physiocrats claim agricultural nations grow rich through productive surplus and enjoy generous cultures, while commercial nations can grow only through austerity and develop selfish characters.
notes: The cultural generalization about national character -- generous farmers versus selfish merchants -- reflects common 18th-century stereotypes about France versus Holland. Smith does not endorse this claim; he is presenting Physiocratic doctrine. The parsimony distinction connects to Book II's analysis of savings and capital accumulation. Cross-reference 4.9.35 where Smith argues merchants may actually be more inclined to save than farmers.

refashioned: The unproductive class -- merchants, artisans, and manufacturers -- is maintained and employed entirely at the expense of the other two classes: landowners and farmers. These two classes furnish the unproductive class with both its work materials and its subsistence -- the grain and livestock it consumes while working. The landowners and farmers ultimately pay both the wages of all workers in the unproductive class and the profits of all their employers. These workers and employers are, in effect, servants of the landowners and farmers. They are merely servants who work outside the house, just as domestic servants work within it. Both are equally maintained at the expense of the same masters. Both types of labor are equally unproductive -- adding nothing to the total value of raw produce, but rather constituting a charge that must be paid out of it.
elegant: In the Physiocratic view, merchants, artisans, and manufacturers are maintained entirely by landowners and farmers, who supply their materials, food, wages, and employers' profits. They are effectively outdoor servants -- as unproductive as household staff, adding nothing to total output but representing a cost paid from agricultural surplus.
summary: Physiocratic theory treats the entire commercial and manufacturing class as economic dependents of landowners and farmers, comparable to domestic servants -- maintained at others' expense and adding nothing to total national output.
distilled: The Physiocrats regard merchants and manufacturers as economic dependents of the agricultural classes, no more productive than household servants.
notes: The 'outdoor servant' analogy is deliberately provocative -- Smith is presenting it to highlight how extreme the Physiocratic position is. Comparing manufacturers to menial servants inverts the common view that manufacturing drives wealth. Smith will directly challenge this in 4.9.30 by distinguishing between servants whose work perishes instantly and manufacturers whose work is embodied in vendible commodities.

refashioned: The unproductive class, however, is not merely useful but greatly useful to the other two classes. Through the industry of merchants, artisans, and manufacturers, landowners and farmers can purchase both foreign goods and domestic manufactures with the product of far less labor than if they tried, clumsily and unskillfully, to import or make these things themselves. The unproductive class frees farmers from many concerns that would otherwise distract them from cultivating their land. The additional produce that farmers can raise through this undivided attention more than pays for the entire cost of maintaining the unproductive class. Though the industry of merchants, artisans, and manufacturers is in its own nature entirely unproductive, it indirectly increases agricultural output by enhancing the productive powers of farm labor -- freeing it to focus on its proper work, the cultivation of land. The plough runs more easily and effectively thanks to the labor of the person whose own business is furthest from the plough.
elegant: Though classified as unproductive, merchants and manufacturers are immensely useful. They supply landowners and farmers with goods far more cheaply than self-production could, and they free farmers to focus entirely on cultivation. This undivided attention raises agricultural output enough to more than cover the cost of the unproductive class. The plough runs better thanks to the labor of those furthest from it.
summary: Even within Physiocratic theory, the so-called unproductive class serves a vital function by enabling agricultural specialization. By handling manufacturing and trade, they free farmers to concentrate on cultivation, generating enough additional output to cover the entire cost of maintaining the commercial classes.
distilled: The 'unproductive' commercial class is nonetheless essential because it enables agricultural specialization, allowing farmers to focus on cultivation and produce more.
notes: Smith's description of specialization benefits anticipates his own division-of-labor argument from Book I. 'The plough goes frequently the easier and the better by means of the labour of the man whose business is most remote from the plough' is one of Smith's most elegant formulations. Even the Physiocrats acknowledged indirect benefits of manufacturing -- they just refused to call it 'productive.'

refashioned: It can never be in the interest of landowners and farmers to restrain or discourage the industry of merchants, artisans, and manufacturers in any way. The greater the freedom this class enjoys, the greater the competition in all its component trades, and the more cheaply the other two classes will be supplied with both foreign goods and domestic manufactures.
elegant: Landowners and farmers benefit from maximum freedom for merchants and manufacturers. Greater freedom means greater competition, which means cheaper goods for the agricultural classes.
summary: The Physiocrats conclude that agricultural interests are best served by granting maximum freedom to commerce and manufacturing, since competition among these trades drives down prices for farmers and landowners.
distilled: Even in Physiocratic theory, free commerce benefits agriculture by increasing competition and lowering the prices farmers pay for goods.
notes: Here the Physiocratic system arrives at free trade conclusions despite its agricultural bias -- one reason Smith respects it more than mercantilism. The competition argument aligns with Smith's own framework. Cross-reference 4.9.18 for the reciprocal argument that the commercial class also benefits from agricultural freedom.

refashioned: Nor can it ever be in the interest of the unproductive class to oppress the other two. It is the surplus produce of the land -- what remains after maintaining first the farmers and then the landowners -- that maintains and employs the unproductive class. The larger this surplus, the larger the maintenance and employment available to merchants and manufacturers. The establishment of perfect justice, perfect liberty, and perfect equality is the very simple secret that most effectively secures the highest degree of prosperity for all three classes.
elegant: The commercial class has no interest in oppressing agriculture, since its own livelihood depends on the agricultural surplus. The larger the surplus, the more commerce and manufacturing can thrive. Perfect justice, liberty, and equality is the simple secret to maximum prosperity for all.
summary: The Physiocratic system concludes that mutual benefit requires freedom for all classes: the commercial class depends on agricultural surplus and cannot prosper by oppressing its source. Perfect liberty and justice maximize prosperity for everyone.
distilled: Perfect justice, liberty, and equality is the simple secret to prosperity for all classes, since commerce depends on agricultural surplus and cannot thrive by oppressing its source.
notes: This is the Physiocratic policy conclusion Smith most admires -- 'perfect justice, perfect liberty, and perfect equality.' The phrase anticipates Smith's own 'system of natural liberty' in 4.9.59. Despite their theoretical errors about productive and unproductive labor, the Physiocrats arrived at sound policy prescriptions. Cross-reference 4.9.37 for Smith's generous assessment.

refashioned: The merchants, artisans, and manufacturers of commercial states like Holland and Hamburg -- composed chiefly of this 'unproductive' class -- are maintained and employed entirely at the expense of foreign landowners and farmers. The only difference from the domestic case is that these landowners and farmers are located at great distance, in other countries under other governments, rather than nearby.
elegant: Commercial states like Holland and Hamburg are maintained by foreign agriculture rather than domestic. Their merchant and manufacturing classes depend on distant landowners and farmers in other countries -- the only difference from the domestic model is geographic distance.
summary: The Physiocrats extend their framework to commercial city-states like Holland and Hamburg, arguing that their entire economies are sustained by the agricultural surplus of foreign countries rather than domestic farmland.
distilled: Commercial states like Holland are sustained by foreign agricultural surplus, according to the Physiocratic view -- dependent on distant farmers rather than their own.
notes: Holland and Hamburg are recurring Physiocratic examples of trade-dependent states. The implication is that such states are economically parasitic on agricultural nations -- a view Smith will qualify. This anticipates modern debates about trade dependency and the vulnerability of service-based economies.

refashioned: Such mercantile states, however, are not merely useful but greatly useful to the inhabitants of the countries they trade with. They fill an important gap by supplying the merchants, artisans, and manufacturers that those countries ought to have at home but, due to some deficiency in their own policies, do not.
elegant: Commercial states serve a vital function for their trading partners by filling the gap where those countries lack their own merchants and manufacturers -- a deficiency usually caused by their own policy failures.
summary: Commercial states like Holland serve agricultural nations by providing the commercial and manufacturing services those nations have failed to develop domestically, usually due to poor policy.
distilled: Commercial states fill a vital gap for agricultural nations that lack their own merchants and manufacturers due to policy failures.
notes: Even within the Physiocratic framework, commercial states provide essential services. The phrase 'some defect in their policy' hints at Smith's broader argument that mercantilist restrictions on domestic trade prevent the natural development of commercial classes. Cross-reference 4.9.22 on how free trade would eventually fill this gap naturally.

refashioned: It can never be in the interest of agricultural nations to discourage or harm the industry of such commercial states by imposing high duties on their trade or on the goods they supply. Such duties, by making those goods more expensive, would only reduce the real value of the agricultural surplus with which those goods are purchased. They would discourage the growth of that surplus and therefore discourage the improvement and cultivation of the land itself. The most effective way to raise the value of the agricultural surplus, encourage its growth, and promote the improvement of the land is to allow the most complete freedom of trade with all commercial nations.
elegant: Agricultural nations harm themselves by taxing commercial states' goods, because higher import prices reduce the purchasing power of their agricultural surplus and discourage land improvement. The best policy for raising agricultural value and encouraging cultivation is complete freedom of trade.
summary: The Physiocrats argue that agricultural nations damage their own interests by imposing duties on commercial states, since this reduces the purchasing power of agricultural surplus and discourages land improvement. Free trade is the best policy for promoting agriculture.
distilled: Agricultural nations harm their own farming interests by taxing imports from commercial states, since this reduces the purchasing power of their surplus and discourages cultivation.
notes: A Physiocratic argument for free trade that Smith endorses. The logic runs: tariffs raise import prices -> reduce real value of agricultural surplus -> discourage agricultural investment -> reduce output. This connects to Smith's broader case that trade restrictions harm the very industries they claim to protect. Cross-reference 4.9.25 on the damage protectionism inflicts on agriculture.

refashioned:
Complete freedom of trade would also be the most effective way for agricultural nations to develop their own artisans, manufacturers, and merchants -- and to fill, in the best and most advantageous manner, the important gap they feel at home.

The continual growth of the agricultural surplus would, over time, create more capital than could be profitably invested in farming alone. The excess would naturally flow into employing artisans and manufacturers domestically. These artisans, finding both their materials and their subsistence at home, could immediately -- even with less skill -- work as cheaply as the craftsmen of commercial states, who must import both from a distance. Even if initially less skilled, they could sell their goods at home as cheaply as imported goods burdened by long-distance transport costs. As their skill improved, they would soon undersell imports. The manufacturers of commercial states would first face domestic competition in these agricultural nations' home markets and would soon be priced out entirely. Eventually, the cheapness of these agricultural nations' manufactures would extend their sales to foreign markets, displacing the products of commercial states abroad as well.
elegant: Free trade would naturally develop domestic manufacturing in agricultural nations. Growing agricultural surplus would generate excess capital that flows into manufacturing. Domestic artisans, with local access to materials and food, could immediately compete with distant commercial states on cost. As skills improved, they would undersell imports at home and then compete abroad -- naturally displacing the commercial states' manufacturers.
summary: The Physiocratic argument for free trade includes the insight that agricultural surplus, if allowed to grow freely, would naturally generate the capital needed to develop domestic manufacturing. Local manufacturers, with proximity advantages, would eventually outcompete distant commercial states both at home and abroad.
distilled: Free trade would let growing agricultural surplus naturally fund domestic manufacturing, which would eventually outcompete distant commercial states through lower transport costs and improving skills.
notes: This is a sophisticated infant-industry argument in reverse -- instead of protecting nascent industries with tariffs, free trade grows the agricultural surplus that naturally funds their development. The proximity advantage (local materials and subsistence) anticipates modern trade theory on transport costs. The progression from import substitution to export competition describes a natural development path. Cross-reference 4.9.23 on how this extends to foreign trade.

refashioned: This continual growth of both raw and manufactured output would eventually create more capital than could be profitably employed in either agriculture or manufacturing. The surplus capital would naturally flow into foreign trade, exporting to other countries whatever raw and manufactured goods exceeded domestic demand. In this export trade, the merchants of an agricultural nation would have the same advantage over those of commercial nations that its manufacturers had: the advantage of finding their cargo, stores, and provisions at home, rather than having to procure them from a distance. With inferior navigation skills, they could still sell their cargo as cheaply in foreign markets as the merchants of commercial nations; with equal skills, they could sell it cheaper. They would soon rival the commercial nations in foreign trade and eventually displace them entirely.
elegant: As agricultural nations develop surplus capital beyond farming and manufacturing needs, it would naturally flow into foreign trade. Their merchants, like their manufacturers, would enjoy the advantage of locally available cargo and provisions -- enabling them to match and then undersell the merchants of commercial nations even with inferior seamanship. Natural development would eventually displace the commercial states from foreign trade entirely.
summary: The Physiocratic growth model predicts that agricultural nations developing freely would generate capital surpluses that flow naturally from agriculture to manufacturing to foreign trade, eventually outcompeting and displacing commercial states at every stage.
distilled: Agricultural nations developing freely would naturally generate surplus capital flowing into manufacturing and then foreign trade, eventually displacing commercial states entirely.
notes: Describes a three-stage development path: agriculture -> manufacturing -> foreign trade. This natural progression echoes Smith's own argument in Book III about the natural order of economic development (agriculture first, then manufacturing, then foreign trade). The proximity advantage compounds at each stage. Cross-reference Book III, Chapter 1 on the natural progress of opulence.

refashioned: According to this liberal and generous system, then, the most advantageous way for an agricultural nation to develop its own artisans, manufacturers, and merchants is to grant the most complete freedom of trade to those of all other nations. This raises the value of the agricultural surplus, whose continual growth gradually builds a fund that inevitably, over time, produces all the artisans, manufacturers, and merchants the nation needs.
elegant: The Physiocratic conclusion: the best way to develop domestic industry is to grant complete trade freedom to all nations. This maximizes the agricultural surplus whose growth naturally funds the development of all needed manufacturing and commerce.
summary: The Physiocrats conclude that complete free trade is the optimal development strategy: it maximizes agricultural surplus, which naturally generates the capital needed to develop all other industries domestically.
distilled: Complete free trade maximizes agricultural surplus, which naturally generates the capital to develop all needed domestic industries over time.
notes: The policy conclusion of the Physiocratic development model -- perhaps its most important practical contribution. The argument that free trade is the best 'industrial policy' remains influential. Smith endorses this conclusion while rejecting the theoretical foundation (that only agriculture is productive). Cross-reference 4.9.37 for Smith's overall assessment.

refashioned: When an agricultural nation instead oppresses foreign trade -- through high duties or outright prohibitions -- it necessarily harms its own interest in two distinct ways. First, by raising the price of all foreign goods and manufactures, it reduces the real value of its own agricultural surplus, since that surplus is what purchases those goods. Second, by granting a sort of monopoly of the home market to its own merchants, artisans, and manufacturers, it raises the rate of profit in commerce and manufacturing relative to agriculture. This either draws capital away from farming or prevents new capital from flowing into it. This policy therefore discourages agriculture in two ways: first, by lowering the real value of agricultural output and thus its profit rate; and second, by raising the profit rate in all competing occupations. Agriculture becomes less attractive and trade more attractive, tempting everyone to shift both capital and effort away from farming toward commerce and manufacturing.
elegant: Protectionism hurts agricultural nations doubly: it reduces the purchasing power of agricultural surplus by raising import prices, and it diverts capital from farming by artificially inflating commercial profits. Agriculture is simultaneously made less valuable and less competitive -- the opposite of the policy's supposed intent.
summary: Protectionism damages agricultural nations in two ways: it reduces the real value of farm output by raising import prices, and it diverts capital from agriculture by artificially raising commercial profits. Both effects discourage the very farming the policy claims to support.
distilled: Protectionism hurts agriculture doubly -- reducing the purchasing power of farm output while diverting capital to artificially profitable commerce.
notes: This is the Physiocratic argument against protectionism that Smith fully endorses. The two-channel mechanism (reduced agricultural value + capital diversion) is analytically precise. The irony -- protectionism meant to help agriculture actually harms it -- is a recurring Smith theme. Cross-reference 4.9.57 where Smith applies this logic to critique the Physiocratic system itself.

refashioned: Even if protectionism could develop a nation's artisans, manufacturers, and merchants somewhat faster than free trade would -- which is itself quite doubtful -- it would develop them prematurely, before the economy was truly ready for them. By accelerating one type of industry too quickly, it would depress another more valuable type. By forcing the growth of an industry that merely replaces its own capital with profit, it would depress an industry that, beyond replacing capital and profit, also yields a net surplus -- free rent to the landlord. It would depress productive labor by prematurely encouraging labor that is altogether barren and unproductive.
elegant: Even if protectionism could speed up manufacturing development -- which is doubtful -- it would do so prematurely, at the cost of depressing the more valuable agricultural sector. Forcing the growth of an industry that merely replaces its own costs sacrifices one that generates a genuine surplus.
summary: The Physiocrats argue that even if protectionism could accelerate manufacturing, it would do so at the cost of depressing agriculture -- trading a sector that generates genuine surplus (rent) for one that merely replaces its own costs.
distilled: Protectionism prematurely forces manufacturing at the expense of more valuable agriculture, sacrificing genuine surplus for mere cost recovery.
notes: This argument uses the Physiocratic productive/unproductive distinction Smith will later challenge. Even within their own framework, the conclusion stands: forced development disrupts the natural sequence. Smith's version of this argument (in 4.9.57-4.9.58) is more powerful because it does not depend on the claim that manufacturing is unproductive. Cross-reference Book III on the natural vs. forced order of development.

refashioned: How the total annual produce of the land is distributed among the three classes, and how the labor of the unproductive class merely replaces its own consumption without increasing the total -- all this is represented by Quesnay, the profoundly ingenious author of the system, in certain arithmetical tables. The first and most important of these, which he calls the 'Tableau Economique,' represents the distribution as it would occur under conditions of perfect liberty and therefore maximum prosperity -- where annual output yields the greatest possible net surplus and each class receives its proper share. Subsequent tables represent the distribution under various conditions of restraint and regulation, where either the landlord class or the commercial class is favored over the farming class, encroaching on the share properly belonging to it. Every such encroachment, every violation of the natural distribution that perfect liberty would establish, must -- according to this system -- progressively degrade the total annual output and cause a gradual decline in real national wealth. This decline proceeds faster or slower depending on how severely the natural distribution is violated. These subsequent tables represent the different degrees of decline corresponding to different degrees of distortion.
elegant: Quesnay formalized his theory in the Tableau Economique -- arithmetical tables showing how annual output distributes among the three classes. Under perfect liberty, output is maximized and each class gets its proper share. Any deviation -- favoring landlords or merchants over farmers -- progressively degrades total output and national wealth, with decline proportional to the degree of distortion.
summary: Quesnay's Tableau Economique is the mathematical centerpiece of Physiocratic theory, showing optimal output distribution under perfect liberty and progressive economic decline under any deviation. Each departure from the natural order produces degradation proportional to the distortion.
distilled: Quesnay's Tableau Economique shows that any deviation from the natural distribution under perfect liberty progressively degrades total national output.
notes: The Tableau Economique (1758) was considered by Physiocrats as one of the greatest inventions in history (see 4.9.40). It is the first formal model of an economy's circular flow -- anticipating Leontief's input-output analysis. 'Very ingenious and profound' reflects Smith's genuine respect for Quesnay. The deterministic relationship between policy distortion and economic decline is what Smith challenges in 4.9.28.

refashioned: Some theoretical physicians have imagined that human health could be maintained only by following a precise regimen of diet and exercise, where even the slightest deviation inevitably caused disease proportional to the violation. Experience, however, suggests that the human body frequently maintains perfect health under a wide variety of regimens -- including some generally considered quite unwholesome. The healthy human body, it seems, contains some unknown principle of self-preservation capable of preventing or correcting the ill effects even of a very poor regimen. Quesnay, who was himself a physician -- and a very theoretical one -- seems to have entertained a similar notion about the political body. He appears to have imagined that it could thrive only under one precise regimen: the exact regimen of perfect liberty and perfect justice. He seems not to have considered that in the political body, the natural effort every person continually makes to improve his own condition is a principle of preservation capable of preventing and correcting many of the ill effects of a partially unjust and oppressive political economy. Such a political economy, though it certainly slows progress, is not always capable of stopping a nation's advance toward wealth -- and still less of making it go backward. If no nation could prosper without perfect liberty and perfect justice, no nation in the world could ever have prospered. In the political body, however, the wisdom of nature has fortunately made ample provision for remedying many of the bad effects of human folly and injustice -- just as it has done in the natural body for remedying the effects of sloth and intemperance.
elegant: Quesnay the physician applied medical thinking to economics: just as some doctors believe only a precise regimen maintains health, he believed only perfect liberty and justice could sustain prosperity. But the human body thrives under diverse regimens thanks to an innate principle of self-preservation. Similarly, in the political body, every person's natural drive to improve his own condition corrects many effects of bad policy. If nations required perfect liberty to prosper, none ever could have. Nature has provided ample resilience against human folly in both body and economy.
summary: Smith critiques Quesnay's rigidity by comparing it to overly precise medical theories. Just as the body has self-healing powers, economies have a built-in corrective force: individuals' drive to improve their own conditions. This resilience means nations can prosper even under imperfect and partially oppressive policies.
distilled: Economies, like bodies, have self-correcting mechanisms -- the individual drive to improve one's condition -- that offset bad policy, so nations can prosper without perfect liberty.
notes: One of Smith's most important passages -- it tempers his own free-market arguments with realism. The 'natural effort to better one's condition' is Smith's version of economic resilience theory. Quesnay was physician to Louis XV and Madame de Pompadour, making the medical analogy biographically precise. This passage is often cited as Smith's most pragmatic statement -- acknowledging that imperfect systems still function. Cross-reference 4.2.9 on the 'invisible hand' as a similar self-correcting mechanism.

refashioned:
The fundamental error of this system, however, lies in representing artisans, manufacturers, and merchants as entirely barren and unproductive. The following observations will demonstrate why this characterization is improper.

First, the system itself acknowledges that this class annually reproduces the value of its own consumption and at least maintains the capital that employs it. On this ground alone, calling it barren or unproductive seems very inappropriate. We would not call a marriage barren just because it produced only a son and a daughter -- replacing the father and mother without increasing the human population. Farmers certainly produce more, yielding a net surplus (rent) beyond replacing their capital and costs. Just as a marriage producing three children is certainly more productive than one producing two, farm labor is certainly more productive than manufacturing labor. But the superior productiveness of one does not make the other barren.
elegant: The Physiocrats' fundamental error is calling manufacturing 'barren.' Their own system admits it reproduces the value of its consumption and maintains its capital. We would not call a marriage barren for producing two children instead of three -- farm labor may be more productive, but that does not make manufacturing unproductive.
summary: Smith begins his critique of the Physiocrats by challenging their core classification: manufacturing is not barren simply because it generates no surplus beyond its costs. Reproducing one's own value is productive, even if agriculture is more productive. Greater productivity in one sector does not make another barren.
distilled: Manufacturing is not barren just because it lacks agriculture's surplus -- reproducing one's own value is productive, and greater productivity in farming does not make manufacturing unproductive.
notes: Smith's first of five objections to the Physiocratic system (4.9.29-4.9.36). The marriage analogy is memorable and effective: replacement-level reproduction is not sterility. This argument challenges the binary productive/unproductive classification with a spectrum concept. Cross-reference Book II, Chapter 3 on productive and unproductive labor for Smith's own (different) classification.

refashioned: Second, it seems entirely inappropriate to treat artisans, manufacturers, and merchants the same as household servants. Household servants' labor does not sustain the fund that maintains them. Their upkeep is entirely at their masters' expense, and their work does not repay that expense. It consists of services that perish the instant they are performed, without becoming embodied in any saleable commodity that could replace the cost of their wages and maintenance. The labor of artisans, manufacturers, and merchants, by contrast, naturally does become fixed and embodied in such saleable commodities. It is for this reason that, in my chapter on productive and unproductive labor, I classified artisans, manufacturers, and merchants among productive laborers, and household servants among the unproductive.
elegant: Second, equating manufacturers with household servants is wrong. Servants' work perishes instantly -- it does not produce any saleable commodity to replace its cost. Manufacturers' work, by contrast, is embodied in vendible goods that replace the capital invested. This fundamental distinction -- between labor that perishes and labor that is fixed in commodities -- separates productive from unproductive work.
summary: Smith's second objection: unlike household servants, whose labor perishes instantly, manufacturers produce durable, saleable commodities that replace the capital invested in their production. This makes them fundamentally different from servants and genuinely productive.
distilled: Manufacturers' labor produces saleable commodities that replace invested capital, unlike servants' labor which perishes instantly -- making them genuinely productive, not barren.
notes: Refers to Smith's own productive/unproductive labor distinction from Book II, Chapter 3. The key criterion is whether labor is 'fixed and realized in some vendible commodity.' This is a stronger distinction than the Physiocratic one because it does not depend on generating rent. The passage shows Smith correcting the Physiocrats' error while substituting his own (also debatable) classification.

refashioned: Third, it seems wrong on any account to say that manufacturing labor does not increase a society's real revenue. Even if we grant the Physiocratic assumption that the value of a worker's daily consumption exactly equals his daily production, it would not follow that his labor adds nothing to real revenue. Consider an artisan who, in the six months after harvest, does ten pounds' worth of work while consuming ten pounds' worth of food and necessities. He really does add ten pounds to the annual value of the land's output and the society's labor. While consuming a half-year's revenue of ten pounds, he has produced an equal value of work capable of purchasing an equivalent revenue for himself or someone else. The total value consumed and produced during those six months equals not ten but twenty pounds. It is true that no more than ten pounds' worth may have existed at any single moment. But if that ten pounds' worth of food had been consumed by a soldier or household servant instead, the value of goods actually existing at the end of six months would have been ten pounds less than it is thanks to the artisan's labor. Even if what the artisan produces is never, at any single moment, worth more than what he consumes, at every moment the actually existing value of goods in the market is greater than it would be without his labor.
elegant: Third, manufacturing does increase real revenue. Even if an artisan's consumption equals his production, the total value in existence at any moment is greater because of his work. An artisan who consumes ten pounds of food while producing ten pounds of goods creates twenty pounds of total value over that period. Had a soldier consumed the same food, ten pounds of goods would simply vanish. The artisan's labor maintains market value that would otherwise disappear.
summary: Smith argues that manufacturing labor increases real wealth even if workers consume as much as they produce. At any moment, the stock of goods in existence is greater because of manufacturing activity -- consumption that merely sustains an unproductive person destroys value, while consumption that sustains a manufacturer is matched by new production.
distilled: Manufacturing increases real wealth because it replaces consumed value with new production, whereas unproductive consumption simply destroys value without replacement.
notes: Smith's subtlest argument against Physiocracy -- a stock-flow distinction. The Physiocrats confuse the flow of value (consumption equals production) with the stock of value (greater because production replaces consumption simultaneously). The soldier/artisan comparison is devastating: same consumption, different outcomes for total wealth. This anticipates modern macroeconomic concepts of GDP as a flow measure.

refashioned: When the advocates of this system say that the consumption of artisans and manufacturers equals the value of what they produce, they probably mean no more than that these workers' revenue -- the fund allocated for their consumption -- equals their production. But if they had expressed themselves more carefully and said only that this class's revenue equals its production, readers would readily see that whatever is saved from that revenue must necessarily increase society's real wealth. To construct anything resembling an argument, they had to express themselves as they did. And even on their own terms, the argument turns out to be quite inconclusive.
elegant: The Physiocrats conflate consumption with revenue. If they had simply said manufacturing revenue equals production, it would be obvious that savings from that revenue increase national wealth. Their imprecise language was necessary to make their argument seem plausible -- and even so, it remains inconclusive.
summary: Smith exposes an imprecision in Physiocratic reasoning: by saying consumption equals production instead of revenue equals production, they obscure the fact that savings from manufacturing revenue do increase national wealth. The imprecise formulation was necessary to sustain their argument, which fails even on its own terms.
distilled: The Physiocratic argument that manufacturing consumption equals production is a verbal trick that obscures the obvious fact that savings from manufacturing revenue increase national wealth.
notes: Smith identifies what amounts to a logical sleight of hand. The consumption/revenue distinction matters because not all revenue is consumed -- savings drive capital accumulation. This connects to Book II's treatment of savings as the driver of economic growth. The criticism is both technical (the argument is formally flawed) and rhetorical (the imprecision was deliberately misleading).

refashioned: Fourth, farmers can no more increase the real annual output of their society without saving than artisans and manufacturers can. The annual output of any society can be increased in only two ways: first, by improving the productive powers of the labor already employed; or second, by increasing the quantity of that labor.
elegant: Fourth, farmers also need savings to increase national output. Annual production can grow only through improved labor productivity or increased quantity of labor -- both require capital accumulation, which requires saving.
summary: Smith's fourth objection: the Physiocratic claim that farmers can increase wealth without saving is false. All growth in annual output requires either improved productivity or more labor, both of which depend on capital accumulation through saving.
distilled: Farmers, like manufacturers, can increase national output only through saving -- growth requires either improved productivity or more labor, both of which need capital.
notes: Challenges the Physiocratic claim from 4.9.14 that agricultural nations grow rich through 'industry and enjoyment' while commercial nations require 'parsimony.' Smith insists that saving (capital accumulation) is necessary for all growth. Cross-reference Book II, Chapters 1-3 on the role of capital accumulation in economic growth.

refashioned: Improvements in the productive power of labor depend, first, on improving the workers' ability and, second, on improving the machinery they use. But manufacturing labor, because it can be more finely subdivided and each operation reduced to greater simplicity than farm labor, is capable of both types of improvement to a much higher degree. In this respect, therefore, farmers have no advantage whatsoever over artisans and manufacturers.
elegant: Labor productivity improves through better worker skills and better machinery. Manufacturing labor, being more divisible into simple operations, is capable of both improvements to a far greater degree than farming. Farmers have no productivity advantage here.
summary: Smith points out that manufacturing labor is actually more susceptible to productivity improvements than agricultural labor, because manufacturing operations can be more finely subdivided. This contradicts any claim that agriculture has superior potential for productivity growth.
distilled: Manufacturing labor improves faster than farm labor because it can be more finely subdivided -- farmers have no productivity advantage over manufacturers.
notes: Cross-reference Book I, Chapter 1 on the division of labor. Smith is using his own foundational insight -- that division of labor drives productivity -- to refute the Physiocratic hierarchy. Agriculture's resistance to fine subdivision is why manufacturing productivity growth consistently outpaces agricultural productivity growth historically. This observation proved remarkably prescient.

refashioned: The increase in the quantity of useful labor actually employed in any society must depend entirely on the increase of the capital that employs it. The growth of that capital must, in turn, exactly equal the total savings from the revenue of those who manage and direct the use of that capital, or of others who lend it to them. If merchants, artisans, and manufacturers are, as this system seems to suppose, naturally more inclined to saving than landowners and farmers, then they are more likely to increase the quantity of useful labor in their society and therefore to increase its real revenue -- the annual produce of its land and labor.
elegant: Growth in employment depends on growth in capital, which depends on saving. If merchants and manufacturers are naturally more inclined to save than landowners and farmers -- as the Physiocrats themselves seem to assume -- then the commercial classes are actually more likely to drive economic growth through capital accumulation.
summary: Smith turns the Physiocratic system against itself: if commercial classes are more inclined to save (as the Physiocrats imply), they are actually more likely to grow national wealth through capital accumulation than supposedly productive farmers and landowners.
distilled: If merchants save more than farmers -- as the Physiocrats imply -- then the commercial classes drive economic growth more effectively through capital accumulation.
notes: A devastating internal critique: Smith uses the Physiocrats' own assumption about commercial parsimony (from 4.9.14) to argue that the commercial classes are better at capital accumulation and therefore better at driving growth. This turns the 'parsimony and privation' characterization from a stigma into an economic virtue. Cross-reference Book II, Chapter 3 on the centrality of saving to capital formation.

refashioned: Fifth and finally, even if we suppose -- as this system does -- that a country's entire revenue consists of the subsistence its industry can procure, a trading and manufacturing country's revenue must always, other things being equal, be much greater than that of a country without trade or manufactures. Through trade and manufacturing, a country can annually import far more subsistence than its own lands, in their current state of cultivation, could produce. The inhabitants of a city, though they typically own no farmland, draw to themselves through their industry enough agricultural produce from surrounding areas to supply not only their work materials but their food as well. What a city is to its surrounding countryside, an independent trading state may be to other countries. Holland, for instance, draws much of its subsistence from abroad -- livestock from Holstein and Jutland, grain from across Europe. A small quantity of manufactured goods purchases a large quantity of raw produce. A manufacturing country therefore buys, with a small fraction of its output, a large share of other countries' raw produce; while a country without manufactures must spend a large share of its raw produce to buy a small amount of manufactured goods. The one exports what can support only a few but imports the subsistence and comforts of many. The other exports the subsistence of many and imports the comforts of only a few. The inhabitants of a manufacturing country must always enjoy far more subsistence than their own land could provide; those of a purely agricultural country, far less.
elegant: Fifth, even on Physiocratic assumptions, manufacturing nations are wealthier. Through trade, they import more food than their own land could produce. A small quantity of manufactures purchases a large quantity of raw produce -- so manufacturing nations exchange the support of a few for the subsistence of many, while agricultural nations do the reverse. Holland feeds itself from all of Europe with manufactured exports. Manufacturing nations always enjoy more than their land could sustain; purely agricultural nations, less.
summary: Smith's final objection: even accepting the Physiocratic premise that wealth is subsistence, manufacturing nations are richer because manufactured goods trade for disproportionately large quantities of food and raw materials. A country that manufactures can feed itself far beyond its own agricultural capacity.
distilled: Even measuring wealth as subsistence, manufacturing nations are richer because a small volume of manufactures buys a large volume of food from abroad.
notes: Smith's fifth and final objection turns the Physiocrats' own value theory against them. The terms of trade between manufactures and raw produce consistently favor manufactures -- a small bulk of high-value goods trades for a large bulk of low-value food. Holland is the paradigmatic example: a small, barren country feeding itself from a continent through manufacturing exports. This anticipates modern concepts of comparative advantage and terms of trade. Cross-reference Book I, Chapter 11 on the relative values of raw and manufactured goods.

refashioned: This system, despite all its imperfections, is perhaps the closest approximation to the truth yet published on political economy, and for that reason deserves careful study by anyone interested in this very important science. Though its view of agricultural labor as the only productive labor is too narrow, its representation of national wealth as consisting not in unspendable hoards of money but in the consumable goods annually reproduced by labor, and its insistence that perfect liberty is the only effective way to maximize this annual reproduction -- these doctrines seem in every respect as sound as they are generous and liberal. The system has attracted many followers -- partly because people enjoy paradoxes, and the idea that manufacturing labor is unproductive has a contrarian appeal. The Physiocrats have formed a considerable intellectual movement in France, known as the Economists. Their work has certainly been of service to their country: not only by bringing into public discussion many previously neglected subjects, but by influencing government policy in favor of agriculture. Thanks to their advocacy, French agriculture has been freed from several of the oppressions under which it had long suffered.
elegant: Despite its errors, the Physiocratic system is the best approximation to truth yet published in political economy. Its view of productive labor is too narrow, but its core doctrines are sound: national wealth consists of consumable goods reproduced annually by labor, and perfect liberty maximizes this reproduction. The Economists, as they are called in France, have done real service by promoting agricultural freedom and bringing important questions into public debate.
summary: Smith judges the Physiocratic system as the best available despite its errors. While too narrow on productive labor, its identification of wealth with consumable goods (not money) and its advocacy of perfect liberty are sound. The French Economists' practical influence on liberalizing agricultural policy has been genuinely beneficial.
distilled: Despite its theoretical errors, the Physiocratic system is the nearest approximation to truth in political economy, sound in its core doctrines of consumable-goods wealth and free-trade policy.
notes: Smith's generous overall assessment of Physiocracy -- 'the nearest approximation to the truth.' He praises three elements: wealth as annual consumption (not money hoarding), perfect liberty as optimal policy, and the practical reforms they achieved. The 'paradox' observation -- that manufacturing is unproductive -- is a wry comment on intellectual fashion. Smith knew Quesnay personally and reportedly considered dedicating the Wealth of Nations to him. Cross-reference 4.9.1 on why this system deserves a shorter treatment than mercantilism.

refashioned: The maximum term for agricultural leases valid against future landowners has been extended from nine to twenty-seven years. The ancient provincial restrictions on transporting grain between French provinces have been entirely abolished, and the freedom to export grain to foreign countries has been established as the general law of the kingdom in ordinary circumstances. The members of this school, in their numerous writings -- which cover not only political economy proper but every branch of government -- all follow Quesnay's doctrine implicitly, with scarcely any noticeable variation. For this reason, there is relatively little variety in the bulk of their works.
elegant: Physiocratic influence achieved real reforms: agricultural leases were extended from nine to twenty-seven years, internal grain trade barriers were abolished, and grain export was legalized. However, the Economists' writings show little variety, all following Quesnay's doctrine with rigid uniformity.
summary: The Physiocrats achieved significant practical reforms in France -- longer leases, free internal grain trade, and legalized grain exports. However, their intellectual uniformity, with all writers slavishly following Quesnay, produced repetitive works with little originality.
distilled: Physiocratic advocacy achieved real French agricultural reforms, though the school's slavish adherence to Quesnay produced intellectually monotonous works.
notes: The reforms listed were genuine achievements: longer leases encouraged agricultural investment, abolishing internal trade barriers was revolutionary for France, and grain export freedom reversed Colbert's policy. The criticism of intellectual uniformity is pointed -- Smith valued independent thinking. The contrast between practical success and intellectual rigidity captures Smith's ambivalence about the Physiocrats.

refashioned: The most clear and well-organized account of this doctrine is found in a short book by Mercier de la Riviere, a former administrator of Martinique, titled 'The Natural and Essential Order of Political Societies.' The entire sect's admiration for their master -- who was himself a man of the greatest modesty and simplicity -- is no less intense than the admiration ancient philosophers held for the founders of their respective schools. 'Since the beginning of the world,' says the Marquis de Mirabeau, a very diligent and respectable writer, 'three great inventions have principally given stability to political societies, independent of the many other inventions that have enriched and adorned them.'
elegant: The clearest account of Physiocratic doctrine is Mercier de la Riviere's 'Natural and Essential Order of Political Societies.' The school's devotion to Quesnay -- a man of genuine modesty -- rivaled the ancient philosophers' reverence for their founders. Mirabeau declared that three great inventions had principally given stability to political societies.
summary: Smith identifies Mercier de la Riviere's book as the best systematic account of Physiocratic theory and notes the school's quasi-religious devotion to Quesnay, illustrated by Mirabeau's extravagant claim about three world-changing inventions.
distilled: Mercier de la Riviere produced the best systematic account of Physiocratic doctrine, while the school displayed quasi-religious devotion to Quesnay.
notes: Pierre-Paul Mercier de la Riviere (1719-1801) was intendant of Martinique. The Marquis de Mirabeau (1715-1789) was Victor Riqueti, father of the revolutionary -- and author of 'L'Ami des Hommes.' The buildup to Mirabeau's 'three great inventions' sets up the punchline in 4.9.40. Smith's characterization of Quesnay as modest and simple reflects personal acquaintance.

refashioned: The first is the invention of writing, which alone gives humanity the power to transmit its laws, contracts, historical records, and discoveries without alteration. The second is the invention of money, which binds together all the relations among civilized societies. The third is the Tableau Economique -- the product of the other two, completing and perfecting their purpose -- the great discovery of our age, though it is our posterity who will reap its benefits.
elegant: Mirabeau's three world-changing inventions: writing (which preserves laws and knowledge), money (which connects civilized societies), and Quesnay's Tableau Economique -- allegedly the culmination of both, whose benefits posterity will enjoy.
summary: The Marquis de Mirabeau ranked Quesnay's Tableau Economique alongside writing and money as one of the three greatest inventions in human history -- a claim that illustrates the Physiocrats' extravagant devotion to their master.
distilled: Mirabeau ranked the Tableau Economique alongside writing and money as one of humanity's three greatest inventions -- revealing the school's extravagant devotion to Quesnay.
notes: The quote is from Mirabeau's 'Philosophie Rurale' (1763). Smith includes this without comment, letting the absurdity speak for itself -- ranking an economic diagram alongside writing and money. The Tableau Economique was historically important as the first macroeconomic model, but Mirabeau's claim is transparently cultish. Smith's deadpan presentation is characteristically understated satire.

refashioned:
While the political economy of modern European nations has generally favored manufactures and foreign trade over agriculture, other nations have followed a different plan, favoring agriculture above all else.

China's policy favors agriculture more than any other occupation. In China, a laborer's social standing is said to be as far above an artisan's as, in most of Europe, an artisan's is above a laborer's. Every Chinese person's great ambition is to acquire a small piece of land, whether as property or by lease -- and leases there are reportedly granted on moderate terms with adequate legal security. The Chinese have little respect for foreign trade. 'Your beggarly commerce!' was how the mandarins of Peking addressed the Russian envoy De Lange on the subject. Apart from trade with Japan, the Chinese conduct little foreign trade in their own ships, and they admit foreign vessels to only one or two ports. Foreign trade in China is therefore confined to a much narrower range than it would naturally reach if more freedom were allowed -- either for their own ships or for foreign ones.
elegant: While Europe favored manufacturing and trade, China followed the opposite policy -- elevating agriculture above all. Chinese laborers outrank artisans in status, everyone aspires to own land, and foreign trade is actively disdained. 'Your beggarly commerce!' the mandarins told the Russian envoy. China restricts foreign trade to one or two ports, confining it far below its natural extent.
summary: Smith contrasts European mercantilism with China's agricultural policy, where farming holds the highest status, land ownership is universally aspired to, and foreign trade is restricted and disdained. China represents the opposite extreme from European commercialism.
distilled: China's policy is the mirror image of European mercantilism -- elevating agriculture, disdaining foreign trade, and restricting commerce to far below its natural extent.
notes: Smith's discussion of China draws on contemporary travel accounts, particularly John Bell's 'Travels from St. Petersburg to Diverse Parts of Asia' (1763). Lorenz De Lange was a Russian diplomat to China in the early 18th century. Smith is setting up a comparative political economy -- different civilizations as natural experiments in economic policy. The 'beggarly commerce' quote became famous. Cross-reference 4.9.42 on why China's domestic market compensates for restricted foreign trade.

refashioned: Manufactures, because they pack great value into small bulk, can be transported between countries more cheaply than most raw produce and are therefore the principal support of foreign trade in almost all countries. In nations less vast and less favorably situated for internal trade than China, manufactures generally require foreign market access to thrive. Without an extensive foreign market, they cannot flourish in countries with narrow domestic markets or where transportation between provinces is so difficult that goods cannot reach the whole home market. The perfection of manufacturing depends entirely on the division of labor, and the degree of specialization possible depends on the size of the market.
