But China's enormous territory, vast population, diverse climates and products, and excellent water transportation between most provinces make its domestic market so immense that it alone can support very large-scale manufactures with very fine divisions of labor. China's home market may be comparable in extent to the combined market of all European countries. Even so, a more extensive foreign trade -- especially if conducted partly in Chinese ships -- would undoubtedly expand Chinese manufactures greatly and improve their productive efficiency. Through broader navigation, the Chinese would naturally learn to use and build the machines employed in other countries, as well as adopt the other industrial improvements practiced around the world. Under their current policy, they have little opportunity to improve by any nation's example except Japan's.
elegant: Manufactures drive foreign trade because they pack great value into small bulk. Most nations need foreign markets for manufacturing to thrive, but China's enormous territory, population, diverse climate, and excellent waterways create a domestic market rivaling all of Europe combined -- sufficient to support large-scale manufacturing with fine divisions of labor. Yet broader foreign trade would still benefit China enormously by exposing it to foreign technologies and innovations. Currently, China can learn only from Japan.
summary: China's vast domestic market compensates for its restricted foreign trade, supporting large-scale manufacturing through internal commerce alone. However, Smith argues that opening to foreign trade would further improve Chinese manufacturing by enabling technology transfer and competitive innovation.
distilled: China's enormous domestic market supports manufacturing without foreign trade, but opening to global commerce would significantly improve its productivity through technology transfer.
notes: Applies Book I's division-of-labor-limited-by-market-extent principle to China's case. Smith's insight that China's domestic market rivals all of Europe is remarkably prescient. The argument for openness as a source of technology transfer anticipates modern development economics. The observation about China learning only from Japan reflects the period's understanding of East Asian trade networks. Cross-reference Book I, Chapter 3 on the extent of the market.

refashioned:
The policies of ancient Egypt and Hindu India similarly favored agriculture above all other occupations.

In both ancient Egypt and India, the entire population was divided into hereditary castes, each confined from father to son to a particular occupation. A priest's son was necessarily a priest; a soldier's son, a soldier; a laborer's son, a laborer; a weaver's son, a weaver; a tailor's son, a tailor. In both countries, the priestly caste held the highest rank and the military caste the second highest. In both, the farming caste ranked above the castes of merchants and manufacturers.
elegant: Ancient Egypt and Hindu India both favored agriculture through rigid hereditary caste systems. In both, every person inherited their father's occupation -- priest, soldier, farmer, weaver, tailor. Priests ranked highest, soldiers second, and farmers above merchants and manufacturers.
summary: Ancient Egypt and India institutionalized agricultural preference through hereditary caste systems that locked each person into their father's occupation and ranked farming above commerce and manufacturing.
distilled: Ancient Egypt and India both favored agriculture through hereditary caste systems that ranked farmers above merchants and manufacturers.
notes: Smith's comparative analysis extends to ancient civilizations as additional 'experiments' in agricultural policy. The caste system examples show how occupational hierarchy can be enforced through social institutions rather than trade policy. The parallel between Egypt and India is historically significant -- both river civilizations with strong agricultural bases. Cross-reference Book I, Chapter 10 on institutional barriers to occupational mobility.

refashioned: The governments of both countries paid particular attention to agriculture. The works constructed by the ancient sovereigns of Egypt for distributing the waters of the Nile were famous in antiquity, and their ruins still impress travelers today. The similar works built by the ancient sovereigns of India for distributing the waters of the Ganges and many other rivers, though less celebrated, seem to have been equally great. Both countries, though subject to occasional famines, were renowned for their great fertility. In years of moderate abundance, both were able to export large quantities of grain to their neighbors.
elegant: Both Egyptian and Indian rulers invested heavily in agricultural infrastructure -- Egypt's Nile irrigation works were famous in antiquity, India's Ganges systems equally impressive. Both countries achieved remarkable fertility and, in normal years, exported large grain surpluses to their neighbors.
summary: Ancient Egypt and India both invested massively in irrigation infrastructure, achieving agricultural productivity that allowed substantial grain exports in normal years. Their rulers' attention to agriculture reflected the policy priority each civilization placed on farming.
distilled: Ancient Egyptian and Indian rulers invested heavily in irrigation infrastructure, achieving agricultural fertility that enabled large grain exports.
notes: The irrigation works exemplify productive government investment in agriculture -- infrastructure that private individuals could not build. This connects to 4.9.59 where Smith identifies public works as one of the sovereign's three legitimate duties. The Egyptian works included canals, reservoirs, and flood management systems built over millennia. Smith's information on India draws on contemporary European accounts.

refashioned: The ancient Egyptians had a superstitious aversion to the sea. The Hindu religion effectively prohibited distant sea voyages by forbidding its followers from lighting fires -- and therefore cooking -- on water. Both peoples therefore depended almost entirely on other nations' ships for exporting their surplus produce. This dependency confined their markets and discouraged the growth of surplus production. It must have discouraged manufacturing even more than agriculture. Manufactures require much larger markets than even the most important agricultural products. A single shoemaker will produce more than three hundred pairs of shoes in a year, while his own family may not wear out six pairs. Unless he serves at least fifty such families, he cannot sell his entire output.
elegant: Egyptians feared the sea; Hindu religious rules effectively banned ocean voyages. Both depended on foreign shipping to export surplus, which confined their markets. This discouraged manufacturing more than farming -- manufactures need far larger markets. A shoemaker makes 300 pairs yearly but his family uses only six, requiring at least fifty families as customers.
summary: Religious and cultural aversions to seafaring in Egypt and India restricted both civilizations to dependence on foreign shipping, confining their markets. This affected manufacturing more than agriculture because manufactures require much larger markets to sustain specialized production.
distilled: Egyptian and Indian aversions to seafaring confined their export markets, harming manufacturing more than agriculture since manufactures require far larger markets for specialization.
notes: The shoemaker example brilliantly illustrates why manufacturing needs larger markets than farming: the ratio of output to self-consumption is vastly higher. A farmer might consume a significant fraction of his own produce; a specialist manufacturer almost none. The religious barriers to navigation -- Egyptian and Hindu -- show how cultural factors shape economic outcomes. Cross-reference Book I, Chapter 3 on how water transport extends markets.

refashioned: The most numerous class of artisans will rarely compose more than one in fifty or one in a hundred of a large country's families. But in such large countries as France and England, the agricultural workforce has been estimated by various authors at one-half, one-third, or at minimum one-fifth of the total population. Since the overwhelming majority of agricultural output in both countries is consumed domestically, each farm worker needs the custom of only one, two, or at most four families to sell his entire output. Agriculture can therefore sustain itself under the discouragement of a restricted market far better than manufactures can. In ancient Egypt and India, the limitation of foreign markets was partly compensated by extensive inland waterway systems that opened the entire domestic market to every region's products in the most advantageous manner.
elegant: Artisans form a tiny fraction of any population, needing many customer families per worker. Farmers, comprising a large share of the population, need only a few customer families each. Agriculture therefore tolerates restricted markets far better than manufacturing. In Egypt and India, inland waterways partially compensated for restricted foreign trade by connecting the entire domestic market.
summary: Agriculture is more resilient than manufacturing in restricted markets because farmers need far fewer customers per worker. Egypt and India's extensive inland waterways partially offset their restricted foreign trade by maximizing domestic market connectivity.
distilled: Agriculture tolerates restricted markets better than manufacturing because each farmer needs far fewer customers, and inland waterways can partially compensate for limited foreign trade.
notes: The ratio analysis is striking: a craftsman needs 50-100 customer families, a farmer only 1-4. This explains why agricultural civilizations with limited trade could still prosper while their manufacturing sectors stagnated. The inland waterway point connects to Book I, Chapter 3 on how navigable rivers extend markets. Egypt's Nile and India's Ganges system were the ancient world's great commercial arteries.

refashioned: India's great territorial extent also made its domestic market very large, sufficient to support a considerable variety of manufactures. But ancient Egypt's much smaller territory -- never as large as England -- must have always limited its domestic market too much to support great manufacturing diversity. Accordingly, Bengal -- the Indian province that typically exports the most rice -- has always been more famous for exporting a great variety of manufactures than for grain exports. Ancient Egypt, by contrast, though it did export some manufactures (particularly fine linen), was always most distinguished for its grain exports. It was long the granary of the Roman Empire.
elegant: India's vast territory supported diverse manufacturing for domestic consumption; tiny Egypt could not. Accordingly, Bengal was famous for manufacturing exports, while Egypt was famous as the Roman Empire's granary -- each civilization's exports reflecting the size of its domestic market relative to its productive capacity.
summary: The contrast between India and Egypt illustrates how territory size determines manufacturing potential: vast India developed diverse manufactures for a large domestic market, while small Egypt specialized in grain exports because its domestic market could not support manufacturing variety.
distilled: Vast India developed diverse manufactures while small Egypt specialized as a grain exporter, illustrating how domestic market size determines manufacturing potential.
notes: Bengal's manufacturing fame included textiles (especially muslin and calico) that later became central to European trade. Egypt as Rome's granary was historically crucial -- grain shipments from Alexandria fed Rome for centuries. The size-of-market argument ties directly to Book I, Chapters 1-3: division of labor (and thus manufacturing sophistication) is limited by market extent.

refashioned: The sovereigns of China, ancient Egypt, and the various kingdoms of India have always derived all, or by far the greatest part, of their revenue from some form of land tax or land rent. This tax, like the European tithe, consisted of a fixed proportion of the land's produce -- reportedly one-fifth -- either delivered in kind or paid in money according to a valuation that varied annually with the harvest. It was natural, therefore, that these sovereigns should be particularly attentive to agricultural interests, on whose prosperity or decline their own revenue directly depended.
elegant: Chinese, Egyptian, and Indian rulers derived most of their revenue from land taxes -- a proportion (roughly one-fifth) of annual produce, varying with the harvest. Their fiscal self-interest naturally made them attentive to agriculture, since their revenue rose and fell with the harvest.
summary: Asian and ancient rulers who depended on land taxes for revenue naturally prioritized agriculture because their income varied directly with harvest yields. Fiscal self-interest aligned sovereign attention with agricultural prosperity.
distilled: Rulers whose revenue came from land taxes naturally prioritized agriculture because their income depended directly on harvest yields.
notes: The alignment of fiscal interest with agricultural policy is an important insight: the tax base shapes policy priorities. The one-fifth proportion is comparable to European tithes (one-tenth) but more burdensome. This fiscal argument explains why agricultural civilizations invested in irrigation infrastructure (4.9.44) -- it directly increased tax revenue. Anticipates modern public finance arguments about how tax structure shapes government incentives.

refashioned: The policy of the ancient Greek republics and of Rome, though it honored agriculture more than manufacturing or foreign trade, seems to have discouraged the latter occupations rather than directly encouraging farming. In several ancient Greek states, foreign trade was entirely prohibited. In several others, the occupations of artisans and manufacturers were considered harmful to the physical strength and agility of the human body -- rendering it unfit for the military and athletic exercises that formed a central part of Greek education, and therefore disqualifying citizens more or less for the hardships and dangers of war.
elegant: Ancient Greece and Rome honored agriculture but promoted it mainly by suppressing alternatives rather than directly encouraging farming. Foreign trade was banned in some Greek states. Manufacturing was seen as physically degrading -- incompatible with the military fitness that Greek education prioritized.
summary: Greek and Roman policy favored agriculture not through direct support but by discouraging manufacturing and trade as physically degrading occupations incompatible with military fitness. Several Greek states banned foreign trade outright.
distilled: Ancient Greece and Rome favored agriculture by suppressing manufacturing and trade as occupations incompatible with military fitness, rather than by directly supporting farming.
notes: The Greek attitude toward manual labor -- 'banausic' work as degrading -- was a profound cultural factor shaping economic development. Sparta's prohibition on trade and money is the extreme case. The military rationale connects physical labor with citizen-soldier ideals. Cross-reference Book III on how ancient attitudes toward trade shaped economic development. Aristotle's Politics contains similar arguments about artisan citizenship.

refashioned: Such occupations were considered fit only for slaves, and free citizens were prohibited from practicing them. Even in states without formal prohibitions -- like Rome and Athens -- the general population was effectively excluded from the trades now typically practiced by urban workers. In Athens and Rome, these trades were entirely performed by the slaves of wealthy owners, who put them to work for their masters' benefit. The wealth, power, and political protection of these slave-owners made it nearly impossible for a poor freeman to find a market for his work in competition with their slaves. Slaves, however, are rarely inventive. All the most important improvements in machinery and in the organization of work that facilitate and reduce labor have been the discoveries of free people. If a slave proposed any such improvement, his master would likely regard it as a lazy attempt to reduce his workload at the master's expense.
elegant: Trades were reserved for slaves in the ancient world. Even without formal bans, wealthy slave-owners dominated urban crafts so completely that poor freemen could not compete. But slaves are rarely innovative -- nearly all important improvements in machinery and work organization come from free people. A slave proposing an improvement would be suspected of laziness, not rewarded for ingenuity.
summary: Ancient economies assigned trades to slaves, effectively excluding free citizens. This suppressed innovation because slaves rarely invent improvements -- and any suggestion of improvement would be dismissed as an attempt to shirk work. Nearly all significant advances in manufacturing technique have come from free labor.
distilled: Assigning trades to slaves suppressed innovation because slaves rarely invent, and any proposed improvement would be suspected as an attempt to avoid work.
notes: Smith's argument that slavery suppresses innovation is one of his most important insights. The mechanism is psychological and institutional: slaves lack incentives to innovate, and masters interpret innovation attempts as laziness. This anticipates modern institutional economics on incentive structures and economic growth. The observation that 'all the most important improvements' come from free workers is a powerful argument against forced labor systems. Cross-reference Book III, Chapter 2 on how slavery retarded economic development.

refashioned: The poor slave, instead of receiving a reward, would probably meet with abuse and perhaps punishment. In manufactures run by slave labor, therefore, more labor was generally needed to complete the same quantity of work than in manufactures run by free workers, making slave-produced goods more expensive. The Hungarian mines, as Montesquieu observes, though no richer than their Turkish neighbors, have always been worked at less cost and therefore with greater profit. The Turkish mines are worked by slaves, and their bare hands are the only machinery the Turks have ever thought to use.
elegant: Slave labor is more expensive than free labor because slaves cannot innovate: more labor is needed for the same output. Montesquieu noted that Hungarian mines (worked by freemen with machinery) were more profitable than richer Turkish mines (worked by slaves using only their hands).
summary: Slave labor is paradoxically more expensive than free labor because the absence of innovation means more workers are needed for the same output. The comparison between Hungarian free mines and Turkish slave mines demonstrates that free labor with machinery outperforms slave labor even in richer deposits.
distilled: Slave labor is more expensive than free labor because slaves cannot innovate, requiring more workers for the same output -- as the Hungarian-Turkish mine comparison demonstrates.
notes: The mine comparison from Montesquieu's 'Spirit of the Laws' (Book XV, Chapter 8) provides empirical evidence for Smith's theoretical argument. The Hungarian-Turkish comparison is especially powerful because the Turkish mines were geologically richer. Smith is building the economic case against slavery that culminates in the argument that free labor is always more productive. Cross-reference Book III, Chapter 2.

refashioned: The Hungarian mines are worked by free men who employ a great deal of machinery to make their own labor easier and more efficient. From the little we know about the price of manufactures in ancient Greece and Rome, the finer goods appear to have been extraordinarily expensive. Silk sold for its weight in gold -- though since it was all imported from the East Indies, the transportation cost may partly explain the price. But the price that a Roman lady would sometimes pay for a piece of very fine linen seems equally extravagant -- and since linen was always either a European or at most an Egyptian product, this high price can only be explained by the enormous labor costs that must have been involved. And those labor costs could arise from nothing other than the crude and inefficient machinery -- that is, slave labor -- used to produce it.
elegant: Free Hungarian miners with machinery outperformed Turkish slaves using bare hands. Ancient manufactured goods were extraordinarily expensive -- silk sold for its weight in gold, and fine linen cost extravagant sums despite being locally produced. These high prices reflect the enormous labor required by slave-based production using primitive, uninnovated techniques.
summary: The extreme cost of fine manufactures in the ancient world -- silk selling for its weight in gold, fine linen at extravagant prices -- reflects the inefficiency of slave-based production. Without the incentive to innovate, manufacturing techniques remained crude and labor costs astronomical.
distilled: Ancient manufactures were extraordinarily expensive because slave labor suppressed innovation, keeping production techniques crude and labor costs astronomical.
notes: The silk-for-gold-weight price was a common classical reference (Pliny, Natural History). Smith uses it to illustrate the economic cost of slavery's innovation suppression. Fine linen was Egypt's most famous manufactured export -- Pliny documents extravagant prices. The argument chain is: slavery -> no innovation -> primitive techniques -> high labor costs -> expensive goods. Cross-reference 4.9.53 on wool prices for additional evidence.

refashioned: The price of fine woolens, though not quite as extreme, also seems to have been well above modern levels. According to Pliny, some cloths dyed in a particular manner cost one hundred denarii per pound -- about three pounds, six shillings, and eightpence. Others dyed differently cost one thousand denarii per pound -- about thirty-three pounds, six shillings, and eightpence. The Roman pound, it should be noted, contained only twelve of our avoirdupois ounces. These high prices seem primarily due to the dyeing process. But if the undyed cloth itself had not been much more expensive than modern equivalents, such costly dyes would probably never have been applied to it.
elegant: Ancient woolens were far more expensive than modern equivalents. Pliny records dyed cloths costing up to thirty-three pounds per Roman pound -- mainly due to dyeing costs. But the cloth itself must also have been expensive; otherwise, such costly dyes would never have been applied to it.
summary: Pliny's records of ancient wool prices -- up to thirty-three pounds per twelve-ounce Roman pound -- reveal that even before expensive dyeing, the base cloth was far more costly than modern equivalents. Costly dyes would not be applied to cheap cloth.
distilled: Ancient woolens cost far more than modern equivalents, with prices reflecting both expensive base cloth and extravagant dyeing -- evidence of primitive, inefficient production techniques.
notes: References Pliny's Natural History (Book IX, Chapter 39). The denarius conversion is Smith's own calculation. The argument that expensive dyes would not be applied to cheap cloth is a deduction about relative price levels -- if the cloth were cheap, the disproportion between cloth and dye cost would be absurd. The Roman pound of 12 ounces versus the English avoirdupois pound of 16 ounces makes the per-weight price comparison even more extreme.

refashioned: The disproportion between the dye and the cloth would otherwise have been too great. The prices Pliny cites for some 'triclinaria' -- a type of woolen pillow or cushion used for reclining at table -- defy belief: some reportedly cost more than thirty thousand pounds, others more than three hundred thousand. These extraordinary prices are not attributed to the dye. In the dress of fashionable people of both sexes, there appears to have been much less variety in ancient times than in modern ones, as Dr. Arbuthnot has observed -- and the limited variety visible in ancient statues confirms this. He concludes from this that their clothing must have been cheaper overall than ours. But this conclusion does not follow.
elegant: Pliny reports woolen cushions costing over three hundred thousand pounds -- prices unrelated to dyeing. While ancient fashion showed less variety than modern dress (as Arbuthnot observed and ancient statues confirm), the inference that ancient clothing was therefore cheaper is mistaken.
summary: Pliny records ancient woolen furnishings at incredible prices, unrelated to expensive dyes. The observation that ancient fashion showed less variety than modern fashion does not prove ancient clothing was cheaper -- as Smith explains in the following passage.
distilled: Ancient woolen furnishings cost incredible sums unrelated to dyeing, and the lesser variety of ancient fashion does not prove clothing was cheaper.
notes: The triclinaria prices are from Pliny's Natural History (Book VIII, Chapter 48). Dr. John Arbuthnot (1667-1735) was a physician and writer, friend of Swift and Pope. His 'Tables of Ancient Coins, Weights, and Measures' (1727) is Smith's source. Smith sets up the counterargument in 4.9.55: less variety means each item was more expensive, not that clothing overall was cheaper.

refashioned: When the cost of fashionable dress is very high, the variety will naturally be very small. But when improvements in manufacturing productivity bring the cost of any single outfit down to a very moderate level, variety will naturally become very great. The wealthy, unable to distinguish themselves by the expense of any single garment, will naturally seek to do so through the number and variety of their wardrobe.
elegant: Expensive fashion means little variety; cheap fashion means great variety. When manufacturing improvements make individual garments affordable, the rich distinguish themselves through quantity and variety rather than the costliness of each piece.
summary: Smith corrects Arbuthnot's inference: less variety in ancient fashion indicates higher prices per garment, not lower total clothing costs. As manufacturing improves and individual garments become cheaper, the wealthy shift to distinguishing themselves through wardrobe variety rather than per-item extravagance.
distilled: Less variety in ancient fashion proves higher garment prices, not lower costs -- manufacturing improvements shift status display from per-item expense to wardrobe variety.
notes: An elegant insight connecting fashion behavior to manufacturing costs. The logic: variety is inversely proportional to unit cost. This has proven remarkably prescient -- modern fast fashion exemplifies the principle perfectly. The observation also connects to Book I's argument about how the division of labor reduces manufacturing costs and expands consumer choice. Cross-reference Book I, Chapter 1 on how specialization increases both variety and affordability.

refashioned: The greatest and most important branch of every nation's commerce, as has already been noted, is that between town and country. Town inhabitants draw from the countryside the raw materials that form both their work materials and their subsistence, paying for them by sending back a portion of that produce manufactured and prepared for immediate use. This trade ultimately amounts to exchanging a quantity of raw produce for a quantity of manufactured produce. The more expensive the manufactured goods, the cheaper the raw produce must be; and whatever raises the price of manufactures in any country tends to lower the price of raw produce, thereby discouraging agriculture. The less manufactured produce that any given quantity of raw produce can buy, the lower the exchangeable value of that raw produce -- and the less incentive either landlord has to improve, or farmer to cultivate, the land. Furthermore, whatever reduces the number of artisans and manufacturers reduces the home market -- the most important market of all for raw produce -- thereby further discouraging agriculture.
elegant: The most important commerce is between town and country: raw produce exchanged for manufactures. Whatever raises manufacturing prices cheapens raw produce relative to it, discouraging agriculture by reducing its purchasing power. Whatever reduces the number of manufacturers shrinks the home market for agricultural goods -- further discouraging farming. Both effects harm agriculture.
summary: Smith identifies town-country trade as the most vital commerce. Anything that raises manufacturing costs or reduces the number of manufacturers harms agriculture by decreasing the purchasing power of raw produce and shrinking the domestic market for farm goods.
distilled: Raising manufacturing costs or reducing manufacturer numbers harms agriculture by lowering raw produce's purchasing power and shrinking its domestic market.
notes: This is the analytical bridge to Smith's concluding critique. The town-country exchange framework was introduced in Book I and elaborated in Book III. The two-channel harm to agriculture -- reduced terms of trade and shrunken domestic market -- parallels the two-channel harm of protectionism described in 4.9.25. Cross-reference Book III, Chapter 1 on the interdependence of town and country.

refashioned: Those systems which prefer agriculture above all other occupations and, in order to promote it, impose restraints on manufactures and foreign trade, act contrary to the very end they propose and indirectly discourage the very type of industry they mean to support. In this respect, they may be even more inconsistent than the mercantile system. The mercantile system, by encouraging manufactures and foreign trade at agriculture's expense, diverts capital from a more advantageous employment to a less advantageous one. But it does genuinely encourage the industry it intends to promote. Agricultural systems, by contrast, end up discouraging their own favorite industry.
elegant: Systems that restrict manufacturing to promote agriculture are self-defeating -- they discourage the very farming they aim to support. They may be even more inconsistent than mercantilism, which at least succeeds in promoting its favored industries. Agricultural protectionism fails even on its own terms.
summary: Smith argues that agricultural systems are even more self-contradictory than mercantilism. While mercantilism at least succeeds in promoting manufacturing (though at agriculture's expense), systems that restrict manufacturing to help agriculture end up harming farming itself by shrinking its market and raising its input costs.
distilled: Agricultural protectionism is even more self-defeating than mercantilism -- it actively harms the very farming it claims to support by restricting the manufacturing that sustains agricultural markets.
notes: Smith's judgment that agricultural protectionism is 'more inconsistent' than mercantilism is a striking claim. The logic is precise: mercantilism misdirects resources but at least achieves its stated goal; agricultural protectionism undermines its own goal. This synthesizes the argument from 4.9.56 about town-country interdependence. Cross-reference 4.9.58 for the general principle.

refashioned: Thus every system that attempts, through extraordinary encouragements, to draw more capital toward a particular industry than would naturally flow to it, or through extraordinary restraints, to force capital away from a particular industry that would naturally attract it, is in reality subversive of the very purpose it claims to serve. It retards rather than accelerates society's progress toward real wealth and greatness. It diminishes rather than increases the real value of the annual produce of its land and labor.
elegant: Every system that artificially directs capital -- whether through special encouragements or special restraints -- undermines its own purpose. It retards economic progress and diminishes the real value of annual national output rather than increasing it.
summary: Smith states the universal principle: any system that artificially redirects capital, whether through incentives or restrictions, defeats its own purpose by retarding economic progress and reducing the real value of national output.
distilled: Any artificial direction of capital -- through either encouragements or restraints -- retards economic progress and reduces national output.
notes: This is Smith's master conclusion for all of Book IV -- the general principle that encompasses both mercantilism and Physiocratic agricultural systems. The symmetry is important: both special encouragements and special restraints are harmful. This sets up the famous passage on natural liberty in 4.9.59. The principle underpins modern arguments for neutral, non-distortionary economic policy.

refashioned: Once all systems of preference or restraint are completely removed, the obvious and simple system of natural liberty establishes itself on its own. Every person, so long as he does not violate the laws of justice, is left perfectly free to pursue his own interest in his own way and to bring both his industry and capital into competition with those of any other person or class. The sovereign is completely relieved of a duty that, in attempting to perform, he would always be exposed to countless delusions -- a duty for which no human wisdom or knowledge could ever be sufficient: the duty of overseeing private industry and directing it toward the employments most beneficial to society. Under the system of natural liberty, the sovereign has only three duties to attend to -- three duties of great importance, certainly, but plain and intelligible to common understanding. First, the duty of protecting society from the violence and invasion of other nations. Second, the duty of protecting, as far as possible, every member of society from the injustice or oppression of every other member -- that is, the duty of establishing an exact administration of justice. Third, the duty of building and maintaining certain public works and public institutions that could never be profitable enough for any individual or small group to undertake, even though they may more than repay their cost to a great society.
elegant: Remove all preferences and restraints, and the system of natural liberty establishes itself. Every person is free to pursue his own interest within the laws of justice, competing freely with anyone. The sovereign is relieved of the impossible duty of directing private industry. Under natural liberty, government has only three duties: national defense, administration of justice, and providing public works and institutions that are socially valuable but privately unprofitable.
summary: Smith's famous statement of the system of natural liberty: remove all artificial preferences and restraints, and a self-organizing economic order emerges. Government's role reduces to three clear duties -- national defense, justice, and public works that private enterprise cannot profitably provide.
distilled: The system of natural liberty requires only three government duties: national defense, justice, and public works that are socially valuable but privately unprofitable.
notes: Perhaps the single most influential passage in the Wealth of Nations. The 'system of natural liberty' became the foundation of classical liberalism. The three duties of government -- defense, justice, and public works -- define the scope of legitimate state action in Smith's framework and structure Book V. The 'no human wisdom could ever be sufficient' argument against central planning anticipates Hayek's knowledge problem by 170 years. Note that Smith includes public works -- he is not an anarchist or minimal-state libertarian. Cross-reference Book V for the detailed treatment of each duty.

refashioned: Properly fulfilling these three duties of the sovereign necessarily requires a certain level of expenditure, and this expenditure in turn requires a certain revenue to support it. In the following book, I shall therefore attempt to explain: first, what the necessary expenses of the sovereign or commonwealth are, and which of these should be funded by the whole society's contributions versus particular groups or individuals; second, what the different methods are by which the whole society can contribute to funding its common expenses, and the principal advantages and drawbacks of each method; and third, what reasons and causes have led almost all modern governments to mortgage part of this revenue -- that is, to take on debt -- and what effects these debts have had on the real wealth, the annual produce of the land and labor, of the society. The following book will therefore be divided into three chapters.
elegant: The sovereign's three duties require expenditure and therefore revenue. Book V will examine: which expenses should be publicly funded versus privately; the different methods of public finance and their merits; and why modern governments have accumulated debts and what effects those debts have on real national wealth.
summary: Smith previews Book V's three-part structure: the necessary expenses of government, the methods of raising revenue to fund them, and the causes and consequences of public debt -- the logical continuation of his argument about the proper scope of government.
distilled: Book V will examine government expenses, methods of public finance, and the causes and effects of public debt.
notes: This is the structural transition from Book IV (systems of political economy) to Book V (revenue of the sovereign). The three-chapter preview maps to: V.1 (expenses of the sovereign), V.2 (sources of revenue/taxation), and V.3 (public debts). Smith's treatment of public debt in V.3 proved particularly prescient and influential. The passage ties the theoretical conclusions of Book IV to the practical policy analysis of Book V.

refashioned:
APPENDIX TO BOOK IV. The following two accounts are included to illustrate and confirm what was discussed in the fifth chapter of Book IV concerning the tonnage bounty for the white-herring fishery. The reader may rely on the accuracy of both accounts.

This is an account of fishing vessels (busses) fitted out in Scotland over eleven years, showing the number of empty barrels carried out, the number of barrels of herrings caught, and the bounty paid per barrel -- both for sea-sticks and for fully packed barrels.
elegant: The appendix provides statistical data on Scotland's herring fishery bounty over eleven years, documenting the number of fishing vessels, barrels carried and filled, and bounties paid -- evidence supporting the analysis in Chapter 4.5.
summary: Smith appends statistical tables on Scotland's herring fishery to support his earlier analysis of bounties, providing eleven years of data on fishing vessels, catch volumes, and bounty payments.
distilled: Statistical tables on Scotland's herring fishery bounty over eleven years support the analysis of bounties from Chapter 4.5.
notes: The appendix provides empirical evidence for the theoretical arguments in Chapter 4.5 on bounties. 'Busses' were large decked fishing vessels used in the herring fishery. 'Sea-sticks' were herrings as initially packed at sea, before being fully processed and repacked on shore. The data covers 1771-1781. Cross-reference 4.5 on the herring bounty analysis.

refashioned: The data shows the following for each year from 1771 to 1781: the number of busses ranged from 29 to 294, with empty barrels carried out from about 6,000 to 76,000. Barrels of herrings caught ranged from about 2,800 to 56,000. Bounties paid ranged from about 2,900 to 27,000 pounds. The fishery expanded dramatically from 1771 (29 busses) to a peak around 1776 (294 busses) before declining to 135 busses by 1781.
elegant: Scotland's herring fishery expanded from 29 busses in 1771 to 294 in 1776, then contracted to 135 by 1781. Catch rates and bounty payments followed a similar rise-and-fall pattern, with bounties reaching nearly 27,000 pounds at peak.
summary: The herring fishery data shows rapid expansion from 1771 to 1776 followed by contraction, with fleet size, catch volume, and bounty payments all following a boom-and-bust pattern.
distilled: Scotland's herring fishery boomed from 29 to 294 busses between 1771-1776, then contracted to 135 by 1781, with bounty payments following the same pattern.
notes: The eleven-year dataset covers the period of the American Revolutionary War (1775-1783), which disrupted fishing operations and helps explain the decline after 1776. The expansion-contraction pattern illustrates how bounties can stimulate industry but cannot sustain it against adverse conditions. The ratio of barrels caught to barrels carried shows declining efficiency over the period.

refashioned: Totals for the eleven-year period: 2,186 busses fitted out, 550,943 empty barrels carried, 378,347 barrels of herrings caught. Total bounty paid: 165,463 pounds, 14 shillings. The bounty averaged about 8 shillings and 2 1/4 pence per barrel of sea-sticks. But since a barrel of sea-sticks counts as only two-thirds of a fully packed barrel, deducting one-third (126,115 barrels) gives 252,231 barrels fully packed -- bringing the effective bounty to about 12 shillings and 3 3/4 pence per fully packed barrel.
elegant: Over eleven years: 2,186 busses, 378,347 barrels caught, 165,463 pounds in bounties. Adjusting for the sea-sticks-to-packed-barrel conversion (two-thirds ratio), the effective bounty was about 12 shillings and 3 3/4 pence per fully packed barrel.
summary: The eleven-year totals show 165,463 pounds paid in bounties on 252,231 fully packed barrel equivalents, yielding an effective bounty of about 12 shillings and 4 pence per barrel after adjusting for the sea-sticks conversion ratio.
distilled: Over eleven years, the herring bounty averaged about 12 shillings and 4 pence per fully packed barrel equivalent -- a substantial subsidy per unit of output.
notes: The sea-sticks to fully-packed conversion ratio (2:3) accounts for the fact that herrings lose volume during processing and repacking. At 12s 3.75d per barrel, the bounty was a significant fraction of the total value of the product. These calculations support Smith's argument that the bounty was excessive relative to the economic value generated. Total bounty of 165,463 pounds over eleven years = about 15,000 pounds annually.

refashioned: If the herrings are exported, there is an additional premium of 2 shillings and 8 pence per barrel, making the total government bounty 14 shillings and 11 3/4 pence per barrel in cash. But if we add the duty on the salt typically used in curing each barrel -- at the average rate of one and a quarter bushels of foreign salt at 10 shillings per bushel, totaling 12 shillings and 6 pence -- the total bounty per barrel amounts to 1 pound, 7 shillings, and 5 3/4 pence.
elegant: Exported herrings received an additional 2s 8d premium, bringing the cash bounty to nearly 15 shillings per barrel. Adding the forgone salt duty (12s 6d for foreign salt used in curing) brings the total effective subsidy to over 1 pound 7 shillings per barrel.
summary: The total effective bounty on exported herrings, including the export premium and the forgone salt duty, amounted to over 27 shillings per barrel -- a subsidy approaching or exceeding the market value of the herrings themselves.
distilled: Including export premiums and forgone salt duties, the total effective herring bounty exceeded 27 shillings per barrel -- a massive subsidy relative to the product's value.
notes: The salt duty component is crucial to the full subsidy calculation. Foreign salt (typically from France or Portugal) was heavily taxed, and the exemption for fishing was effectively an additional bounty. At 1 pound 7 shillings 5.75 pence per barrel, the total subsidy was enormous -- likely approaching or exceeding the market price of the herrings. This supports Smith's argument in Chapter 4.5 that the herring bounty was economically absurd.

refashioned: If the herrings are cured with British salt instead, the calculation is as follows: the base bounty remains 14 shillings and 11 3/4 pence. Adding the duty on two bushels of Scotch salt at 1 shilling and 6 pence per bushel (the estimated average quantity used per barrel) gives an additional 3 shillings. The total bounty per barrel therefore amounts to 17 shillings and 11 3/4 pence.
elegant: Herrings cured with British salt instead of foreign received a lower total subsidy -- 17 shillings and 11 3/4 pence per barrel -- because the duty on domestic salt was much lower than on foreign salt.
summary: Using cheaper British salt instead of taxed foreign salt reduced the total effective bounty to about 18 shillings per barrel, still a substantial subsidy but lower than the foreign-salt equivalent.
distilled: Herrings cured with British salt received a lower but still substantial effective bounty of about 18 shillings per barrel.
notes: The difference between foreign salt (12s 6d duty) and Scotch salt (3s duty) illustrates how the salt tax system interacted with the fishing bounty. Scotch salt was much cheaper because it was taxed at only 1s 6d per bushel versus 10s for foreign salt. The lower total bounty for British-salt-cured herrings created an incentive to use domestic salt -- an additional mercantilist preference built into the subsidy system.

refashioned: When buss herrings are entered for domestic consumption in Scotland and pay the one-shilling-per-barrel duty, the bounty calculation changes as follows: starting from the base bounty of 12 shillings and 3 3/4 pence, deduct the 1 shilling domestic duty, leaving 11 shillings and 3 3/4 pence. But then add back the foreign salt duty of 12 shillings and 6 pence. The total premium for each barrel of herrings entered for domestic consumption therefore amounts to 1 pound, 3 shillings, and 9 3/4 pence.
elegant: Herrings entering Scotland's domestic market paid a 1-shilling duty but still received an effective premium of over 1 pound 3 shillings per barrel after accounting for the foreign salt duty exemption -- a net subsidy even on domestically consumed fish.
summary: Even herrings consumed domestically in Scotland received an effective subsidy of over 23 shillings per barrel, after deducting the nominal one-shilling consumption duty but adding back the forgone foreign salt duty.
distilled: Domestically consumed herrings still received an effective subsidy exceeding 23 shillings per barrel despite a nominal consumption duty.
notes: The calculation shows that domestic consumption was still heavily subsidized -- the one-shilling duty was token compared to the salt duty exemption. The government was effectively paying more in subsidies and tax exemptions than it collected in consumption duties. This illustrates Smith's broader point about the economic absurdity of the bounty system.

refashioned: If the herrings entering domestic consumption are cured with British salt, the calculation is: starting from the base bounty of 12 shillings and 3 3/4 pence, deduct the 1 shilling domestic consumption duty, leaving 11 shillings and 3 3/4 pence. Add the duty on two bushels of Scotch salt at 1 shilling and 6 pence per bushel, totaling 3 shillings. The total premium for each barrel entered for home consumption amounts to 14 shillings and 3 3/4 pence. Though the forgone duties on exported herrings cannot perhaps properly be called a bounty, the premium on herrings entered for domestic consumption certainly can be.
elegant: Domestically consumed herrings cured with British salt received an effective premium of over 14 shillings per barrel. Smith notes that while forgone export duties may not technically qualify as bounties, the premium on domestic consumption certainly does -- the government is paying citizens to eat fish.
summary: Herrings cured with British salt and sold domestically received a premium of over 14 shillings per barrel. Smith draws the distinction that while export duty exemptions may not technically be bounties, the domestic consumption premium is unambiguously a direct subsidy.
distilled: The domestic herring premium of over 14 shillings per barrel is unambiguously a bounty -- the government paying citizens to consume fish.
notes: Smith's closing distinction -- that the domestic premium is unambiguously a bounty -- is the analytical punch of the appendix. The government was subsidizing not just exports (which might have a mercantilist rationale) but domestic consumption, which has no trade-policy justification at all. The total subsidy calculations across 4.9.63-4.9.67 demonstrate that the herring bounty was economically irrational at every level. Cross-reference Chapter 4.5 for the theoretical argument these numbers support.

refashioned:
An account of the quantity of foreign salt imported into Scotland, and of Scotch salt delivered duty-free from the works there for the fishery, from April 5, 1771 to April 5, 1782, with the annual average for both.

Over the eleven-year period: 936,974 bushels of foreign salt were imported and 168,226 bushels of Scotch salt were delivered from the works. The annual averages were 85,159 1/2 bushels of foreign salt and 15,293 1/4 bushels of Scotch salt. It should be noted that a bushel of foreign salt weighs 84 pounds, while a bushel of British salt weighs only 56 pounds.
elegant: Over eleven years, Scotland's fishery used 937,000 bushels of foreign salt versus 168,000 bushels of domestic salt -- a five-to-one ratio favoring imports. Foreign salt bushels also weighed 50% more than British ones, making the weight disparity even greater.
summary: Salt import data for Scotland's fishery shows overwhelming preference for foreign salt over domestic -- nearly six times the volume and even more by weight, given that foreign salt bushels weighed 84 pounds versus 56 for British. This underscores the fishery's dependence on tax-exempt imported salt.
distilled: Scotland's fishery consumed nearly six times more foreign salt than domestic by volume -- and even more by weight -- revealing deep dependence on tax-exempt foreign imports.
notes: This final table completes the empirical appendix to Book IV. The 5:1 foreign-to-domestic salt ratio shows that the fishery depended heavily on imported salt despite mercantilist preferences for domestic supply. The weight difference (84 lbs vs 56 lbs per bushel) means the volume ratio understates the weight ratio. The salt data connects to the bounty calculations in 4.9.64-4.9.67, showing the magnitude of forgone salt duties. The April-to-April fiscal year was standard British accounting practice.
